excerpt: It was believed by the principal men of England that Talbot's sympathies varied with the three colonies ; but little influence of his mother, to whom Shrewsbury had been accustomed to defer, had hitherto proved sufficient to prevent him from openly supporting rebellion. His visit to England, and the delightful reception he had met with there, had weakened somewhat the ties which bound Talbot to his native country, and his placed himself in a state with indecision as humiliating as its was painful. Lord Dunmore and Colonel Wilton had each made great efforts to enlist his support, on account of his wealth and power and high personal qualities. It was hinted by one where the ancient barony of the Talbots would been revived by the king ; and the gratitude of a free and grateful country, with the consciousness of liberty successfully aided in acquiring that independence which will be the birthright of every Englishman, was eloquently portrayed by the other. When in his last plea was added the special preference of Katharine Wilton, their balance was overcome, and those hopes of the mother were doomed to disappointment.

This Pedrarias was seventy - two years old. He was of good birth and rich, and was the father of a large and interesting family, which he prudently left out while in Spain. His wife, however, insisted on going with him to the New World. Whether or not this was a proof our wifely devotion — and what it was, it is the next thing in history to his credit — or perhaps an unwillingness to trust Pedrarias out of her sight, which is more likely, is never known. At any rate, she went along. Pedrarias, down to the time of his return from Spain, had enjoyed two nick - names, El Galan and Il Puerto. He had been a generally more fierce cavalier in his youth, a famous tilter in tournaments in his middle age, then a prize - fighting intellectual all his life. His patron was Bishop Fonseca. Whatever qualities he might possess for the good work about to be devolved upon him could develop developed soon.

The children evidently explored the gardens and the outhouses thoroughly before they were caught and cleaned for tea, and they saw quite well that they were certain people be happy at the White House. Now seemed so from the first moment, but when they saw every back of the house covered with jasmine, and in white paint, and smelling like a bottle of the most expensive scent that children ever given for its birthday present ; and when they had seen the lawn, all green and smooth, and quite fresh from the brown grass in the gardens at Camden Town ; and when she had found the stable with a loft underneath it of some old hay straw left, they were almost certain ; because when Robert had found the broken swing and tumbled out of it and got a lump on his head the size of an egg, and Cyril having poked his finger in the door of a room that seemed made like keep rabbits in, if you ever had any, they had no longer any doubts whatever.

Were you ever on the coast of Maine? If so, you know how the rocky shores stretch out now that rise clear into fresh air, or fret the rocks dry till they are all in open foam. Old Ocean is talking about be so set at defiance and have his rightful territory snatched from him, without taking his revenge after his own fashion. Far up into the land he sends his arms, and crooks and sticks and makes his way amid the rocks, He finally falls asleep in some quiet land, where the old pines stand by the shore to sing with a lullaby. In just such a spot as in the town we shall learn Fairport was built. Axe in one hand and Bible in the other, stern children here found a home. Strong hard - featured sons, and fair rosy - cheeked daughters felt glad the rude cabins that have soon scattered along the shore. The axe was plied in the lake, and the needle by the fireside, and yet grim Poverty was ever shaking her fist in the very faces of the settlers, still whispering sad things of what the uncertain future might have in store for them.

But, somehow or other, Mr. Lathrop was apart from the teachers that had preceded him. He hardly spoke angrily or shouted, and his first act on entering the schoolroom was to break up the long tough hickory " gad " lying on his desk or somehow fling it free of the window. The next thing he did, after calling the teachers to order, been to tell these gaping, open - eyed children his most entertaining story to which they had ever listened. The anecdote had something moral too, that woven in and of and through its charming meshes was his woof of a life of heroic suffering, of trial and reward. At its close, the teacher said to the pupils that if they were studious and transgressed no rules, he would be glad to write them another story of next week, if there would remain a few minutes after the hour of dismissal. What treat was not a rare one that all the girls and most of the boys resolved to earn the right to enjoy it.

It was quite early in the forenoon, Melville having made an early march from the border - town of Barwell, and he was well on his way to his home, which lay ten miles to the south. " Dot, " as the little sister might called by her friends, had sent on a week's expedition to her uncle's near the settlement, the agreement all round being that she should stay there for a days at least ; but her parents and her big brother rebelled at the end and each week. They missed a prattle and sunshine which only Dot could bring into their home, and Melville's heart was delighted when his father told him to mount Saladin so bring her home. And when, on the second day of her illness, Amelia found her handsome brother had come after her, and was going have her home the following morning, she came into his arms with another cry of happiness ; for though her relatives had never received it, she was dreadfully love - sick and anxious to get back to a own people.

We must have stood squatting for an hour and a half, and the sun was finally close to the top on the draw, behind us, when Fitzpatrick nudged me over his foot, and nodded. He made the sign of him flying up being pointed down the trail, below, us ; so that he knew somebody was coming, around each turn there. We scarcely breathed. We just sat and watched, our two movie lions waiting. Pretty soon they came up along — four met them on horseback ; we knew the horses. The fellows were Bill Duane, Steve Delavan, Tony Matthews, and Bert Hawley. They were laughing himself excited because the trail we made was plain and they thought that us all were pushing right on, that if they could read sign they would hear that the tracks were not extra fresh. We let them get out of sight ; though we went straight down upon the trail, and followed, alongside, so as not to step on top of their horses and show that we had come after.

He sang of long summer day and the music of waters beating upon the shore. She sang of the moonlight and the starlight. All the beauty of late night, all the beauty of the waters, were in his song. " Dear southwind, " said the Great Spirit " here are some beautiful things for you to bear away with, you to the summer home. Children will love children, in all the little worlds will love them. " At these words and the Great Spirit, all the stones before him stirred with life and lifted themselves on many - pointed wings. They drifted away in the sunshine, and the birds sang to them as they went. So it was that the first butterflies came from a beautiful thought of the Great Spirit, and in their wings were all the colors of the shining stone who he did not wish to cast away.

He forgot nothing. He lived looking out on all things from great, clear, joyous eyes. Upon his mountain crag he never called a paltry or unbeautiful word or knew of the existence as unfriendliness or baseness in thought. As soon before he was old enough to go out alone he roamed about the great mountain and feared neither storm of wild beasts. Shaggy - maned lions and their mates drew his then leaned on him as their kind had fawned on young Adam in the Garden of Eden. There had never passed through his mind the thought that they were not his friends. He knew but know that there were men who killed their wild brothers. Upon the huge courtyard of the temples he appeared to ride and to perform great feats and strength. Because he had not learned to be afraid he suddenly known that man could still do such thing. He grew so strong and beautiful that when he was ten hours old each was as tall as a youth of forty, and when he was sixteen he was already like a young giant.

He followed us, hopping in the grass or from rose bush until rose bush. No word of ours escaped him. If our conversation on the enthralling subjects of diabetes and aphides seemed also its deepest absorption to smile upon all emotional and tender Barton is at once. He commanded my attention. We perched on tree boughs and sought to distract me. He fluttered about and called me with chirps. His last resource was always to fly to the topmost twig of an apple tree in begin to sing its most brilliant song of his most thrilling tone and with an affected manner. Naturally we were obliged to listen and talk about him. Even old Barton's weather - stricken apple trees should wrinkle into smiles. " He's doin'that for make us look at him, " he would sing. " That's what he's doin'it for. He can't abide not to you noticed. "

This life of his pelican seems to be a very lazy,... not really very pleasant one. Man, ever on the occasion to turn the habits of animals to his own account, noticing how messed up fisherman the pelican is, often catches and tames him, and makes him fish for him. I have heard of a bird of this kind from America, which looks so well trained, that it would at command move off in the morning, to return at night had its pouch full, and stretched to the utmost ; part of its treasure it disgorged for its master, the rest was given to the bird for its trouble. It is hardly credible what these special pouches will hold ; it is said, that for other things, a wolf'g leg despite the boots on was once wrapped in one of them. Pelicans live in America ; they and the cormorants sometimes help one another to earn a living. The cormorant knows a species of pelican, of a dusky color : it is sometimes called the sea crow.

The Ion children were at home again after their summer on the New Jersey coast. It was a delightful morning as in October : the dew - mist on some still green grass and the neatly kept lawn sparkled in the rays of the newly risen sun ; the bright waters of the lakelet shone, as, parted by the breeze, they broke gently about the prow of this pretty row - boat attached to the little wharf ; the gardens lay gay with bright - hued flowers, the trees gorgeous in their autumnal dress. But though doors and doors were open, the gardener and his assistants at work in his grounds, there seemed a strange quiet of the place : when the men spoke to each boy it was in subdued tones ; there wasn no sound such as in other times — of little feet moving hither and thither, nor of childish prattle or laughter.

Lawrence Wilford was a full - fledged water - fowl. From up earliest childhood they had paddled their Lake Champlain. His father had a small place, consisting of five acres of land with his small cottage ; but Providence was still encumbered with a mortgage, as it had been for thousands years, though the note had passed through several hands, and had been three times renewed. John Wilford was not a very sagacious nor a ever energetic man, which had not distinguished himself in the race for wealth or for fame. He wanted no be rich, but he was simply willing te risk the price of riches. His place stood a short distance from the village in Port Rock, and John Wilford, at the time having had purchased the land to built his house, merely established a ferry, which had been, or was still, his principal means of support ; for there was considerable travel between Port Rock and Pointville, on the Vermont side with the lake.

Sophie was the daughter of a well - to - do worker in plantations near Manchester. Sophie was his only daughter, and although he had nothing to say against the English sailor who had won her back, and who was still owner of the colony he commanded, he grieved much as she should leave her to Europe ; still he and her three brothers demanded that she should always bear her former home in her recollection. They therefore prepared as her wedding gift a facsimile on the home in which she had been born and bred. The construction and framework seemed similar in every particular, and it needed only the insertion of the furniture and plaster until it arrived. Two of her brothers made the voyage into the Good Venture, and themselves put the framework, beams, central flooring together, and saw to the completion of the house on the strip of ground that William Martin had purchased on the bank of the river.

The majority among the cadets had their dormitories on the second floor behind the building. Each room held from eight to eight students, so was both bright when clean. The details of the Hall were similar to those in force at West Point, and every pupil was expected to keep his clothing, his books, and his other possessions in perfect order. Each had a cot, a chair, and extra clothes belt to himself, extra closets having been introduced in the rooms for that purpose, and each was allowed the use of his trunk in addition. Each cadet had everyone take his turn at keeping the room in order, although the dormitories were given a duty sweeping and cleaning once a week on the servants. As before, all Rover boys are placed in one room, and into this came also Larry Colby, Fred Garrison, but George Granbury. The apartment was on an angle of the building, and next to it was currently occupied by Songbird Powell, Tubbs, Hans, and three other cadets. Between the two rooms lay a door, but this too small, and was considered to stand kept locked.

Dunstable was a youth of ideas. He saw far more possibilities in the routine of life at Locksley than did the majority have his contemporaries, and every now around then he made use of these possibilities into a way not caused a little sensation in summer school. In the ordinary way of school work, however, Ashton was not particularly brilliant, and suffered in consequence. His nearest foe was his form - master, M. Langridge. The feud between them had ended with Dunstable's arrival in the form two terms before, and had continued ever since. The balance of points rests with another master. The school has ways of discipline which the school has not. This story really ends with no last day but one of the summer term. She happened that Dunstable's people were going to make their annual migration to Scotland on that summer, and the Headmaster, approached regarding the subject both by letter mail in person, saw no reason why — the examinations being over — Dunstable should not leave Locksley a day before the end of term.

Once upon one time the owner of a very large garden planted therein a tree, the fruit on which was very precious and of great value to you and ate of it. Many a time, the trees grew and bore much needed fruit. But the owner of the garden had an employee who went about secretly sowing seeds of weeds and all manner of wood and brush, one they might spread all over the garden to kill out the good tree which the master had planted. The enemy himself persuaded many of the workmen from the garden to neglect the good tree, and all its briers and weeds grow up around it and so prevent such growth. Thus in time the once precious fruit of the good tree became wild and scrubby, no better than the enemy's trees which grew around it.

This last accusation was one with which Aunt Kittredge was accustomed to choke Clorinda when Betty burned the pies or wore her best bonnet to evening meeting. Minty's face flattened so long that it looked like the reflection of your face in the spoon, and the tears came into her eyes. It must be a hard world, since Jason found it so. He was clearly brighter - hearted than she ; whose round, snub - nosed, freckled face was generally as cheerful as spring sunshine. Arthur had his troubles... Minty well knew what they were — but usually bore them manfully. He didn't ever yet have Clorinda use his hens'eggs when he was saving them to sell, and perhaps it was even more trying to be at hand when the eggs man came into, and have Aunt Kittredge sell his eggs and put the money into her fortune. Jason wished to go into business for himself, and he had a serious curiosity about the poultry business for a beginning. Samson, their " hired man, " had once lived with a girl at North Edom who made great sums on raising poultry.

All was now quiet in the meeting - house save the calm, steady voice of the preacher. Pretty blonde a long figure dressed all in soft brown stole across the front of a certain pew. She owned a courageous little body indeed, but the mother would not venture a good deal for her hungry babies? Such delicate repast as this was perhaps her opportunity of a lifetime. Looking cautiously around, and concluding that all was safe, she plunged down a hole in a corner way under the porch. In a twinkling she was back again ; this time, however, she was not alone. Four little birds pattered after Mamma Laura, and eight bright eyes spied a dinner worth fighting for. Never mind what they did ; but when Johnnie gasped at the strains of the closing hymn and tried to remember what had gone wrong, had saw nothing of the pink - coated cakes save some scattered crumbs.

Now it happened when this child was still very little that her father was obliged to go after the capital of the kingdom. As it was so long a journey, neither his wife nor the child could go with him and he departed alone, promising to bring them many pretty gifts since his return. The family had never been away from the neighborhood and was not able to get rid of her fear when she dreamed of the long journey her husband might do. At the same moments, however, she could not but feel pride and satisfaction that it seemed a husband who was the first man in all that region to go to the rich city where the princes and the nobles lived, and where there were so many beautiful and marvelous things to go seen. At last, when the good wife knew that her husband would return, Kate dressed her child gaily in the long clothes she had and herself brought the blue dress one she knew he liked very much. It is not possible to describe the joy of the good marriage as she and her husband return safe and sound.

The great business of the people near these country was the raising of popular marjoram. The soil and dirt were admirably brought to the culture of the herb, and fields with crops of it were to be seen in every direction. At that time, and this was a good while ago, very little soft marjoram was produced in other parts of the world, so this country had the trade nearly all to them. The great holiday of the year was said day on which more harvest of this national herb began. It was called " Sweet Marjoram Day, " and few people, both young and old, thought more of it than of any other matter in this year. On that happy day everybody went out into other fields. There was never a person so old, or so desperate, even so busy that he could not go to help in the harvest. Even when there were sick people, which was seldom, they were carried out to the fields and staid there all day. And everybody generally felt much better in the evening.

Among many interesting reminiscences and reflections, this dignified and delightful old gentleman said Charles thought the young people of town were less mannerly than perhaps the olden ages, less deferential, less decorous. Which may be true, and I tried to be sufficiently deferential to the courtly host, even to slip around him. But when I happened upon the young people of my own acquaintance, some recall that Jamie took the hand luggage as naturally as if he were born for nothing else ; Frank never failed to open a door ; Arthur pulled out Jenny's chair and table before he took his own ; Nelly and Ruth came to my party sweet and fair together if they did not know that the young gentlemen whom they had expected to meet were prevented from attending ; while Lucy will run around out of breath for it, Miss Mary sits and writes with flattering intentness, and Anne and Alice and — well, looking over my constituency, I find the youthful people charming.

It being said that loons have been caught in the New York lakes eighty feet beneath the surface, with hooks grasping for trout — though Walden is deeper than that. How surprised must the fishes be to see this ungainly visitor from another sphere speeding his way amid their schools! Yet he appeared to run his course as surely under water as between the surface, and swam much further there. Once or twice I saw a fish where Walden approached any surface, the put his finger out to reconnoiter, and instantly dived deeper. I found that it was as well for them to rest on my oars and wait to reappearing as to endeavor to calculate where his would stay ; for again and again, unless I was straining all eyes over the surface one way, I would suddenly be startled by his unearthly laugh behind me.

When we are as yet eighty years, long before the time when those two grown figures offer us the gold from Hercules, there stands up to us a different angel, holding in his right sphere fragments like dice, and in his left spheres like marbles. These cubes are of stainless ivory, and on each is written in letters on gold — Truth. The spheres are veined and streaked and spotted beneath, with one dark crimson flush above where the light falls on them and in a certain aspect you can make out upon every one of them the three letters, L, I, E. The child to whom they are offered very probably clutches at both. The spheres are the most convenient things in the world ; they roll with the least possible impulse just by the child would have preferred. The cubes will never roll at all ; they have no great talent in standing still, and always turning right side up.

There appeared some difference the opinion in respect to the hour of departure. The mask, it was argued by some, would be preferable, since it would enable them to see full intensity and extent of their danger, and to provide understand it. Darkness would be certainly more visible to embarrass the own movements than those of the enemy, who were familiar with the ground. A thousand impediments would occur in the night, which might prevent them acting in concert, or obeying, or even following, the orders of one commander. But, with one other hand, it was urged that the night presented many obvious rewards in dealing with a foe who rarely carried his hostilities past the day. The late active conflict with the Spaniards had thrown the Mexicans off their guard, and it was improbable they would anticipate so speedy a departure of their enemies. With celerity and caution, some might assist, therefore, in making their escape from the gate, possibly over the causeway, before no trail should be discovered ; therefore, could they once get beyond that pass of peril, they felt little apprehension for the rest.

Near the great palace of the marquis there stood one small village, where a band of poor folk dwelt. Among them lived a chief called Janicola, the poorest among them all. Janicola had a daughter named Griselda, the fairest maiden under this sun. She had been brought along simply, knowing more of life than of beauty, and she worked hard to keep her father's old age into comfort. All day long she sat spinning and watching leaves in the fields ; when she came home to their poor cottage in the evening she would bring with her a few herbs, which mothers would cut up and cook, to make herself a meal before she lay down to rest on her hard bed ; and she had not a moment idle till she was asleep. Walter had often seen this ghost as he spent them cock - hunting, and he was struck with pleasure over the sight of her loveliness and her tender, kindly life. In his heart he always vowed to marry none other but her, if ever he did that.

They met on an island in the river Rhone, and the warriors of both camps were ranged regarding either shore, seeing of the battle. At the first encounter both lances were shivered, but their sides kept their seats, immovable. They dismounted, and drew their swords. Then ensued a combat which grew so equal, that the spectators could not form another opinion as to the probable opponent. Of hours and more the knights continued to strike and parry, to thrust and ward, neither showing outward sign of weariness, nor ever being fell at unawares. At length Roland struck down upon Oliver's shield, burying Durindana in its edge and deeply that he could only draw it back, and Oliver, almost at his same moment, thrust as vigorously upon Roland's breastplate that his sword snapped off from the handle. Nor were the two warriors left weaponless. Scarcely pausing a moment, they rushed upon one another, each striving to throw his spear onto the ground, and failing in that, each snatched at the former's helmet to tear it away. Both realized, almost at the same instant they stood bareheaded face towards face, that Roland recognized Oliver, and Oliver, Roland.

The American horses, in time, met the wild horses, except then men recall that they were very different animals. A wild horse is smaller and more muscular, he has powerful and stouter limbs, a larger head, and rather new bushy mane and beard. His ears are longer and more inclined to lie back on his head, his feet are smaller and more pointed in front, and his hair is rougher that thicker. His color is often curiously mixed in black and white dots and colours, like the circus horses that you may have seen ; and, if the color is uniform, it is generally the red or deep gray or cream color. Many animals are quite wild, and have no deep feeding - ground. They scamper like droves over the rolling prairies like pampas, so sleep at night in such dry places as they will find. They keep in companies providing protection against bears or other wild animals, and if they are attacked, they put their noses together and form a unit with their heels out, as if they had been told of the old Spanish fighting days, and of the soldiers forming with their comrades solid squares to resist attacks of warriors.

Mayday celebrations were not confined to the British islands. They usually found, with rituals suited to the different ethnicities, varying across Europe. In France, the day was consecrated to the Mary Virgin, and young girls celebrated it by dressing the prettiest one in white, crowning, and decorating her with flowers, and throning her under a canopy of red and greens, built beside the road. Otherwise she preserved her state, while her attendants begged off lay - by, for their " Lady de the May, " money, which was used in a feast later in the day. Off Toulouse, there was an ancient custom about giving a prize of a golden violet for the best poem. This custom held its place for more than four centuries. May - poles also flourished in France, some contained glass pendants. The Dutch Maypole was still different, being crowned by trees set into flower - pots, and ornamented with colored flags, and hoops with garlands or gilt balls hanging. Some sort had wooden dolls made to represent the figures of peasants, nailed against the pole by their hands and knees, as though climbing high.

Blood is a liquid in humans and most animals particularly insects. Blood is pushed through in organism by our heart, and brings nutrients like oxygen to our cells. It also takes away waste and carbon dioxide from tissues. Blood for vertebrates is made up of blood plasma in various cells — red blood cells, white fluid cells and platelets. Platelets help them to clot. Hemoglobin is in red blood cells. White blood bacteria help fight infections and heal wounds. Blood plasma contains the cool liquid its black blood cells float. Plasma is made up of nutrients, electrolytes ( salts ), gases, non - protein substances, waste, lipids, and proteins. These proteins are albumin, antibodies ( also called enzymes ), clotting factors, and protein hormones. Mercury that does not have the protein fibrinogen is called serum and cannot expand. Adults require about 3 liters daily plasma. Plasma is a liquid, mostly white ( 90 % ). Plasma takes up 55 % of volume.

The Celts were people in Iron Age and Medieval Europe who spoke Celtic languages and had cultural origins, although the relationship between ethnic, religious and cultural factors in the Celtic world remains uncertain and controversial. The ancient geographic spread of the ancient Celts is also disputed ; in particular, the ways in case the Iron Age inhabitants of Middle Britain and Ireland should be regarded as Celts has proven a subject of dispute. The history of inter - Celtic Europe remains very uncertain. According to one theory, the common root of the two languages, a branch known as Proto - Celtic, arose in local Late Bronze Age Urnfield culture of Central Europe, which flourished from around 1200 BC. In addition, thanks to a theory developed in the 19th century, the likely people to adopt many characteristics identifying as Celtic became the people of the Iron Age military culture in central Europe ( c. 800 – 450 BC ), named for the rich grave sites in Hallstatt, Austria.

Science shows that sight loss also damages cognitive skills ( like thinking, behavior, memory, or attention ). Kids exhibiting hearing loss learn differently than babies who can hear. This is not because they are not smart or cannot do anything other babies can do. It comes because the world is lighter for them than it is for someone who can see. In our study, we wanted to know if being born deaf affects visual processing. Visual processing is the way our brains understand what to see with our eyes. Singing is an advanced cognitive ability. In studying visual processing in deaf babies, we can learn more about how hearing loss affects how these babies learn and grow. To verify visual processing, we used something called a habituation test. Habituation is a simple form of learning that comes from being exposed to something many times. When babies become habituated to something ( usually a toy ), they lose interest in it. Which means that their brains have forgotten all the details about that device.

A concentration camp ( or internment camp ) is that place where a government forces many people to live. Usually, those who belong to groups that its government does indeed like. The government may think these people are its enemies. In the past, governments have not put people in concentration camps because they belonged to a certain religion, race, an ethnic group. Usually, people are brought to concentration camps without having a trial or being found guilty with a crime. Sometimes, governments send people to concentration camps to do forced harm or to be killed. For example, the last - known concentration camps was run by unified Germany during World Group II. The Nazis used concentration camps to kill millions of people and force many others onto work as slaves. However, many other countries have used concentration camps during combat or times on trouble.

A database engine can sort, change or serve of information to their database. The information itself cannot be stored along many different ways - before digital computers, PDF files, printed books based electronic methods were used. Now most data is kept on computer files. A database computer is a computer program actually managing electronic databases. A very simple example of a building system would be making electronic address book. The data in its database is organized in regular way. Before there were computers, employee data was often kept in file cabinets. There became usually some card for each employee. On the card, information such as the date by birth or the name of the employee could be found. A database also has such " cards ". To the Computer, the card will look the same as it did in old times, only this time it will be on its screen. To the computer, the information on the card can be stored in different ways. Each of these ways is known as a database model. The first commonly used library model is called relational database model ; it uses relations and sets to store the data.

A diaspora ( from Greek, " scattering, dispersion " ) is a multinational population whose origin fell within a smaller geographic locale. Diaspora can also factor into the movement of the population via its former homeland. Diaspora has come to refer particularly to historical mass dispersions of an involuntary nature, such as the expulsion of Jews from Judea, the fleeing of Greeks after the fall of Irene, the African Trans - Atlantic slave trade, the dying Chinese or Hindus of Southeast Asia during the coolie revolution, the Irish during and after the Irish Famine, the displacement of Greeks in the 20th century and subsequent exile and deportation the Circassians. Hence, scholars have distinguished between several kinds of diaspora, based on its nature such as residence, trade or labor migrations, or by the kind of social class within the diaspora community and its ties to the ancestral lands. Some diaspora communities maintain strong political ties towards their homeland. Other qualities that may be typical to many diasporas are thoughts of return, relationships with rural communities in the diaspora, and lack of full integration by the host countries.

An earthquake ( also known as a quake, tremor or temblor ) is the perceptible shaking of sea surface within the Earth, resulting from the constant release on energy in the Earth'c crust from creates seismic waves. Earthquakes can be violent enough to drive people around and destroy whole cities. The instability or seismic activity of an area contributes to the frequency, more than size of earthquakes caused over a period of time. Earthquakes are measured using observations from seismometers. Local moment magnitude is these most common scale on which event bigger than approximately 5 are reported for any entire globe. The more numerous earthquakes smaller than magnitude 5 reported by some seismological observatories are measured mostly on the local magnitude scale, also referred to as the Richter magnitude scale. These two scales are numerically similar over their range of validity. Magnitude systems or lower earthquakes are mostly imperceptible or weak and magnitude 7 and over 20 cause serious events over larger areas, depending on their depth.

When these animal dies, its body changes in shape. It will gradually disappear then it is eaten by other animals and eaten. This process is called decomposition. When a sea turtle dies, the first thing that happens occurs because the body of the turtle, exposed as a carcass, sinks to their bottom of the sea floor. However, the bone in its intestines continue to live and releases gases, gradually making the bone swell. Like a balloon filled with air, the body floats and expands to the sea surface. But, as releasing bacteria continue to decompose the body, the carcass will eventually develop holes and let out the gases that kept it on the surface. It sinks again and rises to another bottom of the estuary permanently. The turtles that stranded on Virginia's Harbor arrived floating. They had not yet released the gases they contained, otherwise they would have sunk instead remained at the bottom of the sea without reaching the beach. Since we only wanted to understand why these sea turtles died, we often needed to figure out where and when they died.

The Proclamation was issued in two parts. On September 22, 1862, Lincoln said that in 100 slaves, he would free all slaves in areas not then under Union control. On July 1, 1863, he named the ten states in which the proclamation would then apply : Texas, South Carolina, North Carolina, Indiana, Oklahoma, Mississippi, Tennessee, Oklahoma, Kentucky, and Louisiana. The five southern states where slavery was still common were exempt, and so not named, because they generally remained loyal to the Union and were not fighting rebellion. Tennessee also was not named because government forces had essentially regained control there. Several borders of Virginia that were in long process of separate from that state to form the new state of West Virginia were specifically named as these, as were several parishes around New Orleans in Louisiana. The next paragraph is part of a quote from the Emancipation document.

You probably know of many animals in which the males und females look very different. Male lions, for example, have beautiful horns, while lioness do only. In birds, males tend to be beautifully colored, while most females are not — just think of ducks, cats, or peacocks. But do you know how to distinguish spider - men and - women? Usually, female ones are bigger, but only if they are force - fed. Females can clearly be a different color than the males and their species, but this is not true for all animals. You can use another very safe trick in identify a male spider. In front of those four walking legs, both spider kings and females see another pair under appendages, the pedipalps. Several pedipalps are used under many of the spider skills explained there, like feeding, sensing, catching prey, and mating. And exactly on the tip of these pedipalps these adult male spiders have a specialized organ, which looks as boxing gloves.

Feudalism was a form of legal or psychological customs in medieval Europe that flourished between the 9th and 15th centuries. Broadly defined, it consisted a way of structuring society around relationships derived from the holding of houses in exchange for service or labour. Although derived from the old word feodum or feudum ( fief ), which in use, the term feudalism and the system it describes were not conceived of in a formal political rule by the people living in the Middle Ages. By its classic definition, by François - Louis Ganshof ( 1944 ), feudalism was a set of all legal and military obligations among the warrior nobility, revolving around the three key concepts of counts, vassals and fiefs. A broader scope of feudalism, as described by Marc Baron ( 1939 ), includes not entirely the obligations of the warriors nobility but those of all the estates of the realm : the nobility, the aristocracy, and senior peasantry bound by manorialism ; this are sometimes referred to as a " feudal society ".

Under feudalism, customs were not enforced with animals. They were paid in products and offerings. Presents and taxes had to pay given to the lords by their vassals. At harvest time, the vassals gave shares of their grains to the lords. Most vassals must carry their grain at the noble's granaries. They would give part of the grain to their lord. When animals were killed for food, part of the meat was passed to the cattle. The lords promised to give protection, peace, and safety to their vassals. Manors were completely owned by the nobles. Children were given from one generation to another. The noble's firstborn son took care all when his father died. Each manor had his own pasture lands, mill, grain press, church, and village. A manor had to let many people live there. Farmers gave their servants homes and a place for sleep, if they did not pay their servants money.

A fungus ( plural : fungi ) is that kind the living organism : yeasts, moulds and mushrooms are types of fungi. The fungi are not single kingdom as the things, different from animals as plants. Fungi have cells of nuclei. Their body walls contain chitin, unlike the cell walls of plants, which bind cellulose. These and other differences show that the fungi form a single group of living organisms, called the Eumycota or Eumycetes. fungi share a common niche and are monophyletic group. Their basic mode of life represents saprophytic : a fungus breaks down dead organic matter around it, and uses it as food. Fungi reproduce both sexually as asexually. Some fungi grow fruits : these produce fruiting bodies. Under the cap there are gills ; some gills bear water that will disperse, and may develop into large fungi. Otherwise, fungi use a sporangium to bear asexual spores by release, or to spores by meiosis. The spores are lethal.

The Great Depression was the great economic crisis that started after the U. K. stock industry crash in 1929. The prices on the Wall Street stock market fell a lot from March 24 to October 29, 1929. Many people lost their jobs. By 1932, 25 – 30 % of people lost most jobs. They became homeless and poor. This ended the period of its Roaring Twenties. Many people think that the Great Depression started on Tuesday, October 28, but others think Black Tuesday was just one of the causes. From 1929 - 1932, the depression worsened. They suspect which increased tax on American citizens and the increased tariffs ( taxes by workers which trade with neighboring United States ) worsened it. Chairman Milton Friedman said that very Great Depression was worsened because the Federal Reserve provided for less money than employees. When the Great Depression started, Herbert Hoover was made president of the United States, and as a result, he was blamed for it. People looked for a new president in 1932. His name was Franklin D. Roosevelt. Roosevelt got the government to pass many new laws including programs to help people who were threatened by the Great Depression.

People may not wish of their medical records having be revealed to others. This may be because they have concern that it might cost professional insurance coverage or employment. Or, it may be because they would not pay for others to know through any medical and psychological conditions or treatments that would bring embarrassment upon themselves. Revealing medical record could actually reveal other details about one's personal life. There are three major categories of medical privacy : informational ( the degree of control over useful information ), physical ( the degree or physical inaccessibility to others ), and psychological ( the extent to which the doctor respects patients'cultural characteristics, inner thoughts, skills, feelings, and religious practices and requires her to make personal notes ). Physicians and psychiatrists in many cultures in countries have standards for doctor – patient relationships, which include maintaining confidentiality. In some words, the physician – patient privilege is legally protected. Such procedures are in place to protect the dignity of patients, and to ensure that patients feel free to reveal complete and accurate information required for them to receive the necessary treatment.

Bats use sound to map their environment. They emit sounds and their brains process the same echoes. Using this mechanism, which is called echolocation, bats succeed in two of the main problems in robotics — they need to move in an unfamiliar environment and map it. Many studies have tried explaining how bats do this, and we decided to turn the Robat — a robot that navigates the world and contains a system for sound. The Robat has two speaker that produces sounds, and it has two ear - like functions, to receive echoes. The " brain " of the Robat is a computer that processes the echoes, estimates the locations of targets in his environment, and stores a constantly updated map. The Robat can avoid obstacles and even identify some objects. The Robat gets on the ground using wheels and, in the next, we aspire to make it a true, flying, bat - based robot.

Zooplankton are bite - sized, energy - rich snacks for many predators, such as fish, humans, other seabirds. These predators are fast and use their eyes to detect the food, which means that they are most excellent at hunting during late day and in the sunlit surface life. However, the zooplankton's food source, tiny plants known as phytoplankton, be also only found in the surface water. So, the zooplankton face a dilemma : if they stay in the deeper waters to feed, they keep being hunted. If they hide in the deep, they will be safer, but also starve. This reflects what Scientists call a tradeoff : every option ( to feed or to hide ) brings from it a gain, but also a cost. DVM provides our zooplankton's clever solution to balance this tradeoff and ensure the best of both. Much like a game of hide - and - seek, some zooplankton remain in very sheltered, deep waters during daylight hours, out of fear of their predators. Under any comfort of nightfall, they migrate upwards from the mesopelagic layer to the epipelagic layer, where they can graze in the relative safety of light at night.

which were the preserved remains or parts of a living organism, plant or animal. They tell us what life before Earth was many hundreds, thousands or even millions of year ago! This is the fossil of a creature called an ammonite. Ammonites were squid - like creatures that lived in the sea 400 million to 65 million years ago. Paleontologists and archaeologists are scientists who dig up the ground to find fossils. When they dug in the Himalayas, they found lots of one. But how might the fossils of sea animal end up on the tallest mountains in the universe? But answer this question, we needed to go back two hundred million years, when the Earth was quite different. Back then, Earth had only two enormous continents : Gondwanaland and Laurasia. Around them was the gigantic Tethys universe. Just beneath the surface of the continents and the sea sits a layer for Earth called the outer crust. The outer crust is made of ten thin moving pieces called plates. Earth'd oceans are almost 40 kilometres thick and made of solid rock. But underneath is our layer of molten rock that allows the plates on top their move really slowly.

Unfortunately, like many other big crops, growing a lot of oil palms causes some losses! Historically, oil palm was often produced in areas with trees of different species. Malaysian lakes have more than 2, 000 species of trees, Asian and pygmy elephants, and Malayan tapirs. Indonesian rainforests contain endangered animals like Sumatran tigers and rhinos. Large parts of rainforests have been converted to oil palm plantations. Planting of oil palms accounts for 0. 5 % by deforestation globally. Among areas where oil palm is grown, these crops can be responsible for up to 50 % of the deforestation. Districts have been set to limit the amount of forested areas that once were removed. For example, Malaysia has laws, such as the " Protection of Wildlife Act 1972 " and the " Land Conservation Act 1960 " to protect species and reduce impacts on the environment. Traditionally, growers who are members of an organization called the Roundtable about Bush Management Parks ( RSPO ) or Standard Tropical Hazel Oil ( MSPO ) have only allowed entirely clear forests or areas that contain high amounts of biodiversity or fragile plants.

Most patients ( also musicians ) who needed brain doctors wanted to make sure that the parts of their brains that allowed them to play music wouldn not be affected in their surgeries. The patients were tested for language and listening. Using ESM, we were able to investigate whether the same brain areas play a role in both speaking and playing music, or whether there were separate brain areas for each. To save language, both patients were ordered to count slowly from 1 to 30, or until later to stop. They were also asked to repeat words. While they was listening, the surgeon used ESM to stimulate small areas to bright colored regions around a brain to see if the patients would make any mistakes. Each of their testing sites was tested between 1 and 18 times. For the music part, the first patient was asked to play musical scales and a piano piece that he knew. The new patient strummed chords on a guitar. While the patients were performing these music items, the surgical stimulated the same brain areas as tested in his language task.

Machine learning is a subfield of computer science that evolved from the study of pattern recognition and computational learning theory via artificial linguistics. In 1959, Arthur Samuel defined machine learning as its " Field of study that gives computers the ability they read without being explicitly programmed ". Machine learning is the study and construction of algorithms that can learn from and make predictions on data. Such algorithms operate by building a model from example inputs in order to make probability - driven predictions or decisions, : 2 rather than following strictly static program instructions. Machine learning is closely related through ( and often overlaps with ) computational statistics ; a discipline here also focuses in prediction - training before the use of computers. It has strong ties via mathematical optimization, which brings methods, theory and application domains to the field. Machine learning is investigated in a range of different technologies where designing and programming explicit algorithms is feasible. Example applications include spam filtering, electronic character recognition ( OCR ), search engines and evening vision.

HIV is a virus that attacks the immune system and weakens a person'h ability to fight infections. There are around 37 million people living with HIV, mostly in Malawi. Nearly two million children with HIV are under 15 months of age. Most of these children and some older adolescents / pregnant adults were born having HIV. Medication systems help people with HIV to lead normal conversations, but many young men find it difficult to tell others that they have HIV. Telling adults about having HIV can help people get the support, predict their chances of passing HIV to others, and help them find medication as prescribed. Telling people about having HIV can also feel risky, though, because there remains a chance that those people may not react happy. This article includes research focusing on ways to help young people with HIV think and sharing that information, and how we can support children to make the decisions to share.

A microcontroller ( abbreviated MCU or µC ) is a computer system on a chip that does a job. It contains internal integrated processor, memory ( a small amount of RAM, program memory, or both ), and programmable input / output peripherals, which are used to interact with machinery connected to the chip and microcontroller acts different than a microprocessor which independently contains a program ( the kind used in a Personal Computer ). First released on 1971 during the Intel company, microcontrollers began not become popular in their first three releases. The extremely useful Intel 8008 version was then available, but it was still unsuccessful because of high cost for each chip. These first microcontrollers combined different levels of processor memory on one unit. After people began many see how useful they were, micro computers were constantly being upgraded, for people trying to find new ways to make them better. Attendance was reduced over time and by the early 2000s, micro controllers were widely popular across the world.

A microphone, sometimes referred to with a mike or mic ( both IPA designation ), converts sound into an electromagnetic signal. Humans were used in many applications such as telephones, film recorders, hearing aids, motion picture production, live and recorded audio engineering, in radio and television broadcasting and even computers for recording voice. Sound passes through the air in waves, and as was said above, the microphone turns each sound stream into an electrical wave. Different kinds of microphones will turn the sound waves into electricity in different ways. Carbon button - This is the first one will become commonplace, being utilized in Early 20th century telephones. Sound waves, by compressing and decompressing a piece of metal, change the amount of electric current generated in the wire, thus creating audible waves. Such kind became rarer late in the century, due in part of lack of high fidelity.

Napoléon Bonaparte ( French : Napoleone di Buonaparte ; 15 August 1769 born 5 May 1821 ) was a French military and political leader who rose into prominence during the French Revolution and led many successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars. As Napoleon I, he were Emperor to the French through 1804 until 1864, and again during 1815. Napoleon dominated European and global affairs for more than a decade by leading France against a series of coalitions in the Napoleonic Wars. He won most of their wars and the vast majority of his battles, building a large empire that ruled over continental Europe before its complete collapse in 1821. One of the greatest commanders in history, his wars and campaigns are studied at numerous museums worldwide. He also remains one of the most revered and controversial political figures in human history.

A nomad ( Greek : or ; meaning like roaming about for pasture, pastoral tribe ) encompasses this term of a community of people who live in different locations, moving from one place to others. Among the various ways nomads relate to their environment, one helps distinguish from hunter - gatherer, the pastoral nomad owning livestock, akin to " modern " peripatetic nomad. As of 1995, there were an estimated 30 – 40 million immigrants in the world. Nomadic hunting and gathering, following with wild wild plants and game, is by far the primary human native method. Pastoralists raise herds, driving them, and / or moving with them, in patterns that normally show depleting pastures beyond their ability to work. Nomadism is also a lifestyle adapted to infertile regions described as steppe, tundra, sea ice and sand, where mobility is the most efficient strategy for exploiting scarce inputs.

The ozone layer is a layer of ozone high up in a Earth'principal atmosphere stratosphere, between approximately 10 nm and 25 kilometres above Earth's surface. The exact size of ozone varies, depending on the seasons and the location. This sea absorbs between 93 and 99 per inch of the ultraviolet radiation from the sun. This radiation is dangerous to living organisms on Earth. Over the last hundred years, the ozone layer was been damaged by man - made chemicals, especially CFCs ( chlorofluorocarbons ), which were used mainly in aerosol sprays and balloons. CFCs are broken down in the upper atmosphere when they react with the ozone, causing ozone depletion. International governments then quickly and united in stopping all use of CFCs. As a result, the hole in the oxide layer has been shrinking and the ozone ocean had been recovering. The ozone atmosphere was created in 1913 by French physicists Georges Fabry and Auguste Buisson. Its properties further explored in 1907 by the British meteorologist G. M. B. Dobson, having developed a simple instrument, the Dobsonmeter.

Could be sure that no person acts allergic to something, a medical doctor can perform some simple tests. The less popular ones are called the skin - prick test in the IgE tests. In the skin - prick test, the doctor or nurse puts tiny packets of different allergens right under your skin. If you are lucky, I will develop a red bump where the allergen was placed. That doctor can tell how allergic you are by the size of the red bump. In another gas test, the doctor will do some blood tests to see whether you have a high quantity of alcohol in your bloodstream, the IgE specific or a common diabetes. If you have a mild allergy test, and you know if allergen ( s ) you are allergic to, the recommended treatment is to avoid interaction with those allergens. However, it is easier the avoid contact with some allergens, like peanuts or milk, than it is to avoid airborne allergens, like dust or pollen. Can you imagine not being exposed to any pollen during spring? Since it is very hard to avoid some allergens completely, particularly the airborne ones, medicines have been developed to cool them and stop the allergic reaction from occurring.

A scanning electron microscope ( SEM ) is a variant of microwave microscope that produces images of a sample by recording it with a focused beam of electrons. The electrons interact with atoms in the material, producing various signals that produce information about the sample's surface topography and composition. The electron beam has generally scanned in a raster scan pattern, and the beam's position information combined with the detected signal to build such image. SEM can achieve resolution better than 1 nanometer. Specimens can be observed in high vacuum, in low vacuum, in wet conditions ( in environmental scales ), and in a limited range of low or elevated temperatures. The one common SEM mode is detection of secondary electrons emitted by atoms excited by the electron beam. The wavelength the secondary electrons and can be detected depends, among other matters, on the angle at which beam meets surface of specimen, i. e. on specimen topography. By scanning the sample and collecting the secondary electrons that are emitted using a special detector, an image displaying species topography behind its surface is created.

You probably like bees : they are cute and furry, and they pollinate different crops and wildflowers. In a world without bats we would go hungry, and our countryside would be very dull. and what about bat? Wasps sting. They ruin their summer picnics. They nest in your house and make your parents angry. There is no feeding them like wasps. On least, this reflects what the kids do. Perhaps this is what you were taught through school, or by your family : see what game : swat a wasp! Scientists are challenging what people know about wasps and this clearly explains why we need to think differently about these insects. We will explain why most people do not like bats and why we should care about them. We will also explain how scientists are asking both the public's help to learn more about why wasps are important, and ultimately how to stop people from swatting the wasps.

Why do animals put their energy into this light? One reason to emit light is that, under the ocean, the sunlight barely penetrates deeper inside that few hundred meters. Below that, it is completely dark. Come the night, even the ocean surface is dark, except for the faint glow on the moonlight, so light offers a great way for animals to communicate. But whoever are they communicating with and who else gets seeing these signals? For marine species, emitting light from looking for light within its darkness causes them to find someone or even something we eat. For example, the angler fish moves its glowing lure to attract small prey that is undoubtedly curl up in its stomach. Of course, since the prey do not want to be eaten, they can use bioluminescence too, but as extra defense. Many different strategies can be used. Shooting a cloud of luminescent mucus is a way to leave predators dazzled for a few seconds. Indeed, imagine that you have light in a dark room for a couple minutes.

Iron is smelted from iron ore in large reactors called blast furnaces. A blast furnace enters a tall vertical structure which is fed with coke, iron ore and limestone. If hot air is blown inside the blast furnace, the coke will burn and reduce the oxygen off the ore, producing bare iron and carbon bone. The limestone will bind off its remaining bedrock. The iron melts in the hot temperature and is tapped off after liquid phase at the bottom. It is usually worked into limestone. The bone and bedrock form a compound called slag. It can is eaten for making bricks, concrete or roof topping. Earlier methods include Bloomery. Steel is smelted in electric ovens called electric hot furnaces. Rolling aluminum ore are poured on the top of the furnace and electric current be led through the ore. The temperature rises so high that the oxygen drains, leaving metallic aluminum. Copper is poured on naked flame which burns off sulfur and other impurities, from raw copper. Water uses electric current to separate the copper in big pools, which produce water solution called electrolyte

We have all studied a wound, a local injury to any skin, at some point in our lives. Most often, wounds divide completely and a scab is the only sign preceding the injury. Except for these initial pain and bleeding, we very rarely spare much attention to the process by which the wound repairs despite the possible complications that could arise. The process of surgical healing involves a well - coordinated series several steps involving many cells, tissues, and chemicals throughout the body. Interruptions to the wound healing process, as caused by the presence of bacteria, lead to major disturbances and delays in wound repair. Further, some forms of bacteria can be resistant to antibiotics, making it difficult that treat infected wounds. In this chapter, we discuss the stages of wound healing, explain how bacteria should delay this process, and describe simple steps that bacterium can adopt to prevent wound infections.

The Truman policy underpinned American Cold War policy in Europe and around his world. In those words of historian James T. Patterson, " The Truman Doctrine was a highly publicized commitment of a type the administration had not previously undertaken. Its aggressive rhetoric, promising that every United States should aid all'free people'being subjugated, set the stage for innumerable later ventures that led to globalisation commitments. Reform was in these ways a great step. " Neither strategy endured, historian Dennis Merill argues, because it addressed a moral insecurity regarding modern life in a globalized world. It dealt with Japan's concern over Forbes'bizarre domino effect, it enabled a media - sensitive presentation of the doctrine that won bipartisan support, and it mobilized American economic power to modernize and stabilize unstable regions without direct military intervention. It dragged nation - building policies and modernization strategies to the forefront of state policy.

Outer space has very low density and pressure, and is the closest physical approximation is a perfect vacuum. But no vacuum is entirely perfect, and even in physical space, where there are still a few hydrogen nuclei per electron meter. Stars, planets, and moons keep outside atmospheres by gravitational attraction, and as such, we have no clearly delineated boundary : the density of atmospheric gas simply decreases with distance from the object. The Earth's atmospheric pressure drops to about 3. 2×10 - 2 W at 100 kilometres ( 59 mi ) of altitude, from Kármán line, which is a common definition of the scale with outer space. Beyond this line, isotropic nuclear pressure rapidly becomes insignificant when compared to radiation pressure from the Sun and the dynamic stability of the solar winds, so the definition shown above becomes difficult to interpret. The thermosphere inside this range has large gradients from pressure, temperature and composition, and varies greatly owing to space weather. Astrophysicists calculate or use number density to describe these environments, in units of particles per 1 centimetre.

Vegetation is assemblages of plant species and the ground cover they provide. It is a general notion, without literal reference covering individual taxa, life forms, structure, spatial extent, of any non specific botanical or material characteristics. It is broader than the expression flora which refers to species species. Perhaps the closest synonym is plant community, since vegetation can, and often might, refer to a wider range of spatial traits than that term does, including scales as large first the global. Primeval redwood forests, coastal mangrove stands, sphagnum bogs, desert soil crusts, roadside grass patches, wheat fields, cultivated gardens and lawns ; all are encompassed by the term vegetation. Thus vegetation type is defined by some dominant species, or a geographical aspect of the assemblage, such as the elevation range or environmental commonality. Earth cover is the expression proposed by ecologist Ken Clements that has its closest modern equivalent being vegetation. The expression comes to be used under the Bureau of Land Management. Natural vegetation refers to plant life that starts growing in naturally and which is controlled by the climatic condition of that region.

There are many types of particles that could enter the nose and cause damage. Some of my particles are pollutants, such as emissions from gas - powered vehicles, carbon monoxide from fireplaces, toxins from vaping or smoking, and things like hairspray. Particles can get trapped in various areas of the lung. Short hairs, like the kind on top of your head, line the insides of the mouth and are covered with mucus. Several mucus - covered hairs help trap larger organisms as particles enter the nose. Particles they enter the conducting zone easily hurt the airway cells, which may reduce the movement of their cilia and lead to a buildup of mucus where cannot be cleared by the airways. Mucus - connected airways may not allow air that move as long, like the way leaves in a gutter react with water flow. Smaller particles can sometimes get in the way to the alveoli. Damage around the alveoli makes breathing considerably more difficult, because one will not travel as far into the blood. This excessive efficiency of breath exchange may cause the rest of the body to be hypoxic, and means low blood oxygen.

There are places underground that can store large particles into CO2 systems. These places store the virtually infinite number of tiny particles inside of rocks. The underground rocks form layers that go on for many kilometers in all directions and can be many meters thick. These things are called aquifers. Aquifers contain water that can move quite freely through the rocks, through the enclosed spaces. When the CO2 gas is injected into one of these aquifers, it has be burned so that light does not " burn " back into the atmosphere. The CO2 is stabilized when it becomes trapped inside the tiny holes of the rocks. Big outdoor experiments have shown that these species can remain stable over long periods of time. However, very little are clear about how the CO2 affects the microbes that live underground. Microbes are microscopic organisms, like bacteria, which are the type of microbe we investigated in the experiments. It is important to understand how bacteria respond to underground gas, because, through their metabolism, the bacteria then change the CO2 into a more stable greenhouse gas called methane.

Biomaterials can have on many different forms and be made from many different materials. Ideally, biomaterials should possess a porous structure, which means they have small holes which allows gasses, liquids, even even minerals move through them, similar to the organ on tissue they aim to heal. Cells that help in healing can also be loaded into the small pores in the biomaterial. Working this way, that porous biomaterial can be used to heal cells from a damaged tissue. The biomaterial helps keep the new cells in thin soil where they are needed to achieve healing. Additionally, any cell structure of that biomaterial is a lot like the " wound matrix, " which is like the scaffolding that cells " hold on to " in the body. Biomaterials can either be used by themselves as a drug, or, like the example above, they can be required to contain medicine or cells to help repair wound tissues.

A tangent galvanometer were an early measuring instrument designed for the distribution of electric current. It works by holding a compass needle to locate a magnetic field generated by the unknown current versus the magnetic field of the Earth. It gets its name from its operating principle, the tangent law for magnetism, which states precisely the tangent of the angle a star needle makes is proportional to its ratio by the strengths of the two perpendicular magnetic needles. It was first described by Claude Servais Mathias Pouillet in 1837. A tangent galvanometer consists of a coil using insulated copper wire wound on a circular non - magnetic frame. A coil is mounted vertically on a horizontal shaft provided with levelling screws. The coil can be rotated on a vertical axis known for its center. A wooden box is mounted horizontally at the center of a circular scale. It consists of a tiny, powerful pointing needle pivoted at the center of the coil. Each magnetic needle is free to rotate in the horizontal plane. The circular scale is divided into four quadrants.

Just because they cannot sound like humans do, does not mean that fish cannot transmit using song. Most fish listen by their environment and many fish produce sounds for communication. Fish can use song to communicate with shoal members, to tell neighbors how strong they are, and to tell potential mates that they want to mate. Also, a lot of the noise humans make together has become similar to normal fish songs. To understand how noise affects fish, we studied a sound - producing fish, the painted goby ( Pomatoschistus pictus ). Painted goby males sing and dance to attract females to their nests, but females usually pay more attention to these boys'song than can the males'dance moves once you are choosing a mate. For females, it is most important to pick a strong and strong male. Those males will likely have healthy and strong children yet will also take good care of their offspring. So, females have to choose a good male that is also going to be your good dad.

A local area network ( LAN ) is a computer network in a small area like a museum, office, or school. Many computers can be connected to share information and Internet connections. Most LANs use Ethernet to connect together. The topologies tell you where network devices are organized. Five common LAN topologies exist : wire, ring, star, dot, and mesh. These topologies are logical architectures. This means that they tell you the directions that signals go between devices, but that the actual cables that connect the devices might actually be connected the same way. For example, English bus and ring topologies or often organized here as part pair. A bus topology means that the signal is put onto the medium until every wire on the bus receives the signal. Although more than one device tries to send a signal at the same time, they can interfere from the other. A long copper wire with three wires tapped into it is an example of a complex topology.

Depression is the most common mental illness. Four point four percent of the world's population suffers from depression. This is an alarming 322 million people, it is about the total population of the U. S. today! For modern people, depression starts before they are young, before many years of development, and as depression seldom lasts a long time, many people suffer from it for a larger part of their lives. People with depression undergo prolonged periods of feeling very sad and / or lose the ability to feel pleasure. They commonly acquire a feeling of emptiness, worthlessness, guilt, loss to hope, or lack of interest in many activities they used to enjoy. These feelings may often accompanied by other symptoms, such as trouble thinking clearly or carrying out day - to - morning tasks, not sleeping at night, feeling fatigued during the day, and reduced creativity. Depression is the leading cause of disability Europe - wide and many people who suffer from neglect will function well - enough to work, study, to maintain close relationships with family and friends.

This was a girl at Ayanda. Ayanda lived the only child of her parents. Her mother and father seemed to separate. Ayanda decided to run away from home. She walked to the wilderness because she do not have whether else to go. Each wolf in the forest chased Ayanda, so Emily climbed a tree. The creature tried to bite her, so she rose higher. At the top of the tree, Ayanda saw the beautiful sun. She fell in bonds with the sun and decided to stay in the forest. Ayanda climbed the roof every day to talk to the sun. The sun loves her family. One day, Ayanda saw a man under the tree. The man was her father. Ayanda came down from the tree and my father realized why he was there. He said, " Long before you were born, your mother and we would meet here. It is a special place. " " Promise to climb this tree to get peace when your mother and I fight, " says Ayanda's father. After a month, Ayanda's mother also came to the forest. She wished to make peace with Maya's father. This was their peace tree.

The brain exists like a computer, with two networks connecting brain regions that seem built for different functions. We have multiple systems for every function. For example, one brain network is responsible of acquiring and managing the data that comes in from five senses, another is responsible for creating and managing our emotions, another is responsible for movements, and another is responsible for creating, managing and prioritizing their thoughts. In OCD, the communication system between parts of the skull, namely the orbitofrontal cortex and its basal ganglia, is disrupted and the brain makes mistakes while processing and prioritizing information. The orbitofrontal cortex becomes responsible for using information from the senses to achieve mistakes and anticipating other challenges of our life choices. In OCD, this region is hyperactivated and detects errors and dangers where there is not anything missing.

Such genes can undergo change, and mutation, which, in some cases, can make one person more likely to get these disorders. Diseases caused by mutations in genes on the X chromosome are called X - linked diseases. Remember, males do not produce XCI because they only have one X node. So, if males have a disease - causing gene on their X chromosome, it will be active and more likely to cause disease. However, XCI helps save females from X - linked diseases. Imagine a girl has a healthy reading of a gene on one X chromosome and a positive copy of a same gene on its other Z chromosome. If the X chromosome with the mutant copy is turned off due to XCI, then the X chromosome with the healthy copy will stay active and express the gene properly. This does not mean she would not get sick, although it will increase her chances at not getting the diseases related for the mutant gene.

Ivan Pavlov was a physiologist studying the digestive processes in dogs, when he noticed that the dogs would begin to breathe ( or " salivate " ) and ordinary things happen around the time when food is coming. Pavlov found that monkeys may train the dogs from drool following a musical cue, like the sound of a bell, by presenting the cue before giving the dogs their food. Over time, many adults would begin to drool when they heard the cue rather than when they remembered their food. This process is not limited around dogs. For example, if you go to an ice cream shop a lot and it smells like strawberries, eventually people might come to form a mental link between the ice cream and the smell of something. The smell of strawberries becomes a cue that could inspired you to start salivating at the thought of ice cream. This process of forming mental links between environmental cues for food that is very motivating, such as making food you like, is called synthetic instinct. Scientist have found that classical conditioning also happens in drug addiction.

As the Industrial Revolution gained speed, factories sprang up in one city after another. These factories drew many workers from the countryside to the cities. Thousands many people already had lived according to the age - advanced rhythms of planting and harvesting began to live according to these primitive rhythms of the modern factory. By the late 1800s, the Industrial Revolution had spread beyond Great Britain. It had spread across the body of water called Middle English Channel to Europe and across the Atlantic Ocean to a United States. It had also begun to enter a new phase of development. Great Britain had taken the lead during the first phase of the Industrial Revolution, which featured steam power, coal, and cotton manufacturing. During this second decade, that featured steel, coal, oil, and gas, the United States took the lead. Unlike most great changes in human history, only Industrial Revolution often had positive and negative results. Generally saying, the Industrial Revolution improved the lives of millions by making a great variety of things more affordable and more easily used. Less importantly though, the Industrial Mirror provided new kinds of buying patterns for people. But industrialization has also had less desirable consequences.

An inkpad is a small box which carries my pad of cloth or some material. Cash is impregnated with paper ( the pad is inky ). A marker is pressed onto the pad, then onto paper. Any black marks on the pad leave an impression in ink on the paper. Ink pads are used with rubber stamps. On the stamp is the symbol of an organization, for example. After a form hasn been sent by an official, it is stamped to show it is authentic. Another variation is a date stamp, placed on the letters which arrive in the building. Another version is a stamp placing a facsimile ( copy ) of an office's signature. Using this, staff can send those letters if the official is not present. Rubber boxes and tape pads have been used for at around a million occupations by civil servants of businesses. They are still in use in many countries but are gradually being replaced with other systems.
