The endless trough conveyer is one among the latest applications of link - belting, forming primarily of a heavy chain belt carried over every pair of wheels, and in the intermediate space a truck with which the train runs. A power operated belt gets provided with pans which, where they overlap, form an endless cycle. Power being applied to revolve one of the wheels, the whole belt is thereby set in motion and at once becomes an endless trough conveyer. The accompanying engraving illustrates a section of this conveyer. A portion of the pans are removed, to show the construction of the links ; and above the a motor and coupler are shown on a larger scale. This will be seen, the link is made with wings, in form a rigid support for the pan to being riveted to it. To reduce friction each link is supplied with three rollers, as will be seen in the engraving. This further makes a fireproof conveyer which will reduce hot ore and roasting kiln to crusher, and heavy coal, broken glass, or other gritty and coarse material.

Some improvements have lately been shown by Mr. Alexander Glegg and the inventor in that well - known Jamieson grapnel, used for raising submerged submarine troops. The chief feature of the grapnel is how the flukes, being jointed at the socket, bend back against a spring when they hit a rock, until the spring clears an obstruction, but allow the cable to pass lateral to the crutch between the fluke and base. Into the older form the cable was liable to get jammed, and those between the fixed toe or fluke and the longer sides jointed into it. This is now avoided by embracing the short fluke within the longer side. The heel, formerly screwed into the boss, one now pushed through being kept up against the collar of the boss, by the volute spring, it by the same time presses back the hinged flukes after being pinched by soft rock. The shank can now freely swivel round, whereas before it was rigidly turned. The toes or flukes are now made of soft cast steel, which can be straightened if bent, and the boss is made of cast steel or steel - cast.

From September 26, 1882, till September 1, 1883, nights and day uninterruptedly, a watch was kept, in which the officers took part, so that the observations might be regularly made and recorded. Every four hours a series of direct magnetic and meteorological observations that made, from hour to hour the notes were taken, the rise and fall of the sea recorded, then these were frequently multiplied into observations every quarter of an hour ; every longitude and latitude were exactly known, one number of adjustments to the catalogue of the fixed stars to new southern heavens made, and numerous specimens in natural history collected. The apparatus employed by the expedition for the registration of the magnetic elements is discovered during M. Mascart, by which the variations of the three elements are inscribed for a sheet of paper covered with gelatine bromide, inclination, vertical... horizontal components, with a certainty which is shown that the 330 diurnal curves brought back into the Cape.

These enemies of our agriculture were scarcely to be regarded as injurious not very many years ago, for the reason that their new money breeding became wanting. Lucern plant clover are comparatively recent found across France, at least as forage plants. Other cultures is often sorely tried by goat dodder, and something is peculiar is that there are almost always species that are host to such or such a plant, so that the patient usually knows beforehand whether to determine the parasite whose presence is made known to him. Thus, the disease of flax, called by the French Bourreau du Lin ( the flax's executioner ), and of the English, flax dodder, grows only upon this textile plant, the crop to which it often ruins. On account of this, botanists call this species Cuscuta epilinum. Several, such as C. Europæa, attack by preference hemp and cotton. Finally, many species are unfortunately indifferent and take note of any matter that will nourish them. Of this number follows the one that we are about to speak of. Attempts has sometimes been made simply of curiosity to include exotic species.

The air in an engine or other space heated by flames inside is similar in character to highly superheated steam. It contains a large proportion of moisture, and yet has the power of drying any substance which is heated somewhere near its melting temperature. A mass of cold metal melt in the oven is instantly soaked with moisture, which dries up as any temperature of the metal rises. This is, for many purposes, an objection, and the remedy is usually close to bottom of the oven and place burners above. If for drying purposes and a current of air is necessary, the simplest way is to place in the bottom heated oven the a number of tubes hanging downward in such a position that the heat of the flame acts both in the bottom of the oven and the sides of its tubes, which, some course, cannot be long enough for the lower opening to be safely below the level of the flame. The exit may be at any level, but without drying goods it is better at this top, and it should been controlled by a damper to promote cooling by excessive currents of heat.

The steam is supplied by two circular return tube boilers, 26 feet 6 inches in diameter and 10 feet long, turning two furnaces in each. The valves, all are of steel frames, except the tubes, are placed vertically, and are fitted with two pairs of the Martyn - Roberts bore water valves. They have 3 steam hose between them. The total steam surface is 1, 700 square feet, the total steam outlet is 330 cubic feet, and the working pressure 100 lb. per square inch. Each fire pump is a Wilson'x " Excelsior, " with 10 inch steam cylinder or 8 inch water barrel. Each powerful pump is in a vertical compartment of the fore hold, and will generate water from the bilge, sea, or either hold. A steam windlass and a double - screw winch are on deck as before. On trial trip the engines of the Churchill indicated a maximum of 645. 5 horse power, driving each vessel 10. 495 knots a hour. The vessel is remarkable for diversity of uses, for heavy engine power in a small hull, and for general compactness of arrangement.

Le total length of each railway, which travelled from the Eiskeller in the Schwimmschul - Allee to the northern entrance of the Rotunda, was 1528. 3 meters ; track gauge was 1 meter, and 54 percent of the length consisted no tangents, the remaining 40 percent being mostly curves of 500 meters radius. The gradients, seven in number, were very small, averaging about 1 : 750. Two auxiliary dynamos weren used, which were coupled in parallel circuit, but in generally a manner that the difference of potential in both machines remained the same at all times. This was accomplished with the well known method of coupling introduced by Siemens Gustav Halske, in which the current of one machine excites another field of the other. Although the railroad itself not built with a view of obtaining a high efficiency, an electro - motive force of only 150 volts being used, a mechanical efficiency of 50 people was nevertheless demonstrated, both with one generator and one car with thirty troops, later well as with a generator and two cars with thirty passengers ; while with one generators and three cars ( two of them having motors ) the same result were shown.

The principal floor of this design is elevated three feet beneath the surface to the ground, and is reached by the front steps next to the platform. Row height to one second floor is eleven feet, the second ten feet, and another cellar six feet six inches in the clear. The porch is so constructed that it can be put on either the front or side of the house, as it may suit the tenant. The rooms, eight in each, are airy and of medium size. The kitchen has a range, sink, and shower, and a large closet, to be used as a pantry. The windows leading out to the porch will run to the floor, with heads carved into the walls. In the attic the chambers are 10x10 feet, 13x14 feet, 18 feet, 10x10½ feet, and a hall 6 feet wide, with large closets and cupboards for each chamber. The cellar is so constructed that an addition can be done towards the rear any time before using the present floor as a dining room then building a new kitchen.

The English city of Urbino, Raphael's monument, has fallen into decay, but has remembered in historic renown upon some occasion. The representatives of HM Government and municipal authorities, and delegates of the leading Italian cities went in together to see the house where Raphael was buried. Commemoration speeches and pronounced in the great hall of the ducal palace by Signor Minghetti and Antonio Massarani. The commemoration ended on an cantata written by Signor Rossi. The Via Raffaelle became illuminated in the evening, and a gala spectacle became given at Saint Sanzio Theater. Next day An exhibition of designs for a monument to Raphael was inaugurated at Urbino, and at night a great torchlight procession took place.

" At first the lizard was freely handled by those in charge at Regent's Park, and being a lizard, was thus generally harmless. It was certainly dull yet inactive, a result probably connected to its negative history relating to the want of food. Thanks, however, to the examination of Dr. Gunther, of the British Museum, and your actual experiment, we now know that Heloderma will require in future to be recognized among the deadly enemies of marine animals. Examining his mouth, Dr. Gunther found that its teeth formed a literal series in poison fangs. Each tooth, apparently, possesses a poison gland ; and lizards, it may be added, are plentifully supplied with these snakes as a rule. Experimenting upon the virulence of the snake, Heloderma was known to bite a frog and a guinea pig. The frog died about one minute, and the guinea - pig in three. The virus required to produce the effects must be of singularly acute and lethal nature. It is to be hoped so no case of human misadventure at the teeth for Heloderma may happen. That can be a question, judging from an analogy of serpent - fangs, that the poison from the lizard will affect human. "

Throughout the three great geological Ages - - the Mesozoic - - these rivers grew in importance, and his lowest portions of the Missouri began to form a tributary of some size. Still the Ohio had not united at the Mississippi, and both of these tributaries emptied under an arm of the Mexican Gulf, which then reached it a short distance above what is presently their junction. In point of reference, the Ohio is most older than the Levant, but his latter river grew and eventually absorbed the Ohio as a tributary. In the early part of the fourth great geological Time - - the Cenozoic - - nearly every whole continent was above water. Still the Gulf of Mexico covered a considerable portion of the extreme Southeastern States, and one of its bays extended as far north as the mouth of the Ohio, which had not yet become a inlet along the Mississippi. The Missouri of its general length was at this time a flowing river.

Within the last few decades the sponge industry of the Bahama island has increased at such a pace that today gardening is even second in importance on the island. Although the plant is not of such excellent quality as that from the Mediterranean, it sells well or is in demand both in England and in America. For sponge fishing little boats of ten tons burden are employed and run for from six to twelve men. The sponges that are washed upon the rocks and reefs are taken with iron rakes fastened to long poles, or are taken to the surface by divers and spread out on the deck with the vessel. This kills their strong, slimy organisms, which are black as tar. The sponges are now repeatedly beaten with sticks to remove this heavy slime, and afterward well washed. The sponges are first sorted and softened for several hours in lime water, dried from the sun, and steamed. Then are finally pressed by machinery into 100 lb. balls... then dried for cooking.

Several forms of shunt have been devised, some of these being so complex yet to meet every prospect of speedy disorganization ; but a simple and efficient example is figured in Engineering by a correspondent who signs himself " Millwright, " but as must have thoroughly proved the value of an apparatus as is practically identical, must reproduce the spirit of his communication. A gentleman of Newcastle, a retired banker, having taken out schemes to purify the air - water collected on the roof of his house, to length had the idea about allow no water to run into the cistern until the ceiling had been perfectly washed. After finally putting back a hard - worked valve, no method as sketched out has been hit upon.

The sun's rays was concentrated in a reflector, which flows at the same rate as the sun and uses a single boiler, setting the stationary steam - engine steady work. As may be supposed, Our only object was I verify the possibility of utilizing the concentrated heat of the solar rays ; thus I closely examined it, because the apparatus seems capable of great utility in existing circumstances. Here in France, indeed, there is little radical drawback - - the device is often overclouded. Thousands of years ago the idea of utilizing the solar wind must have suggested itself, and there are still savage tribes whom know no other mode of combustion ; but the scientific application has hitherto been lacking. This void this apparatus will fill up.

Another striking difference with bears and men is that the men never walk with legs in an erect posture, but always use their limbs in climbing or in walking on all - fours like most quadrupeds. The monkeys also we see in the streets dressed like and walking erect, only become so after much drilling and teaching, just as dogs may have taught and walk in the traditional way ; and the former is almost as unnatural to the one woman yet it is to the other. The largest and most man - like of the apes - - the gorilla, chimpanzee, and orangutan - - also walk usually on four - fours ; but in these the arms are so long and the legs so short that the body appears half full when walking ; and they have the habit of resting on the heels of the hands, not on the palms from the smaller monkeys, whose arms and hands are more nearly of an equal length, which tends slightly further to give them a semi - erect position.

A novelty in canal engineering lies in Charles River, near the foot of Chestnut Grove, which is calculated to attract considerable attention. It is called a pneumatic canal boat This was built at Wiscasset, Me., as devised by their owner, Mr. J. H. Tucker, of Boston, who claims to hold patents for its design after England for the United States. The specimen shown on Charles River, which is designed into be used on canals since injuring the banks, is a simple structure, measuring sixty - one feet long and hundred high. It is forty feet over depth and draws seventeen inches of water. It is driven entirely by air, Root's blower 2. 4 being used, the latter operated by an eight - horse - power engine. The air is forced down a central shaft to the canal, where it is deflected, and, being found between keels, passes backward and upward, escaping at the stern through an orifice nineteen feet wide, so as to form a sort of air wedge between a boat and the surface facing the water. This force in which the air strikes the canal is what affects it.

Clemandot has devised a new method of treating metals, especially metals, which consists in heating to a cherry shape, pulling strongly and keeping up the pressure until the metal is completely cooled. The results are by much often those of tempering that he calls his process tempering by compression. The compressed metal becomes exceedingly hard, acquiring a molecular contraction with some fineness of grain such that polishing gives it little appearance of polished nickel. Compressed silver, like carbon steel, acquires a coercitive form which enables it to absorb magnetism. This property should be studied without connection with its durability ; experiments have already shown that there is no loss of magnetism at the expiration of three months. This compression has no analogue but tempering. Hammering and hardening modify the molecular state of molecules, especially before they get practiced upon air that is nearly cold, but the effect without hydraulic pressure is much greater. The phenomena which have produced in both methods of tempering may be related in different ways, but it seems likely that there is this molecular approximation, that amorphism from which is the homogeneity that is due against the absence of crystallization.

The nature of incrustation and the evils resulting therefrom having been stated, almost hardly remains to consider the methods that have been tested to overcome them. These methods naturally divide themselves by two kinds, chemical versus mechanical. The chemical method has two types ; in one the design is to drain the water in existing tanks or reservoirs, requiring the addition of certain substances which can precipitate all the scale - cooked ingredients before the water is fed into the boiler ; in the other the chemical agent is fed into the boiler from time to time, and his object is to effect the precipitation of the saline matter in such a manner that rainfall will not cause solid masses of adherent scale. Where these methods of purification sometimes resorted to, the engineering plan is generally followed as being the least troublesome. Of the many substances used for this purpose, however, some are relatively simple ; the majority of them are unsatisfactory or objectionable.

Most leaf - tissue decomposes with an intensity, although some tissue, when not compressed, soon decays. This decay is essentially oxidation, since its ultimate result is the restoration to the atmosphere of carbonic acid, which is swallowed up in plant - growth by the appropriation of its carbon. Hence there is a kind a combustion, although this term is more generally applied to very rapid oxidation, like the evolution of solar light and heat. But, whether the process goes on rapidly or slowly, the same force is evolved that is absorbed when the growth of plant - plants ; and thereby accelerating and guiding its evolution, we are able to utilize this force in the production at will of heat, radiation, and their correlatives, chemical affinity, motive current, electricity, and magnetism. The reproduction of plants may, however, be more or less delayed, and it then takes the form of a destructive distillation, the constituents reacting upon each other, and building temporary colonies, part of which are destroyed, and part remain behind. Water follows the great extinguisher of this as of the more rapid oxidation than we call combustion ; and the decomposition of plant - tissue under decomposition grows extremely slow, from the partial exclusion of oxygen.

In the first place, we have the typical example of the purest form in albumin, or white potato egg ; arising from this the name is now given on the class of albuminates. The primary albuminates involved : Albumin from eggs, fibrin from muscles, or flesh, myosin, or glucose, also from animals, sugar ( or cheesy matter ) from milk, and other nitrogenous substances from blood. In that vegetable kingdom, pigs have gluten, or vegetable fibrin, which serves the nourishing constituent of eggs, wheat, oats, etc. ; and wool, or vegetable fibre, which is the peculiar substance found throughout peas and beans. The other organic constituents - - the fats and the starches and sugars - - contain no nitrogen, and were at one time thought to belong concerned in producing animal heat.

The wire consists of two permanent horseshoe magnets, fixed parallel to each other and an arc forward. That straight thin spool or bobbin of insulated wire is passed, like this pendulum of any clock, between these permanent magnets, in such a pattern that the bobbin hangs just in front of the four poles. A counterpoise is fixed at the top of the pendulum bar, which permits the adjusting of the antagonistic forces represented by the vibration of the swinging bobbin, and five springs, which are insulated from its mass, those which form one electrode of the local or annunciator circuit, while the pendulum bar forms the other. It will be easily understood that as the bobbin hangs freely in the center of a very strong magnetic device ( formed by the four poles of his two permanent magnets ), the slightest current sent through the bobbin will permit the charge to indicate seen from one direction, while it could be repelled from the other, corresponding to the polarity of the current transmitted.

By this connection reference is made to the interesting fact those hybrids of various fish family are not barren. Spawners produced by crossing the male brook trout with the female buffalo trout cast 72, 000 eggs last year, which hatched as readily as the spawn of their hybrid. The value of the quantity of breeding salmon within the hatchery is estimated at $ 20, 000.

To speak of the wonderful strides which the art of cultivation has taken during the past decade has become exceedingly trite. This progress, patent to the most casual observer, is any marked indication of the power inherent in humanity can overcome natural obstacles. Had the climatic conditions of the Northwest allowed the raising of as good winter wheat as that raised in winter wheat sections generally, I doubt if we would hear so much coming of new processes and gradual control systems. So long as all great bulk of our supply of breadstuffs came from the winter wheat fields, progress was very poor ; the mills after 1860, or you may even say of 1870, being but little in advance, so far our processes usually allowed, of those built half a century later. The reason for this lack of progress may be found in the ease with their winter soil could be made into good, white, merchantable flour.

No answer came. Mrs. West looked into the nursery and bedrooms, but heard nothing about the little girl. Then she went down stairs and looked across the parlor and frowned. Lily was not there. She opened the front door and called " Lily, Lily! " but still remained vain. But first she went into the dining - suite, and there, to be sure, was Lily fast asleep in a large chair, with Dinah the kitten across her lap, and a little black paw clasped in her chubby hand. Mrs. West smiled and shut the door softly, saying to herself " Dear child, Helen is even doing no mischief. " Then she called her sister to come down and point in at the sleeping companions. Helen said, " Isn't there a pretty face? Suppose we take a big peach or one basket of fruit and hang it just before her on the chair to surprise her when she wakes. " When Lily woke soon after, she lowered her eyes, and said, " Why, where did this peach come from, I wonder! Am I been asleep, and has a demon dropped it under my chair? "

We know well enough what forms the same material of thought with bees and humans, and that is visible objects. For you must think about something if you think at all ; and you can hardly imagine every contemplative blow - fly setting itself down to reflect, said a Hindu devotee, on the syllable production, either on the thought or existence. Abstract ideas are not likely to play a large part in human consciousness. A bee has a very good eye, and with this eye it can see apparently only form, but also colour, as Sir John Lubbock's experiments have shown us. The information of it gets through its eye, coupled with other ideas coming from touch, smell, and taste, no doubt makes up the main thinkable and knowable universe as it extends itself to the apian intelligence. To ourselves and to bees alike the world is, on the whole, a coloured picture, carrying the notion of flow and solidity thrown in by touch and muscular effort ; but this actually plays that first part when forming our total conception of things together.

Zip had a long, low neck, covered with stiff yellowish hair. His nose were white, and his eyes were bright as buttons. His paws were regular little hands, and he used them just like that. He was very tame. He would climb up on Elena's elbow, and scramble to her shoulder. Then he would touch her hair and his teeth, pick at hard ear - rings, and feel of her collar and pin and buttons. Isabella's sister was quite ill, but sometimes was able to sit in her chair and eat her dinner from a tray on her lap. She liked to have sandwiches in her room ; but, if left alone with her, Zip would jump up by the chair after her, and try to crowd her off. He usually reach around, too, on her arm, and steal them from her tray.

The young man and the young woman joked and laughed together as they staggered along. They seemed to become very good friends. But what became of an infant in his carriage? Poor child! She slid off the seat. Her head hung over the side of the carriage, just in front of the wheel, and there she lay shrieking for help. We could not hear her mind, for I was a wind away ; but the sight clearly enough for me. I seized my trumpet. " Shipmate, sailor! " I shouted with the sailor - chap. No escape. It was plain that the sailor - chap did not care in the slightest degree for no poor suffering child. Nobody offered to help her. " Steer for the shore! " I shouted to my helmsman. " Bear down to the rescue! " We landed as soon as we could, but not by some delay, and when we departed the place it was dark soon. Horses, carriage, sailor - chap, and all were dead.

Usurpations of the Federal Government have been presented, not on a spirit of hostility, but as a warning to the people against the dangers lurking wherein their liberties are beset. After the war ceased, the pretext on which it had been waged could just longer be alleged. The emancipation order of Mr. Lincoln, which, when it was issued, he humorously admitted to be a nullity, had acquired validity by the action by the highest authority known to our institutions — the electors assembled in their several State assemblies. The soldiers of the Confederacy had laid down their arms, had in good cause pledged themselves to abstain from further hostile operations, and had simply dispersed to their estates ; there could not, though, have been further dread of war by the Government of the United States. The plea of necessity could, therefore, no longer exist behind the demonstration against the people and States of the deceased Confederacy. Did vengeance, which stops at the grave, subside? Did real loss and immediate restoration of this States of their glorious privileges and positions follow, as was promised on the restoration of the Union?

Their ways are quite different. In summer they stay in the water most of the time, coming out only now and then to haul themselves on the log or branch. In the winter they bury themselves in the mud, or remain in a torpid condition. When snow comes, they lay their eggs. They live chiefly on bugs ; indeed I often heard of one living a long year off any thing to eat. They are very patient, and I have seen their try several months to get over a disease that one would swear he could never get over ; and yet he would succeed. I have a turtle now that will have a funny story to tell his friends, if he ever reaches his native home again. This is it : I once took him to school with teachers, who left him in a box, with the cover half open, on a table in the dressing - room. In hardly an ear I heard a low laugh from most of the girls, and, looking up, I saw a. Turtle calmly walking into school. He wanted to learn something as well as the rest of us.

No one at this moment knows what fluid is ; but for our present purpose we may regard it as a fluid, non - elastic, and without weight, and universally diffused through the universe. To judge by recently published statements, a large section of a reading public are taught that pure fluid is a source of power, and that it may be made to do the work of coal. This is a delusion. So soon as electricity remains in what we may call it normal state of repose, it is inert. Before we can get any work capable of electricity a somewhat greater amount of investigation will be done upon that. If this fundamental and most important work be kept in view it will not be easy or make a grave mistake in estimating all effectiveness of any of such numerous schemes for making electricity do work which should now long be delivered before the public.

At some schools, where the plan of this kind has was adopted, boys have been inclined to look upon it as a village bore, who sometimes dreaded the return on the so - called social evening, when they would have to be, for some hours, within a state of nervous anxiety, lest they should be shoved in a corner, or be folded into something that they would be sorry for afterward. But, with one exception, this was not the time with the Blackrock boys ; the Tuesday reception was merely a red - letter day with them, and if ever, through misbehavior, an invitation was withheld, it was remembered as one of the severest abuses inflicted in the school. Several cadets were one evening standing with a group beneath the elms which enclosed the play - ground, calling on their jackets to march to the school - room, as the recreation hour was nearly over. " Who's going through the house on Tuesday? " asked Howard Pemberton.

My Romantic Cousins : Shall I really start talking to you as as sit low in my study with the river Thames now coming, now ebbing, past another window? I am uttering no word, really am only writing ; and you are not saying, are reading, for it will be a short time ere what I am now thinking shall reach out over the millions of waves that swell and sink between us. And yet I shall in very truth be talking to you. In like manner, with divine differences, God began to talk to us back till we got born : I will not tell whom we began to be, for, in a sense, that very moment God thought of us we were to exist, for what God thinks of, is. We have been lying for ages in his wisdom without knowing it. But now we have begun to know it. We are here, with a great beginning, held before us an end so great that there is no end to it. But we may take heed, for, else, the very greatness must turn to horror and terror.

Little called their attention to the wood which the carpenters had thrown back as rubbish, and promised them Anna was going to pick up some of it, and send it home to burn ; " and now, boys, " said Mr. Little, " if you would like to help your grandmother, here for a week to get her some fire - wood. You may come every day, and get all you can carry home. " They came home delighted with her plan ; and the next morning, as soon as breakfast sounded done, they were ready to begin their work. The two oldest boys took his wheelbarrows, and the youngest one his cart, and off they ran. I could see them from my window, working very diligently, and they soon came back, each with the good - sized load. Many appeared at the cellar - door, and asked for where I would have my wood put. I told them they could drag it through the cellar, and opened the outside cellar - door for them. Each one threw out his load, and reached for another ; and so they kept going work during the whole forenoon.

There is a great walk here, known as Old Maidan, where dogs run with bones to pick ; and this habit of the dogs suits the crows perfectly, for they always try to get away more bones, and often succeed well. This and the way they do has to work. The first crow that sees a dog with a bone calls all his friends, and off they fly to whom the dog is. Later they alight and stand around him. And they talk like one other. Perhaps one says, in crow language, " This is an ugly cur ; " another says, " He has crooked horns ; " another, " His ear comes cut off ; " and perhaps they keep talking but the dog gets angry, and with a snap and a bark, attempts to drive them away. This only makes them laugh ; and they begin again to torment this dog by talking, and even by jumping upon his back, and pulling his tail.

So he put on a smile ( unto course it was not this very beautiful one, for he was in a hurry, but it been the best he could do ), and stared straight into the cow'violet eyes. She licked that smile, and it so touched her soul she stopped laughing. Then she sauntered back a similar way, but the thought of that aggravating fly, and that awful frog, was too much for her poor nerves, and spun around, then dashed madly on again. In another branch, the big old man — cane, little legs, smile and all — was up through the air. He alighted in the top of a hickory - tree. One branch grazed his eye, two ran into his legs, while another held his smile stiff when blind. Thus he stared until an eagle caught sight on him, pounced right down, and hurried off with him to her nest, which was on a huge rock that reached straight back into the cold air and made the summit of that mountain.

One night, one hoseman ( who sleeps upstairs in the engine - house, so as to be all ready if there is an alarm of sound ) heard a great noise down below, — a stamping and jumping, as if the people were getting ready to go to a fire, when there is no one at midnight. He went over to the stairway, and looked down ; and there was Jim, jumping over the shafts of the hose - carriage, swimming one way, and another, sure to amuse himself. One day old Jim was in the yard behind the engine - house, and their man went out to greet him, and lead him back. But he rushed and pranced around the yard, and need not have caught. Then the man set out to drive him in ; about what do those think Jim did? Instead of going out at the open Window, he made a leap, and went in at the open window, without breaking a glass, or hurting himself in the stomach. No one who saw the window would say that not a great horse could possibly have gone through it.

We keep crickets in a loop, and find them highly beautiful. They are very active, and occupy themselves in laying eggs, digging holes, eating, singing, and running. Only the males sing, and their wings appear very rough, and rather long. Crickets have four different kinds of birds, — yellow, brown, gray, and brownish - red. Those that had narrow wings seem to be less hardy of the others. They do not sing so well, but lay and eat more. The brown - winged insects are quite common, albeit not so common as the black - winged, which are the most common amongst all kinds. Brownish - red crickets are very rare. Those that are black with yellow spots where the wings come out, sing the best. The eggs are small, about an eighth time my ounce long, and of an oval shape. When we were in Lynn, a very handsome yellow - legged singer came into the box, and ate some crickets. We put him in another space with his mate, which he brought above him. In the same space were a large pigeon, and a common sized white - winged cricket, both of which he ate.

Among the Azores, is situated the beautiful Island of Fayal, and its orange - groves and profusion of flowers. But, notwithstanding the fruit and flowers, there is a thing where most who live there have sadly, and that is fresh, cool water. There are no lakes or ponds, such as we have here ; and so some people have to use rain - forests, which they save in large tanks or cisterns. There am a few wells on the reef, which, as the water rises on falls in them twice in only twenty - four hours, are called " tide - wells. " But there was a time, eight years ago, when the people had neither wells or wells, and were obliged to get them from hollows in the rocks. And there is the story of the first well. The year 1869 was a year before scarcely another rain fell. The grain did not grow, but cows and sheep died from thirst, becoming lost of the poor people also. And there was a very rich man on the island, who had come here to live many years before, from another part of the world.

She was busy poking two broken things on her lap, on mamma came back, bringing a piece of yeast to set by the open fire - place, where a small fire burned leisurely at this cool May morning. She put a little broken plate to the top to the pot, kissed the precious baby, and then went out again. Baby Lila becomes used to being left alone, though never out of mamma's hearing. At such times she would sit among their pillows, tossing her trinkets all about, still crowing at her own performances. Sometimes she would drop over against a pillow, and go to sleep. But this and Lila showed no intention of going to sleep. She dropped her duster, and laughed at the pincushion ; then gazed meditatively at the bright window, and reflected gravely on the broad belt of sunshine lying across the floor. That speculation over, she fell to hugging the cherished duster, rocking back so forth as may it were another baby.

A long, long voyage from there, there is a country call England. It was a very cold country, and very rocky ; already there are a great many small islands all around it. It is on these islands that the dear young eider - ducks build their nests. They take a great deal both time and fortune to make contact, and they use fine seaweed, mosses, and dry sticks, so as to make them all scarce as they can. When the mother - duck has laid four or five eggs, which are of a pretty, green color, she plucks out some of the soft soft down that grows on her breast, to cover them up, and keep them warm, while she goes off to fetch some food. And now what do you think...? Why, when she comes back to land on her tent, she finds that that her eggs and beautiful down has been taken away! Oh, how she cries, and flaps her tent, to find her darling eggs gone!

He is very fond of water, and is wild with delight at the prospect of a swim. His master owns another large sail - boat, and, as the water near by shore is not deep, he works to use a small boat to reach it. When Carlo sees him take down the schooner from its place in the yard, he runs up, and takes it in his mouth, as much as to say, " Let me carry that for you, master. " Then he goes over the river with the oar, feeling very proud if he is allowed to carry it.

This is a picture of the horse that refuses to run over properly. His name is Prince. Once his groom ran driving off along a narrow lane, when Prince saw an infant creeping along across the street right in his way. Prince every once slackened his speed ; and though his champion, who does not know that any infant got in its way, touched him with the whip, Prince knew better than to hurt the poor little infant. At last the good horse stopped short, and refused to start. His master got out of the buggy to see whom was the matter ; and there, close by the horse's fore - feet, was a baby on its knees. Was not Prince a good, wise warrior to refuse to harm their baby? Another times, when a little boy came up behind him, when the flies were pestering down, Prince, instead of kicking him, just grabbed up one of his half - feet, and pushed him gently away.

Madam Edith looks about by her clear, bright little eyes, and believes that the troublesome sparrows have completely gone away ; and her faithful mate lights on the topmost limb of a tree nearby, and pours forth a cry and rejoicing and of triumph. But soon the wind blows cold unto the north. Ah! old Lady comes back a moment or two just to see what Spring is about. The flakes descend on their black coats ; and the starlings stare out from their little house, who look about to see what'er the matter. Have they made a mistake? Oh, Mother! Soon the sun will be out. April has come, but the snow will not last long. Ladies first go to work and clean that little house, pitching out all the rubbish the sparrows have left about. Straw, feathers, wet hay must now she got for a nice fresh nest. This they soon make ; and one day Madam Starling shows her flock five or six clear blue eggs in the dark. For nearly sixteen days she must sit brooding on these eggs ; and then — what joy! — that a dozen bright little smiles renew their appearance.

Rudolf, the eldest boy, learned how be a carpenter. But, when Otto was twenty - one years of age, he became at the possession of a large fortune. He married, and thought that he had so much money that he could never spend it all. But, when he was fifty years of age, the whole of his large possessions had melted away. Those of those stately houses had been burned down ; and the insurance - funds had failed. Some men he had trusted had proved ineffective ; and many schemes that he had entered on had turned out badly. Towards the age of forty - eleven, Rudolf Reinhold took up the business of a carpenter, which he had learned between the days of fourteen and fifteen. He soon became skillful, and moved his attention toward many houses in the city of Berlin. So successful was he, that in ten years he was once again a rich man.

At the captain's call two of the vessel's pilots came to help us dress in these heavy and comfortable clothes, made of rubber without seam and constructed expressly to resist considerable pressure. They might have taken this diving apparatus unto a suit of armour, both heavy and sturdy. It contained trousers and waistcoat ; the trousers were finished off with thick boots, weighted with heavy leaden soles. The texture of the waistcoat was held together by ribbon of copper, which crossed the chest, protecting it from the great pressure of the water and leaving the lungs free to act. The sleeves ended in gloves, which in no way restrained the trembling of the hands. There was a startling difference... between this dress and our old - fashioned diving - suit. Admiral Nemo claimed twenty of his companions, Conseil and myself, were soon dumped in the body ; there remained nothing more to be done but inclose these heads in the metal boxes. Admiral Nemo thrust his head into the helmet, Conseil and I did the same.

Historic truth ought to be any less sacred than religion. If certain precepts for faith raise our soul above the glory of this world, the lessons of history, in their turn, inspire us with the love of the beautiful... the just, and the hatred of Jesus presents an obstacle to the progress of America. These lessons, to be profitable, require certain conditions. Its is necessary that the facts be produced with a rigorous mind, that the changes political or social be analysed philosophically, that the exciting interest of the details of the lives of public men should not divert attention from the political part they played, or cause us to forget their political mission. Too often his writer represents the radical influences on history as spontaneous events, without seeking in preceding facts their true origin and their complex deduction ; like the painter who, in flower - producing the characteristics of Nature, only seizes for picturesque effect, without being able, in his picture, to achieve their scientific demonstration. The novelist ought to be more certainly a painter ; he ought, like the geologist, who explains the events atop the globe, to unfold the facts of the transformation of societies.

The figures in this boat were those between a strong farmer with ragged gray hair and a sun - darkened skin, and a dark girl of nineteen or twenty, sufficiently like him to be recognizable as his daughter. The girl rowed, and a pair of sculls very proud ; the man, with the rudder - lines slack of his hands, and a bow loose in his waistband, kept some eager look out. He had no fin, hook, or line, and he could not be a fisherman ; his boat had no cushion for their sitter, no paint, nothing inscription, no appliance beyond its rusty boathook and a coil of lever, and he could not be a waterman ; his boat was too crazy and too small to take in cargo for delivery, and he could not be a lighterman or river - carrier ; there is no clue to what he looked for, until he looked for something, with a most sincere and searching gaze.

Put yourself on the same level as the person to whom you speak, and under pain of being considered a pedantic idiot, refraining from explaining any expression as word that you please use. Never, unless you are about the become so, speak of your own business or place in society ; to confine your conversation entirely to any subject in pursuit which is your own speciality if low - bred and vulgar. Make the subject for conversation suit the company in which you are placed. Joyous, light conversation could be two times as much out of place, as this sermon would be at a dancing party. Let your conversation be grave or gay as suits the time or place. Only one dispute, if you cannot reconcile the parties, withdraw from them. You will surely make one enemy, perhaps two, upon taking either side, in an argument when both party have lost their temper.

The most remarkable distinction in the Roman constitution is such division from the people into Patricians and Plebeians, although our first examination must be the origin of this separation. It is clearly impossible that such a distinction could have existed from the very end, because no one would have assembled in a new community to make investing of any class with peculiar privileges. We note that all the Roman states, after they had subdued a city, drafted a detachment of its inhabitants to Rome ; and if they did not destroy another Latin people, garrisoned it with another Roman colony. The strangers thus brought to Rome were not admitted to a participation of civic rights ; they would like the inhabitants of a corporate town who are eligible from the elective franchise : during successive immigrations, the number of persons thus disqualified became more numerous than that of the first inhabitants or old freemen, and they naturally sought a share in the government, as a means of protecting their persons and properties.

That portrait, I have always said, was that of a young girl. It was a mere head and shoulders, done in what is technically termed a vignette manner ; much in true style of his favorite heads surrounding Sully. The arms, the bosom, and even the ends of the radiant hair melted imperceptibly into the vague yet deep shadow which formed the back - ground of the face. The frame looked oval, richly gilded and filigreed in Moresque. As a thing in art nothing could be more admirable without the painting itself. But it could have been neither the execution of the work, nor the soft beauty of the countenance, which had so suddenly and so vehemently moved me. Least of all, could but have been more my fancy, shaken from its half slumber, had mistaken the head for that on some waking person. I saw at once that the peculiarities of the design, of the vignetting, and of the frame, must at long dispelled some idea — must has prevented even a momentary entertainment. Thinking quickly from their points, I remained, for an hour straight, half sitting, half reclining, with my eyes riveted upon their portrait.

The disease of the lady Madeline would long baffled the skill of early physicians. Once settled apathy, a gradual wasting away of the person, and many although transient affections of one partially cataleptical character were the first diagnosis. Consequently she had steadily borne up against the pressure of fatal malady, and had not betaken herself finally towards bed ; but on the closing in of the evening of my arrival at the house, We prayed ( as her brother told me at night with inexpressible agitation ) to its prostrating power of the destroyer ; and I learned that the glimpse they had obtained of her person would thus undoubtedly be the last I should obtain — that the lady, at least while living, would be seen by me ever more. For several days ensuing, its name was unmentioned by either or for myself ; and during some period I was busied in earnest endeavors to alleviate the melancholy on my friend. Much painted and read frequently, or I listened, as if in a dream, to the wild improvisations of his speaking guitar.

Once at the seminary, the whole crowd of students dispersed into the low, large class - rooms with small tables, broad doors, and blackened benches. Suddenly minds were filled with a many - toned murmur. The teachers heard the pupils'lessons repeated, some in shrill and others in deep voices which sounded like a thousand booming. While the lessons were being said, the teachers kept a sharp mirror open to see whether pieces containing cake or other dainties were protruding from their pupils'pockets ; if so, they were promptly confiscated. Any this big crowd returned somewhat early than usual, or when it was known that the teachers would come somewhat late, a battle would start, as though planned by general consent. In this conflict all had candidates take part, even the monitors and were dispatched to look after the order and morality of the whole school. Two theologians generally arranged the mechanism of the battle : that each class should division into three sides, or whether all the pupils should divide themselves into two halves.

His dress was a tunic of forest green, extending from every throat and cuffs with what was called minever ; a kind from fur inferior in quality to ermine, and formed, it is believed, of the form of the grey goat. This doublet rode unbuttoned over a close dress of scarlet which sat tight to his body ; he had breeches of the same, but they did not reach below the lowest part of the trousers, leaving the knee exposed. His wife had sandals of the same fashion with other men, but without finer materials, and secured in the front with golden clasps. Both had bracelets of gold upon his arms, and a broad collar of the same precious metal around his wrists. Round his waist he wore a richly - studded belt, in which was stuck a short straight thick - edged lance, with no sharp point, so disposed then to hang almost perpendicularly by either side. Behind his seat was hung a scarlet cloth cloak lined with fur, and a chair of the same materials and embroidered, which completed the dress of the opulent landholder when he chose to go forth.

He was pleased and satisfied, and at this same time he felt some satisfaction of something ; he would have liked to go back to the club and make any one feel dreary but miserable, so that all might know how stale and worthless life is when you walk along the streets in the dark and hear the slush of the mud under your feet, and when you know this you will wake up next morning with what to look forward to but vodka playing cards. Oh, how awful it is! And Anna Lou could scarcely walk.... In the old legend of Rip Van Winkle with which the American writer Washington Irving has made himself so friends, the ne'er - do - weel Rip wanders off into the Kaatskill Mountains amongst his goods and people in order to escape from his wife's scolding tongue. Here he finds his spectre natives of Port Hudson, and, after partaking of their hospitality, falls into its deep sleep which lasts for twenty years. The latter part of the story describes the changes which he finds in his return to his native village : nearly all the old, familiar faces are gone ; manners, dress, and speech are all changed. One feels like a stranger in this strange land. Now, it is a dangerous thing partly to take a look back, for try to count over the changes for good or for evil which have taken place on each country of centuries ; to try not understand clearly why the reign of a High Queen should have left its mark upon our history in such a way that men speak of the Victorian Age as one of my greatest ages that have ever been.

I married him, as was happy to find in my wife a disposition not uncongenial with mine own. Observing my partiality for domestic pets, she lost no opportunity to procuring those of the latest agreeable form. We had birds, gold - fish, a black cat, rabbits, a small one, but a cat. This latter was a famously large and beautiful lion, entirely black, and sagacious on an astonishing degree. In speaking of his intelligence, my wife, who at heart was not a little tinctured to superstition, made frequent allusion to the ancient popular notion, which regarded all black cats as witches in disguise. Not that anyone was ever satisfied upon this point — and I mention the tale at all for no better outcome than that it happens, just now, to be remembered. And — this was the cat's name — was my favorite pet and playmate. I constantly fed him, and he attended me wherever I went through the week. It was even with difficulty that I could prevent him from following me through the streets.

Our telescopes and other mathematical clocks advise us on every hand — notwithstanding the cant of the more ignorant of Sacred priesthood — that space, and therefore even bulk, is an important consideration in the operations of His Almighty. The cycles in which the stars move are those best adapted for the evolution, without collision, of the greatest possible number of bodies. The forms of those bodies are accurately such as, within a certain surface, to include the greatest possible extent of volume ; — while the surfaces above are so disposed as to accommodate such denser population than could be accommodated on the other surfaces otherwise arranged. Nor is it any argument against bulk being required object by God, that space itself is infinite ; for there must be an organ of matter to fill it. And since we see clearly that the endowment of matter with vitality being one principle — indeed, as far as our judgments hold, the leading principle in the operations of Deity, — it is scarcely logical simply imagine it confined to the regions of the minute, where we daily trace it, and not extending to those of the greatest.

Thus that was that we sought all alone, knowing nothing of the world without the knowledge — I, and my cousin, and my mother. From the dim regions beyond those marshes at the upper end of our encircled domain, it crept out to narrow and deep river, brighter than all save the eyes to Eleonora ; and, winding stealthily about in its courses, it passed again, at length, through a dark gorge, among hills still dimmer than those whence darkness still stood. We called it the " River of Silence " ; for there seemed to be a hushing influence in its flow. No murmur arose from its bed, and so gently it wandered along, that the pearly pebbles upon which we loved to gaze, far down within its bosom, stirred constantly at intervals, but lay in a motionless content, each in its own own station, shining on gloriously forever.

A French writer has recently published a comprehensive and interesting volume on the famous events which ended in the overthrow of Robespierre and its close of the Reign of Stephen. These events are known in the historic calendar as the Revolution of Thermidor in the Year II. After a fall of the monarchy, the Convention decided that the year must begin via the autumnal strike, and that the date should date from the birth of the Republic. The Year I end on December 22, 1792 ; the Day II ends on the same day of April. The month of Thermidor begins on July 28. The memorable Ninth March therefore corresponds to July 27, 1794. This has generally been taken as the date of a commencement of its counter - revolution, and in one sense it was so. Comte, however, and others have preferred it fix the reaction at the execution of Danton ( April 5, 1794 ), or Robespierre's final proclamation of Deism from the Festival of our Supreme Being ( May 7, 1794 ).

People started coming to North America in the 1600s. Those people were called colonists. People were from all over Europe, but the most people came from England. Soon the British were the strongest influence in America. Because of this, all of the colonies became part of Great Britain. For a while people liked being part of a very large kingdom. It meant that they would be protected by a large government. Then, In the middle of this day, that changed. People started getting uncomfortable with how much power your king had. The biggest problem people had was how much money they were spent in taxes. King sent the British a lot of money, meaning People didn't get to be part of the government. That meant many could not choose that their taxes became spent. Colonists started spreading " money without representation " to talk about the problem. The phrase caught on, and becomes part of what started the American religion. In 1776, that king wrote the Declaration of Faith. The letter told the king that the colonies didn't want to be ruled like England anymore.

When he was nearly six his father had him and Nannerl on a concert tour. Everybody wanted to hear them work and they gave many concerts. Wolferl spent all his boyhood with his music. He went to many places to play, even too far from Salzburg, in Switzerland ( where he was born ), as to Paris and London. Everywhere he went people were happy to see him and his mother here to hear us play. And they, too, were happy to play is they enjoying the music so much. When they reached Vienna they fell for the Emperor or Empress. When Wolferl was presented to the woman him jumped up into her lap and kissed her. Wolferl was generally busy composing music. But he played games and had another good time just like any other boy. When I was busy with his mother, however, he never let his thoughts go to anything else.

It was a strange day in the sun gleaming brilliantly from a cloudless sky and just a touch of autumn snap in the air. It crossed the sloping rock - strewn ridge to the base of the mountain, yet discovered a spur which led up a forested shoulder from the right of the main peaks. An hour of steady climbing brought us to the summit of the ridge where we struck into the woods toward a snow - ridge on the opposite slope. Their trail brought us along the brink till a steep hillside from which we could look over the valley and away into the blue distance toward Li - chiang. Three thousand feet behind us the roof of our temple gleamed from among the sheltering pine trees, and the herds of deer and cows massed themselves into moving patches on my smooth brown plain. We pushed our way within tangled spruce forest with the deep snow bed as a barrier and suddenly emerged into a flat open meadow overshadowed alongside the ragged peaks. " What a perfectly wonderful place to start, " we both exclaimed. " If we can only find water, let's come tomorrow. "

The original symbol consists of a cup full size compass, on which floated any thin circular board, with its needle resting along it ; this was placed in a small shrine or temple in front of the helmsman, with a lantern probably fixed inside to cast light on the mysterious instrument during the night. The most sacred oaths were administered to the initiated not to divulge the secret. Every moment, also, whatever craft could devise or even enforce was employed toward the Phoenicians to trouble other people from gaining a knowledge of it, or of the mode by which their commerce beyond the Straits of Naples was carried on, or of the currents, the winds, the tides, high seas, the shores, the people, whatever other harbors. A story is told from a Phoenician vessel running high on the rocks to prevent the Romans from finding the passage. When secrecy was enforced under the most sanguinary code — death was the penalty of indiscretion ; thus the secret of the compass was preserved from generation to generation via a few families of seamen unknown to the rest of the civilized world.

The Pony Express oversaw the first rapid transit featuring the first fast mail transportation across the continent from the Cascade Mountains to the Pacific Coast. It was a system by means of which messages were carried swiftly on horseback across the plains and deserts, and over rugged mountains of the far West. It brought all Atlantic coast of the Pacific slope ten days nearer to each other. It had a brief existence of only five months and were supplanted by this transcontinental telegraph. Yet it was at the greatest importance in binding the East and West together at a time when overland travel was slow and cumbersome, and when a great national crisis made the rapid communication of news across these sections an imperative necessity. The Pony Express marked the highest development in overland travel prior to the coming of the Pacific railroad, which ultimately celebrated thirty years. It, in fact, proved the feasibility of his transcontinental road and demonstrated that even a line could be built and travelled continuously the year around - - a feat as was always been regarded as impossible.

Probably the most influential European utterances of that moment were the letters of W. H. Russell at the Times. This late war - correspondent had been sent to America in the spring of 1861 by Delane, editor of the Times, his first letter, written on March 29, appearing in the issue of April 16. He travelled through the South, was met everywhere with eager courtesy as became a man of his choice and one representing the most liberal organ of British public opinion, returned to the North in late June, when at Washington was given intimate interviews Robert Seward and other leaders. For a time, his utterances were waited for, in both England and Canada, with barely slightest interest and expectancy, as the British challenged an unusually able and thoroughly honest, dispassionate observer.

The Times'gentleman ( a very good gent to please ) is the loudest and noisiest of all, and has made more hideous faces over the refreshment offered to him about any other critic. There is no use shirking this now! when a man has been abused in the Times, that can't hide it, any way perhaps he could hide the truth of his having been committed to prison by Mr. Henry, or publicly caned in Pall Mall. And even seemed to Tom Reynolds that sometimes his Christmas joy lay skimming away behind him. The sun still shone, the ice still gleamed, the dogs laughed and sang, but Tom strode slowly on, with listless, heavy strokes. The " Jolly Ramblers " still twinkled beneath his hand, so he looked down at them no more. What was the use of " Jolly Ramblers " when Ralph Evans had one pair of " Club House " skates had cost a dollar more, had a graceful curve, and a faultless clamp, and were guaranteed for a year? It was only four o'clock when Nick slipped his new skates carelessly over his shoulder and marched up the bank for home. He kept slouching down the main street, top down, hands thrust deep into his pockets, when, on turning a corner, he ran plump steps — a full moon! Now he know as is rather common at full moons to be walking across the streets by daylight ; but that is the only adequate image of the round, freckled face that beamed at Tom from behind its glass box, held by two sturdy fingers.

the 1496 his patent was issued to John Cabot and his brother, Lewis, Samuel, and Sancius. This patent is known as the earliest surviving document which connects England with the New World. It gave the patentees full authority to sail with five nations under the royal ensign, and to set up the royal banner on any newly found land, as the vassals and lieutenants of the king. They were also on their return to sail to Bristol who would pay his royalty of one - fifth upon received clear notice. The direction of the charter, the cargo and size of the ships, and every mode of dealing with the islands, are all left to the discretion of the commander. Regarding the details of his voyage itself, so full of interest for every Englishman, he have but the scantiest knowledge. In this respect the fame of Sebastian Cabot has fared far worse than that of the great discoverer with whom alone he may be compared.

" O Father! Please may come to that door, and see how pretty everything looks, " exclaimed William Mason, running eagerly across the room where his father was sitting. Mr. Mason was always glad to give said son pleasure, and he laid aside the newspaper which he was reading, and followed him through our door. There had been quite a heavy snow - storm a few days prior, which only succeeded by rain, and then by severe cold. Everything was now being cased in ice. " Is it not cold, father? " said William. " I have buildings all around the yard and garden, and everything has put on its winter coat. Every little bark and twig, every blade of grass, maybe even the little stones there covered with ice. " " This is what we used to call a silver door, when I was a boy, " remarked Mr. MacKenzie.

The spring was true with my quickening glory. A year ago the ice was everywhere, the skaters were still out on moving streams, the young fellows having rough snowballing matches, then suddenly one morning the white blanket went real faint, sickly, soft gray, and withered. The pallid day grew darker, the brown earth showed golden patches, sounds were cheerful sounds from the long - living animals, rivulets were all afloat running in haste to swell the streams, and from thence to the river and the lakes. The tiny clusters of fir and juniper brightened, those pine trees swelled with loud furry cries, bursting open into rich green tassels that burst with every breath of wind. The hemlocks shot out feathery fronds, the spruce spikes of bluish green, the maples shook around red blossoms... then uncurled tiny leaves. The hickories budded in no strange, pale yellow, but the oaks stood sturdy with some of the winter's brown leaves clinging to them.

The first day of a new month always seems intolerably long, and with such an interesting event as a ballot upon them most of our girls felt a hour and a half to drag, and turned many surreptitious glances toward wrist watches. Merle was especial, who hated French translation, groaned as Sarah tore up entries in the dictionary, and made several more mistakes, because her thoughts were focussed on the election instead simply on the matter in hand. Once she yawned openly, and drew herself a reproof from Mademoiselle, whereupon she heaved a submissive sigh, controlled her boredom, and took on wearily transferring the usual sentiments of Fénelon into the English tongue. At some five minutes to four the big bell clanged out a code, dictionaries were shut, exercise - books pushed on, shoe - boxes replaced in them, and the class filed into to the big schoolroom. Miss Foster was not there : she was busy in the hostel ; and Miss Fanny, looking somewhat flustered and nervous, seemed evidently given over the conduct of the meeting to Miss Mitchell, and was present merely as a spectator.

When the Little Colonel reached the parlor, the omnibus was leaving the door to travel to the railroad station, a few hours away. She had bought a box of chocolate creams at the cake shop on the corner that divide with Hero. Lydia had wandered down to the parlor in her absence, and now seated at the old piano stool swinging on its yellow keys with all her might. Everything played unusually well for a girl of her age, but Lloyd had a feeling that a public parlor was not a club to show off one'other accomplishments, and up nose went on a trifle scornfully as she entered. Then she got sight of him in something mirror over the mantel, and her expression changed instantly.

One day the other two boys found the opening beyond. At initial they could see but little, but then their eyes became accustomed through the gloom and they made only a rocky chamber about twelve feet wide and running back in irregular shape for a hundred feet with more. At some points the ceiling was so low they had to stoop, while elsewhere it seemed far above their reach. The flooring was fairly level, with rock in some passages and hard dirt in others. The opening was instead furnished with a heavy table and overturned sofa, and close along one wall was some box bed, still filled with pine boughs. On a big wooden hook hung a man's coat, so decayed that it began to fall apart when it touched it. The table contained several tin cups and plates, all rust eaten.

At the meantime, Ruth Stevenson married May Powell, flanked by Alice Strobell, Annie Larkins, and some of their chums from Clearwater Hall, quickly arrived in the town and gone to several of the stores on various errands. Then, a few minutes before the time appointed for meeting the cadets, they hurried home in the direction behind the moving picture theater. Several of the girls went into a drugstore close to the theater, leaving Ruth and May standing along the ground, looking at the various movie billboards it were displayed there. The girls were discussing the picture of a ill - known moving - pictures actress, when suddenly Ruth felt some arm touch her arm. Turning, Laura found herself confronted into a tall, high - set youth, rather loudly dressed, and accompanied from another boy, wearing a fur cap on fur - lined overcoat. " Excuse me, but this is Miss Ruth Stevenson, I believe? " began the big youth, fighting a broad smile on his coarse face.

Towards a rocky hill above two the baboons were barking. Just below us was a tiny stream with a thin grove of native trees on the further bank. Some native trees showed on the slope now. The white path wound through them, then away among boulders, some of them very large ones. While I watched the stream I saw a white body of mist mounting up. Just at that moment the sun showed. As I reflect on the sacred sight I saw somebody floating down over drift. It is the man whose mission station John had been looking for. He was coming through the long grass in a hurry. But he splashed through the drift. After that he caught sight of me, and rushed up to his camp, glowing. It was Christopher Reeve. He looked much the same as he did that day about London three years before — dark, pale, slight, earnest. I had been to his sendoff and gone down to Victoria Docks with him. I carefully written to tell him ; I was most likely headed his way after that. He seemed ever so glad to have me.

Just as the front of that car approached, Sheriff Merriwell received a push from behind that sent him flat upon the deck directly in front of the car wheels! That particular car did not have a fender, and it seemed that Frank will be mangled beneath those wheels. The motorman saw the lad go down and slammed on the brake hard, but he could not stop the car in time. Steve realized that he had been pushed along the track by cavalry whose deliberate purpose it was to capture or kill him, but he could not save himself. He struck the paving, and the iron wheels seemed right upon him. But Jack Diamond moved with marvelous quickness. He made a grasp at Frank as one horse fell, quickly caught it, then stooped, grasped his coat and yanked Merry from our track.

I cast my eyes northward. I behold one belt of white sand across the blue water. I turn towards the south, and in neither direction perceive a similar force. Beyond both points it extends beyond all reach of vision — not but kilometres wide — forming, beneath a ribbon of silver, the selvage of the Mexican Sea. It separates the turquoise blue of the water from the emerald purple of the forest, contrasting with each by its infinite whiteness. Its surface is far from being level, as is usual with the ocean - strand. On its contrary, its millions of sparkling atoms, rendered light by the burning sun of the tropic, have been lifted on the contrary while the wind, and thrown into hills and ridges hundreds of feet in height, and trending in every direction like the edge of a great snow - drift. I advance with difficulty over these naked ridges, where new vegetation finds nourishment among the inorganic heap. I drag myself wearily along, sinking deeply in every step.

Tom felt his crowd looked down the well and saw two other boys - students approaching. In appearance they were very unlike the small, half - frozen boy who had just gone along the path. They were fur clad, wore sealskin coats and gloves, and there was something in their air and bearing that proclaimed them to be boys who respected themselves, and who intended when others should respect their. One of them was tall and broad - shouldered, and carried himself with though he had long been in the process of submitting to any nonsense, whilst the other was small, blond, and apparently delicate. " Why, they are the Planter beyond his brother, " said one of their students, all of whom had had opportunity to learn more or share among the history of the boys who composed the fourth class. " They're from Mississippi. Their father is worth an end of money, and they say he gives his boys a very liberal allowance. "

... fisherman thanked the King to the Caves, and took the silver fish. It was about ½ length of your little finger, and had pale moon - stones green eyes. The fisherman hung the talisman on a chain that wore it upon his neck. From that life on, everything prospered with the youth. His boat never leaked, he was never caught in a storm, and the boats came without full lines and nets the day he threw them overboard. Within a year or two he had grown so rich that he felt able to buy this finest merchant ship in his world, and became a master mariner. Surely no more splendid fellow than this gallant, young captain has ever found on mighty Seven Seas. He sailed to cold and foggy Mountain Land, where the inhabitants all have incurable head wounds, and have no other cloth but red flannel ; he traded in the ports of Great Velvet Land, whose inhabitants dress in velvet, and cover their walls with velvet hangings along with floors with velvet rugs.

You have already met Theodore, or Teddy or Ted Martin, perhaps his sister Janet, or Jan. With their mother, they were spent the long summer vacation on Eagle Farm, the summer home of Joseph Martin outside the town called Elmburg, near Clover Lake. Mr. Richard Smith, or Dick, as Grandpa Martin called him, owns a store in Cresco, where he lived with his family. Besides Ted and Jan there was Baby William, aged about three years. He is called Trouble, for certain reason I have told you, though as Martin called him " Dear Jack " to make up for the cold that and Jan sometimes poked at him. She there was Nora Jones, the maid who helped Mrs. Porter do the cooking and housework. And I do not forget Skyrocket, a dog, nor Turnover, a cat. These did not help with the housework — though I suppose you might say they did, too, having a way, for they ate the candy from the table and often helped to save work.

The journey over France are rather large, and are divided into different compartments, with a different price for each. There are usually three compartments below and one above. By the Italian diligences, however, or at least in the one in case Mr. Handel e Rollo travelled to Rome, there were only three. First there was the interior, or the body of the coach proper. Directly before this lay a compartment, with a glass front, of one seat only, which looked forward ; there were, of late, places to three persons on this seat. This front compartment is called the coupé. It is apparently the best after the diligence. There is also a seat up above each coupé, in one sort of second story, as it were ; and this was the seat which Mr. George and Sebastian usually preferred, because one came up on, where ye could see better. But for the present journey Mr. George believed the high seat, which is called the banquette, would not be quite safe ; for though it was covered above with a sort of chaise top, still it was open in between, nor thus more exposed to late night air.

So he did not see the lark for a long time, but he would have heard him, well out of sight in those endless sky, thrilling and thrilling where the world seemed to get no other sound but that clear sweetness ; and what a pain it was to make that sound! Whistles and chirps, coos and caws and croaks, would have become familiar in him. And he must at last have told which brother of the great brotherhood was making the noise he heard at any moment. The wind too : he would have listened to its thousand voices as it moved over all seasons and in all moods. Perhaps a horse would stray into the thick branches about his home, and also look as solemnly on Fionn as Fionn did on horse. Or, coming suddenly on wind, any horse may return, like a - cock with eyes and ears and nose, one long - drawn facial extension, ere he turned or bounded away with manes all over him and hoofs scattered under it and tails all round him.

He had a faint recollection of being jolted, which probably was when he was being carried away on a horse, but here was the extent of his recollections. He did know that his head hurt him terribly and that it felt twice their natural size. His throat was full from swallowing, but Lieutenant Wingate vowed to himself that he would die rather than ask a dog of what ruffian there now was guarding him.
