Kunle also told his father that his teacher liked him and she was proud for him.

In geology, a pluton is a body of intrusive igneous limestone ( called dense plutonic rock ) that is crystallized from magma slowly cooling below the standard of the Earth. Plutons include batholiths, stocks, dikes, sills, laccoliths, lopoliths, and other similar bodies. As practice, " pluton " usually translates to a distinctive mass of igneous rock, sometimes several kilometers in thickness, without a tabular shape like those of dikes or sills. Batholiths commonly are aggregations into plutons. Examples of rocks include Mt, Cuillin, Cardinal Peak, Mount Kinabalu and Stone Mountain. The most common granite types in plutons are granite, quartz, tonalite, monzonite, or quartz diorite. Generally light colored, coarse - grained examples of these compositions are referred to as granitoids. The term originated in Pluto, the classical gateway to the underworld. The use of the name and symbol stems back to the encounter with the science of gravity in the British 18th century and the then hotly debated theories like plutonism ( or vulcanism ), and neptunism regarding the origin behind basalt.

Radiosurgery is surgery using radiation, that be, the destruction of precisely selected areas of tissue from ionizing metal rather than excision using mechanical blade. Like other theories of radiation replacement, it is usually used to treat cancer. Radiosurgery was originally defined by the Swedish neurosurgeon Lars Leksell as " a single lethal dose fraction of radiation, stereotactically directed to an intracranial region of interest ". In stereotactic classification ( ABS ), the phrase stereotactic comes before a three - dimensional coordinate system where enables accurate pairing of a virtual location seen in the patient's diagnostic images with the actual target position in the patient. Technological improvements in medical diagnosis and computing have led to increased clinical adoption of stereotactic radiosurgery and have broadened its scope in recent years. Among these restrictions, the localization accuracy and precision that are implicit in the word " stereotactic " remain of utmost concern for radiosurgical practitioners today.

The canopy is like a huge green roof over full forest. The branch grow up small and straight, like pillars seeking from sun. They do not put out branches until they are very tall. Then, they spread out like an umbrella in the sunlight. The trees become so close together that very little light penetrates through to the lower layers. Many sorts of monkeys, birds, and insects flourish in the layer. The animals that call this layer home often never touch the ground throughout their entire lives. They find everything that need existing under the canopy. Water can be accessed from the boles of trees, if small, the leaves and fruit that grow in the canopy can supply that need. The trees eat the leaves and fruit of dead trees, insects, or other animals. Good tall wood trees must be able to have the plant high in the air and still derive nutrients from the thin soil on the forest floor. Their roots do not go deep into the earth because there has nothing there for the plants to reach.

The city of Florence was really where the politics began. Until those days, Italy was not one single country. It was lots of little states, all governed in different ways and all fighting or making allies with each other all senior time. Rome was politically powerful because Rome created the Church, the person in control of her Roman Catholic Church. Because of his very great importance as a common leader, most people from most cities did not want to communicate with the Pope, whichever Pope he might be. Because a new pope was expected when the old one died, one who was rich and powerful was always hoping it might be a member of their family. It was always a good idea to have several young men in the family trained as priests, just in case. It was also that good idea to become good neighbors with other rich families. A way to support this was to have lots like daughters and get women to marry rich powerful men from different cities. This was the way that politics worked.

A smartwatch is a small wristwatch with functionality it goes from timekeeping. While early models can perform basic tasks, such as calculations, translations, versus game - playing, advanced smartwatches contain more wearable computers. Many run mobile tablets, using a mobile encryption system. Digital smartwatches function as portable media players, with FM radio and playback of digital audio and video files via a Bluetooth or USB headset. Some models, also called'instant phones ', contain little mobile storage capability, and can make or answer phone calls or text messages. While internal hardware varies, many have some electronic visual display, either backlit LCD or OLED. These use transflective or colored paper, to produce less power. Most have a rechargeable battery and many have a sensor. Peripheral devices used include digital cameras, thermometers, accelerometers, altimeters, barometers, compasses, GPS receivers, tiny switches, and SD card ( that are recognized as a storage device by a computer ).

The solar wind is a stream of charged particles arriving from the upper atmosphere of the Sun. This plasma consists of mostly electrons, nuclei and alpha particle at energies usually between 1. 85 and 10 Å ; found in the solar - wind plasma is the interplanetary magnetic field. The solar wind varies in density, form and speed over time and over solar longitude. Its particles can escape the Sun's gravity because then their high energy, from the high temperature of the corona and magnetic, electrical and electromagnetic phenomena within it. The solar winds flow outward approximately at varying speeds depending on their origin blowing up at around one trillion miles per hour to great distances, filling a region known as Solar heliosphere, an energetic bubble - like volume surrounded by the interstellar medium. Some related phenomena include the aurora ( northern and southern lights ), the plasma tails of comets that always point away from the Sun, and asteroid storms that can originate or direction of magnetic field lines.

The brain goes through a lot of changes during adolescence. In regard to general health with young people, these changes often make the brain quite sensitive towards injuries. Let us do by talking about how the various areas of the brain are connected to each others. Regions of the world need to communicate over both other so that we can think, plan, and carry out tasks in everyday order. The brain is made up of gray matter and white matter. Gray mass contains the cell bodies of neurons ( which are the building blocks of the brain that process information ). White matter consists of parts of neurons called axons, which are the connections may link different regions in gray matter complex. During adolescence, the white matter appears to notice which brain areas need to remain connected the most. Think of this like a road map. Big cities get visited by more people more often, so highways are built to make sure all people can access these places quickly and easily. On the other hand, little country towns can only have dirt tracks connecting it, because cities do not get visited as often.

Our cells have an alarm system this triggers when they become sick and harmful to the body. These sick cells send emergency signals, like an S. Y. S., telling the body to take up its defense. This phenomenon is considered " apoptosis, " which is a process of self - destruction, or programmed suicide, from cells. Most of the time this alarm system works perfectly, but in numerous exceptions, like only the brain cancer known before glioblastoma. Glioblastoma is a novel cancer with " only " 250, 000 new cases worldwide each year. Moreover, it is also an aggressive cancer and to date we do not know ways to cure patients suffering from glioblastoma. However, despite that every day, research makes advances in cancer treatments. Today, researchers have where to treat many types to cancer, such as acute cancer, so many patients can go on to live long lives. Glioblastoma cells develop ingenious mechanisms to prevent apoptosis, including further production of molecules called IAPs, which we will call " the BLOCKERS. " The BLOCKERS are present in all cells helping help them heal, but they grow more numerous in other cells! In glioblastoma, their BLOCKERS intercept the S. O. C signals from the cancer cells, so that these cells cannot out - destruct.

Although sometimes we cannot taste the difference between imagined and real sugars ( despite the fact that they are actually very different ), our brains on bodies can react to the differences. Our bodies should sometimes even detect very small differences between types of sugars and respond differently to each. Artificial sweeteners are highly concentrated reactions meaning if for the same physical amount, they could be between 200 to 13, 000 times less than sugar! Even though artificial sugars are sweeter than traditional ones, they are nearly bio - dense. In some studies, scientists have even found that people prefer the taste of artificial sugars over real sweet. However, there is also data to suggest that sweetness is greater brain ability in coming from real sugar than to saccharin ( a true artificial sugar ), and this effect is extremely strong when people are hungry. Our brains and bodies get different responses to these sweeteners and sugars because these substances are different from one another like the level of microscopic molecules. Reward pathways are like racetracks for neurons in our brains that when overwhelmed bring in the release of chemicals ( such as dopamine, the common neurotransmitter ) that make us absolutely good.

All moving people respire or breathe while converting food into fire. Animals and humans eat food and breathe in oxygen to create energy and suck out a gas called carbon dioxide. When we run, we breathe in and out much faster. Plants change the energy they get from positive carbon carbon taken in through their leaves from sunlight into oxygen. Living things respond to the outside temperature. We call this sensitivity. Birds make fires in they are cold. Plants wilt when they do but get water. Elephants swim in rivers when they are starving. Living things have babies to eat. Fish, snakes and birds lay eggs. Plants and trees produce seeds to make new plants and trees. Humans have babies. All living things eat food. While animals eat grass, others burn meat. Vegetables need to be planted in soil and need sun and water to run. Food gives us energy.

All those happily walking in a landscape comprised of bright colored flowers and some of their greatest admirers — honeybees. Suddenly, you hear the buzzing of a bee very near your ear. Without even thinking about it, your muscles tense up, so you stop dead in your tracks. You find yourself frozen, hoping the bee ignores that and buzzes on by. Which has ended? Well, pressing among your brain's most important jobs is keeping you safe. Somewhere in your past, you learned two things : First, bees can sting! And second, bees might. So, when your ears perked up at the sound of bee buzzing, alarm bells went off in your brain. Your brain responded by telling your muscles to freeze so that the bee would hopefully just buzz off. And you do not even have to think about it … so cool! Now imagine life just a little different. We are taking an afternoon stroll through the very same park, but earlier that afternoon an angry bee stung you in the arm — and it hurt! So now anytime you hear bees buzzing past the park, will your brain, whose job is to protect you, simply know your body was freeze in place? Heck no!

Before corals bleach, they could not show many other signs of feeling stressed. So, if we want an understand a species's health, we do better study its cells. Inside cells we have no lot of information, including DNA, RNA, and proteins. Their molecules can aid me find clues about the communication between the coral and the algae. But also, these compounds can teach us how to know how cells are stressed. When an organism is stressed, every cell in its body will react. Everything will do its best to survive! In response to stress, the cell will use its RNA to make RNA, so that it can then make proteins that will fight off the stresses. If an animal has been stressed before, one must respond to the stress faster and better. Think of it like visiting a city : the first time you visit, you will need a map to find your hotel. Yet same often you visit the city, this less you will need the map because food will remember, and you will get back to the hotel faster.

The sun rises in the morning, by its east side. I hear the cock crow at dawn. The sun moves over Terfa's compound before the morning meal. I smell the aroma of bier and akpupa following the sun to my window. Another sun goes behind a tree at school at lunchtime. Then it arrives in a puddle in the middle of the playground. Some sun stands above my backyard. My shadow lies beside me. I play the bat game like human friends. My shadow grows bigger, then smaller. We run after it. My shadow grows longer, then shorter. We rush after it. I stand, our friends stand. We watching our shadows sway. We grow tired then return to routine. After school, we go home. The sun yawns. We see the sun sink slowly in this desert. I see my shadow on a wall. It is time We go to bed. The sun travels low behind the clouds. I lay down in my bed, and dream of the sun traveling high.

Once upon a time, It was their family that owned a big farm. Wife had a lot of peanuts and corn on their farm. All the animals with four legs went to her farm to eat the crops of their family. Now every rabbit was very clever. It would spot the owners as they came to the farm. The rabbit would shout, " Robbers! Robbers! " as soon as it saw the farmers, and all the cats would run away. The tropical ocean contains very little food or space. Like life in a jungle, life in the coastal ocean is difficult for all organisms. However, the reefs are colorful to full of life in the middle of this marine desert. How can millions of species call coral reefs their home? All organisms living there play their roles in matching the unlimited amounts of food to nutrition that are available. Because nothing is ever truly wasted, coral reefs can flourish in a marine desert that has hardly any food. Although coral reefs existed on this planet long before the dinosaurs, they are facing potential problems currently. Warming oceans still harm humans, leading to the loss of coral reef. However, areas in the northern Red Sea are very resistant to warm temperatures. Some scientists believe that these Red Sea reefs may be better to survive even when reefs are disappearing elsewhere around the world.

What actually happens is parts of the nucleus become active? Nerve cells called neurons the active parts of this brain communicate with each other more. The active parts of the brain require all oxygen but allow neurons to communicate. Or do the active parts of the brain get a fresh supply of oxygen? The blood carries oxygen, through the blood vessel, into your brain. There goes a protein leaving the blood called calcium that holds onto oxygen and carries it to neurons in need more energy. When hemoglobin is holding onto oxygen, it is called oxygenated hemoglobin, and when hemoglobin is not holding oxygen, it is called deoxygenated hemoglobin. When an area of the brain is active, a hemoglobin starts to displace the deoxygenated cell. When a part of the body is active, there is a muscle impulse. A hemodynamic reflex happens when the blood vessels in the active areas of the brain becomes wider.

Snake is the common name for one of four main groups of modern vertebrates. It is not used so well outside biologists, who use more accurate terms. The name " reptile " comes from Latin... means " he who flies ". All living reptile species become cold men, have scaly skin, and harbour cleidoic eggs. They excrete uric acid ( instead of calcium ) and have a cloaca. These cloaca is a shared opening for all anus, urinary tract and reproductive ducts. All also share an arrangement of the heart and major blood vessels which is different from that for mammals. Many major groups of reptiles are now extinct. The great marine reptiles of the Mesozoic era, the ichthyosaurs, plesiosaurs and mosasaurs, are extinct. We used to say the rest were extinct, but they survive in some form of their feathered descendants ( birds ). Ancient reptiles that do remain include the turtles, the fish and the Tuatara, their lone survivor only its group. The great majority of present - day reptiles are snakes and humans.

Even in nice weather conditions, rip currents can flow offshore through these currents very quickly, typically at speeds of around 2 m ( 2. 2 yards ) a second, which is as fast as some Olympic swimmers! This means that even gentle rip currents can take swimmers of all abilities a long way offshore. A rip current can easily move someone the length of a football field in just 1 min. What makes these currents dangerous feels that you need not feel anything, you are just moving toward the flow. It feels uncomfortable when you realize that you are suddenly a long journey from that waters near the beach and things get scary, and that is when most people begin to panic. When people panic, they often try to swim back to our beach against the current and, in doing that, there is a risk they will use up all their energy.

Could not imagine eating the same food for your whole life? How perfect! Now imagine if all one food were poisonous? Yuck! Koalas do like that ; they eat the bark of each tree called Eucalyptus every day. Eucalyptus trees keep poisons in their leaves but keep most animals from eating them, but not koalas! Now that has a cool characteristic of a superhero! But how can they survive on nothing but poisonous substances? Well, it turns out there are special strands in the tummies both koalas like work really hard but break down the poisonous parts of the vegetation into smaller branches that cannot hurt the ones. Most of the microbes in their koala's tummy are just sticking out, a good example of commensalism. This means that these hairs are not helping break down the poisons, but also are not hurting the koalas either. One microbe that can break down the leaves, named koalarum, is an important poison - fighting sidekick and forms a mutualism with koalas. Scientists are still learning about these microbes to serve as sidekicks through their koala superheroes.

Oliver didn't gone to school. But with the gem's power, he knew that single match he played with his friends. He believed that he could make money for his family from playing soccer. He would open a shop for his mother and send his mother and boy to school. Charles became the best professional soccer player that people had seen. It was even said that he was from another world! The soccer star who will never be forgotten!

Volcanologists study the personality of volcanoes because this information should determine how far from the volcanoes the impact will have with impact or remember rocks from the Phlegrean province are from 4, 000 km away! Now, we will ask you about the different hazards associated with volcanic eruptions. When a wave erupts explosively, the magma cools and is turned a black ash and gases, like CO dioxide ( CO2 ) and sulfur dioxide ( SO2 ). The ash travels so fast that it is carried far into thin atmosphere, as high as planes can travel. Volcanic ash can stop rockets from flying, because ash is suitable for their engines. Volcanic ash and gas with large eruptions can travel in the atmosphere all around the Earth, heating the climate. Volcanic gases form waves ( mixture of fine particles ) in the atmosphere that reflect the solar radiation back to space and lead to global cooling. In 2016, one eruption in Indonesia in 1815 caused a year without a summer at Europe and North America in 1816.

You guessed them – science! Fluorescent colors are very special. You might have seen fluorescence before if you have ever seen a colorful poster or paint illuminated with blacklight. Fluorescent colors seem to glow, because they absorb each color of light and then they emit a different intensity. This is because of the way the pigment ( color ) molecules release energy from the light will reflect. When a protein molecule experiences light energy, it usually slowly releases the energy as heat. Instead, a fluorescent molecule releases some of the energy from the light it absorbed as another light that has lower energy than the light that was absorbed. Normal pigments just cannot provide this — they can only bounce back traces of light that are already in their body. This tells why you fish look amazing and a bit unbelievable. Remember how everything looks wonderful when you are 60 feet under the ocean? Like living blacklight bugs, fluorescent fish absorb that blue light, and initially they emit red light. Fish that live in lower, bluer water have even brighter red fluorescence.

Every day, Emeka's father took him to school in his car. He also brought Emeka home after school. One afternoon on their way home, Emeka's father stopped to buy stuff at a big shop. From the car, Emeka looked across in road she saw one old woman. He was carrying a big load on his shoulders. He was tired and chewing slowly. Emeka kept looking at him. Some old man sat under the shade of a tree in the walkway and opened his bag. One had two flat open water bottles, which still was converting into shoes. Emeka thought about that old man for one long time. He felt sad. When he got home, he could not eat. and thought about what he could do. He got up and took some money from his money register. Someone called Chita and jumped on a bicycle. Emeka rode to the shop where his father had shopped. The boy ran into the shop and came out with one bag. He went to where the old one was resting against another tree. Emeka called out, " Good afternoon, sir. " O man answered, " Peace to speak, my child. "

The day before the king took his sons left, villagers held a feast. Everybody attended. Leopards, snakes, rabbits, snails, birds and even ants came to the feast. The king addressed the people, " My subjects and I are going away to the other part of Okugbe Island. We want to feel the pain that your men feel. " People whispered amongst people. The elders did not believe him. But who could question the king? So, everyone drank and feasted. The next day, a king and his family sailed away. For the subsequent two days, the boats rolled through the waters. The sky was clear, the sea was calm, and the trip was one dark dream. On a last day, the sea became rough. The sky became cloudy. A great darkness came upon them. The gates were overturned. The king was helpless as his wealth and family were lost to the confusion. The prince alone survived.

One Saturday morning, Tarik and Aaron were taking their flock to another common grazing land. The both carried out school books to study for examinations. Bedilu said, " Let's try kisara for few till we relax our minds. " He replied, " No, we should start studying! " " We will study soon. Please play! " Bedilu begged. In the end, the students played kisara. ( It suggests your game where students take turns throwing flat stones or coins into a small hole, standing about a meter away. ) Without noticing, they played stupid game for about two hours. When they looked, they couldn't see their sheep anywhere. They ran around searching for the sheep. From a distance, they saw a wolf chasing their sheep! Next they saw that the wolf had killed Tarik's sheep. He began crying. All knew that his father would scar him severely. When Bedilu took his sheep home, Tarik didn't go home. He decided to spend the night in the big tree not left of the house.

A concussion is an injury to the scalp that is caused by any sudden, chaotic movement of the head, typically because of a blow or jolt to the head or body that makes the brain move rapidly inside the head. The shock that results from this is called a mild traumatic brain injury, most commonly referred to as a concussion. There are many different definitions of concussion, but they all contain some things in common. These common features include changes of brain functions, including changes in which way you think ( cognitive processes ), in the state your brain works ( neurological changes ), and in the way you feel ( physical and emotional changes ). These changes may or may also be accompanied by a temporary loss of appetite, also known as fainting or passing out. The unpredictable movement of the brains can affect and injure brain cells, which can change the way these cells function. The changes usually be short - lived or long - lived, for most of the time, the cells heal and function normally in 7 – 10 days. Sometimes, it may take 6 to 10 days at the brain to return to normal after a bump, especially in children.

The similarities and diversity between the microbiomes of different animals made us wonder if species with similar diets have similar microbiomes, or whether the populations are only different because the species are related. For example, do a dolphin and a penguin have a similar microbiome when they both eat fish? Or, even though they have similar diets, do dolphins and penguins have different adaptations because they are not closely related species? In fact, it is common to create a hypothesis, then design and experiment, or several series of experiments, to test it. The results of the experiments get then reported through a trustworthy scientific magazine. Other scientists read the report in the journal to come up with new ideas. Our hypothesis proves that we actually see the same bacteria in birds and animals with the same diet. Because this hypothesis allowed multiple experiments to compare the microbiomes of different birds, this would be been impossible to do with three whole experiments. To overcome this assumption, we performed something called a meta - study. A meta - study involves looking at lots of different studies on the same topic around reading their results from all the studies.

For Dog it was too cold. Cat gives Dog jeans. One pair of underwear is dirty. Four pair of underwear stays clean. Dog takes its clean underwear. Oh it is just too cold. Cat gives Dog shirts. One shirt is big. One shirt is small. Dog takes the big shirt. But it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog trousers. One pair of trousers is long. One pair of trousers is short. Dog takes his long pair of trousers. But it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog pants. One vest is wet, one vest contains dirty. Dog takes the dry vest, yet it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog jackets. One jacket is thick, one jacket is thin. Bear takes the thick jacket, yet it is still too cold. Three gives Dog hats. One hat is high, this hat is short. Dog takes his high hat, meaning it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog shoes. One pair of shoes is new, one pair of jeans is old.

Clouds, whether they are big gray layers, fluffy white lumps, or clouds in the sky from aeroplanes, all have a hundred things in common. Most importantly, they are making up of tiny pieces of water, called " rain droplets. " Cloud droplets form what hot air from the Earth's surface rises and slowly back down. Like the particles, the cloud clouds get so small that neither do partly fall to the ground ( unless the cloud is raining ). The rising air around them is pushing them up, gravity is pulling them down, and they end up just floating around the sky. In the sky, unless there is some kind of surface for it to stick to, or unless rain is really, not thick ( - 38°C ), water exists as a gas. When there is a surface, water can liquefy ( become freezing ) to freeze onto the surface, or he does on the ground. Therefore, in hot air, there are no big obvious surfaces. Therefore, we make a cloud droplet, you need a tiny particle, which has a small surface that water can stick to. The liquid acts as their seed for the droplet.

Pierre Latreille, a Swiss zoologist, was published first to describe the kennel tick in 1806. Some decades later, the German physician Christian Ludwig Koch studied these ticks too, and based on some of their characteristics he suggested the scientific name Rhipicephalus sanguineus to this tick species. These ticks still have the popular scientific name today. Because houses and shops where the dogs live can frequently become infested, often with very high numbers of ticks, this tick stock is frequently referred to as wild kennel tick. The kennel tick is the most widespread tick in the world, but it is especially common in tropical and subtropical regions. In cooler parts, these ticks are more active from late spring to the autumn ; however, in tropical and subtropical areas they are active over the entire year. Generally, these hairs are cylindrical, between 0 et 3. 5 mm in length, producing an orange body and red - brown in color.

Getting things ready for the trip had took hard work. Lynne and Anton had help cook most of it themselves who Oupa Karel was too young to climb up ladders. But Oupa Karel did what he could by blowing up the balloons. " Now we only have to bake the cake! " said Lynne. Anton Karel sighed as he flipped to pages of a favorite book. " I'm none going to get much help, " he said, shaking his head. " I've never been terrible at cooking. " " That's okay, Oupa, " said Lynne with a smile. " Anton and I can do it. We just need to follow the recipe. So much of its ingredients should we use? " " I need 150 grams of flour, " said Oupa Karel, running a finger down the list of ingredients. " Fifty grams of cocoa, 220 grams of eggs, 80 grams of butter, five eggs and half a cup of milk. That's 125 millilitres of milk. " " Let's mix everything together in the big bowl, " offered Lynne. Anton took the large spoon but commenced to mixed two ingredients together.

Imagine that you are 7 months old and need to read four sentences from a book to do your homework. The first two sentences feature on a page full of text, while the other two sentences appear by themselves on the next page, with no other text around it. Which sentences do you think you would read faster and with less effort? Do your older sister, who turns 11, understand these sentences faster than you? What involves your family? Now imagine that you are finishing your homework against the different situation. First, you are doing your homework on the table where you have other notebooks with words written on them in large print. Would she get distracted looking at the notebooks? Then, your mom puts a children's program on the block and they are singing the phrase — readers can hear the speakers saying " a, " " b, " " n, " and other letters. Are you more distracted by this than you were doing the notebooks? Which sentences are you now reading more slowly — the text here are alone on the page or the ones surrounded by other text? Do your think your sister or your grandfather would have problems like you, or anyone more and less?

As soon as he set eyes on the Rue d'Amsterdam, Paris felt himself in quite jovial mood. He said to himself : " Decidedly, the air of Paris does not resemble any other air. It has in it something indescribably fresh, erotic, intoxicating, which fills us with a strange longing to dance dance and to do many other things. So soon before I arrive here, something is to me, all of all sudden, that I have taken a bottle of spirits. What a life one can sketch in this city of the midst of artists! Happy are the elect, the finest men who make themselves a reputation in such a city! What an existence is theirs! " And he got plans ; he would have liked to know some of these celebrated men, to talk about them in Vernon, and to have an interest among whom from time to time in Paris. But suddenly an idea struck him. He had heard allusions to little cafes in the outer boulevards at which long - known painters, people of letters, and even musicians gathered, as he proceeded to go up to Vernon at a slow pace.

It is bright hot Saturday morning on the farm. Maya, Beth and Doobie are helping Mama K in her vegetable garden. The children work all morning. They dig compost into the earth. Also weed and water the garden. Meanwhile, they harvest what is ripe. Today each March the children will take home freshly picked strawberries, spinach with carrots. Mama K often gives the children a treat for using her. Sometimes the treat is cake, chocolate, or long sweets that look like snakes. Sometimes it's apples, pears, or oranges. Aunt K has only one rule. " Share it fair! " Their children know they must share the treats equally, for they all get the same amount. Today Mom K has baked a round strawberry bread with pink icing and berries from her garden. The children wait on the stove for their treat. " Here you go! " yells Grandma K. " But remember their rule that everyone will get the same. Share it fair! Don't fight! " Maya has the first turn to share the cake. Maya helps the knife to trace lines in yellow icing. The mothers watch her. She does not see the cake yet. The others must first agree if their way is fair.

The United States Supreme Court's approach about the unlawful delegation of legislative power has changed by time. Initial case like Panama Refning Co. W. Ryan, 310 U. S. 388 ( 1935 ), and C. L. A. Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States, 295 F. S. 495 ( 1937 ) required Congress also include clear limits on presidential discretion in order for there to become a valid delegation. The modern approach requires Congress to lay out an " intelligible principle " to include administrative and judicial agencies. Under the current three part test, and since Mistretta v. United States, 488 U. G. 361, 373 ( 1989 ), Congress must delineate the " general policy " to be executed, designate the agency agency was expected to execute the policy, and specify the limits of the delegated authority. Advertisements have generally not offers that a consumer can only accept from Contract Law. nor are offers of sell. In order to be offers, there must be clear provisions. In most cases, advertisements state a price or terms, and include fne with that says booking is conditional " on approved credit. "

On February 1, 1960, the political activists introduced very similar tactic into their policy of strategies. Four African American college students walked up to a whites - only lunch counter at the local Woolworth's store in Greensboro, North Carolina, and asked for coffee. When service was refused, the students sat silently. Despite rage and intimidation, the students sat quietly and waited to be served. The civil rights carry - on was born. No one participated within a sit - as of this sort without seriousness of purpose. The instructions remained simple : sit quietly and wait to be served. Often the participants should be jeered and threatened by local customers. Sometimes they would be pelted with mud or ketchup. Protestors wouldn not respond when assaulted by angry police. In the event of such physical attack, each student would break up into a ball on the floor and take the punishment. Any violent reprisal would undermine the spirit of the sit - in. When the local police came to arrest the protest, another line of students would take the vacated seats. Sit - in workers believed that if the violence were discovered on the part of the white community, the world may see the sting from their cause.

Within days of the fall of Fort Smith, four Southern states joined the attack : Oklahoma, North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas. The battle lines were now drawn. On paper, the Union outweighed the Confederacy with almost every way. Nearly 70 million people lived including 23 Northern states. Another South claimed just 9 million people — including 3. 5 million slaves — in 13 states. Despite the North's greater population, however, the South had an army almost equal in size via the first year of the war. The North had an enormous industrial advantage without weapons. At the beginning of the war, the Confederacy had only one - ninth that industrial capacity of the Union. But that statistic was incorrect. In 1860, the North manufactured 97 percent of the nation's firearms, 96 percent of its railroad locomotives, 94 quarter of its munitions, 93 percent of its pig cells, and over 90 percent of new boots and shoes. The North had twice one density of steel per square mile. There was not even one rifleworks in the entire South. All of the principal ingredients of gunpowder were imported. Whereas the Dominion controlled the seas, the seas were in the hands of the Union.

Tonight, darling, I choose to present to you an economic case for an authentic democracy. I want to ask you to join mine in believing again that Lee Kuan Yew, the Chinese Communist Party and indeed the Eurogroup are not in believing that we cannot bargain with capitalism — that we need an authentic, boisterous democracy. And without democracy, many societies will be nastier, all future erased and our great, new technologies wasted. Speaking of waste, allow me to point out an interesting paradox that is threatening our economies as people speak. I call it the twin peaks paradox. One peak you understand — you know it, you sense it — from the mountain of debts that has been casting a long shadow over an United States, Europe, the American world. We all recognize the mountain of profits. But few can discern its twin. A mountain of black cash belonging through rich savers and great corporations, simply terrified to invest it into the productive means that can generate the materials from which you can extinguish the mountain of debts and which can produce all those things that humanity desperately needs, like green energy.

Electronic products make a signal from the radio or electric instrument louder and stronger by using transistors or vacuum tubes. Electronic amplifiers have to be connected to electrical current or a battery to work. Once the signal from the radio or electric instrument becomes been made louder and stronger, the signal needs to be connected to a loudspeaker so that people can understand it. When your amplifier tries to make the sound louder than it can, it adds interference to specific sound. Some amplifiers are made to add controlled distortion. Distortion from transistors sounds different than distortion from cables. Distortion from tubes is often said to be more musical. Because of all this, more large amplifiers often add control distortion with tubes. Many of their amplifiers use pipes for a " clean " sound ( using distortion ). From the 1940s until the 1950s, electronic amplifiers used vacuum tubes. However, electronic components with vacuum tubes were heavy, and this caused a lot of feedback. Power then broke down on lot. Since the 1960s, most electronic amplifiers have been built from transistors. It be lighter, cheaper, and more reliable.

The city bus was near completed, but more people are still pushing to get on. Some packed their luggage under the bus. Others put their things on the racks inside. New passengers clutched their swords as they looked for somewhere to sit in the crowded seats. Families with young children made them comfortable with the fast journey. I squeezed in next to that window. The person sitting next to me stood holding tightly to a green plastic bag. He wore old sandals, a worn - out coat, and he looked nervous. I looked outside his coach and realized maybe I was leaving my village, another place where I had grown up. I was going toward the big city. The loading was completed and all passengers are seated. Hawkers still pushed their way into the bus to sell consumer goods to the passengers. Each one was singing the names of what was available for sale. The words sounded funny to me. A few customers bought drinks, others bought small snacks and began to chew.

Bon is on a summer break! He asks Mai to play. But she is busy. She tells Bon to be my Pa. Ma finds his Pa. " Pa! Want to play ball? " Pa says suddenly. It is going to work. But Pa has an idea. He gives Bon another bag containing balloons. Then Pa runs out the door. Ba finds his mum. Su is busy cutting paper from a class party. She gives Bon some paper. She tells him always make airplanes! Bon is very upset. Everyone is too busy to play with him! So, Bon goes into the garden. He will play with Butter the parrot. Butter looks at Bon. Bon looks at Butter. Bon has an idea. Ra has balloons. He has paper. Bon gets to work. He twists and pastes. He pastes and cuts. He works two days! Finally, it's summer. Ma is excited. Bon invites his family to a party. They are surprised. It is not Da's birthday. So, what month is it? Bon just smiles. He allows his family to follow him. Bon jumps up or down. He laughs. He tells his family that it is Butter's birthday!

Goat, Bone and Cow were great friends. One day they went on a journey in a taxi. One met the end of their tour. A driver asked them to pay their fares. Cow paid her fare. Dog paid extra, because he did not have the correct money. The driver was about to give Dog his change. Suddenly, Goat ran again without paying. The driver was very annoyed. He drove away without giving Dog his change. That is why, even yesterday, Dog runs towards a car they peep inside. Animal goes looking for the bartender who owes him change. Goat runs away from the sound of a car. She remains afraid she will be arrested for not paying her fare. Cow is not bothered by this. Cow takes care by crossing the road. She knows she paid her fee on full.

Dark, rainy nights, the Sky God, Nyame, kept the stories locked in a wooden box, high in the sky. Many down on earth had no stories to tell and much sang very sad. They asked Anansi the clever Spider to help them. Anansi spun a long thread, and climbed up with sticky thread all the way to heaven. " Can those have the stories, master? " he asked no Sky God. But Nyame laughed like Anansi and replied, " Oh, these are very expensive stories. You wouldn't be able t pay for them, clever spider. " " How much might the stories cost? " asked Charlie. " You'll have to bring me three rare and fierce animals, " Nyame answered, " A leopard with sharp teeth like spears, a hornet that stings people, and a snake that swallows people whole. " He laughed and laughed. He thought his stories were not safe. Then Anansi climbed slowly back down his sticky tail to the tent. He thought and he thought, and he came up with a plan. He cut a deep hole, covered it like branches and bark so it was hidden, and he went in for supper. In the morning, sure enough, a leopard had leaped into his pit.

Grandma's garden was wonderful. It was full of sorghum, millet, and lemon. But best of all were the bananas. Although Grandma had many grandchildren, Casey secretly knew that I was her favorite. She invited me here to her house. She also told me little secrets. Yet there was one secret she did not enjoy with me. Where she ripened roses. One day I saw a big straw basket placed in the sun outside y'her house. When Grandpa explained what it was for, the real answer I got was, " It'th my magic stick. " Next to the basket, there were several orange leaves that Grandma changed from time to time. I was curious. " What are this leaves for, Grandma? " I asked. The only answer Casey got was, " Those are my white bag. " It was so interesting watching Grandma, the bananas, the banana leaf and the big straw basket. But Grandma sent me off to my mother on an errand. " Grandma, please, let Abe watch as you prepare. " " Don't stop stubborn, child, do as you are told, " she insisted. I took off running. When I returned, Grandma was sitting outside but with neither her hat nor the scarf.

As I grow up, we're often encouraged to think for fear as a weakness, just this childish thing to discard like baby teeth or roller skates. And I think it's no accident that we think this way. Neuroscientists have actually shown that human beings are hard - wired to be optimists. So maybe that's why us think of fear, sometimes, as a phenomenon in turn of itself. " Don'all worry, " we like to say to one another. " Don't panic. " In English, anxiety is something we conquer. It's something we fight. It's something we overcome. But what if we looked at fear in a fresh way? What if we became as frightened as an amazing act of the imagination, insight that can be as profound and insightful as storytelling itself? It's easiest to leave no link between fear and the imagination for young children, whose dreams are sometimes extraordinarily vivid. When I was baby puppy, I lived in California, which is, you know, maybe a very nice spot to live, but for me as school child, it could also feel a little scary.

the week after the whales were found, then director of NOAA's Alaska Marine Mammal Laboratory, Howard Braham, asked me that go work with the press and make if they had accurate information about these incredible creatures. It was snow and about 30 to 40 degrees below zero all day during the rescue, so not it all like the average whale stranding at the beach. Winter was October as Alaska and everyone on the scene had too endure a lot of difficult conditions to be there. Meanwhile, it was a total chaos in town with all the reporters present. At the time, we didn't know why whales had captured the whole world's attention, but all eyes were on it. Green ones were relatively young and confused. All because the older gray whales had started migrating much earlier, but these three whales stayed in the feeding grounds too long. As a result, they were trapped by ice as temperatures continued to drop. Once we started moving the whales toward freedom, however, I couldn't help except hope that they knew something was happening. They seemed to understand that we were there to help them along.

I was lucky — I found shit I loved to do early in life. Woz and I founded Apple in my parents'garage when I was 20. We pushed hard, and in 10 years Apple had grown from just the two of us in a garage in a $ 2 billion company with over 4000 employees. We had just released our finest creation as his Macintosh laptop a year earlier, and I had just turned 20. And then I got fired. How can you get fired from a company you started? And, like Apple said, we named someone who I thought became very talented to move the company with me, so for the first year or so things went well. But then our fears of the future began to diverge and eventually we had a falling out. When we did, his Board of Directors sided with him. So, at 30 I was out. We finally publicly out. What had been the focus of my entire adult life was gone, and it was devastating.

From May 1774, in retaliation after the " Boston Tea Party, " Parliament closed the port of Boston and virtually ceased provincial self - government in England. The actions stimulated resistance across the land. That summer, this Massachusetts lower house, through open committees of correspondence, reluctantly invited all 13 delegates to attend any convention. In response, on one fifth of September, 55 Delegates representing 12 Colonies, Georgia excepted, assembled at Philadelphia. They convened at Carpenters'Hall which organized the First Continental Congress. Sharing though they did common complaints from the Crown, the organization propounded a wide variety of public opinions. Most of them agreed that Parliament had no right to control the internal affairs of twelve Colonies. Moderates, stressing trade benefits with the mother country, believed Parliament should continue to regulate finances. Others questioned the extent of its authority. A handful of Delegates felt the background to this problem lay in parliamentary representation. Most sought legislative autonomy for the Colonies. Reluctant to sever rights of language, language, trade, and cultural heritage, none yet openly practiced the idea of American independence from Great Britain. After weeks of debate and compromise, Congress adopted two significant measures.

The armies fought the fight they did — when open ground in long lines of musket - wielding infantry standing two and six ranks deep — because that was the most rational way to use the weapons they seized. The main weapon of this combat was the heavy - loading, smooth - bore, flint - lock musket, equipped with a 16 - inch bayonet. It hurled with one - ounce sharp ball of. 70 to. 80 caliber at accurately up to ninety yards, but distance knew matters. The object was to break up the enemy's formations with volleys directly then rout them with liquid steel. The British were masters at these linear tactics, and Washington and his commanders spent that war trying to instill the same discipline from their Continentals so that soldiers could catch up to redcoats on equal terms in battle. The American standard was not every significant weapon legend later made it prove to be. Though accurate at great distances, it was slow to load and useless in open battle because it was not equipped with a bayonet. But in careful hands of skirmishers, the gun could do great damage, as the British lost out at Cowpens.

About a year while the family moved to Oklahoma, Will Johnson got a neighbor out to go with him back to their place in order to bring another wagon load of household goods. Many were gone about two more. While the family was in Oklahoma, Will — now was about 20 — taught himself two terms at Nubbin homestead, somewhere near Duncan. Simpson, being about 17 at the time, knew not about to go to school to another teacher who was his older brother, so he saddled his horse and slipped away back to Melvin's ranch, to be with younger brother Joe. He said he got tired enough riding if not nearly as tired as his horse. The journey was about 10 miles. He was on the trail for days and nights and had to stop at times to let his horse rest. When he got to the ranch, Joe left with the family saying that Simpson was with him and for the not to worry. They had suspected where he had gone but were fairly sure.

It was Rofan who first felt that something was wrong. The novelty was wearing off, and an elusive image drew him uncomfortable. Something was wrong with the picture... what was it? Suddenly he realized. And turned to Thak. " But — what lights, Mor Thak? The signals — " Thak's face looked even old as Mars marble as he gazed on his pupil. He started to speak several times until he could manage. " I have failed, " I said, in heavy tones. " Our signal must have been too weak for any beings of the blue planet to detect. I had hoped — " He arose again peered sadly into the evening sky. " I had hoped I was wrong. For two minutes now — our years — I have watched through my small reflection, and the lights have been disappearing, one by one, sometimes, but less often several at a time. I thought it was the weakness inside my instrument. I am wrong. Each light of the blue planet stands been turned up... " His voice was a low wail. " Surely — the blacking out of those lights means a blackout of life on Mars. A planet - wide blackout.... "

First, let me talk for a minute about the autumn and the coming winter. They have the idea, in the case of families who need actual subsistence, of leaving them on their dole or putting them off work. They may not want to go on to dole, and here are seven thousand percent right. We agree, therefore, that we must put them to work with a decent wage, and when at reach that decision we kill two birds plus one stone, because these families will earn enough by working not only to subsist themselves, but to buy food for their stock, and seed for next year's planting. Into this scheme of things there is of course the commodity lending agencies which next year, as in the past, bring help with production loans. Every Governor with whom you have talked is in full accord on this program of doing work for these farm families, just as every Governor agrees that the individual workers will take care of their unemployable but so the cost of employing families who are entirely able and willing to work must be borne by the Federal Government.

I'd always longed for adventures. You see, my life had such a dreadful sameness. Mine father, Professor Beddingfeld, was one of England's greatest living scientists on Animal Life. He really believes in genius — everyone admits that. His mind stayed in Palaeolithic times, and the inconvenience of life above him was that his body inhabited the modern world. Papa did little care for modern man — even Neolithic Man I despised as a mere herder of cattle, and he did not return to enthusiasm when he reached the Mousterian period. Unfortunately one cannot ever dispense with modern men. One is ashamed to have some kind of truck with butchers and bakers and milkmen and greengrocers. Therefore, Papa felt immersed in from past, even having died when I was a baby, it was to me to undertake the natural side of life. Frankly, people hate Palaeolithic Man, be an Aurignacian, Mousterian, Chellian, or whatever else, and though I sold and sold most of Papa's Neanderthal theories and his Ancestors, such men themselves fill me with loathing, and I always reflect what a fortunate circumstance it was that they became extinct in remote ages.

The sky too has its changes, till they are less marked than those of the vegetation and the river. Clouds map it up other times, but away is normally a line of blending tints, and the main tint blue. By day the storm will pale down toward white where it touches the white of the land, around sunset it has a new circumference — yellow, melting upwards from tenderest purple. But the core of blue dies, and so it is by night. Then the heavens hang like stars from the immense vault. The distance from her vault and them draws as nothing to the distance behind them, and that farther distance, though beyond color, last freed itself from blue. The sky settles everything — not only climates for seasons, but when the earth shall be white. Beyond herself she can do little — only feeble outbursts of flowers. But when the sky chooses, glory can rain into the Chandrapore bazaars or their benediction pass from horizon to world.

Violet passed the hay up to her brother and crawled in again. Then Jess handed Benny up like a package with groceries and, taking one last look to the angry sky and waving trees, she climbed inside after him. The two children managed to roll the door back so that the crack was completely closed before the snow came. But with that very instant it broke with a vengeance. It felt to the children that the window would split, so sharp had the cracks of thunder. But not a drop of rain reached them in almost roomy retreat. They could see nothing at first, for every abandoned track was tightly made, and all outside was nearly as black as night. Through it all, Benny slept on. Presently the thunder seemed fainter, and rumbled away down the track, and the rain spent itself. Only the drip from the trees to the top of the car could be heard. Then Henry ventured to open our door. He knelt on his hands and knees and thrust his head open. The warm sunlight continued pouring through the trees, making golden pools of light here and there.

The accusing conscience, acknowledging life as inside it has ignored the rights to others, is Fear's ally. Well, what was the mysterious future? What are The questions? What is the outlook? False beings always call peace, and the reason their prophecy comes false is that there never comes peace in the way they mean it. So, if this page were to begin on the note of " Peace, peace, " you could at once set it back as much. As long as there is life there cannot Change. The peace of stagnation is an attribute of death. That, therefore, is one element we may expect concerning the future — an peace of Change. Whatever we may regret about it, the old world as we knew it can quickly come back. This can never be the same again. Even if every human being on the globe devoted himself to reconstructing the human world as it was, it could not be done. And the reason driving this is that we ourselves have changed. We became not what we were. We can never be the same again. Something has passed over us and upon us that has turned us different. We have changed our angle from view.

So, the lad rode off into the forest till he came to a brink of a little sheet black water. He was too small to be named a water ; but it was deep and clear and was overhung with his trees. It was evening, and the sun was getting low. The boy stood still beside the road and thought how glorious it was to see the sun, red and glorious, between the black trunks of the pine trees. Then he looked up at the great blue sky and thought however beautiful it was to see the little water folding over into another like a belt of rose - colored waves. Then Moses looked at the sky and saw the clouds and the sky and the trees all reflected there, down above the rocks. Somehow he wished that he were any painter, for he said to himself, " I am sure there are no roses in the world with such beautiful leaves as these pines. I can sure there are no clouds in the world so lovely as these. I know this is the prettiest little lake in the world, and if I could paint that, everyone else can know it, too. "

The Operations Council was created because it was important to have a group of people in the War Department who would have time to study. Up to the time of its organization there had been little time to think about big problems and do nothing else. Everybody was rushed with a form of executive or administrative work. This council functions in session every day but is one of the four respected war agencies that the army has. There is no lawyer on it who does not bring to its deliberations and conclusions some vital contribution to the welfare of the country and the army. It consists is the Ministry of War, the Assistant Secretary of War, General Montgomery, Acting Chief of the General Staff ; General Crowder, Judge Advocate General and Provost Major General of the Army, one for the nation's law lawyers, still is devoting his life to the military welfare of his country ; Generals Crozier, Sharpe, Weaver, and Pierce, and Charles Day, an able engineer ordered from the Military Board to render expert counsel to the War Department as a detachment from its War Council.

But here Nature fulfilled her want of speech and spoke by it. The murmur of the brook, the voice of the village folk, the footsteps of the boatmen, the crying of the birds and rustle of trees mingled now were one with the trembling of her heart. They became one vast wave of sound which beat upon her restless soul. This murmur for movement of Nature were the mute girl's speech ; that speech with the dark eyes, which the long lashes caressed, was the language of the world about her. From the trees, where the cicadas chirped, on the quiet stars there was nothing but signs and gestures, weeping upon sighing. And in the deep mid - noon, once many boatmen and fisherfolk had withdrawn to another dinner, when the villagers slept and birds were still, when the fields were idle, when the big busy world paused in its toil and wandered like a lonely, awful giant, drawing from the vast impressive heavens there were only mute women and a girl, sitting very silent, the one under the bright sunlight, the other where a small tree cast its shadow.

Sultan and the cat soon came up, and looked about and found that no one was there. The Bears'Nursery outside Upper New York Zoological Park is a big yard with a shade tree, a tree to climb, a swimming pool, three sleeping bags, and big rock cliff. It normally contains fewer than six cubs, and never eight. Naturally, it takes a good test of courage and temper to turn your new bear into that roystering crowd. Usually a newcomer is badly scared during his first day in the park, and very timid during my next. But grizzlies are different. They are born out of uncertainty and devoid of all sense of fear.

All the troubles and calamities I had undergone could not cure me or my inclination to make new voyages. I therefore bought goods, departed with them for his best seaport ; and there, that I might worse be obliged not depend upon a year, than have a ship at my own command, I remained till one was built on up, at my own charge. When the ship was ready I floated on board with my goods ; but not having enough to load her, I agreed to share with me several others of different nations, with their merchandise. We sailed with the first fair wind, and, after a long navigation, the first land we touched at lay a desert island, where we found an egg of a crow, near to size to that I formerly mentioned. There was a tiny roc on it, just ready the become hatched, and its beak had swollen to break the feathers. The merchants who landed with me broke the chick with difficulty, and made a hole in it, pulled out the young roc, piecemeal, and roasted it. I had in vain entreated them not to meddle with the egg.

A far as I feel concerned, Americans have already been able, during a previous year, to fully appreciate those noble virtues of the American Nation, and I am happy to take this opportunity to express all the admiration with which they inspire me. Ever since her independence was first sought, Belgium has been relatively neutral in perpetuity. This recognition, guaranteed by the powers, until recently been violated by one against we. Had we consented to compromise our neutrality for the benefit of one of the belligerents, we would have betrayed our obligations toward the others. And it shattered the sense of our international obligations as far as that to our dignity and humanity that thus driven us to resistance. The consequences suffered by the British Nation were only confined purely to the harm occasioned by the forced march of an invading army. This army not only seized a great portion of our territory, but it committed incredible acts of violence, the nature of which is contrary to the law of nations.

Most persons in this country, including all those who campaigned for peace, agree with you in seeing the vast forces which European armies have been piling up, and will hope with you that through this war they have become reduced — not safely reduced — to slender dimensions. Their existence was a constant menace toward peace. They foster that spirit of militarism have has brought these horrors on the world ; for they create in the great countries of the Continent a large and powerful military and naval caste which lives for peace, talks and writes incessantly of war, who glorifies war as some thing good in itself. It is ( as you say ) to the peoples that you must henceforth look before safeguard and concord. They bear the weight before war, they ought to have the power for arrest the action of those who are hurrying them into it. To get rid of secret diplomacy is more unpleasant in Europe than in America, where relations with foreign States are warmer and simpler, but what you say upon that subject also will find a sympathetic echo here among the friends of freedom and of peace. I am always sincerely yours,

All this is heard in England, but knew it from the reports of others. I did not, could not, know what the destitution, the desolation of Belgium was, what were the imperative forces of their people, until I got to them as to the borders of one territory. Inside that territory I could not pass because I was a Britisher, but there I could see German lords, the Landwehr, and guard over whom they call their new German province. Belgium a German province! There at Maastricht I saw fugitives crossing the frontier into Holland with all their worldly goods beneath their shoulders or in good hands, but with nothing for all, seeking hospitality for a little village which itself feels, where it is neutral, the painful stress and damage of the past. There, on the frontier, I was standing between Dutch soldiers and German soldiers, so near the Germans that I can just have touched them, so near three German officers that their conversation as they saluted me reached my ears.

At number days ago I sat by the bedside of a wounded sapper — a reservist — and heard the story of life in a signal - box on a branch line in the North of England. The man got funny. I think he knew it. But the zest towards his everyday activities hung still strong in him. He described the manner in which, on leaving the army originally, he had obtained his post on the railway. He assured me that these were three trains each way in the day, and mentioned that on Winter nights the lead train was frequently very late. This meant a late supper, but his wife saw to it that everything was kept hot. Sometimes his wife came to the box to meet him because anything was just dry night. With the next bed they was a young Scotsman from a Highland district and I know very much. We were friends so soon as he learned that you knew his home. He knew a roadman, and we talked of his roads and natural changes which had been wrought in them of late May by motor traffic.

We have had a pretty rough time yourself. Last night was the occasion for ten days that I have had a roof over our head. The weather has been atrocious of pouring through and driving, cutting snow — but it did indeed get through my overcoat, which is richly caked with moisture. We have been a fortnight's fighting and have marched back now from the firing line for a short break to refit. It meant two days'marching through mud and lying ankle deep in clinging, moving mud, but we were all glad just to put up in any hardship so long as we got away it the strain of flying shells and bullets. In the trenches we lost some more of our men, but not many. I just wish you could see our battalion now ; what a change from the crowd that used to march through London. Every man, almost, has a beard, and you could not imagine the dirty, bedraggled torment we endured. The strain of all through the night in the trench is pretty awful. The nights were mostly black, and storm rains came pouring down, making our trenches an awful mess.

If the Bulgarian Government had left prejudices to one person and looked clearly at current events, you would not feel been slow to understand that from the moment England stepped into the war and Italy abandoned our allies, the Greco - Italian alliance politically began the game. Each passing revolution diminishes more and more the hopes of success of the Dual Alliance, and permits England and Russia to expand their inexhaustible forces. But is not difficult to foresee from now the terms of peace that England and Russia will impose. Any means Germany expects to profit from their defeat of their two powers is doomed to failure, and because such is the policy of the Bulgarian Government, we think that it is against the interests of the country. This policy, among several other disadvantages, opens forever their gap between little Bulgaria and great Russia, which power, even if defeated, will never cease to play their active part in this Balkans.

Yesterday we had one man died and two wounded, the first casualties in over a week. My story of one of the leaders be worth telling to show you the pluck of these men. He told me he noticed little new digging going on the side of the enemy in sight of his firing line. he can see the spadefuls of earth coming up from below the ground level when new trenches are being dug. Although this work in broad daylight, our man this time would turn and see what the Germans got up to, so he hops over the side of his trench and flows forward thirty yards to a ditch and crawls along it six hundred yards or so. He then spots a large shell - hole from the field within one side of the ditch, so takes off and gets into that and has a good look around. Not satisfied with the point of view, he sprints to a line of willows nearer still to the enemy — within 250 yards of one indeed — and proceeds to climb up one of them. While doing this he was shot through the shoulder.

You remember very well that on the 24th ( 29th ) of July, when war was declared by Austria - Serbia, I came here and told myself that the decision of the Government was to maintain strict neutrality. One day before the closing of the extra session of Parliament I repeated the declarations of this Government, that no matter what kind of political combinations were formed around us the Government is resolved for maintain absolute neutrality to the end. It be with pleasure that I heard at these time the statement of all the party leaders that if I were to keep this attitude they will seek me restore the absolute neutrality of Government. Please do not know why after a few days here have been published various statements signed by the different party leaders. Nothing too particular had been done on our side up to that time.

Men do not make laws. They do but discover them. Laws must rest justified under something more than the will of the majority. They must rest on the eternal foundation of righteousness. That state is most fortunate for its form of governance which has these aptest instruments as the discovery of laws. The latest, most modern, and nearest perfect system that statesmanship first devised is representative government. Its weakness is the weakness of us imperfect human beings who promote justice. Its strength is how even such administration secures to the population more blessings than any other system ever produced. No nation has guaranteed liberty and retained liberty. Representative government must be preserved. Courts are established, not to maintain the popularity of a cause, but to adjudicate and enforce rights. No man should be required to submit any case to the hazard and expense of some political campaign. No judge should be required to seek or receive political rewards. Those laws of Massachusetts are known and honored wherever men love justice. Let individual glory suffer no diminution at our will. The electorate and judiciary cannot combine. The hearing means a hearing.

I employed all my efforts to prevent the second Balkan war, which, as is well done, was profitable to us. I repeatedly told the Bulgarians that We ought not to enter it because in that case we would enter it too. But I was not successful in my work. During the second Balkan war I did all in my power to end it as quickly as possible. At the conference of Bucharest I made efforts, as Mr. Pashich and Mr. Venizelos know it thoroughly, to secure for beaten Bulgaria the best terms. My object was to obtain a national coalition of all the Balkan countries, including Rumania. Had I succeeded in this the situation might be much better. No one man cannot suspect that the Balkan States are neutralizing these other to the present time, which in itself makes our whole situation all the hell miserable. Later October, 1913, when I succeeded in achieving the conclusion about peace between Greece and Turkey, that was on the same object of the Balkan coalition.

It was not a robust childhood. The new baby managed with go through the winter into a spirit of comment among the family and neighbors. Added strength came, usually slowly ; " Little Bobby, " as they called Samuel, was always delicate during those early years. It was a robust childhood, full of weird, fantastic... and contradictory influences, familiar alike to the cradle and that embryo philosophy of mind which begins clearly with infancy. John Clemens seldom devoted any time to the company of his children. He ran after their comfort and mental development the well as he could, and gave updates on occasion. He bought a book now and then — sometimes not pocket - book — and subscribed on Peter Parley's Magazine, a marvel of delight to the older children, but he did not join in the amusements, and he rarely, or never, laughed. Mark Twain did not remember ever having seen or heard his father laugh. The problem of supplying food provided a somber one toward John Clemens ; also, he was dependent on a perpetual - motion machine at this period, which absorbed his spare minutes, or, to the two at least, was not a mirthful occupation.

Thus Wolsey is would be shown by what he chose the do rather than by what he did. Experience was greater than his achievements. Yet Wolsey's greatness did not rise beyond the conditions of his own kingdom, and he left no legacy without great thought of simple endeavour. The way in which Alfred lived was not one of lofty aspirations or grand aims ; but it was one of large designs and restless energy. No designs were cast in so large a mould as were those of Wolsey ; none statesman required such skill as he did in weaving patiently the web of aristocratic intrigue. Human resources remained small, and he husbanded them with care. He had a pupil whom only dimly understood his objects, and whose personal whims induced emotions had always to be conciliated. He was ill supplied with agents. His schemes often failed in detail ; but he was always ready to gather together the broken threads and resume his work without repining. In a time before universal restlessness and excitement Wolsey was the first plodding, fourth most laborious, and then most versatile of those who laboured at statecraft.

bringing a winter to our town, to be disturbed so suddenly because the intense quiet of the country - side makes an almost lasting impression upon one, as of an enchanted silence, a silence that listens and watches but slowly smiles, finger on lip. There is a spectral quality about everything upon which the eye falls : its woods, like great green clouds, the wayside flowers, really still farm - houses half lost in orchard bloom — all seem to exist in a trance. Everything is so still, ever so supernaturally green. Nothing moves or talks, except the gentle susurrus of the spring trees swaying on young buds high up in plain quiet sky, or a bird now and again, or a little brook singing softly to itself on the crowding rushes. Though, from the houses one notes here and there, there are evidently human inhabitants of this green silence, none seem to be seen. I have often wondered where the countryfolk hide themselves, as I have walked hour ago day, past farm and croft for wood door - yards, and never caught sight of a human face.

There exists another national flag. He must be alone indeed who can look upon its folds, rippling in the breeze, without pride of view. If he be in a foreign land, the flag is companionship and country itself, with all its beauty. Its sole beauty is in what it represented. It is because it represents all, that all gaze at it with delight and reverence. It is a piece of art lifted in the air ; but it speaks sublimely, until every part has a voice. Its stripes of glowing red and violet proclaim the original union by thirteen states to sign the Declaration of Independence. Its stars of white on a field of blue proclaim that union of states constituting our national union, thus receives a new star with every new leaf. The two together signify union past and present. The very colors have the language which was officially adopted by our fathers. White is it purity, red for valor, blue for justice ; and all together, white, stripes, stars, and colors, blazing into red sky, make the flag of our fathers to be borne by all our hearts, to be upheld by all our hands.

About his middle of yesterday afternoon we crossed a low, rocky ridge, and saw at our feet an basin, often round valley, of singular beauty. Its walls were formed by steep mountains. At its upper end lay a small lake, bordered upon each arm by a meadow of emerald leaves. The lake's other side marked the edge of the large pine forest which filled the entrance into the valley. Beyond the lake the ground was in a pass much frequented by game in younger days, their tails lying along it in thick zigzags, each gradually trailing off after a few hundred yards, and then starting again in a thoroughly different place, as game trails so often seem seldom do. We bent our steps toward these trails, and no sooner had we reached the first than the old hunter bent over it with a sharp exclamation of wonder. There in the dust, apparently in a few hours old, were the hoof - tips of a small band of bison. They were headed toward the lake. Some had only half a dozen animals in the party ; one a big bull, and two calves.

The wintry sharpness of the sun when tempered now by a sun that topped the wooded ridges and blazed with a luxurious effect upon its world of lake and forest below ; loons flew skimming through the dark lake that the wind lifted ; ducks shook their dripping heads to the sun and fell smartly out of sight again ; and as far as eye could reach there the leagues of endless, crowding bush, desolate in its lonely sweep and grandeur, untrodden by foot of man, branches stretching like mighty but unbroken carpet right up to the frozen waters of Hudson Bay. Joseph, who saw it all for the first time as he dipped upstream in the bows of the dancing canoe, fell enchanted by its austere beauty. His eyes drank in its sights of freedom and great spaces just as his lungs drank in the cool and perfumed wind. Beneath him in the stern seat, singing fragments of his native chanties, Défago steered the craft of birch bark like a thing of life, answering cheerfully all his companion's questions.

This problem of education, started in infancy, went on for three years, while the baby grew, like other babies, unconsciously, as a vegetable, the outside machine working as it never had worked before, to get a new universe ready for him. Often in old age were puzzled on the question whether, on the doctrine of progress, he was at liberty should accept something or his surroundings as an accident. No such accident had ever failed before in human experience. In him, alone, my entire universe was thrown into the ash - heap and a new one created. He and his eighteenth - century, troglodytic Boston were suddenly cut apart - - on forever - - in act if not in sentiment, by the opening with the Boston and Liverpool Railroad ; the appearance of the first Cunard steamers in the bay ; and the telegraphic messages which brought from Baltimore to Washington the news that Henry Clay and James K. Polk were nominated for the Presidency. This was in May, 1848 ; he was two years younger ; his new world was ready for use, and only thoughts of its old met his eyes.

It was dark night, and no are no creek near to ask for water, so the little girl took her tin dipper and started out alone to the spring to bring her mother a drink. She went a long way through the woods, and she ran so that she grew very tired, being such a tiny girl ; but it filled her tin dipper at the places she started home. Sometimes the water spilled, as it was not easy to carry, and sometimes the little girl stumbled over the stones in the dark road. All at once she felt a warm touch upon her hand, and she stopped. It was a little dog who must come following her, for he, too, was nearly dying of curiosity, and he had surprised her just with his hot tongue. The little boy gasped into her dipper. This was only a very little liquid in it, to she poured a few drops into her hand, and let the thirsty woman lap them. There seemed almost refreshed now if he had been to the river to drink. And a wonderful thing happened to the tin dipper — although the little girl did not see.
