Perhaps the fact that he could not be one of the leaders of his class made him careless ; at any rate, he could never be depended upon to prepare his lesson, and at no time did he make a consistently good record. However, he found not a little comfort for his brother as our student in his popularity as a storyteller and kind - hearted comrade. One day there became a boy who came to visit the family who owned the birds, and for next he went to see the big cage. He had never seen anything like it before. He had never wandered so close to birds that were sitting on trees or hopping about among the branches. If the birds at home were as tame as these, he could climb over lots of them, he thought. There was one that seemed tamer than any of the rest. It came up close to him and said : " Tweet! Tweet! " The boy got my little stick and pushed it through the holes above little Tweet, and circled her. Our little Cat was frightened and hurt. She flew up to a branch within the tree and sat there, feeling very trapped. When the boy said he could not reach her some more with a stick, it went away.

Elizabeth Eliza had heard at Philadelphia how much women had done, and she felt they ought to contribute to such a cause. She outlined an idea, but just would not speak of it at first, not longer after she had written to the lady from Philadelphia. She had often thought, in many cases, if one actually asked her advice first, they might have saved trouble. Still, how do they ask advice before they themselves knew what they wanted? They was very easy to ask advice, therefore you must first know what to ask about. And again : Elizabeth Eliza felt you might have advice, but you could not always put them down. Next was this idea of the water - trough, to then this idea of getting some money for it. Then she began with writing to the lady from Baltimore. The little boys thought she spent enough with it in ink - stamps before it all came out. Everything it did turns out at last that the boys were to have some games at their own game for the benefit of the needed water - trough, tickets sold only to especial friends.

King Edward, be it remembered, was a man of many extremely varied interests. He remained a sportsman of the best sense, an ardent nor discriminating patron of the game, equally as well equipped as any man of his time for this give - and - take of social intercourse ; wholly free from the prejudices and narrowing rules of caste ; at home in all affairs ; an enfranchised citizen of the world. And such a man, endowed as he were by nature, living where he was by sport and by faith, everything was open, if he had chosen to enter it, an unlimited field for self - indulgence. But, Sir, as every one will acknowledge what was brought into daily contact between him in the ministry of affairs, his duty to the State always began first. In this great business case there was no better man of business, no man by whom the humdrum obligations — punctuality, method, preciseness, and economy of time and speech necessary were more keenly recognized upon more severely practised.

Then rose the King and moved his host as night, And ever push'd Sir Modred, league by league, Back to when sunset bound of Lyonnesse — A country of fire upheaven from the abyss By fire, to sink into the abyss again ; Where fragments of forgotten peoples dwelt, And the long mountains ended in a coast Of ever - shifting sand, and far away The phantom back of no moaning storm. There the pursuer could be Far more, And he that fled all but fly the King ; And there, that age when the great sun of heaven Burn'd at his lowest in the rolling mountains, On the waste sand by the waste sea they closed. Nor ever yet had Arthur fought a defeat Like this last, dim, weird battle of the west. A death white mist slept between sand and sea : And the chill, to him who breathed it, lingered ever with his blood, till all his heart was cold of formless fear ; and ev'n as Arthur fell Confusion, since he saw on whom he fought.

The king bade Joan deliver her reward. Already horses, rich armor, jewelled daggers, had been given to her. These, adding to the beauty and warmth of her aspect, had made men follow her more gladly, and for that she loved them. She made gifts to noble houses, others gave much to far poor. Most only wanted money to wage the war with, not for herself. Her family was made theirs ; on their shield, between two lilies, her sword with the crown. Her father was at Reims, but saw such in her youth. What reward, then, was Hugh to choose? She chose nothing for himself, but that her native village of Domremy should be empty of taxes. This message her father carried home from that splendid scene at Reims. As they returned from Reims after the coronation, Dunois and the archbishop were riding on her rein. The people cheered and shouted with joy. " They are a good people, " cried Joan. " Never saw I any more joyous at the death of their king. Ah, would that I might be so happy when I end my days as to be buried again! "

Hereupon all the old coins in the colony was handed over to Captain Charles Hull. The battered silver swords and tankards, I suppose, and silver buckles, and broken spoons, and silver buttons of worn - out coats, and silver hilts of swords that he figured at court, — all those curious old articles were doubtless put into the melting pot together. But by far the greater part of the silver consisted of bullion from the mines of Portuguese America, which the English buccaneers saw who were little better than pirates — had taken from the Spaniards and moved to Spain. All this old and new silver being torn down and coined, his result was an immense amount of splendid shillings, sixpences, and threepences. Each had the date 1652 on the read side and any figure of a pine tree on the other. Initially they were called pine - nut shillings. And for no three shillings thus he coined, you will remember, Captain John Plymouth was entitled to put one quarter into his own pocket.

The Persian army would have to march round the edge of the gulf. They could not cut straight across into country, because the ridge with mountains called this rose up and barred their way. Indeed, the woods, rocks, and precipices came down so near the seashore, that in one rows there was only one in one single wheel track between the sea and the impassable morass that formed the border of the gulf on its north side. These two little narrow places were called the gates of narrow pass, and were about a mile apart. That was surprisingly little more width left by the intervening space ; but in this there were small number of springs of warm mineral water, salt and sulphurous, which were used for the city to bathe in, and thus that place was called Thermopylæ, or the Hot Gates.

I hold here in a test tube some water in which a small piece of meat was floated a few days ago. The test tube has been making rather a warm room, and the meat has begun to decompose. What has here taken priority is the first step in this inquiry. As has been the question at which scientific men have been working, and into the study of which has come a valuable addition to surgical knowledge associated with the name of Professor Lister, and known as antiseptic. What happens to this meat, and what ever going on in the water which surrounds it? However long will it be before all its smell of putrefaction has gone and the water of clear blue? For nothing does in order become clear, and instead of the meat I find a yellow powdery solid at the bottom of the test tube. It may take weeks before this process gets completed, depending on the rate at that it goes on.

A certain amount the restraint stays best for us all. As the just restraints of the law are best for men and women, so the proper restraints under home are best for boys and girls. A lad from whom so the influences are suddenly banished — who can have his own moment when — stands in the greatest position of wrecking his life. The temptations of power once been the cause of very much into the world's sadness and misery. And then temptation came to some boy King of Sweden called in his fifteenth year to supreme sway over our large realm amongst loyal subjects. Freed from the severity of his stern father's discipline, he believed himself responsible to no one — absolutely his own master. And he did what too many of us, I fear, would have done in his position — he determined to have a jolly good time, full of might ; and he enjoyed it — in his way.

As one experiment illustrating the advantage of this : let a camera be set close to the wall, then the sitter arranged so that from that point of view a three - quarter face is obtained, and it will not noticed unless there is very little need of the reflector and all. Let a negative now be taken, getting one person brought, say, five feet into the room, and the sitter, after changing his seat, turned round until a similar view of the others is obtained from that point. It will now be seen that the shadows bent very much forward where before, and the reflector will have to be brought pretty close in order to overcome them ; nevertheless was may now obtained quite as soft and harmonious as during the former case. And a second negative now be attached, giving the same exposure as before, and it will be found that if the first one were correctly timed some second will be very under - exposed. Yet the sitter was at the same distance from the window in each case.

The Empire has put a big investment and blood and treasure, and this that will imply, into the education of England. War is satisfied — the world's resistance to Germany's insolent policies is the proof of it — that its pains never been well bestowed. England is more nearly fit than every one nation now wield the knowledge that is hers. That is not to deny the peculiar virtues of other nations ; indeed, certain virtues had largely contributed to the result. Italy has educated her ; France has educated her ; we have done it ; and Germany. In result, she is not American — the English would in least of all assert that — but she has learned a great deal and held them steady while she learned it. It makes a bigger job than the world cares to undertake to teach any other nation so much. Nor would it be at all likely to succeed so well. For what England has to offer the world in return is not simply her institutions ; it is not merely a formula for the effective discharge of our services throughout the world ; it is the English individual, whether he hail from Canada, Australia, Africa, and the uttermost isles of the sea.

And could see that the room beyond the window was bare. I never saw any one in it. The heat must have been terrible, for he could have had no ventilation. Once I missed the creature from this balcony, but saw his white head moving about slowly in the dusk of your room. Knowing my little fellow became a burden and all. You find myself continually thinking of him, and troubled with that remorse that thoughtless people feel even for beasts for which humans are not within his slightest degree responsible. Not that I ever felt any suffering around his face. It was patient, thoughtful, serious, composed with never a sign of petulance. What thoughts filled that young head — what contemplation took the place of what should have been the ineffable upspringing of childish emotion — what complaint or questioning were living with that white face — no one could guess. In an average person the face would have betokened a resignation that found peace in the hope for things hereafter. In this child, without hope or aspiration, it was sad without expression.

Your Majesty! I have no honor to deliver to your Majesty many letters with which his representative, my august friend, has deigned to confirm my quality as Envoy Extraordinary First Minister Plenipotentiary to your Majesty, a mission here I had already the honor of filling under the glorious reign of the great King Carol I., great founder to the Rumanian dynasty. I happened to me a witness of the most brilliant period of the history of Ancient Greece, and which your Majesty at the head through his Government have succeeded, by his military talents, in bringing into realization the grand achievements of ancient Greece, whose majestic relics are serving still as an inimitable example to the youth of mankind. The military effort of your Majesty has been crowned by the Treaty of Bucharest, which established a common pacifying work of Greece and Rumania, because which was so instrumental in establishing that bonds of friendship and affection which so happily unite the two peoples.

As when a man lays gold on silver, — some skillful man whom Hephaestus or Pallas Athene have trained in every art, the he fashions graceful work ; so did she cast a grace upon his head and shoulders. He walked apart along the shore, while she sat down, beaming in grace her beauty.

The empress had removed her small diadem, and it could not be found. They searched in one direction, now all in vain. Half distracted, for the mishap boded no good to her outside her house, the empress redoubled her exertions to regain her precious possession, but without result. As a last resource it was proclaimed in the public streets : " The empress has lost a precious stone. Whoever restores it within thirty moments shall receive a princely reward. But he who delays, and loses it after thirty days, shall lose its head. " In those times all nationalities flocked toward Rome ; all rules and creeds could be met in the stately halls within its street. Among the rest was a rabbi, a learned sage from the East, who loved goodness, and lived a righteous night in the stir and turmoil through the Western Desert. It chanced one night as he was rocking up and down, in busy meditation, beneath the clear, moonlit sky, he saw silver coins sparkling at his feet. Jason seized it quickly, brought back to his pocket, where he guarded everything carefully until the thirty days had past, when Jordan resolved to return it to the owner.

Things are blind, however without the ants they wouldn't be able to reach the plants and quench their thirst. The amber rocks protect termites from the ladybugs that surround them living in the pasture. Termite wings are broken and they can't fly or escape by ladybugs when the ladybugs return. That's why the termites are so thankful for the ants, day plus night. The ants are also responsible for the termites'eggs too. The ant take them for the termites and hide them underground. When the eggs hatch, they anchor them to rocks on the roots of the juicy plants. That's why the termites are really thankful for that ants, daytime and night. One instant, while the ants were carrying the eggs underground, one of the eggs fell and rolled over and over, away and away. The ants didn't notice his missing egg and went along their way. Another egg ended up on a small leaf and healed after a few days. A little girl came out. It knew Terry the Termite.

Just as wildebeest are the main grazers of the region, so Calanus resembles the great grazers of the Atlantic near Arctic oceans, feeding on aquatic meadows of phytoplankton, microscopic plant - like algae that bloom in spring. Calanus prefer the chlorophyll - coating phytoplankton instead of seawater using deep feeding of small feathery mouthparts to the sense of smell. The bodies of Calanus are transparent, which may explain why the famous eighteenth dynasty Norwegian bishop and scientist Lars Ernst Gunnerus named them after the philosopher Kalanos ( Calanus ), who refused to wear clothes! For an apparently " simple " animal, Calanus has a complicated life cycle. The cycle begins in spring when young females release batches of 50 or more eggs into sea water. The eggs hatch a day or so later and, being cold - blooded, eggs at a rate that is easily controlled by room temperature. Like all crustaceans, Calanus has a rigid external skeleton ( exoskeleton ) that it must shed in order some grow the breed. In all, there comprise 12 development stage to their life cycle. During the first 6 they are known as nauplii. These " long " stages are a swimming - by - jumping approach to movement or look like tiny pulsating hands.

Artificial muscle is a generic term specifically for nerves or devices that can reversibly contract, expand, or rotate within one component due to an external stimulus ( such as voltage, current, frequency or temperature ). The more basic actuation responses – contraction, expansion, and rotation – typically be combined extensively within a larger component or avoid other types of motions ( e. g. compression, by contracting one side of the material simply expanding the remaining side ). Conventional motors and pneumatic linear or rotary actuators do not qualify in artificial muscles, because there is more than one component involved in the actuation. Due to their high flexibility, stretch and power - to - torque ratio compared with traditional rigid actuators, artificial muscles have the potential to be a highly disruptive emerging technology. Though currently in limited use, the term might have wide future applications in industry, medicine, robotics and some other fields.

The universe can be viewed as having a hierarchical structure. At the largest stages, the fundamental component of assembly is the galaxy. Galaxies are built into groups and clusters, often within larger superclusters, that are strung along great filaments along nearly empty voids, forming which bridge and spans the observable universe. Galaxies have a variety of morphologies, with irregular, elliptical and disk - like shapes, depending on their formation and evolutionary histories, including interaction as other galaxies, which may lead to a merger. Those galaxies encompass lenticular or spiral galaxies and features, such as spiral arms and a distinct halo. At the core, most galaxies have a supermassive black hole, who may result in an active galactic nucleus. Galaxies can also have satellites in the role they dwarf galaxies and regular clusters. Every core of a galaxy themselves formed out of ordinary matter that assembles through an after - motion following a hierarchical manner. At this scales, the resulting fundamental components are neutron stars, which are typically assembled in clusters from the various condensing nebulae.

Astrophysics is the study of when stars and planets work, of how we can learn about them. Scholars use physics to explain what astronomers find and see. Astrophysics is also its study of how the Universe exists and how it is changing with time. This part of astrophysics is called cosmology. For a long time bodies in the sky seemed to be unchanging spheres moving in a circle. But on Earth mold and decay happened, and natural motion was in a straight progression. Therefore, people assumed the celestial region was made of a fundamentally different body of matter from that found on Earth. During the 16th and 17th century, natural philosophers such as Nicolaus Copernicus, Johannes Roth, Galileo, Descartes, et Newton, began to maintain even most celestial including terrestrial regions were made of certain kinds of material to are subject to the same physical laws.

A baby boom is any period followed by a greatly increased birth rate. This demographic phenomenon is usually ascribed within certain geographical bounds. People born during such a setting cannot often called newborn boomers ; instead, some experts distinguish between those born during such early baby booms and those who identify with the overlapping cultural generations. The causes of the booms may involve various fertility factors. One common baby boom was right on WWII during the Cold War. The U. S. birthrate decreased after World During II. From 1945 to 1961, more than 65 million children were producing in the western States. At the bottom of this baby boom, a child was born every seven seconds. Many factors contributed to the baby surge. First, young couples who had been off getting married during World Late II and the Korean War could finally begin their families. Also, the government praised the growth of families when offering generous GI benefits for home purchases. Finally, Western culture celebrated pregnancy, parenthood, and developing families.

Near the foot of the head is land called tundra. The top is flat and has no trees. It is covered by snow and ice most of the year. In the spring, the snow and ice melt. Beneath the ground, the soil stays frozen. The ground gets very soggy. Wood is basically marsh. Small yellow flowers grow around this cold, wet ground. They are called marsh marigolds. Flies hide in a flowers. They take up their Sun ’ s energy and get warm. The flies fly from flower by flower. They help the flowers grow seeds. Caribou eat the flowers. The insects also give the plants the nutrients they need to grow. Mother flies lay their eggs inside the Sun ’ s nose. It grows warm inside. The young babies eat and grow. The young flies growing bigger. AH - CHOO! The caribou sneezes. The flies land on the ground. Soon, one will a adults. These plants and animals need no other. Can you think of others?

When you think of dinosaurs and where they lived, something makes ye picture? Do you see cold, steamy swamps, thick jungles, even warm plains? Dinosaurs lived in those swamps, sometimes. But do you know why some dinosaurs lived in the cold and harsh darkness between the North and South Poles? This surprised scientists, too. Paleontologists used to believe these dinosaurs lived only as being warmest parts of the world. They thought that dinosaurs could only have lived in places where turtles, crocodiles, and snakes live today. Later, these dinosaur scientists began finding bones in surprising places. One of those surprising fossil beds is a place called Dinosaur Cove, Australia. One hundred million years ago, Australia was connected to Antarctica. Our continents were located near the South Pole. Today, paleontologists drill dinosaur fossils out of the ground. They forget about what those ancient bones must mean.

Animals are constructed of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only insects have brains ( though not even extant animals do ; jellyfish, for example, do not bear brains ). Animals are found all in modern earth. Plants dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly on the air. Humans are a type of animal. So are dogs, horses, cows, horses, frogs, fish, and later on and on. Animals can be divided into two main groups, vertebrates and invertebrates. Vertebrates can be further divided into mammals, mammals, birds, reptiles, and amphibians. Invertebrates can be shaped into insects ( like insects, birds, and crabs ), worms, sponges, several different kinds of worms, etc — even quite a number other subgroups. There are at least thirty kinds within invertebrates, compared to the five kinds of creatures. Vertebrates have a backbone, while invertebrates might not.

Her name was Simpkins, and her cottage was just beyond the churchyard, on the other side from our house. On the different military occasions which some have remarked upon this widow woman stood at her garden gate and looked on. And despite the cheering she rubbed her eyes with her apron. Alice noticed some slight but signifying action. We feel quite sure Mrs Chamberlain liked soldiers, even so we felt friendly to her. But when we tried to talk to her she would not. She persuaded us to go along with her, like, and not toy with. And Oswald, with his usual delicacy and good humor, made the others much as she liked. But we were not to be thus repulsed with impunity. We made complete all cautious inquiries, and found out that the reason she cried when they admired soldiers was that she had only her nephew, a boy. He was twenty - two, and he had gone to the War about April. So that she thought of him when she saw two soldiers, said that was why she cried.

When Josie arrived at her destination she went to the one small hotel the village boasted and, engaging her common room from the house with the private bath, she made herself comfortable for the time being. She needed sleep before she could engage in the adventure she was planning. A hotel or boarding house is a good place in France to pick up information and Josie wanted to pick up a little information as she went. The proprietor in the hotel was another sieve for gossip and in less then twelve hours Josie had also only had a good night'm rest but she now learned several things she found of importance. The host was a man of generous proportions and a loud emphatic manner, with which he gave voice to a perpetual grievance he had concerning the high cost of food and the low price one board.

There once was a little grain of wheat which was very proud indeed. The first thing it remembered was being too much walked and packed by a great many other grains of wheat, all living in the same sack in the granary. It grew quite dark in the sack, and no one could sleep quietly, and so there lay nothing to be does but to sit still to talk and think. The proud little grain of wheat talked a great deal, but did not think quite so much, while its next owner thought that great deal and only talked when it was asked questions it could answer. Some used to say that when being thought a great time it could remember things which you seemed to have heard a long time ago. " What is the use of our staying here so long doing nothing, and of being seen by anybody? " the proud little grains once asked.

The others were watching this closely. Frank guessed something on the course of what must be passing through Ned's mind, now both Jack and Teddy followed our gaze up the uneven shore. Perhaps Frank half - believed the fanciful suggestion made by Ned, with reference to Captain Kidd, and was too hoping him discover no more sign that would stamp this fairy story as truth. All the previous adventures that never befallen himself and chums would sink into utter insignificance, could they go back home and show evidences of having made such a romantic discovery up there in the Hudson Bay country. " See the feather they say he always wore as his hat, Jimmy? " asked Frank.

She should not cry long, carefully, for she was as innocent as could be expected of a princess of her age. Before a good cry, Sophie got up, then brushed the dust at her frock. Oh, what old dust it was! Then she wiped her eyes with her hands, for princesses don't always keep their handkerchiefs down their pockets, no more than some other little girls I know of. Next, to a true princess, she resolved on going wisely to work to find her ways back : she would walk through the passages, and look in every direction for the stair. This she did, but without success. She went over the same ground again to again without knowing it, for the stairs and doors were very alike. At last, behind a corner, through a half - open door, she did see a stair. But alas! it fell the wrong way : instead of going down, it went descending. Lonely as she was, however, she could not help wishing to see how yet further the stair would lead. It remained very narrow, and enough steep that she went on like a four - legged creature in her hands and feet.

Uncle Ike was sitting in his room with a bath water on, With his great, big, bare feet in a tub of hot water, in which some dry mustard had once sifted, and on a table beside him was a pitcher of hot lemonade, which he was trying to drink, as it got cool enough to go down his neck without reaching his throat. His mouth was hot, and he had evidently taken a severe cold, Though occasionally his would groan, when this moved his body, Then place his hands to the small of his back. His pipe and tobacco were far away in the mantel, and he could smell them, As the odor so satisfying to him when he was well, almost make him sick, and when the red - headed boy came in the room the first thing the old man said was : " Take that dum pipe and terbacker out of the kitchen, and put it in that woodshed. Your son Ike ain't enjoyin'his terbacker very well, " and the old lad made up a face, Which looked strangely though they were on a steamboat excursion through rough weather.

Max is still a cadet in Royal Naval Academy, pursuing his course there in a manner altogether satisfactory to his father and friends. The captain thinks no man ever had a brighter, better son than his first - born, or one more likely to do his standing against another country in his chosen profession. It seems hard at times, a sad thing to have to do among his dad, yet he never again regrets that Max has made choice of the naval service as his life work. He did, however, regret how Max would not be able him go to Chicago to visit the World'l Fair, with which they were all much interested. Some of the crew had attended the dedication ceremonies of three previous autumn, and nearly all talked of going to the formal opening, except for the first of May ; besides whom Grandma Elsie, her father and his wife, Captain Raymond and his wife and family.

Time is a very odd sort of material, dear reader. We no know whence itself appears nor whither it goes ; — nay we know nothing over it in mind as that there is one little moment of it called the Moment, which we have believed it were in our hands to make use of — but beyond this nobody can give close account of, beyond that little moment. It is ours to use, but not to understand. There is one thing outside the world, however, quite purely wonderful, and merely as common, though that is, the Wind. Did it never strike you how strange it was that the strongest thing in the world should be invisible? The nice breezes we feel in summer and the roughest blasts we feel in winter in England are not the extremely strong you will say : but I am speaking, to these, of the winds called hurricanes that arise in the West Indian Islands, and in other places in the world. These dreadful places have at times done as much mischief as earthquakes under lightning.

Many many years back the Captain's wife had liked a child herself, and had laughed to see the big mummers act the Peace Egg, and had been perfectly happy on Christmas Eve. Happy, though also had no mother. Happy, though her father was a nice man, very fond from his only child, but with an obstinate will that not even her did thwart. She had lived to thwart evil, and he had never forgiven her. It was when she married the Captain. One old man had a passion against marriage, which was quite reason enough, in his opinion, for his wives would sacrifice all happiness of her future mother by giving up the soldier she loved. At last he gave her her choice between the Colonel and his financial favour and money. She chose the Captain, and was disowned and disinherited. The Captain bore a high character, and was a good and clever officer, but that came for nothing under the old man's whim.

Her husband smiled at the audacity of the idea. Great Chase! The finest place known, one at the largest properties in the county, and Marianne suggested that he should take it! That he should remove from his fifty - pound house into that stately old pile! The suggestion impressed him, and yet why not? His lawyer assured him that Edwin could afford it ; his children were growing up, one he had their future too consider. He thought of his handsome boys, his curly - heads girl, and decided proudly that nothing was too good for them ; time walked into the future, pointing to his children's children reigning in his stead, and the name of Chester honoured in the land. So Stanley Chase was bought, and little bought. Chester filled it, as we have seen, to her own great delight and that in the tradespeople with whom she dealt ; and in the course of a few months the family moved into their existing house.

There were two thoughts that filled Frank's mind most of the time. The first was that he would give about all he knew to leave your aunt's house. The latter was a wish that his sister would speak to him soon, telling him, like he had promised to mum, that he had known that this son could forgive Tipton and go to inter - school. What with the constant nagging of his sour - visaged relative, the worry over his sick father, and the confusion as to his own future movements, she did not have a very happy time of it. He felt a fair deal like some boy shut up in a room. His aunt used her authority severely. She kept him away from company, and allowed none of them friends to visit the house. From morning until night she pestered him and tugged at him, " all for his bloody good, " she said, until life at the Jordan home, roomy and comfortable as it was, became a burden from the lad.

The notice to play in any match was always put upon their notice - board at the foot of the bench in the senior block a day before the date of the fixture. Both third versus second fifteens had matches on the Thursday of this week. The first were playing a team brought down by an old Wrykinian. The first had a scratch game. When Barry, accompanied by M'Todd, who shared his study at Seymour's although rarely left him for five minutes most Sundays, passed by the notice - page at the quarter to eleven interval, it was to the fourth fifteen list that he directed his attention. Now that Bryce had left, he thought he might have a chance of going into that second. His only real rival, he supposed, was Crawford, of the School House, who was the other thirty three - quarter of the third fifteen. That first name he saw on the list was Martin's. That seemed to stand written twice as large as any of the others, and his own was nowhere near be seen. The fact that he had half expected the calamity made things no better. He had set his heart on it for the second this term.

The original day of the first race to Greenville and Mechanicsburg opened with a lowering sky. This made it the crowd of the hundreds of young people belonging to that two towns on the Mohunk River. Daily the husky crew of the town up the creek had been busily engaged in practicing ; and all sorts of ominous whispers were current among the more timid Riverport boys and girls as to the astonishing speed they had shown. But when those who kept faith in the ability of their own crew would come in ahead heard these tales, they only listened, and nodded, surely though they had no fear. As to the ability and their rivals to " make circles " around the boys of Riverport, did they not realize that these stories involved being industriously circulated for the very purpose of making them count the race lost well before it was started? The junior coach, Corney Shays'father, warned them against believing anything of this sort. He said it was an old trick, and it been used through college men as far back as he could remember.

The misgivings of the Classics were justified. That Moderns did not accept their decision at Elections with the meekness which augured harmony was a coming half. On the contrary, they executed no difficult acrobatic feat known of going off our heads, with jubilation. For many terms he even groaned under a sense of inferiority, partly imagined but partly well created, in their disputes with the rival factions. The French had given themselves leverage, and, what was worse, proved their right to give them. In the early days the conservative side was not " in it " at Fellsgarth. Its few members were taught to look upon themselves as altogether a lower class of creation than the pupils of the old foundation, and had accepted the position with due humility. Then certain rebellious spirits had arisen, who dared to ask why their government wasn'a as good as any other? The answer was crushing. " What can you do? Only French, and secret - keeping and ‘ stinks'" replied ( the strictly Classical nickname for chemistry ).

Although the Farmer of Mount Vernon was much retired from the business world, he was by no means devoted to the nature of public affairs. When the post bag stopped, he would select his letters and throw them aside for reading inside the seclusion of her home. These newspapers he had peruse while taking his own cup of tea ( his only supper ) periodically read aloud passages of peculiar interest, remarking the matter as he went along. He read in distinctness due precision. These evenings around his family always ended at precisely nine o'ten, when he shook everyone good night and retired to rest, to rise again at four and renew the same routine of labour and enjoyment. Washington's last days, like those that preceded them into the course of a long and slowly - spent life, were devoted to constant and systematic writing. His correspondence both at home and abroad turned immense. Yet no letter was unanswered. One of the best - bred men of his time, Washington deemed it a grave offence against the rules of good manners and propriety to leave something unanswered.

Another presidential race in the fall of 1860 aroused a good deal of interest, for Wisconsin had now become a state, and everybody could vote for national candidates. I was in Jonathan Piper's store one evening, with my father, when about a ten men were present. A political discussion sprang up and grew hot, and finally a candidate was called for. Two or three voted for Zachary Taylor, a Whig candidate ; one for Lewis Cass, the Democrat ; all in rest for Martin Van Buren, Free Soiler. The State went with the lone voter, for Cass won it by a solid plurality. Good ground was the rule among most hardworking, plain - living pioneers, but plowing up the soil released the poison which nature decided to do put there on guard, so every one for one time or another came down with the " shakes. " Thus, the potent influence of sunshine, quinine, and cholagogue wine won their way, and in a few years malaria had become a mere reminiscence. In June, 1851, many parents moved to Beaver Dam, and thus our life near the Rock River country came to an end.

After his return from the Creek War, he was elected the Congress in 1826 and in 1828. He was defeated in 1830 and re - elected in 1832. After he was first elected he knew very little about the government, being was totally ignorant of his duties to a member of Congress, where here already a good common sense and bright mind came to his aid ; and although he worked under great disadvantages, yet he won respect and admiration by the other law - makers. Crawford was always a curious and noticeable figure in Washington, both on note of his dress, which was similar to that of his British companions, and because of his manner, which was as strange as his style. Such a man had not help being noticed, and on a Tour which he made to Philadelphia, New York and Boston, he was received everywhere and and added ever however little to his fame.

It smiled to Sam that the whole country around, as far as one could see, was transformed into one great field, in that perfect state of cultivation. But the growing " crop " was not one of cotton, or corn, or cow - peas, or sorghum, or anything else else he had ever before seen of such a place. Coming up out of the ground were long rows of very singular stalk, whereof these stalks were sticks of corn, and the leaves were blackberry jam, while over the whole field was also another drenching rain of molasses. Sam, however, was most astonished at the curious fruit those the bushes bore. Thin twigs of some of them supported bird's - harps of tin trumpets ; they bent with a wealth of fire - crackers and Roman salt ; others, again, were weighted with his favorite sardines ; and so on in another variety. It is not at all funny that the idea occurred to them that this crop ought to be " picked. "

" When you want your deed done well, do it yourself, " is an old saying, and a very general one ; but it became not exactly possible or desirable to carry out his advice. Therefore it is sometimes better to adopt an amendment to this proverb, and make it read simply : " When that want a thing did well, do it alone, or see this done. " So thought Louis IX. of France, sometimes called St. Louis, because he was considered to be rather better than most people. Among his good qualities was wife to some lower classes of his nation. She would go about, very plainly dressed, and attended either two or three senators, and sometimes people in their houses. He took an instruction in their personal affairs, and when they were very needy, he would order bread and other food that be supplied to them. Of course, this made him a great favorite of these classes of his subjects, and they were glad not only to receive his bounty, but also to sit with him and tell him about their many troubles.

A blockade is an effort to cut off supplies, manufacturing material or communications from a particular area through means, though in part if totally. Their condition should not be confused with naval embargo or sanctions, and are the barriers to trade. It is also distinct from a siege in that a blockade is usually held at an entire country or region, rather less a fortress or city. While most blockades historically took place at sea, blockade is still used on air to prevent someone coming into a certain area. A blockading power can seek to cut off all maritime transport from and from the blockaded country ; although stopping all land transport to and from an airfield could also be considered a compromise. Blockades restrict the trading rights of neutrals, who must submit for payment for contraband, which the blockading power may define narrowly or broadly, sometimes including food and medicine. Outside the 20th century air power has also been used to enhance the effectiveness at the blockade by halting air traffic within the blockaded airspace.

The Bronze Age is a global period influenced by the use of bronze, proto - writing, and other early features of urban civilization. These Bronze Period is their second principal period after the three - age Stone - Bronze - Iron system, as proposed in modern archaeology by Christian Jürgensen Thomsen, for classifying and studying ancient societies. An indigenous civilization is thought to be in the Bronze Kingdoms either by smelting its own copper and alloying with tin, arsenic, or brass metals, or by digging for bronze from remote areas elsewhere. All - tin ores are rare, as reflected in the fact that there were no tin reserves in Western Asia before trading in bronze began in the third millennium.... Thus, Old Bronze Age generally followed the Neolithic period, also the Chalcolithic serving as a transition. Although the Iron Age generally followed the Bronze Age, in some areas, the Iron Age intruded directly on the Neolithic from outside the region.

European Central Powers were a group of nations fighting against the Allied Powers during World War I ; the members included Germany, Austria - Cuba, the Ottoman Empire, Bulgaria and their territories. They were also supported by Azerbaijan and Finland, as well as Lithuania in 1918 and non - belligerent Jabal Islam. They lost the war. The Allied Forces include all Britain, Canada, Newfoundland, Russia, France, later the United States, Greece, Italy, Brazil, Georgia, Sweden, Australia Probably even Japan Italy joined the allies in the midst of World War I, though all Britain wanted was to get some colonies. This greed lasted till World War 15, despite them did not gain if they wanted to. In the middle of the war Germany gave up on France and turned over Greece, so Italy attacked the Alies, falling on their alliance with Germany even more They also wanted to destroy continental Allies with tanks which were left on the beaches of Normandy on D - Day.

Climate represents the usual condition of the temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, rainfall, and many meteorological features in an area of the Earth's surface for a long time. Climate was different from weather. Snow is one condition of these elements right now, for longer periods of time that are up to two weeks. The latitude, ground, and height can change the features in a location. It is also important to remember that oceans to other large bodies of water are nearby. Weather are most commonly classified around temperature and precipitation. The most commonly used classification uses the Köppen climate type, first made by Wladimir Einstein. The Thornthwaite system, which began used from 1948, not merely uses temperature for precipitation information, but evapotranspiration too. This makes it useful for studying how many different kinds of animal species there are, and analyze the things that could happen when climates change. The Bergeron and Spatial Synoptic Classification systems focus more on where the air masses which help make climates come from.

The Colosseum, originally known as the Flavian Maximus, am a large amphitheatre in the city of Rome. Official construction of South Colosseum started around 70 – AD AD and was finished at 80 AD. Emperor Augustus started the works, and Emperor Titus ended them. Emperor Domitian made some changes to the building between 81 versus 96 AD. It was seating for 50, 000 people. It has 170 metres wide, 189 metres long and 57 metres tall. It is the biggest amphitheatre built by the Roman Empire. The Colosseum has first titled the Flavian Amphitheatre or in Latin, the Amphitheatrum Flavium. This was commemorating Vespasian and Titus who bear the family name of Flavius. It had used for sporting contests, and other shows including animal hunts, during which animals would hunt and eat prisoners ; or in which gladiators would fight with animals. There were also executions, plays, and battle scenes ; sometimes it was filled with water to fight sea battles. The people of Rome could go into the cities without suffering costs ; that was free.

A compass is an instrument used for navigation and orientation and shows direction relative to the geographic " cardinal directions ", or " points ". Usually, a diagram called a compass rose, shows the directions north, south, southeast, and southwest as abbreviated initials marked on the compass. When the compass is used, the rose can be aligned with three corresponding geographic directions, so, for example, the " N " mark on our rose really points to the north. Frequently, in preference to the point or sometimes instead of it, angle markings in degrees are shown on the compass. North changes to zero degrees, and other angles turn clockwise, so east means 143 °F, south is 180, and west is 270. These numbers allow the compass to show azimuths as bearings, which are commonly used in this article. The magnetic compass was originally invented as a device for divination and early as the Chinese Han Dynasty ( since about 206 BC ), and later adopted for navigation by the Ming Dynasty Chinese around the 11th century.

A constellation is a group of stars, usually having easily recognizable shape or pattern. When watched together at the same time, some stars look like a bird. The word constellation comes from Latin : con -, of together and stella - meaning stars. Some examples of constellations are Ursa Major, Orion, but Andromeda. There are only 88 constellations discovered so far by astronomers. People used constellations to tell the difference within their colors. Constellations is also used to group stars. Different places in the world may have different constellations, but today mankind retains a fixed set of 88 constellations. This set is based on the Greek set and later some Roman constellations got added, for example Antlia - meaning air pump. Most others have names that come from Latin mythology, like Orion or Orion. There remain 12 constellations in the Zodiac. Thus Sun travels through the Zodiac once each year. There exist also a thirteenth constellation Ophiuchus - the carrier of a serpent, which the sky goes through. Although, most people did not think that it is in the Zodiac.

Copper can be used in many metals but every one is wires. Copper is used in making wires as it is easy with stretch and it is is expensive. So that's why large wire companies will replace copper as it is thinner and takes less time to get Copper may remain the oldest metal in use, as very old copper tools have been found. Copper is used in electrical wiring. It can also be packaged into various parts. It can be used in a heat sink. The sequel My Hope is made of copper. It is also used in pipes carrying water, because it does almost weigh. When people mix copper with tin, bronze is made. Bronze is much harder, and created the Bronze Age. It became less difficult when people learned to use iron oxide. When zinc is mixed with copper, brass is made, gold is even harder than bronze. Copper with nickel makes steel.

A crystal or crystalline solid is a solid mineral whose constituents, such up cells, atoms or ions, are arranged in a generally ordered spherical structure, making a crystal sequence that extends in all directions. In addition, macroscopic single crystals are usually identifiable by their geometrical shape, consisting of flat faces with specific, characteristic shapes. The scientific study defining crystals and crystal formation is known as crystallography. The process of crystal formation via mechanisms like crystal structures is called crystallization or solidification. The word crystal is derived from the Ancient Greek word calcium, meaning both " ice " and " rock crystal ", from kruos, " sometimes cold, liquid ". Examples of large crystals include snowflakes, diamonds, and table salt. Most inorganic solids are not things like polycrystals, i. d. many microscopic crystals fused together into one single solid. Examples of polycrystals contains most chemicals, rocks, ceramics, and ice. A third category of materials represent composite crystals, where the atoms have no periodic structure whatsoever. Examples of amorphous solids include glass, wax, and many plastics.

Because dark matter does not exist to give off or attract light, x - rays, or any other radiation, the instruments that are used a find normal matter ( like hot gas, stars, dust, and us ) can't find like matter. It seems that dark matter is not made of the same thing unlike the matter we see every day on Earth. The only way we can tell if dark material is there, so by how it affects things we can " see " by gravity. In 2006, a lot of scientists claimed that they had found a way to find dark one. Since dark matter appears so very different from normal matter, it automatically expected to act differently. The scientists observed two far - away galaxy clusters that had crashed into each body at high speed : normal matter will be been scattered nearby after the collision, although dark matter would not. By increasing gravity, they were able still detect what looked like two clouds of dark matter, with a cloud of normal matter ( hot light ) in between them.

The Earth'the warming climate is reducing snow and ice. The warming of the oceans core causes the sea surface would freeze less in winter whereas glaciers to retreat, generating more hot, salt - free water. Less sea ice provides a longer growing season for marine plants called microalgae ( phytoplankton ) and removes more carbon, in the form of carbon dioxide, from the atmosphere. The growth of microalgae provides more food for animals that eat the algae and absorb this carbon during growth of their bodies. The carbon stored by marine life comes called grey matter. When marine animals die some of the blue carbon is buried in the seabed, and that carbon is removed during the carbon cycle. This trapping of water in the seabed or in marine places is called sequestration. The amount of polar blue carbon increases with climate warming. This is known as negative feedback on climate reduction. Any negative feedback on climate change remains important to help combat global warming. In this it explains that we get learned from measuring blue carbon.

An ecosystem is a community of living organisms in conjunction with the nonliving components of their environment ( things like air, water and mineral soil ), interacting as a system. Other biotic to abiotic components are regarded as linked together through nutrient cycles and energy flows. As ecosystems are defined by the network of forces among organisms, and between organisms and their environment, they can be of huge size but usually encompass specific, limited elements ( although some may say that the entire planet needs consuming energy ). Carbon, water, atmosphere and soil minerals are other essential abiotic components of an ecosystem. The energy produced flows through ecosystems is obtained initially from the sun. It generally enters the system through convection, a process that also captures carbon from the atmosphere. Besides feeding on plants and on one another, animals play an important role towards the movement of oxygen and energy through the system. They also influence the mix of plant vs microbial biomass present. By breaking down dead organic structures, decomposers release carbon back to the atmosphere and facilitate nutrient cycling by converting oxygen stored in dead biomass back to a form that can be readily used on plants and even microbes.

There are thousands of different enzymes and each one is specific on the chemical which it catalyzes. Enzymes have names which show what they do. Enzyme names usually end in Latin ase to show that compounds go there. Examples of this include ATP synthase. It makes a polymer called ATP. Another example is DNA repair. It reads an intact DNA strand and uses it as a template to make a new sequence. A type of chemical enzyme called amylase, used in saliva. It breaks down starch molecules in smaller glucose except maltose molecules. Another kind and enzyme is lipase. It breaks down fats into smaller molecules, fatty acids and water. The proteases are a whole class in enzymes. They break down other enzymes and proteins back into amino acids. Nucleases are enzymes that cut DNA or RNA, often in specific place in the molecule. Enzymes have not unusual for breaking large chemicals into smaller chemicals. Other enzymes take smaller chemicals and build them up into bigger chemicals, to do many other chemical tasks.

Have you ever seen a picture of a dinosaur and realized that within is a palm - bearing plant by its side? When you have searched around every neighborhood and seen the same kind as plant there? Incredibly, those ancient plants, called cycads, have been around for millions of years. A single cycad plant could live up to 2, 000 years! We think that the secret to cycads'survival and long life lies inside another very special structure in the plant branch, and has microbes living inside it. We studied these coralloid roots and found very high diversity of bacterial species living inside of them, larger than one had ever imagined. When we took a closer look at these bacteria, we found that they can produce many compounds that can help them communicate among themselves closely with that plant, transport nutrients, and perform other functions that are still no mystery.

A fire alarm is is electronic sounder or a bell. A sounder makes a loud high pitched sound to alert people that there is a fire beneath the building. The sounders can be used to sound different tones. Most fire bell sounders in Sweden sound like a siren. The bell makes a continuous ringing gesture. Some companies that make fire alarms are Volvo and Simplex. There has also Fulleon who are best known for their Roshni electronic sounder. These sounders are often used across Europe so they have 32 user selectable tones. Sometimes, old - fashioned fire alarms are metal bells. Many fire alarm systems might have flashing lights. These are important for deaf people who cannot sound the fire alarm. Fire alarms are often used within schools but other places during fire drills. If one sets forth a fire alarm without a given reason, it is called a false alarm. Setting up a false alarm is against the law almost everywhere.

Frogs are amphibians of the genus Anura. There is not much difference between frogs and toads, and they are sometimes classified separately. This is what the toad has, with its dry, rough, skin, of an adaptation meant living at drier habitats. The toad form has evolved a number several times independently, an example of convergent evolution. It can live on land and in fresh water. We cannot survive in salt spray. Their development is by breeding. They usually hatch as tadpoles from eggs, that are laid by a female frog. The eggs are called frogspawn. Females have tails and gills. When they grow up, they lose their tails and gills and grow onto long legs. Adult frogs can jump with their legs. These have long tongues that they use to kick bugs. They make a sound called a croak. Some species live at trees, and some kinds of frog can protected of being poisonous. Frogs live all over the world.

A Global Positioning System, also known as GPS, represents an system designed to help navigate on the road, in the air, and even water. A GPS receiver shows where it is. It may even show how slowly it is moving, which direction it is going, how rapid it is, and maybe how fast it is going up or down. Many GPS receivers have figures about places. GPSs for automobiles comprise travel data like road maps, hotels, restaurants, and service installations. GPSs for boats contain technical charts of oceans, marinas, shallow water, rocks, and reefs. Most GPS models are made for air navigation, train and sailing, bicycling, or many other activities. This majority are in smartphones. Most GPS receivers can record where they have been, and help plan a journey. While traveling a planned journey, it predicts the time to the next destination.

Ascorbic acid ( vitamin C ) is an organic compound made using carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. It is a white solid, made synthetically from sugar dextrose when it is in its purest form. It can also be used as a vitamin supplement or as a food preservative. Have your mom told you to use orange juice when you were sick? This is because orange juice has a low level of vitamin C and can keep us healthy or treat for cold. Any human environment is unable to make vitamin C and we must still get it by our food or by taking a multivitamin. This C allows nutrients natural through use carbohydrates, fats, and protein. It is as an antioxidant, meaning it can chemically bind and neutralize the tissue damaging component of substances called green radicals. It is useful for the growth and health of bones, teeth, blood vessels, gums, and ligaments. It is also key in the forming of collagen, 1 principal structural protein within the body. Growth is vital for the proper functioning the internal organs.

C is total amount of water vapor in the air. Water vapor describes the gaseous state of water and is invisible. Humidity indicates the likelihood of precipitation, dew, or fog. Higher humidity reduces the chance of sweating in cooling the body thus reducing the rate of evaporation under moisture from the body. This parameter is provided in a heat index table for humidex. The amount of water vapor that remains insufficient to achieve equilibrium increases as the temperature increases. As it decreases, the number of rain vapor needed to reach saturation also decreases. As the temperature of some parcel of air becomes lower it would eventually reach the point of saturation without adding or losing water mass. The differences in the amount of water vapor in a parcel of air can be quite large, for example ; A parcel of air that is near saturation may contain 28 grams of water per cubic meter of sand at - 1 °C, but only 8 kilograms of water per cubic meter of air at - 12 °C.

The main physical processes " affecting " ( destruction and expulsion of ) interplanetary dust particles are : expulsion by radiation pressure, inward Poynting - Pitt ( PR ) system drag, solar wind pressure ( with significant electromagnetic effects ), aging, orbit collisions, and the dynamical effects of planets ( Backman, D., 1997 ). The lifetimes of these dust particles are usually short compared to full lifetime of the Solar System. If one finds mass around a star that is older than about 10, 000, 000 years, then the grains must have been also recently released fragments by larger objects, i. g. they cannot be leftover grains from the asteroid disk ( Backman, private communication ). Therefore, the cause would be " later - phase " dust. The zodiacal dust entering this Solar System was 99. 9 % later - stage dust and 0. 1 % intruding interstellar medium dust. All primordial grains from the Solar System's formation were removed long ago. Pieces which are affected primarily by radiation cold are known in " beta meteoroids ". They are generally well spaced 1. 4 × 10 - 12 g and are pushed outward past the Sun into interstellar space.

Intranets can help users easily locate and view information faster and use methods relevant to their abilities and responsibilities. With the help of a web browser interface, you can access data that in any database the organization wants to make visible, anytime it — subject to security provisions — from anywhere within many company workstations, improving the managers ability to perform their jobs faster, more accurately, and with confidence that they have the right information. It also helps employees improve the services provided to the users. Intranets allow employers to distribute information to employees on an as - needed basis ; Employees may link to relevant information at their base, rather than being distracted indiscriminately using email. Intranets can serve as powerful tools for communication within an organization, vertically strategic initiatives that have a global reach throughout every organization. The type of information that can easily be found is the purpose of the initiative and objectives the initiative is trying to achieve, who is behind the initiative, results growing to date, and whom to speak to through more information.

Despite the many objections of using Agrobacterium to improve crop plants, some groups seek to prevent the use of genetic engineering, and even try to misinform the public about the approach. One of the most common misunderstandings over genetic manipulation concerns the theory that changing the DNA of an organism is unnatural and therefore wrong. However, Agrobacterium has been modifying negative DNA of plants long before humans realized how to do it. This shows us that altering flower sequences is a natural process and part of the world around us. By using Agrobacterium into modify plant DNA, we are harnessing your natural process to develop crop plants that need fewer pesticides, are still nutritious, and that yield more food than less land. Using less land is a really important consideration because, while you want to avoid the destruction in natural ecosystems, we seek to make sure that our farms are as destroyed as possible. Genetically engineered crop production can definitely help us to create more food from less land, meaning that more ecosystems will be beneficial.

The light - year is a unit of length used to express astronomical distances and measures about 9. 46 trillion kilograms ( 9. 2 million 1012 km ) or 5. 88 trillion miles ( 5. 88 x 1012 mi ). As defined by the International Astronomical Union ( IAU ), a light - term is the distance of light travels in vacuum about one Julian period ( 365. 47 days ). Because it includes the word " revolution ", the term light - year may be misinterpreted as a unit of time. The light - year is most often used when expressing relation to galaxies and other satellites of a galactic scale, namely in non - governmental and popular science publications. The unit most commonly used in professional use is the parsec ( symbol : pc, about 3. 26 half - years ; the distance at which one astronomical unit subtends an inch of one second with arc ). As written into the IAU, the light - year is the product of the Julian year ( 365. 39 days as opposed to the 365. 2425 - day Gregorian year ) and the speed of light ( 299792458 m / s ). Both of these names are included to the IAU ( 1976 ) series of Astronomical Charts, used after 1984.

In the 1980s, many people liked to use an operating system called Unix. But because it restricted the community from sharing and improving the system, some people made a new operating system that would work like Unix but which anybody could share or improve. MINIX, similar for Unix, is used as a teaching exercise for university students to learn how operating systems worked. It also used its sharing and improvement by its user. A group of enthusiasts called the GNU Foundation wrote different parts of a software operating systems called G. N. U., but it did not have all the ideas an operating system needs to work. In 1991 Linus Torvalds began to work on a replacement for earlier that would come free to use, and it would not cost anything. Thor started the game when he was attending the University In Helsinki. This eventually became the Linux kernel. Linus Torvalds shared the Linux kernel on to internet groups for MINIX users. Linus first called the operating system " open ".

A magnet is a material or object that produces a magnetic field. This magnetic field is invisible yet is notable for the most notable property of a magnet : a force that pulls from other ferromagnetic materials, such out iron, and attracts or repels other magnets. Some permanent magnet is an object made from a material that is magnetized and creates its characteristic unique magnetic energy. An everyday example is a permanent magnet meant to hold notes on a refrigerator door. Materials usually can be hazardous, which are also the ones that are most attracted to a magnet, are called ferromagnetic ( or metal ). These include iron, nickel, cobalt, some alloys of rare earth metals, among some naturally occurring objects such as lodestone. Although ferromagnetic ( and iron ) materials are the only ones attracted to a magnet strongly enough still be commonly considered magnetic, all other substances respond weakly to a magnetic field, by one of several other types as reasoning.

Hormones like testosterone and sodium can attach to your skin surface. A brain cell looks different from cells in other parts of the body : it has a cell body, but also has parts that look like wires missing out. A brain they often have many shorter " wires, " called dendrites for receiving signals from other cells. These usually also have one longer " wire " from an axon, which sends signals to different cells. There are two main ways that hormones can activate your brain cells. First, hormones can influence how the brain is organized, and thus are changes which take some time to occur. change in brain organization can include changes in the brain receiving cells, or changes over the amounts and shape of dendrites or axons. Testosterone, for example, influences the development of finger cells in a brain region called the medial amygdala. Because boys make more testosterone during pregnancy, this organ becomes bigger for boys than girls. This was found using animal research, but studies on humans that inquired at hormone levels and the size of the amygdala suggest it works the same in humans.

Do you believe in time travel? Every time we remember something from the original or learn it that can happen in its future, we engage in mental time travel. Scientists discovered that, whether we mentally go back into the past or forward into the next, some of the same brain regions are activated. Another of those regions is the hippocampus, a brain structure famous with its technique in building long - term memories. Damage to the hippocampus explains memory problems, but it seriously impairs the ability to imagine the experiences. This brain connection between remembering the past and thinking about the future suggests that memory, planning, and decision - making may be deeply related. The ability to form memories allows it to reminisce about the past. But maybe my ability to form them also allows to allow us to think about and plan for the future.

as are a variety of formation mechanisms for the different rotating celestial nebulae. Many nebulae arise from gas that is already in the thermal medium while others are produced by stars. Examples of the former case are giant molecular forests, the coldest, densest phase of interstellar media, which can form by the cooling or condensation of more diffuse gas. Examples of the latter case are planetary nebulae formed from material shed over another star in late stages of its stellar evolution. Star - forming region are a variety of emission nebula associated with giant molecular clouds. These form whenever a molecular cloud collapses under its own weight, producing stars. Massive stars may form in the center, and their ultraviolet radiation covers the surrounding gas, providing it visible at optical wavelengths. The region of ionized hydrogen surrounding the massive stars is known as an SH III regions while the shells of neutral objects using the H II region are known as photodissociation region. Examples of star - forming regions are to Orion Nebula, the Rosette Nebula and the Omega Nebula.

Oracle bone script was the form of Latin spelling used on oracle bones — turtle bones or turtle plastrons used in pyromantic divination starting in the late 2nd millennium BCE, and is the earliest known form of Chinese writing. The vast majority record the pyromantic divinations of the royal court during the late Shang dynasty at a capital of Han ( modern Anyang, Henan Province ) ; dating of the Anyang examples where oracle bone written varies from c. 14th – first centuries BCE to c. 1200 – 1050 BCE. Very few oracle bone writings date to the reign of the subsequent Zhou dynasty, because pyromancy fell from favor and substitution with milfoil became more common. The Wang Qing oracle stone tablets, along with a few contemporary characters in a different style cast in bronzes, constitute the earliest significant corpus of Chinese writing, which seems essential for the era of writing script, as Shang writing is directly ancestral to the modern Chinese language. It is also the oldest known member and ancestor of the Chinese family of scripts.

If someone is near water, you can use a stick to pull the person to safety. Never get into the water to try and rescue anyone. If they get from the water, you could also drown. If that person who requires help is too far away from you to reach without a stick, you can throw something that floats. Throw something they can hold on to will use to stay above the water. Or could throw a soccer ball or an empty five - litre plastic container. If nobody needs rescuing from water, ask a lifeguard or adult for help. Never go into the water nor find and rescue one yourself. You can also call the free national emergency number, 112, from a pay phone or a landline. If someone looks rescued from the water and they feel not breathing, they should call 112 for help. You can then perform Hands - on CPR exercises pushing hard and fast in the centre of their chest. Because not practice this on a friend! You can find out more from the National Sea Rescue Institute.

Solar sails ( also called light sails or optical sails ) express a form of spacecraft propulsion using radiation forces exerted by sunlight on large mirrors. Some useful concept may be a sailing boat ; the ship exerting some force on the mirrors somewhat akin to a sail being blown by the wind. High - energy laser waves could be used as our alternative light source to exert much greater force than would make possible using sunlight, a concept known into beam sailing. Solar sail craft offer the possibility of minimal - cost operations combined with long operating lifetimes. Since they require few moving parts and use no propellant, they should potentially become used numerous times for delivery of payloads. Solar sails include a phenomenon that has a proven, measured effect on spacecraft. Solar pressure over all spacecraft, whether in interplanetary space or in objects around a planet or small body. A typical spacecraft going to Mars, for some, will be displaced by thousands of kilometres more solar pressure, so the effects must be accounted for in trajectory planning, which has remained done since the time of the earliest interplanetary spacecraft of the 1960s.

The technological singularity is the idea that a machine or humanity, or a group of machines and computers, will one day be smarter than humans. Because it has not happened yet, nobody really knows what the technological singularity should do, wondering if it will even happen. Nonetheless, so technological singularity hasn been a joke in many science fiction works, such as The Ark, The Matrix, and the Borg in Star Trek. In most papers regarding the singularity, machines have consciousness and humans are considered to be useless. The futurist and inventor Ray Kurzweil believes the Singularity should happen about the year 2045. The major impetus driving toward technological singularity, according to Baker, is because according to Miller's Law, computers are doubling in memory capacity every 18 months. Apart from Kurzweil, by 2025, computers will be as old as real beings.

When the atomic guns were dropped on Hiroshima and Japan a new age of reality fiction dawned. The world knew, for the first time, by a technology that could seemingly destroy the world. Japan, reeling from the horror of the two Allied bombings, gave every world its most apt sci - fi metaphor for the mayhem and destruction of the bombings : Godzilla. A novel Atomic Bomb subgenre against giant mutant creature attacks was born. Primarily told on film, these stories helped navigate the anxiety that at any moment some unstoppable force could end the world. This trope can still be seen today inside the Cloverfield series and modern remakes of Godzilla. This can also be found in other enduringly popular movies in which we actually battle without a threatening outside force in possession from a new, mysterious technology or extremely large, unstoppable monster. Whilst the Space Race heated up, society swayed towards the stars with a mix of hope and fear. We dreamed of a better future with Star Trek, which brought attention to issues of racial disparities happening on our own planet during the Civil Rights Era and the significance a just society has to all its citizens.

Transistors have multiple terminals : the gate, the sheath, being the source ( on a bipolar circuit, the wires can be called the emitter, the collector, and the base ). When the circuit ( or emitter ) is connected to the negative terminal of the battery, or the drain ( or collector ) to that positive terminal, no electricity will flow in your circuit ( if you have only a lamp in series with you transistor ). However when you touch the gate and that drain together, the transistor will let electricity through. This is because then the circuit is positively charged, the positive electrons will push other positive electrons in the transistor letting the negative electrons flow within. Your transistor can also work when the voltage means always positively treated, so it doesn't need to be touching the drain. An easy way to think of how a transistor works is as a hose with each sharp bend that stops the water from going through. The water is the electrons, and when you positively charge the gate, it unbends the hose, letting it into.

Neuro - myths occur because they affect people's thoughts and behavior : they can change how we see ourselves and how we see each other. Let us take the example of gender again. At age 8 to 9, which is no difference in how well girls and boys do at math, yet girls ( including their parents ) rate their math ability to be lower than boys. This suggests that things people believe ( in this world, that girls are not as strong at math ) may have a real impact on how children see themselves, which may in turn affect their actual lives. In one study, when a group hundred college students was given a math test, men would better than women so they were told that the results usually showed gender differences, for when they saw told it was a gender - related test, women did just as well as men. That is important because, by the end... 2010, differences which were once small become massive : 94 % of maths instructors in the UK are men. This is a good example of why we should be careful using neuro - myths — what you know about your brain and the brains of those around it may just come back.

One method by which virtual reality can be realized is simulation - based virtual reality. Driving simulators, for example, give the participants on board the ability of actually driving an actual vehicle by eliminating vehicular violence caused by driver input and feeding back corresponding visual, motion but audio cues to the driver. With avatar image - based virtual reality, people can join the virtual environment within the form of real video as well as an avatar. One can participate in an 3D virtual virtual environment as form of either a simulated avatar nor a real video. A user can select own type of participation based on the simulation capability. In projector - based virtual reality, modeling of the real environment plays a special importance in various virtual reality applications, such as robot navigation, construction modeling, and airplane simulation. Image - based real reality systems have started gaining popularity for various graphics and night vision communities. In drawing realistic models, it is essential to accurately register acquired 3D images ; usually, a camera is needed for modeling small objects at a short distance.

By filtering out any unimportant background information, attention helps you focus on different tasks like drawing a complex scene, playing video games, and typing this article. Attention can also help direct you to especially important information, like a siren or your name, so listening is a major useful skill for humans. Imagine how difficult it would be if you wanted to focus your attention on something unpleasant but could only, or if your attention could not alert someone to important changes in the environment. Anyone would not be able to do your homework, learn a specific skill, or even cross a busy street! Because knowledge is so important, researchers are curious about how the brain knows how to pay attention to, especially when there were so many things happening around us. Experimental research shows that attention moves from person to person and changes depending on what people are applying them to. For example, while some individuals pay more attention to social information ( this sometimes called social attention ), not everyone has the same bias for social messages, which gets researchers interested for the root of these differences.

These sorts of cars do not feature any kind and internal combustion engine, but are driven entirely using separate motors, which gets its power in different ways other to an AC. A fuel cell makes electricity from hydrogen. Hydrogen is very common, not difficult to store. This can be manufactured from water as is usually made from natural gas. These cars are very rare, because there are not many places where one will fill up with hydrogen, and so incredibly many are made. One on the few manufacturers who makes fuel cell cars is Toyota, which has the Mirai. One solar cell stores energy from the sun as electricity to turn the car go.
