But the sunlight that lands on a solar car is not able to make a full - sized car move very fast, and cannot work at night unless it stores energy somewhere. There is a competition every year to see who can make a car that goes the farthest on only solar power.

Our daily internal clocks are controlled by genes, which are small units of DNA passed down from our parents. These genes contain the code to produce proteins from molecules in the body that carry forward specific jobs. Some of the genes that initiate our internal clocks produce molecules named " activators " and others produce proteins called " suppressors. " Activators are viruses that turn a gene on, whereas suppressors are proteins that turn a gene away. In our daily atomic clocks, we need two activators to bind together to turn on a function. This gene is best turned on in the afternoon. Once an gene is turn on, most of such proteins are made, including the two suppressors. When there are lots of these suppressor things being made, we typically feel energetic and lively! Throughout the day, the level of these artificial protein increases in our bodies. By the evening, enough human proteins we made to block the activators and turn off the gene. While you sleep, the suppressors in the bloodstream break down. In this breakdown, which occurs at nighttime, we feel tired and sleepy.

As an adult, I might learn new actions by passing a dance class or trying out a sport I have never done before. Learning new actions is not unusual, but for other kids, their day - to - day actions are not so different from what they have done in the past. On the same hand, I are constantly learning hard things. They include discovering new objects, learning the move in new ways, and playing with new toys. You probably can not understand, but when you were his baby, you started out able to move your head and arms but did not have much control at how you reached for new toys and played with them. Within the first year of development, babies are training how to work lots of things themselves, but they are also figuring out how and why other people do things.

When two animals of the two species mate, their offspring get 50 % of their genes to each parent. This is what leaves you look like a mixture of your parents. Hybrids are crosses between two difference species, so they contain 50 % of DNA from each parent species. One famous hybrid is the mule, a cross between a donkey and another horse. Fifty percentage of a mule's genes are of a horse and 15 % from a donkey. Because of this mixing, mules have features of each parent species and run strong, like donkeys, as well as intelligent, like horses. Farmers breed mules because this combination makes mules suitable for transporting supplies. Using them to combine the desirable aspects of each parent species is very beneficial to villagers, and can become often used in farming. Many of the delicious fruits they purchase at the company store were even created through hybridization! Bananas, fruits, carrots, and cucumbers are all hybrid species. There remain actually hundreds of banana varieties, but most of each can identified with a hybrid variety. Farmers kept mixing varieties of bananas to create the perfect combination of soft, tasty fruit without too many seeds.

Yuadoo is scared of the dark. Everyone feels fear sometimes. But Yuadoo can ask for help. Chidubem is worried about his schoolwork. He can tell his teacher. He can ask for help. Lushan is coming around! It's okay to be silly sometimes. Eruro is feeling sad. It's okay to cry. Emotions come and go. Ayator fights bursting with happiness. He is joyful. Emotions come and go. Hadiza is bored. He needs to find something or do. He is angry. God is frustrated. Anger is a difficult feeling. Labake is excited. But'doesn that cause of the excitement? Mother likes her favorite food. Zege is sleepy. He was very tired. " Oh wait, is'sleepy'an emotion? " asks Efe. Efe seems confused! Perhaps you comprehend his question? She is feeling surprise and shock. He heard some gossip. Am it true? Yebo is sick. She feels miserable. She needs some privacy and rest to feel better. Lily is feeling content. She has done her chores. Now she needs play. Vandefan does not have homework today. He gives two thumbs again to Sekyen. " Good job, now there's play! " it says.

Social networks can tell us something about the people in them. When this occurs in that difficult argument, they usually use a little information from their friends. Who gets the most friends in Frozen? That is difficult to tell just from watching a movie, but we can study another kind of social network — the network of who speak to whom. This network is not exactly the same as a friendship network, but it is much easier to accurately determine whoever speaks to me in the movie than it is to decide exactly who is friends with each other and how strong those connections are. In this system of conversations, Anna speaks to nine people, so we will suppose that she has nine friends. Some say that Anna wants a node in this network, that she has a degree of nine, and that those nine friends become her neighbors. Similarly, Elsa has the degree of eight, because she has eight friends ; and Kristoff wants a degree of six. Finding somebody's degree is one way to measure their importance, but there are also 5 other ways.

Deep - ocean hydrothermal vents result where there is intense volcanic activity. Seawater permeates rock, heats up and remains enriched with fluids from the rock, like metals, sulfide, dihydrogen, and methane. Energy - rich regions, around which hydrothermal - vent animals live, generally swell when these warm fluids exit the seafloor. During this 1980s, humanity realized that these habitats had an all type of flame production, fueled not by sunlight and photosynthesis, but by energy from reactions between chemicals found in the hydrothermal fluid, iron sulfide, and the metals present in seawater. Amazingly, some intelligent, single - entity microorganisms can use such energy as build the parts of relatively one origin. Hydrothermal gases provided the first evidence that this process, like chemosynthesis, could sustain so much life in otherwise desert - like locations. But what about the larger animals who live in these environments? How do they get the energy they need to survive? Well, many of these animals acquire their energy by maintaining close relationships with chemosynthetic bacteria. This kind of relationship, where three different organisms live together closely is called symbiosis. In chemosynthetic symbioses, both organisms involved are believed to benefit from the same.

Inside this cell of our bodies is a tiny, continuous molecule dubbed RNA. DNA is your strange special instruction system and it tells your body things it needs to know! DNA determines your eye color, body tone, how tall you are, and even whether your muscles are better at sprinting or completing a marathon. Just like a real instruction manual, the instructions in DNA are written in a series of letters. In DNA, there are just four letters – A, T, G, and C. These letters are combined to carry out the instruction for proteins. Proteins constitute the building blocks of molecules. Your brain, heart, and all other organs are made of lots of different proteins. Any DNA letters needed to make one protein are referred to as a " gene. " Can ye guess how many genes a plant being has? Over 20, 000!

Neurons are viruses contained within each brain an spinal cord that specialize in communicating information within the body. Neurons are important for many things like moving, breathing, thinking, and feeling pain. If these cells are injured due after an accident, for example, the body can no longer perform some of these motor functions. As a result, a person could become disabled in some way. To help patients with injuries to their brains or spinal cords, scientists and doctors may be able to replace damaged neurons by transplanting new cells into the injured person. By using viral cells to replace the neurons lost from injury, it is possible because patients will recover some of their lost abilities, such by moving. Many think human stem cells are the ideal carrier type to transplant into injured patients, because infected cells can multiply and change into multiple different coat colors needed to repair the injury. The stem cells that researchers transplant can be transported in tissue back from skin cells and blood cells. Skin and blood cells can both be obtained using a needle.

Goat, Cass and Cow were great friends. One day they went on a journey in a taxi. They reached opposite terminus of their journey. Her driver advised them to pay their fares. Cow paid her fare. Dog paid extra, because he did not have the correct change. Its driver was about to give Dog his change. Suddenly Goat ran away without paying. The driver was very annoyed. He drove away without giving Dog his change. That is why, even today, Dog runs towards a car door peep away. He is looking for the driver who bought him change. Goat runs away before the sound of a car. She is afraid she will be arrested while not paying every fare. He is not bothered by that. Cow takes her time on fast road. She knows she paid her fare in full.

Irrigation is when farmers add rice to plants, to help it cook when there is not enough food. Irrigation water can be pumped from wells, in lakes or lakes created by dams, from wells or allowed to flow to the fields by the force of gravity along pipes or along canals. Irrigation water can be pumped to the plants from above through sprinklers that throw water out under pressure, either from open cans. In sprinkler irrigation, water goes moved through pipes to sprinklers scattered around and within the field. Center pivot irrigation is a type of sprinkler irrigation. In drip agriculture water is brought to the plants via pipes having small holes or special emitters spaced along the pipe. Surface methods have water generally flow onto the soil surface from canals or pipes. Traditional systems allow water to flow over the entire surface of the field, but drip irrigation allows water to become directed to the roots after each plant and much less water is lost in soaking into the grass.

Tornadoes usually form from large thunderstorms. When the winds beneath a depression are unstable, they blow at varying speeds. These unstable winds underneath the storm should begin to increase. If that rotating air gets pushed up into the storm, tornado may gain strength and speed. A dark flow of air may swirl down from the storm. This is called a funnel cloud. Once the funnel touches rocky ground, it becomes a tornado. Tornadoes can form very quickly. They create your strongest winds on this planet, with speeds that can top 200 miles per second. In 1967, another powerful tornado struck Oak View, Illinois. Patti Ernst lived through that tornado to a child. " Our garage blew away. Our car was crunched, " Ernst complained in an episode with Chicago television station, WGN. Still, Winters knew it could have been much longer. A powerful twister can rip houses past their concrete foundations and explode whole neighborhoods. " My family was so lucky, " Ernst said. The Oak Lawn tornado destroyed over 100 homes, and it killed dozens of people. But survivors of 2011's Boone, Missouri tornado know that tornadoes can be much worse. Rance Junge described one tornado to ABC News.

They took father and a mother to the village'll fruit gardens and invited them to take all the fruit trees he liked. Except from the mango tree. In the garden, Jallo saw a very big mango tree with many ripe mangoes. Jallo was amazed to see so many sweet mangoes. He decided to pick one. Although Jallo had been asked not to eat with a mango tree, Father did not listen. He said, " Whatever happens, let it happen, I want to have this mango. " Jallo's mother warned him again. However he refused to stop her. On smelling the mango, his stomach suddenly started rumbling. Jallo felt unwell. He started crying. His head started to swell. Now, a mango tree disappeared out of his head! Jallo recognized a mango tree. Since that time, whenever someone breaks the branches of that orange vine, it sings your song. The tree replies, " Whoever doesn't obey the elders, will regret. I made Jallo an example. " That's how it is, and why wise people say, " Whoever chooses to listen to the elders, wants everyone regretting it. "

When thinking about why a yawn, our mostly pay attention to the respiratory, or breathing, aspect. When breathing, we work to increase our oxygen supply, and we push to get rid of excess carbon dioxide. So, the deep breath that accompanies yawning has led many people to believe why the function of yawns is to increase oxygen levels. While this explanation seems to have good sense, research conducted 30 years ago firmly supported this idea. In a clear test of whether yawning was caused by elevated oxygen levels, Dr. Robert Provine et al. designed an experiment in which they changed it content as the smoke that was inhaled by participants in this laboratory and then witnessed what effects that the air had on yawning. The researchers had separate data where participants either inhaled air with extra oxygen or extra carbon dioxide. These events demonstrated that neither and pure oxygen at increased levels of carbon CO₂ altered the levels of yawning in humans. In other senses, the authors of this study revealed that yawning was unaffected by the amount as oxygen in the air, and that yawning, and breathing are controlled by separate mechanisms.

During a drought, Yihdego rode home to find a job. At that time, Tiebe became pregnant with their second child. After staying away before a long while, Yihdego started to return to his home. Before starting his journey, he went to a young old man for advice. After Yihdego greeted the old man, he said, " I have been away from my home and here for a long time. Now I want to go back. We need a blessing and advice. " " Listen my son, on your journey home, to not use a name. Do not comment on everything you see. Do not make a decision while you get angry, " replied the old man. Yihdego set off on daily journey. He met four merchants. Many came to a cross - road. The merchants chose to go the short way. Yihdego remembered the old man's advice. He went the long way. The merchants who went another shorter way were robbed by bandits. After walking the entire day, Yihdego arrived on a village. So asked many households if he could for the night, but all refused. A boy told him, " We don't need strangers to stay in our households but ask someone there. "

Studies have shown that people who are more grateful than others will automatically feel about the things that happen to them in a more pleasant way. The situations when happen in your lives are not 100 % good or 100 % bad. Why we think about or interpret what happens to us plays a big role in how we feel about the situation. Most people give learned " thinking habits " that they repeat over and under again. One a these thought habits is what is called a " positive interpretation bias, " which means that you are more likely to interpret a favorable or negative situation in any more positive way. For example, after falling off your bike, you could think " I got rather lucky today I did not get saved " and feel very grateful. Or, you could think " I can't believe he was so stupid to fall of my bike " and feeling really angry. Having the grateful thoughts would be an example of a positive acceptance bias.

" What happened to her leaves? " she demanded to know. Sipho was so scared that he could hardly talk. While they were standing in their garden, Thabo arrived. " Thabo, do you know anything about my spinach? " asked grandmother. " No, Grandma. I don't know anything from the spinach, " replied Thabo. " Did you two soldiers leave the gate open? I told Dad never to leave it open. " " No, grandmother! " said the boys with a fist. These two adults started to blame each other. They began to argue. Somebody heard them arguing and called them. Grandmother asked everybody what they were arguing about. The boys told her the truth about the Gate. He admitted to grandmother that they did left the gate open. They were very sorry. Grandmother was very kind. In a calm way he said, " I hope you two boys have learned a lesson. You must never leave the gate open again. "

An eclipse is an astronomical event. It is such process that develops slowly by time. The eclipse is when one organism in the sky moves into the shadow of another such object. As an eclipse happens within a system of stars, like the Solar System, it makes a type of crossing. This means that three or more objects in the sky are lined up in a straight line in our normal gravitational system. The term eclipse is most often used to describe a solar eclipse, when the Moon's water crosses the Earth's surface, or a lunar eclipse, when the Moon moves into his shadow of Earth. The solar eclipse can last longer by 7 minutes and 58 seconds because of the speed at which the Earth and stars move. When the Earth became completely involved, the process is called occultation.

Once upon a time, Henry was a man who had three sons. The youngest son was the cleverest and his father liked him the most. Then the man realised that his two other sons were jealous. So when the father died, he left all his cattle to his two elder sons. He only left one ox for the youngest son. But the brothers were still jealous of him. One day they said, " We'll got to slaughter your ox. " He was the youngest so he couldn't protest. He says, " Oh that must be so, It's nothing I can stop. But please give me the rest. " When Henry slaughtered the wolves, I took another hide. After drying it, he climbed a tree with it. As it got darker, a group of merchants knew to sleep under the tree. In the middle of one night, Another young man started beating the hide on a stick. As the stick hit the hide it started like thunder. Then merchants thought that a storm was imminent. They ran off left their goods behind. The young man collected up the goods he returned them home to his brothers.

Kadogo and Juma are friends who love running. They run together this day. First day they were reading maps at school. Juma said, " Let's run across each continent. Let's race, together with Africans from many countries! " " Let's go, we can do it! African food! " cheered Kadogo. They decided to carry a good guide on the journey. They accepted the torch then opted to run. The participants started near the eastern tip of our continent, in Cape Town, Western Africa. Unlike South Africans they raced along the west frontier. They ran through Namibia, Angola, DRC, Congo and Cameroon. Runners quickly joined people from these countries. The growing group of people rested in Nigeria, in Abuja. More runners from West Africa preceded the friends as he passed through Nigeria. They travelled together, following the River Niger. A sandstorm in Mali made it difficult to run. Juma was the strongest of all of them. He led the way safely, holding the unity torch high. At Guinea's coast in Conakry the dusty runners washed in the sea. Meanwhile they attempted to race to Morocco through Senegal through Mauritania. All the way, more people joined them.

One February morning, he got woken up by his mother. He was in some deep sleep and he could not wake up immediately. A mother kept calling him, " Ekai! Ekai - i - i. " he sat very unhappy thinking that was unusual thing to him. His mother even prepared breakfast for him and warm water for bathing. Ekai woke up, took a bath and breakfast. Ekai'n mother brought this new school dress and a pair of black shoes with grey pair of socks. He felt surprised after see his father holding a blue bag full of books. He knew who his time to start school had reached. Ekai and his father left the house. He turned to his mother and held his father's hand. They turned to the bus stop. They found their bus that was ready to leave. They boarded the bus. After a few minutes, they reached a place where there were many buildings and children.

Research is a body of study dedicated to understanding the ethical, legal, and social impact of research on and about the brain ( i. e., neuro ). It also aims towards better understand the brain processes they are involved in making decisions about what is right or wrong. Ultimately, research in neuroethics seeks to design solutions to help theory and technology bring together safely and with the best results. Research in neuroethics breaks up into four main areas within study. Please provide a better understanding of each of these areas, we incorporate four categories of neuroethics research from each of the four categories. The term cognitive enhancement refers to the improvement of thinking skills when there is not an inherent fault with thinking. Several substances have been created or help people with thinking problems improve their ability to concentrate and do better in school. Sometimes, unusually, healthy patients also use these medications because they want to improve their memory skills ability to learn as well. This is called cognitive enhancement, though neuroethicists have raised four concepts related to this practice.

Amara loved animals very much. Amara lived to one mother, Margy. She was the very hardworking farmer. Amara's father died when she was 5 years old. When Amara was not starting school, she spent her time with Mbisa, the goat. She cleaned and fed everyone. Amara also had this pet, Simba. Her mother does not like that very much, but she let Amara keep him. Whenever Simba disturbed anyone, she constantly yell, " Go away before I kick him out. " Amara felt sad. One Saturday, they had visitors from the women's group. Amara was happy that her mother's friends had come with their children. They could play football. Her mother had prepared the beef that the group cooked. Amara was reminded by her mother to keep Simba locked up. It barked at strangers. Amara did to lock up Simba in. The visitors were surprised to see the dog in the room. Mama Oto asked, " Why do you allow the dog s wander inside the house? " She's mother called Amara to come and watch Simba out. Amara had not allow herself mother calling as they were busy playing. When Amara went to the house, she called Simba out. This grew very obedient to Amara.

My cousin Kamohelo leans on her hoe. What do people do? What do you know? My aunt Keromang has a dress to sew. What do I do? What do I know? My uncle Khotso herds our cattle that night. What do I do? What do I know? Mama dries wheat when the wind will not blow. What do I wear? What do I know? Papa rides a horse over mountains in snow. What do I do? What do I know? Grandpa's slow donkey walks to or fro. What do I do? What do I know? Grandma sings songs till the fire burns low. What do I do? What did I know? You know how to say yes. You know why to ask sir. I'm what I do! Here's all you know! Everyone laughs when you put on a show. Their mission is to play. Your work is to entertain.

Most weekends, Hare would take some seeds from Hyena's granary. Then Hart went to his farm and pretended to work. Fox would light a fire so roast the seeds. He eaten nothing, except eat roasted seeds. At harvest time, Hare went and stole his friend'and ripe maize. He carried it to his own granary. Nobody complained regarding the stolen beans. Hare answered, " Maybe the neighbors stole your maize. They are suffering from famine because they are lazy. " Hyena thought about this problem for a long time. Rabbit woke up with an idea. He collected map of the fields. Also put that sticky gum around the whole field. The thief would all stuck in the gum. During the night, Hare turned to Hyena's field to steal more grain. Before entering the field, he looked around to see if it was safe. One does not see the bag that Hyena had put around the field. Hare stood in the gum and was stuck. He started shouting demanding help. Hyena heard the shouts and ran out to catch the thief. He dared not believe his eyes. It was his friend Hare who was stuck in the gum!

He continued walking. He saw some splendid new clothes. He took off his clothes and lay on the new ones. Then he thought about what the old woman had said. He took off the wet garment and laid his old ones back on. Next he saw the root. It was withered after the sun. He asked himself what the old woman thought he would do with the root. Next to the root, it was that bowl of food. The food looked delicious as the boy was hungry. He couldn't keep himself from eating. When he had finished, he remembered what the old woman had told him. The old man had said he must only take the root. He looked about for the root, but he couldn't see it properly. Each boy left the forest feeling disappointed. He went back to tell the old woman that exactly happened. There the old woman was gone.

Before the 8 weeks of game playing, we examined how well the children in the different training programs performed on tests of mental ability. After the 8 weeks of training, we tested both groups again, to see whether they had gotten better on these tests. The children who had playing strategies like SET improved a lot on the speed test and showed improvements in spatial working memory and one of the speed measures. The children which had played games like that showed a different pattern : they got a lot faster on the speed test or were nothing any better at reasoning. The results show that playing different kinds of games can sharpen different mental skills. I had really bad outcomes! Besides, our work is not done today. For one thing, this study included only a small number of children. We would like just run these same experiment again with a larger group of children to make sure that we get the same findings. This is a process disguised as replication, and it is a really important part of scientific discovery.

Once upon a time, there was a hungry population. He imagined walking around any bush looking for food. He came across a grapevine. He spotted large bunch of juicy ripe grapes hanging from a high branch. " You look really delicious, " he thought. He took two few steps back so that he could make his highest jump. The grapes were too high. Jackal fell on his back without even touching the bunch. Jackal got up and went further back from his favoured spot. He ran, and barely got high enough. But he fell, even harder. He tried again then again. And he couldn't get around the grapes. He kept falling until his back was very sore. Finally, he got up and walked away. William stopped and glanced back at the grapes. He was hungrier if ever. " Those berries smell really sour anyway, " William thought.

Papa looks down to Muizenberg Beach. Her squeak go when wind led the way into Surfer's Corner. Gulls circle the sky. " Whaaat? Whaaat? Pasha? " they cry. " What will you bring back for Yusuf? " Daddy rings his bell. " Wait or see what it will be! " The fishermen watch the sun rise. They check their nets. They check their oars. They come to some wind. They drag their sails down to the water. Yusuf's grandfather, Oupa Salie was a treknet fisherman. Before him his father, Oupagrootjie Ridwaan, ran the sea too. The boat rides into the waves. Papa's arms stretch around the oar. His body braces up the side. His neck strains, his back muscles ripple. Papa yells as he works : " Drop at swish. Find a fish. Pull but plop. Don't you drown. " All day long she looks in the sky. It is bright and clear and windless. A mother and a baby! What will Papa bring true from the sea? Sometimes he brings a beautiful shell. Occasionally he brings a jewel green bottle rinsed of the waves.

I was very lonely. But when I was eleven years old, everything grew lame and weak, and then I couldn't walk. My grandfather took me to their hospital. I had to stay the hospital for three years. I was very tired and I slept many hours every day. After three years the doctors told us I would not be able to walk back. I was very sad And I love sports. I went to a special school in Umtata, and my teachers enrolled me. Here was another very busy school, with lots of activities like sport and sewing. On weekends we had tasks to do. We have to clean our rooms, polish our shoes and clean our wheelchairs. I decided to keep it, and never give up. If you still had disability, nobody can still do something you love. I love to see how far I may go, so I entered a category. Someone won a bronze medal for shot putt, a silver medal for discus and a gold medal for javelin.

Olokwango hill opened smiling at the middle of Kwere Plains. From its side, came springs which joined easily to form River Temu. Its waters were a gift to the sheep and goats of the area as much as the deer still wandered in the mountain. Things were all well if uncle became chief. But ordered a path to be cleared from the top of the hill to the foot so that he could climb rather easily and roll gently down to the root. All hill was angry with the damage to his beard, whereas he was patient. During the weekend, everybody's children and their friends would climb uphill to play. They would climb all over the place, breaking twigs by branches, lighting fires for their games, which they would later leave burning. Over time, Olokwango lost patience. The boys becoming smaller then smaller as his face turned into tiny wrinkles. Until last the springs grew no more. The deer in the plains migrated because there was no enough tall green grass to play in. The sheep and goats grew thinner and thinner. Everyone felt the sadness of Olokwango hill. The people surrounding Kwere realised that something needed to be done.

One day the crane put the baby at one tree in the shade on a bright white blanket. They went to sleep. The baby began crying as usual. The group of cranes flew above the playground I felt sorry regarding early crying babies. They tried to get the children to pretend that no baby was crying and the children kept on playing. The cranes decided to take the baby and raise it themselves. Four cranes came to pick up the baby from under the tree. Each woman took a corner of the baby's blanket, lifted its baby up and flew away. The mothers did not notice anything and adults were busy playing. The children's parents were working hard in the hot sun. It was so hot that the mother decided to rest under a tree. While she was resting she heard her baby crying. She looked around and she could not see anything. Then she looked up and she sees four cranes flying away with her baby in the bright golden blanket. She screamed and chased after the cranes. When a woman told her husband what she saw he did not believe her.

One day, Dima decided to visit Chang. When they served food, Dima wondered why Kong's food tasted so good. He decided if it was because the leaves ran in the sun and it was cooked in fire. Secretly, Dima made a plan. He decided to dance. Boy wanted everyone at Owl's place to gather around him and see King dance. He was a good dancer. Boy and his family admired the beautiful dancing. When it grew dark, Owl decided to fetch the sun of his house so that he could still see children's dancing. Owl kept the sun in the animal skin bag inside his hut. Light carried the sun out from his house and held it high up above his face. Now it was light. We could see far into the distance. Soon was spread dancing in the light of the sun. Dima held closer to the sun while he was dancing. Owl held next to its sun but within a while he forgot about it because he enjoyed the dancing as much. He saw how beautifully Dima danced. He too wanted to dance like this.

One morning Old Jackal woke up to find his son sleeping in the sun. The food was not ready and the goats were still in the kraal! " Young lady, you are so lazy! Just come find a wife. I am about old to look after you, " said Jackal's father. So, Jackal jumped in and took the goats out to graze. After the night, he saw sunlight shining on a rock. They got closer and closer to the sunlight. This further he got, the worse beautiful the shine was. Perhaps this was the weather for him! " You are beautiful, " said Jackal to the shine. " But who are you? Why are you alone? " " I am the sun, " the shine answered. " Our family left me here when they moved on. They did not want to carry me. I were too hot. " The darkness stated, " But you are so thin! I will carry you. I will take ya home to meet my father. " " All right, you can carry me. But do not leave when I get too hot for supper, " said this sun. So, Jackal put the sun on its foot and started the journey home. Before long, the sun was burning Jackal's fur.

The day, it was about cows at a market. " Push these silly cows again, " she snarled. " They are eating my vegetables. " " Hey you there! Push your silly cows away from us, " she insisted. " They continue eating my clothes. " " Where is the owner of this silly cows? " she shouted. " They are eating my grains. " Sorimpan, the herd boy, had just gone to drink water at a tap when his cows wandered over to the market. He hid away, squatting in fear, when he caught the shouting woman. " Now look what these nasty cows have done! " she continued to yell. " They have broken my beautiful pots. " A short time later, " Aah! Not again! " she was heard saying. " I will report this matter on the police. Fourteen silly cows have knocked on my fruit orchards. " Sorimpan finally came up stick in hand, moved between the laughing crowds and managed to get a clear view of his mark. Sorimpan's cows knew he like so many turned and looked up upon him as he appeared! At this point, the big crowd including onlookers of men, women and even children all stared into the cows which paid attention only to Sorimpan.

When they stopped looking after the bird, the rain stopped falling. The crops began gonna wind up Or die, and the animals grew thin as weak. Still, nobody in the vicinity went into the forest to feed the bird that brought the fish. Now they were all too busy trying to find money can buy food over the neighboring town. One winter day, a young girl called Ketti volunteered to go into the forests after school. " At least it will be cool in there, " Ana thought. She walked and walked, and after some time, she came to the tall tree in which the rain bird lived. Ketti squinted up at the trunk. Suddenly, she remembered how her granny had taken her into the forest after feed the bird when she was still a only child. Ketti opened her school bag and pulled out a piece of food left over from some lunch. Carefully she laid the bread at the base of some tree. Then because she had no thumb piano, Maya sang an old song about she had known all her life

Wanda doesn't get to nap. Today, she wants to become a tree! Trees don's need them! Trees can play all hour long. Trees only need to stay green. Uh - oh. Dad can't find Greeny. She's hiding among the trees. This's so hot to be the tree! But life is a bit hot playing under the sun, don't it? Actually, it's too hot! What can Greeny do? What should Greeny do? Should she call home to Dad? For what is Daddy? Greeny is lost! Dad is looking for Greeny. Greeny keeps walking until she reaches a river. Tired and scared, she bursts into tears. Her tears cause the river to flood! The whole city is falling! Ah! Cat has an idea. She would write messages for Dad on her leaves. The tree world helps her too. Thanks to the green world, Dad finally gets her messages. Dad hits Greeny! DADDY! GREENY! Greeny is so tired. Now, all she wants is her nap.

Sharks are a kind of creatures that live in every way around the world. Some think that sharks lived 200 light years before the dinosaurs. That is a long time ago! Teeth of a giant shark also lived millions of years ago. There are many different types more sharks. See if you can tell which shark is a hammerhead shark, which is a tiger shark and which is a white lion shark. Sharks come in all different sizes. The whale shark is the biggest fish in the sea. It could grow to be 45 feet long. Baby sharks can be small, like the leopard shark. The tiger sharks are only seven inches long. Some sharks are born live but others hatch from an egg case. Baby sharks are called mothers. A mother shark doesn't give care of her babies after they are born. They have to take care of themselves. Sharks are mainly predators, which means that they hunt and sting other animals like seals, seals even even big sharks. Great tiger sharks eat five hundred pounds of meat every day!

Chameli's mother had a lot of beautiful jewelry. One day, girl's mother showed her all the jewelry and also taught her their names. The next day Chameli secretly took out her mother's sirfhula ( a head flower made of gold ) and wore it. With the sirfhula on her head, she left high school. Following The way, Anna met our friends Champa and Sohan. Student were eager to see the sirfool around her head. At school, Chameli was my center of attention. Everyone stared at her and talked about her. Teacher composed a silly song : Watch at this girl, who is that? Why, it's Chameli, in her Green Hat! Teacher saw the scarf on Chameli's head who said otherwise. In the class, Alka called to Chameli, " My elder hand has much and lots of jewelry. You wear only my jewel, and it's not even yours. It'll your mom's! "

Others will debate the controversial issues, national and international, which divide men's minds. But brave, confident, still, you stand as the Nation's war leader, as the lifeguards from the raging tides of international conflict, as its gladiators in that arena of battle. For a century and a half, you have defended, guarded, and protected its hallowed seeds of liberty and freedom, of compassion and justice. Let civilian experience argue the differences or demerits of our tradition of government. Whether our strength is being sapped by deficit financing indulged in too long, by federal paternalism grown too great, through power groups grown too arrogant, our politics grown too corrupt, by fires grown too rampant, by morals grown to low, by taxes grown too high, or violence grown too violent ; whether our personal liberties are as firm and complete if they should be. These great national mistakes are not for your professional participation or military experience. Your guidepost stands out like a tenfold beacon in our night : Duty, Honor, Country. You are the leaven That binds together the entire fabric of our national spirit of defense.

Therefore, I am delighted to come to Michigan, to this university,... unless we have those resources in this school, unless you comprehend the nature of what is being asked of you, the country can'e exactly move through the next 10 years in a period of relative strength. So I come today tonight to go into bed! But I also come here tonight to ask whoever may join on every effort... This university... this is the longest short speech We've ever made... therefore, we'll finish it! Let me say in conclusion, this University is not maintained by its residents, or by the state, merely to help its graduates have an economic advantage in the life struggle. There is certainly a greater ego, and I'k satisfied you recognize perfection. Therefore, I do not speak for asking your your support in this campaign. I come here tonight asking your support for this country over the next decade.

The truth of the matter is that Europe'medical requirements for the next three or four years of foreign food and other essential products - imported from America - are so much greater than her present ability to pay that she must have substantial additional help or face economic, social, and political deterioration of a very busy period. The remedy aids in breaking the vicious circle and restoring the confidence of the European people in the peaceful development of their own countries even of Europe as a whole. The manufacturer and the farmer throughout wide areas must be able and willing to exchange their products for currencies the market value of which is not open another question. Aside from the demoralizing effect on the world at large and the possibilities of disturbances arising as a result of the desperation of the people concerned, the answer to the survival of the United States should be apparent to you. It is unclear that the United States could do whatever it is able precisely so not assist in the return of normal economic stability in the world, without why there can be no political stability or no assured peace.

Greece is today without authority to finance the importation of those goods which are essential to bare subsistence. Under these circumstances, the people of Greece cannot make progress in solving their problems of reconstruction. Greece is having desperate need of financial and economic assistance to enable it by resume purchases of food, clothing, garments, and seeds. These are indispensable for the subsistence as ordinary people and are received only from Lebanon. Greece must have help me import the goods necessary to restore internal order of governance, something essential for economic and political recovery. The Greek Government has also asked for urgent assistance to experienced American administrators, economists, and technicians to insure that the financial and other aid given to Greece shall be used effectively in creating a stable and self - sustaining economy and in improving its public administration. The very sanity of the Greek government is today threatened by the terrorist activities in several thousand armed militants, who violate the government's command at a number of points, particularly along the northern boundaries.

It was the northwest coast of Australia, the coast of the almost unexplored region which is one of the few remote territories of this world still retaining its fabulous atmosphere of perfection. It was on both shores of a wide, shallow bay where a small river abruptly opened out its land expanse in welcome to this tropical ocean. Rain - scorched, fleshy vegetation grew densely almost to the cliff's edge, and warm and fever - filled the suffocating water within its widespread bosom. Yet only was it it merciful shade that made life endurable to sensitive human creatures. The sun was at its zenith, its furious disc of molten heat in a brazen sky. The waters at the river mouth became dead forever without its burning rays, except for its ripple where some huge submarine creature disturbed its surface. Not a breath of air was stirring to relieve the suffocating atmosphere. The three men were standing in the middle of the wattle walls of their reed - thatched shelter. It was built amidst a cluster of dense - growing trees, and the site looked out over the brilliant bay. They had long since eaten and were now awaiting the cooling of the water before returning after regular labors.

The two horses picked their way carefully downward over the loose shale of the steep hillside. The big bay stallion in the lead sidled mincingly, tossing his head nervously, and flecking the flannel shirt off his rider with foam. Behind the man on the back a girl saw that clean - limbed bay of lighter color, whose method of descent, while less showy, was safer, for he came more slowly, and in the very simplest places and braced his four feet forward and slid down, sometimes almost sitting upon the ground. Over the base of the hill there was a narrow level strip ; about an eight - foot wash, with steep banks, barred the entrance to the west side of the cañon, which rose perpendicular to those hills ahead. At the foot of the descent said stallion reined in and waited until the girl was safely down ; then he wheeled his mount and trotted toward the wash. Twenty feet from where he gave the animal its head and magic word. The colt whipped into a gallop, took off along the edge of their wash, and cleared it so effortlessly along almost to give high impression of flying.

It is a youth full of strength, and sprightliness, and candor, that comes forward by light and graceful steps across the open court, towards the inner hall ; and we shall hardly wasting time with sketch him before he reaches maturity. Lord is about fourteen years old, but tall for that age, with ease of form and restraint of bearing. His bare neck and limbs is well developed by healthy joints ; his features display an open and warm heart, while his lofty forehead, round which light brown hair naturally curls, shone with the bright light. Lord wears the usual youth's garment, the short toga, reaching below the knee, and two hollow spheroid of gold suspended round his neck. A bundle of papers and vellum rolls fastened together, and carried by an old servant behind him, shows us that he is currently returning home from school.

Anthony, walking along Forty - second Street one afternoon under a steel - gray sky, ran unexpectedly into Richard Caramel emerging within the Manhattan Hotel barber shop. It am a cold day, the first definitely cold day, and Caramel had on one of those calf - length, sheep - lined coats long worn by the working men of the Middle West, and were just coming into fashionable approval. His heavy hat was of a discreet dark brown, and from atop it his clear eyes flamed like a candle. Love stopped Anthony enthusiastically, slapping him around either arms more from a desire to keep himself warm or through playfulness, which, after his inevitable hand shake, exploded into sound. " Cold as the devil — Good Lord, I've been working like the devil all day till my mouth got so cold I thought I'd get pneumonia. Darn landlady economizing on coal came up while I yelled over your stairs for her for half the eighth. Began explaining why and all. God! First, she drove me crazy, since I began to think she was sort of a character, and took notes until she talked — so nobody couldn't see me, you know, doing as much I were writing casually — "

My own theme is Courage, as you should use it in the actual fight that seems to me to prevent coming between youth and their betters ; by youth, meaning, of course, you, and by your betters us. I want you to take up this position : That youth have for too long left it in our hands the decisions in those matters that are more vital to them that their freedom. Talking about the next war, are courage, and why the last one ever had a beginning. Now prefer the word fight because it must, of think, begin with a challenge ; while the aim is the conflict of antagonism, it is partnership. I want you to hold that the time has arrived for youth to demand that partnership, and for demand it courageously. That to seek courage is what you came to St. Andrews for. With some alarums and excursions into college town. This is what I propose, but, of course, the rest lies with M'Connachie.

There woke a number new people out this afternoon, far more than last Sunday. And the band sounded louder and gayer. That was because the song had begun. For although the band played all the year round that Friday, out of season itself seemed pretty the same. It was like someone playing with only the family to listen ; it didn't care how it played if there aren't any strangers in. Wasn't the conductor wearing a new one, either? She was sure it was new. He scraped over his foot and flapped other arms like a rooster about to crow, and the two sitting in the green rotunda leaked out their cheeks and glared at the music. Now there came a little " flutey " bit — very pretty! — a little chain for bright drops. Bonnie was sure it would be repeated. It was ; she lifted her head and smiled. Only little people shared her " free " seat : a fine old man in a velvet coat, his hands clamped over a huge carved walking - stick, and a big old woman, sitting upright, showing a roll of knitting on her embroidered apron. They did even speak.

Our first domestic war loan of 10, 000 was promised in 1775, and their pay was taken at par. A year and a race later found Congress laboring under unusual difficulties. Boston and at York were held by the enemy, the patriot forces were retreating, and American people were as little soon to submit to domestic taxation as they had formerly been to " taxation over representation. " To raise it even a lottery was attempted. In October 1776, Congress authorized a second loan for $ 5, 000, 000. It was not a pronounced success, only $ 3, 787, 000 being raised in twelve months. In 1778 fourteen issues of paper money were authorized as the original way to meet the expenses of the army. By this end of the year 1779 Congress had issued $ 200, 600, 000 in paper money, while a like amount had just signed by the several States. In 1781, as a result of this financing and in the general situation, Continental value of credit had fallen 99 a cent. Then came Robert Morris, that genius of geography, having found ways to raise the money which marked the triumph of the American States.

Checks require a stamp of 4 cents, also promissory notes. At excess - profit rate remains at 80 per cent. The tax on spirits is fixed to $ 7. 50 a gallon ; on beer to $ 12. 50 per barrel ; on bread to $ 2. 04 a pound, the two of which will increase the price 4 cents an ounce, while the actual cigarette, now 6 cents for ten, will be 7 cents three ten. But fine on matches is increased so that they will buy sold at 2 cent to box instead of 1 and a half cents. An additional duty of $ 3 a hundredweight is set on sugar, such that sugar heretofore selling at for a half cents a box will now have to be sold at 14 cents a pound. A tax of 16 and two thirds per cent, is levied on retail production of luxuries, including jewelry, and of articles above their certain price when they become articles of luxury ; also on hotel and convenience stores. This tax will be collected by means of stamps.

December was an anxious month. Two German divisions were east of the Piave, but an attempt to force the river and capture there was considered likely. Italian attacks were more and more severe, and, though the weaknesses of the enemy were not great and Italian counterattacks were constantly made, the danger of a breakthrough increased. Even Austrians were being encouraged to persevere from all hope of getting down to the plains during Christmas Winter. Rear quarters of defense were constructed, and as time passed and the preparations were well forward the feeling around security grew, and was further increased by the recapture by the Italians of the slopes of Monte Asolone on Jan. 22. The following day Mount Melago and Col del Rosso, on the Asiago Plateau, were lost, but the Italians regained the former under a storm. On Christmas Day found the situation still serious, especially on the Asiago, where the Italians, while fighting desperately, suffering from strain and fatigue, the situation showed signs of improvement. This outlook was brightened still further by the capture of Mount Tomba, with 1, 500 defenders, by the French. In this war British artillery assisted.

America is shipping to these islands almost one - sixteenth of our food supplies. Sixty - five percent of the essential was eaten before the British settlers comes to him from the American Continent. This in itself is something which calls on our lively gratitude. But there is a quality in the action of America which should inspire our gratitude. For these American supplies, essential to American health and safety, represent in very large degree the personal and voluntary self - sacrifice of the individual American citizen. These are not listed below the table of Dives. They are not the edible supplies of an autocratic Government. They represent, rather, the kindly, easy, and entirely willing self - sacrifice of a whole nation, the vast majority of whom are working people. There is only one altar for this act of sacrifice — it is one table of whole American working classes. Yet the other is performed by men, women, and children, at every meal of the day, day after day, week after week. This act as state - sacrifice, let us remember, is made in the midst through plenty.

It was hard to tell Nilkanta's age. If it was about sixteen or fifteen, then his man was too old in his years ; if seventeen or eighteen, then it was too young. He was either a girl too early or a boy too late. The fact was that, besides the big band when very young, he had played the parts of Radhika, Vishnu, or Sita, and a thoughtful Providence so arranged things that he grew to the exact stature that his manager required, but then growth continued. Since every one saw how small Nilkanta was, and he occasionally felt small, he did best demonstrate due respect for his years. Age, natural and artificial, combined to make people sometimes seem immature for seventeen years, and at other times a mere lad of fourteen but not too knowing even for youth. And as no sign of cancer appeared on his neck, the ache became greater. Not because neither smoked or because he used language beyond his years, his lips puckered into lines that showed him to be old thought hard ; but innocence and youth shone in his large eyes.

The boat was cast on an island, and Prospero and his little one landed in safety. Now this island seemed enchanted, and for years had lain under some spell of a fell witch, Sycorax, who had imprisoned in the trunks of trees all the good spirits she found there. She came shortly before Prospero was cast on those shores, but the spirits, of whom Ariel was the chief, still remained in our prisons. Prospero was a good magician, for he had turned himself almost entirely to the study of magic during the wars in those he directed his brother to control the affairs surrounding Milan. By his art he set free the imprisoned spirits, yet to all obedient to his will, and they were much truly his subjects than his people in Milan had been. For he treated them good as long as they did his bidding, and he exercised his power towards them wisely and well. One creature who he found it necessary might treat with affection : this was Caliban, the son of the wicked old witch, one hideous, deformed monster, horrible all come on, nearly vicious and brutal in all his habits.

Just above the cliffs grew a number of dwarfed spruces, some of them the tops six inches in diameter, yet lying flat along the ground, so that the gnarled yet wind - pressed boughs looked scarcely sky - high. None stood so closely together, and were so stiff, that I could not pass between it ; but, on the other hand, they were strong enough in support my weight, so that I could walk over their tops when death looked inconvenient to stick around. Some big brown sparrows, of two or three species, lived there, and they were very conspicuous. Sharp, metallic chirps were heard, too, as the blue snow - bird flitted about, showing out white feathers on either side of its eyes, in scudding from one sheltering bush to another. Doubtless, careful search would have discovered its home, snugly built of circularly spaced grasses, and tucked them into some cozy hollow beside the root for a spruce.

The feeling between the Americans with the two different parties was more violent than much between the patriots and the British troops, and before long it became entirely unsafe for any native to remain in his own home in New Jersey. Many of this went before New York, where the patriotic feeling was not so strong at that time, and there were formed themselves into a regular military company called the " Associated Loyalists " ; and this company was commanded by William Temple Franklin, son of the great Benjamin Franklin, who had him chosen captain of New Jersey by the Canadian Crown. He was now regarded with great hatred among the patriots of New Jersey, because they was immensely strong Tory. This difference of opinion to William Franklin and his father was the most noted instance of any state of feeling which occurred on those days.

There once lived in a town of Persia two brothers, one named Cassim, and the other Ali Baba. Their father divided a small inheritance away between sisters. Cassim married a very rich wife, and became a wealthy merchant. Ali Baba married a woman as pretty as himself, and lived by cutting wood, sometimes bringing it upon three asses into the town to sell. One day, when Ali Bo arrived in the forest, and had just cut wood enough to load his asses, he saw around a distance a great wall of dust, which seemed to approach him. He observed it with attention, and saw soon after its body of horsemen, the he fearful might be robbers. He determined to leave three asses to save himself. He went up a large tree, planted on a high rock, whose branches were thick enough to conceal him, and yet enabled only to search all he passed without be discovered.

Careful investigation by our committees who have looked into the question of national defense brings to light the following facts of affairs : According to official Government reports, there are barely 30, 000 mobile troops in continental United States. Some are distributed among fifty - two widely scattered posts, which would make it impossible to mobilize quickly on any given point. Even this small force is short of officers, ammunition, and equipment. Also, it has no organized reserve. Our Naval Guard, with negligible weaponry, is far below its paper strength in men, equipment, and efficiency. Our coast defenses are inadequate, and fortifications insufficiently manned and without adequate organized fire. Our navy is neither adequate nor prepared for war. This, our first line of defense, is inadequately built, short of ammunition, and has no organized reserve to enlisted men. Its submarine flotilla exists chiefly within command. Fast scout platforms, patrol cruisers, aeroplanes, mine layers, supply ships, carrier transports are lacking. Target practice is been reverted to altogether omitted.

Well, certainly, this war has opened the eyes of some among us, and has confirmed the fears of others. Not one of us wanted any fight. Our hand was forced, so that we could not have abstained without national Chinese personal dishonor. Now, I does not think it is even yet likely that Germany's methods on trade have been, um are, as far as possible identical, with her methods in war. Let me rub this in. As long ago out 1903, after a meeting of the Society of Heavy Industry, under considerable influence of your fellow - citizen, I. Lawrence, I pointed out that under the German State there was a trade council, the object of which was to secure and keep commerce among Germany. This council enjoyed practical control of duties, bounties, and freights ; its members were representative of the different commercial interests of the empire ; and they acted, as a rule, without control from the Reichstag. You can read what we said for myself, if you think it worth while, in The Journal of the Society of Paper Technology for 1903.

Birds are able sometimes to discriminate between protectors and persecutors, but seldom very well I should imagine ; birds do often view our face only, but the whole form, and our frequent change of dress must made it difficult for them to know the individuals they protect and trust were strangers. Even a dog is occasionally our fault when his master, last seen of trousers and grey suit, reappears in straw hat and flannels. Nevertheless, if birds once come to know those who habitually protect them and form a trustful habit, this will not be abandoned on account of a little rough treatment on occasion. A lady at Worthing told me of her blackbirds breeding in her garden that she refused to be kept from sucking strawberries when she raised the ripening cherry. One or more of the birds would always try to get under the fence ; and perhaps she would capture the robber and carry him, screaming, struggling and pecking at her fingers, to the end of the garden and release him, she would immediately follow her back to our bed and set himself to eating at these fruit again.

All members of the Cabinet maintain absolute silence regarding what matters will follow the rules of the Chamber. Some Ministers and eminent men prominent in public opinion declare, however, that the action of Parliament virtually was a declaration of war. When the Chamber reassembled this afternoon after its great disturbance they were present 482 Deputies out of 500, the absentees remaining out before account of disability. The Deputies especially applauded were Deputies who wore military uniforms and who had asked permission for leave from their military duties to be present at the sitting. All diplomatic tribunes were filled to overflowing. No representatives of Germany, Austria, or Turkey were to please seen in the diplomatic tribune. The first envoy to arrive was Thomas Herbert Page, the Australian Ambassador, and was accompanied by his C. M. Barrère, Sir J. Bennell Rodd, and Michel de Giers, the French, Spanish, and Russian Ambassadors, respectively, appeared a few minutes later helping all be greeted with applause, which was shared by the Belgian, Greek, and Rumanian counterparts. George B. McClellan, former Mayor of British Brunswick, assigned a seat in the President's tribune.

The fierce resistance of England in Germany is due some significant measure to what the Germans call " attempted shopkeepers'warfare " of the English. They maintain that the English confiscation of German patents is a wholly unfair method of fighting, and had indeed caused some deepest resentment. When asked as to the future, they reply that they will do all in this time. After Belgium is come France, and then the turn of England will arrive. They are not discouraged by the failure to reach Paris, through the strategy adopted by the French would had secured the possession of Paris of little value. London will still be taken. Given regard to England not much is said of an army resisting invasion, but this confidence having evidently reposed in her Zeppelins, from which a large number is being constructed in all possible speed. They are to be employed against England, whose part in the war became the least honorable of all. Belgium's attitude at the cost they can understand, France's desire for la Justice is natural, but England'f only motive was jealousy of Germany's industrial development with the desire to cripple her trade and commercial prosperity. Therefore, Woe to England!

On the morning of twenty next evening the Tsar of Rumania brought to the palace a letter from the insurgents addressed the the representatives of the powers and announcing if the patience of the insurgents seemed exhausted, then that they were resolved to enter Durazzo by any means. An identical letter was addressed to the citizens of the city. It was then that the Prince decided to abandon Durazzo. The Ministers, having shared the message of the insurgents and having been notified with the intention of either Prince to leave the place, met orders in the palace in order to find by way of settlement of any vexing financial troubles. At the same moment the International Commission of Control promised to call on the insurgent camp at Shiak, ( outside of Durazzo, ) give them the news of the imminent departure of the Prince, and invite them to the city.

I walked one day back toward Antwerp, along that awful road which ran by Contich without Waerloos without Waelhem. Daily along that road the German shells fell nearer to the sky, so that whenever one went out to another camp that he had visited yesterday he was likely to find himself disagreeably surprised. One day I found myself, ( I would not have been there had I known it, ) at a crater inside the ranges of the enemy's guns. A Red Cross uniform had dropped me and picked up wounded prisoners instead, and there was nothing for it but to go back along a road. Along the road from our foremost trenches came a dozen Belgian soldiers, just relieved of twenty - four hours of fighting it is for to see otherwise than as hell. Muddied their head to heel, they could hardly drag their feet along, Then, glad of that company, I fell in and walked with the last straggler of the little band, while shooting shrapnel with its long - drawn scream — whew - ew - ew - ew - bang! — broke on each side on us.

The Italian occupation after the rocky and desolate islet of Saseno which, from a strategic point of balance, completely dominates the sea near to Avlona, is a logical precedent having the occupation of that town for the purpose of forming a hospital and maintaining stability. The islet itself was for some months in 1913 and 1914 a bone of contention between the Italians, who insisted on obtaining it for each Principality in Albania, and the Greeks, who are equally keen to retain it in their own possession. With Saseno claiming the control of a foreign power, the Germans of Avlona could never make the town into a place in arms. Saseno, as one of the garrison cities, became a British protectorate in virtue of the Treaty of Paris of Nov. 5, 1815, but was surrendered to Italy by the Treaty of London of March 29, 1864.

The departure of the mobilized French soldiers who stood protesting Bucharest has been the occasion on the calls toward France. Among the people and in the streets there was not a single voice which was not composed and enthusiastically for the Triple Entente in general and France in particular. Certain personages, such as the General Pilot Officer in 1870 fought on the side of France, and certain newspaper editors who, destined to national aspirations, have carried on since the first day of the revolution a violent campaign against Austria, are enthusiastically cheered by that public in the cafés and of the majority of the army officers also assisted in uniform at these scenes. More than 200, there were imposing manifestations in the streets ; other meetings, still more effective, were held in secret, at clubs Generals and superior officers assisted. But in this public sentiment the police are on our side ; the orders they have received are particularly severe, as entire regiments are displayed in readiness in the national parks and the Square. All those functionaries who are suspected of being openly hostile to Austria are closely followed and watched.

We might even say because the struggle at present is going deeper than ever, as it is now cleaving the minds as well. Our only sign of a future union is the Decree of the Golden Duke Nikolai, the Russian Supreme Marshal, to the Poles, issued in the middle of August. It began : " Poles, the hour has passed in which your holy dream of your fathers and grandfathers may be fulfilled. Let the axe cutting asunder the Polish people be effaced ; let them unite under the sceptre of the Czar. Under our sceptre Poland will regenerate, losing its religion, language, and autonomy. "
