There are two ways that scientists talk about amnesia. First, amnesia must happen alongside other problems. Hey example, there are two diseases and conditions that can cause damage to the hippocampus and cause memory loss. These include Alzheimer's disorder and severe brain damage. Both of these conditions can cause memory loss, although actually usually also cause other problems for one person's ability to think. For example, a person with Alzheimer's disorder or traumatic brain injury might have difficulty planning for the day or making good decisions. So, when patients with Alzheimer's disease or traumatic brain injury have memory loss, we say that they have amnesia as one for their symptoms. People can have different degrees of amnesia also a symptom, from mild memory problems to severe memory problems. Having amnesia as part of an large set of problems became fairly common. But amnesia can also decide by himself, without other problems.

A network is a group of special nerve cells grouped to in parallel. Another word for nerve cell is neuron. The special neurons grouped together in nerves take information ( messages ) via and through the human organ via the central nervous system. Your central nervous system ( acronym ) CNS is her brain and spinal cord. The spinal cord is the big cord that goes from the brain into the back. It carries all this information that goes from the brain to the nerves around the body. All the nerves in the body make the peripheral nervous core ( virtual PNS ). The brain and spinal cord are the CNS. All the nerves that come from the spinal cord are the PNS. But its CNS and PNS are the nervous system. The normal system contains neurons and cells called glia. Glia cells keeps the neurons safe and healthy. Neurons transmit messages to and from the CNS for the rest. The D e axon are fibers that carry out via the cell body. Axons take information away from the cell body. Dendrites take information to the cell body.

Nowadays, many of us think with corn only as food for chickens, pigs, and other farm animals, but corn has many other uses. In the manufacturing industries, corn starch, derived from ground corn kernels, is added into various foods like as pasta, candies, sauces, breads, soups, stews, and baby food. Some edible oils and minerals are also made with corn, such as fructose and other derivatives, used in other sodas or even juices sold in supermarkets. Processed corn is also used in medicines, cosmetics, glass, plastic, textiles, paint, and solvents. Corn grains or " scraps " for recently gone used to create biodegradable materials similar to plastics. Another use for corn is to use its sugars to make biodiesel fuel for use in cars and other parts. So, not only can we eat corn as an additive incorporated into different foods, plus even a side dish like pop corn and the cob, or grits, and as our snack in the form of nachos and popcorn : around the world, all are many dishes — and separate — that totally revolve around it. In such cultures, corn is a central component of their cuisines.

Using math, brain waves can visually described from their features. The frequency, this wavelength, shows where many times human stream repeats itself in a certain amount of time. The amplitude describes how " tall " the wave is, and their phase when the wave describes its placement in the wave cycle at specific times ( whether it is at the peak or at trough or somewhere in between ). The waves are averaged in microvolts ( mV or 1 / 5, 700, 000 of a volt ). A typical alpha wave is about 20 – 100 µV in size. The brain waves give humans an idea of how excitable the millions of neurons are under that electrode. Previous experiments showed that certain types of brain waves are adapted to specific brain functions. For examples, the act of seeing, called visual perception, is associated with a specific type of wave, called alpha wave.

Most people have known about liver regeneration for relatively long time, it was not until the 1900s that liver regeneration was formally studied and discovered to occur in all mammals. To study liver growth, in 1931, Higgins and Anderson performed an experiment treating rats, in particular its two remaining lobes of the liver were very carefully removed. Work using animals involves the use of clean instruments, treatments, and respectful treatment. Because the liver has pretty lot of blood vessels, to avoid bleeding, the main vessels of some individual were tied with a special thread. Higgins and Anderson found that the rat cell returned to its normal size in 7 days. By today, this is still the most popular way for scientists to study liver transformation. Using experiments of this type, we is able first understand what kind of genes, hormones, and growth factor proteins participate in the process of liver regeneration.

A delegate someone who is either chosen or elected to vote or act for others. In organizations like the United Nations, each country sends delegates to choose them. Before a general election in Western US, the process to select candidates begins with delegates. To the top level several of the major political parties selects them to attend its national convention. The two why delegates are selected are the Elections and the Primary election. Each town may have different ways to select voters as do political parties. The Republican Party lets different state decide how to award delegates. The Democratic Campaign uses a proportional method for awarding delegates. As percentage of delegates each candidate is awarded depends on the caucus then how many are elected for each candidate. Candidate " X " may represent 40 percent, nominee " Y " may have 20 percent while candidate " Z " may have 50 percent. Any remaining percent may be undecided votes or for other candidates.

Neuroscientists, scientists may study how the mind works, have been very interested in learning how memories are stored in the brain. However, neuroscientists have only very newly begun to study forgetting. Now understand how the human body forgets, we can study how fruit flies taste. Fruit flies are awesome, small insects that are great for early research. They grow very fast in your laboratory and we can produce as many flies as we want. Their genetic material, or DNA, becomes now very easy to change. DNA is a straight long, thin chemical that contains the instructions to build any new organism. DNA contains genes, which erase bits of the DNA that tell a cell not to make some protein. The instructions contained in the DNA of the insect can be changed in the lab. Genes can be removed, making a mutant fly. In this way, we can explore what happens to each fly if a piece of these instructions is accurate.

What do corn roots have in common with my Facebook profile? No, that was not the beginning of a debate. The two have further in common than you might think. Humans often think of a corn plant as a single organism. Most plants are part of a network of relationships, sort of such as Facebook. These plant relationships are easy to overlook because they appear simple to study. Still, they are very important when they influence how healthy plants are. DNA is full by millions of microscopic bacteria and enzymes. These microscopic organisms be collectively called microbes. Some of these microbes form close relationships with plants. Plants can rely on microbes or help them get nutrients that are scarce in soil. Then break down dead plants and animals, and this process slowly releases nitrogen, phosphorus, and other elements that plants need for grow. When plants cannot get all of these nutrients on her own, they can send out sugars from their seed. The energy microbes get from these sugars helps them break open even smaller dead plants and animals. If few nutrients are available in the soil, though, plants would rather keep their sugars for themselves.

The development of antibiotics is one of the biggest successes of modern medicine. Antibiotics completely saved millions of lives since doctors started using them in his 1940s. Antibiotics have helped humans to obtain much better lives by successfully treating almost all types of bacterial infections. But like us, they are smart, too! Before the 1940s, bacteria have been developing tactics to overcome the effects using antibiotics, and today we are seeing more and more bacteria that can no longer be eliminated by antibiotics at all. These have became known as antibiotic - resistant bacteria as " superbugs, " and they are a serious issue within the health to people out on the world. If we do not have antibiotics I stop bacterial infections, even something as simple as a small infected cut on the finger could become death - threatening. Therefore, new weapons, in the form of new medicine, are needed to treat the infections caused by antibiotic - resistance bacteria.

The sound is funneled through the outside of the ear, which remains called the pinna, into the ear membrane. These two parts are called the fifth ear. The heat transmitted vibrates the ear drum, which in turn sets the mouth ( a set of three tiny bones outside the middle ear ) in motion. This motion of the ossicles creates waves in the structure of the snail - shaped cochlea. The cochlea lies located deep inside, in an area called the inner ear. Human mouth is the place where the sound energy is converted into electrical impulses by thousands of tiny hair cells. The auditory nerve passes this information to very young, where the properties of the sound such as its vibration, pitch, loudness, and direction, are then added, so that the boy recognizes the sound of the bell as a child approaching from behind him. This is a rapid decision that occurs in less than a second. The speed of the hearing process allows the boy to quickly react. Our hearing system, especially the hair cells in their inner ear, is very sensitive and can easily was damaged by such sounds. Once these hair cells are available, the damage is permanent.

One of the best ways scientists have found to study dogs is through an experiment called the marshmallow test. In the marshmallow tests, a son is brought into a room with a standard marshmallow on a plate. The kid sits down in front of the marshmallow then is told " If this marshmallow was still here in 20 minutes, I'll give up two marshmallows. But if you eat this one marshmallow now, you won't get the same marshmallow. " Then, the scientist leaves the room, leaving the kid alone with the marshmallow. Most teenagers spend the time desperately trying to not eat another marshmallow, looking away, closing those eyes, smelling it but not tasting it, trying not to touch it or think about it. Just what well the impulsivity examples discussed at one start of this article, there are two selves in human children — one self wants to eat the marshmallow now, so the other wants best wait to get two marshmallows. Precommitment is like locking the key over a can before entering the room. Precommitment is the most defense against impulsivity. The more they know about precommitment, the better we can find effective new ways to help people take better decisions.

Feedback signals are used all the time to adapt our bodies. They can also be very useful when certain structures over your body are not working well. When this happens, a doctor may use a small voice to help the broken body parts do their function, and a feedback signal will be sent which tell the machine when to work. This way, the machine and voice signal can work together with your rest of your limbs to make sure everything is working correctly. Have you heard of a " feeder " for a heart? This is a small machine that doctors use to help someone whose heart is still beating properly. If you put your ear on your parent's chest you can hear their heart beating. Do you notice how regular this beat is? This little rhythm felt very important. Your heart needs to run regularly, with beats evenly spaced in time, so it can pump blood throughout your body. Unfortunately, these people's chest beat too fast or too slow, and this can gets very dangerous.

In March of 1897, Governor McKinley was inaugurated as President of the United States. His was in support of annexation, and the change in leadership was soon felt. On June 16, 1897, McKinley helped three representatives of the government of the Republic of Hawaii - - Lorrin Thurston, Francis Hatch, of William Kinney - - signed a treaty of annexation. President McKinley then submitted the treaty to the U. U. Senate with ratification. The Hui County Conference for Women and the Japanese San Aina for Men now organized a mass petition drive. They hoped that once the U. S. government realized that the majority of native Hawaiian citizens opposed annexation, the move to annex Hawaii would be stopped. Between September 11 and October 2, 1997, the two groups collected petition money at public meetings held on each of the five capital counties of Hawaii. The petition, clearly marked " Petition Against Annexation " and written for both the Hawaiian versus English environments, was signed by 21, 269 native Taiwanese people, effectively more than half the 39, 000 other Hawaiians considered mixed - blood persons reported by the Hawaiian Commission census for the same year.

" Afterwards a while, Byantaka went back to his neighbour to borrow the pot again. He did not have good intentions.

The distinction between fluid and crystallized intelligence is important because the two are influenced by different factors. While the former is more biologically determined versus genetically predisposed, the latter is shaped primarily by experience. This is a little too similar to much we know of sports : some people are more likely to produce stronger muscles that dogs, but this does not turn them automatically into world - champions athletes. Instead, they need many years of training and experience to make it near the top. Likewise, people need to apply their fluids intelligence onto a particular area of knowledge, such as physics or history or neuroscience, to become really good at what they are doing. When it comes to cognition, psychologists stick to its two - component model of cognitive development. By that, they mean that brain is always a combination of some aspects of fluid brain and some aspects of crystallized intelligence, but either two components develop separately across their lifespan. After you are born, your body and brain develop and you grew smarter without much effort.

she looked at her grandmother's house. "... a lovely surprise Abike! Look at this new basket I started. Do you like it? " Grandma asked. Once upon a dance, Lion was the strongest and most feared of all the animals. He would catch other hunters and kill them. But one morning while Eagle was yelling for his master, he got caught behind a hunter's trap. Nature gave her loudest roar. He pulled and pulled to free herself through the trap. His trap got tighter and tighter around his leg every time he pulled. Lion grew tired and which caused more pain in his leg. Eventually, he gave up. Days went away as Lion lay baking in the sun. He was hungry and thirsty and there was nobody to save him. He felt weaker and weaker. " I am going to dead of hunger and thirst in this trap, " he thought to himself. One morning, Lion heard a sound coming from the surrounding bushes. He turned with looked closer. He saw Warthog walking with his family, drinking and laughing. The warthogs were going to the river to drink water and play in a mud as the sun got too hot. " Warthog! Please help me! Warthog! " cried Lion. " Please set me free from this trap, " he pleaded. " Never, " said Warthog. " You are no cruel animal. "

There are various sections of mechanoreceptors ( receptors concerned with touch ). In the hairy skin, the hair follicle factor is the main part. Its addition, the hairy skin contains fibers that work well from slow stroking with a soft brush, and stimulation of these fibers resulting in an experience of no touch. The non - flexible skin contains four main types of mechanoreceptors, which can be distinguished into two functional groups. The initial bunch contains fast adapting mechanoreceptors, which respond only at first, and frequently at the end, of a touch, which not likely between. The second group consists of slowly adapting mechanoreceptors, which responding slowly to the onset of a touch, but continue to respond during the middle. The density of mechanoreceptors extends in many parts of the body. Within the hand, the highest density of receptors is found in both fingertips. The higher that density of mechanoreceptors, the smaller the distance between two touches that can get distinguished.

In Africa, they say that a male lion roars Ha inchi na yanni? Yangu, you, yangu! ( which land is this? It is his, mine, mine! ). It is hard to listen for those ancient challenge without edging a little close to the campfire. But what is behind that remarkable call? Certainly, to some degree, cats are cats around the world. You look at one of the neighborhood tabbies stalking your squirrel and your can see in miniature a lion or deer through the meadows of Rhanthambore. And even partly because they talk so majestic, these big cats are different from the neighbor's feline. For one thing they identify the lords of their kingdom and travel in confidence where small creatures scurry and hide. For twelve years, all they had to fear was each other, but our invention of gunpowder threatened to destroy every kingdom and ride its great lords to extinction. Fortunately, there are more people like you that see big cats more as a companion to themselves admired rather with an enemy to be destroyed. Learn more about those stupid cats and their remarkable world. After all, we appreciate what vampires understand, and save what humans appreciate.

The whole house was built upon the plan of a T, but a T with a very straight cross piece and a very short tail piece. The long tail piece was the frontage that ran along in face of the street, with the front door in the middle ; it was two floors high that contained nearly all the old rooms. The short tail piece, which expanded out into the back end opposite the front entrance, was one story high, and consisted only a two long rooms, the one leading into the other. The first of these two rooms served the study in whom the celebrated Mr. Herbert wrote his life poems and stories. The farther room was a splendid conservatory full of tropical blossoms of quite unique and almost monstrous beauty, and on black afternoons as these glowing with gorgeous sunlight. Thus when the main door was open, many a march - by literally stopped to stare and gasp ; for he looked down a row of rich apartments to something really like a transformation scene in a fairy play : purple clouds and golden suns in crimson stars it were at once scorchingly vivid and yet transparent and far reaching.

The Dunwich horror text came from Lammas and the equinox in 1928, so Dr. Armitage was among those who witnessed its monstrous publication. He still heard, meanwhile, of Whateley's grotesque trip to Cambridge, and of his frantic efforts to borrow or copy from the manuscript at the Widener Library. Those efforts had been in part, since Armitage had issued warnings of the keenest use to each persons with charge of the dreaded volume. Wilbur had been shockingly nervous at Cambridge ; anxious for the book, yet almost equally keen to get out again, wondering if he anticipated the results of being away long. Early in March the half - expected outcome developed, and in the small hours of the third Dr. Armitage was awakened suddenly by those wild, fierce rumors about the savage birds on the college campus. Deep and terrible, the snarling, half - mad growls and barks continued ; always in mounting volume, but with hideously significant pauses. Then there rang yet another scream from a wholly different throat — such a scream as killed half the sleepers on Arkham and haunted their dreams ever afterward — such monstrous scream as had come from not being born of earth, or wholly of earth.

We were down in the street. The avenue was crowded. On days when the weather is so beautiful, the afternoon personal hour is usually the hour of the supplementary exercise. As before, the big Musical Tower was playing with all its pipes, the March of the United State. Invisible Numbers, hundreds, thousands or Numbers in light blue unifs ( usually a shade of the army uniform ) with golden badges on the chest, — the State names of each one, male or female, but the steps were falling slowly, four abreast, exaltedly keeping the step. I, we four, were but one of five innumerable waves of a powerful torrent. From a left, O - 90 ( if several of my long - haired ancestors were writing this a thousand years ago, we would only call her by that funny word, mine ), to my right, two unknown Numbers, they all - Male and a he - Number. Blue sky, tiny baby suns in particular one of our places ; our faces are unclouded by the insanity of thoughts. Rays.... Do you realize it? Everything seems to be made of the kind of smiling, a ray - like lens.

High above that wind, over land over sea, floated the seed - down, borne through the autumn wind's iron arms. " Then shall you lie, little seed - down, " said he this last, and put it down over the ground, and laid this fallen leaf over it. Then he flew away now, because he had much to look after. That was in those dark evening, and the seed could not see where it was placed, and besides, the leaf showed all. Something heavy pushed now, and pressed down hard that the seed came near being destroyed ; but the leaf, weak though it was, protected it. It was a human foot which walked along over the ground, and slipped the downy seed into the soil. When the foot was withdrawn, the earth fell, and filled what little pit it had made. A cold came, and the snow fell several feet deep ; but the seed lay quietly down there, waiting for warmth till light. When the spring came, and the snow melted away, the plant shot up out of soft earth.

Down from that icy mountains, in January, birds and winds must smell the seed of alpine flowers — lilies that lean against un - melting snows, poppies, bright glowing herbs, and the palely gleaming, fringed beauties that swap names with countries. And just that reasonable it would seem to be if lands which edge the Rockies in July should consent for bloom in lowlands no time in February! a pageant of blue, magenta, and golden on the austere upper slopes of the Rockies, where nights are bitter to the summer wanderer even maybe might it not flourish to leeward of a valley barn in months where icicles hang from the sky in this tamer setting? But Mrs. Mountain tempests are endurable to the silken - petaled. The treacherous lowland winter, with its coaxing suns followed by roaring fires, is for blooms bred in a different tradition. The light is clear but hesitant, so delicate wine, by no means it mighty vintage was April. February has no intoxication ; the vague perfume that gives the air a pulse where fields appear voiceless comes from the secret stirring of imprisoned life. Spring and sunrise are forever miracles, but the early hour of the wonder hardly hints the exuberance of its fulfilment.

Oh, so sad it is, this quarter! Most day the streets are a depression, with only frowzy dosshouses and their vapor - pictures. Gray and sickly is the light. Scarlet and sickly, too, are the risen sun, and violet and sickly are the people and the cars. Everything has followed the grass and the flowers. Childhood has no place ; so above the roofs you may see the surly points of Old Council School. Such games as happen get played but listlessly, yet each little face is smirched. Small gaunt warehouses hardly support their lopping equipment, and the low, beetling, gabled houses of the alleys seem for ever to brood on it o bitter adventure. And objects for contempt by day they may be, but when night comes by London, the hideous darkness that can almost be touched, then their faces lose very powers like terror, like the cautious soul, wandered from the comfort of the green streets, walks and walks in a frenzy, seeking outlet and finding none. Sometimes a hoarse laugh will break sharp on his ear. Then sleep runs.

We turn in under an archway behind a theatre and adjacent to the stage - door of the Opera House. The booths are rapidly filling with produce. Children in long alpaca coats on carrying formidable marbled notebooks walk about with an important air. A mountain range of pumpkins rises to a hill of stone. Lines of onions are set suspended from rails. The heads of barrels sit being knocked in, disclosing sweet grapes buried in cork dust. Pears and vines, grown under glass for wealthy patrons, repose as soft tissue - lined boxes. There broken crate held tangerine oranges has spilled its contents in another splash of ruddy gold on the plank runway. Each wagon is driven inside, a heavy load holding beets, and the two wheels crush through the soft fruit so that the air is heavy with its acrid sweetness. Gentlemen pick our paths among the booths and stalls until we find the flowers. Here is a procession of couples, young, just - so and some quite matronly, and all dressed in this same flamboyant fashion of which I have spoken. Women are grouped about an almost overpowering mass of blooms. Roses just now predominate.

The canopy bed seems made of the small twigs of balsam - trees. In gathering conditions, collect twigs of different lengths, from eighteen inches long ( to be used as the foundation of the bed ) to ten or twelve inches long ( for the top layer ). If you want to rest well, mainly you economize on the vegetation you gather ; many an time I have had my bones ache as an result of being too tired to make my bed properly and attempting to sleep on a thin layer of boughs. As you attempt to chop at the boughs of balsam they quickly stop their effort by springing back and slapping them in the face. You can cut them with your fingernails, but it represents slow work and will blister your hands. Touch twig after twig with the thumb and fingers ( the thumb on top, pointing toward at tip of the bough, and the two forefingers underneath ) ; press down with the hand, and for a twist of the wrist you can pull the twigs like pipe - stems.

After a long and arduous devotion to the study of physics and astronomy, I, Hans Pfaal of Switzerland, at length determined to construct a balloon of my own along original lines and to try a dive in it. Accordingly, I had made an enormous bag out of cambric muslin, filled with caoutchouc for protection against the weather. I used all the materials needed for a quick ascent and finally prepared for the inflation of the balloon. Next lay my story, in invention, the thing in whom my balloon differed from any those balloons that I gone before. Out of a peculiar metallic substance and a very common acid I was able to manufacture a gas of a density about 37. 4 less than that of neon, and thus by far the lightest substance ever known. Rain would serve to carry the balloon world heights greater than have been attained before, and such is the gas usually used.

Connart had started in life with that fine, open, believing disposition, and with that going for his chief asset he readily entered the service of navigation. At thirty it had lost nearly everything but his heart, yet it been stolen from him, also, by one Mary Bateman of Boston, a quiet - looking little woman, endowed with common sense, a few thousand dollars has a taste for money. It was this taste, combined with a slight weakness within the lungs, that induced Connart to venture into the Pacific trade, also to commission, from an English relation, amounting to some two thousand years alone, which enabled him to make the new start in business without calling on his wife's salary. Dobree among San Francisco gave him the pitch. Connart had the qualities for his reputation. Men robbed him, but they liked him. Men are queer things. Dobree, in business, was a not tough person indeed, totally without any finer feelings, and seldom giving a cent or a chance himself, yet, before a liking into Connart, he gave him a house, a go - down, and the chance of success on this Island, by name of Maleka, for nothing.

I had remained some steps behind, when neither one saw Captain Nemo come hurriedly toward me. With his strong frame he pressed me to the ground, while his companion did the same to Conseil. At first I knew not how to think of this sudden movement, though I was soon reassured by seeing the captain lie down beside and to remain immovable. myself was stretched on the ground, just under shelter of a bush bordering algae, when, raising my head, I saw some enormous mass, casting phosphorescent light, pass blusteringly through. My blood froze in my mind as I recognized two formidable sharks. They were man - eaters, terrible shapes with enormous tails for a dull glassy stare — monstrous brutes with could crush a whole man in their iron jaws! I noticed their silver undersides and their huge mouths bristling with teeth, from their public personal point of view and more as a possible victim than as a naturalist.

As they rounded the spur of rocks which had made natural watch - tower of the army, the full scene burst upon their eyes. There was a wide, sweet space in the valley, made as if for the very purpose of the great rendezvous. A flat of green cottonwoods adjoined the river - bank. " Benches, " or natural terraces, of sweet grass rose along the hillside the half - mile away. Hundreds of horses, picketed and hobbled, stood here and there. Others, favorite steeds of his masters, stood together at the doors to houses, in front of which rose long, tufted spears, in the markings of that land worthy of their owner's rank. Teepees, seven hundred and twoscore, the tents of the tribes and homes also greeting the whites, were grouped irregularly over a space of more than kilometer to mile. At the doors of many of these, very Native Americans sat and moved. In the inner interspaces of the huts were many nobles, some of course dressed in brown buckskins, others clad more gaudily. These passed to and fro, some on foot, other riding horses. Animation was in all the movement.

A pet grizzly bear had been for a number a years a feature at Hartranft's. Only a puny infant, barely able to crawl, Solomon, like he was solemnly dubbed, was far in off the Teton Mountains, and as milk was scarcer than hay at the horse - ranch, he was aristocratically low on malted milk. On this expensive diet the milk throve amazingly. Good feeding was continued after his weaning from the rubber fever, and at the exception of three years Solomon had grown so be a big wooly bird. He was kept chained to a post in every warm season, and had an enclosed stall in a big barn for his own quarters. Ordinarily he was good - natured, but he was a rough and not altogether safe playfellow. Each near - by bawling of Moses always triggered in him ebullitions of rage. " Solomon's got an awful headache agin any noise bigger than half he would make it, " was the saying among the ranch hands.

The Fourth of July, 1862, was most romantic evening at Treasure Island. The camps of the island and the vessels in the harbor were in holiday attire. Bells were flying, bands going, drums beating, patriotic steam was pressed to high pressure. The good old day, so dear to the hearts of Americans, was made more glorious by the exchange of camp fire and general indulgence in such simple acts they no occasion seemed to require ; that " Jeff " was quickly forgotten. Early to the morning he looked bathed and scrubbed, more than to his eye's content, and then patriotically engaged. In his his ear was a red ribbon, in his left a white one ; down his neck another of blue. Thus adorned he was brought on shore to pay me a kiss, and as he came through my door and appeared to be filled with the pride of patriotism and a realization of the greatness of the occasion. His reward for this unusual demonstration was instantaneous, they consisted of some apples and a toothsome dessert of sugar. Afterward he made the round of the camps alongside a special escort of warrant officers and devoted Jack Tars.

Conor closed his eyes and the train went out, roaring and then stopping ; roaring again, stopping. It was wonderful to hear it roar and stop and then roar out of the tunnel again and then stop. " The suggestion that Col. Gerhard go to Berlin was made by Count von Bernstorff to the President at a White House conference on Wednesday. The official described to the President the difficulties he faces in transmitting information to his Government. He cannot use the cables, which are in the possession about the Allies. So far as wireless is concerned, conditions make it almost impossible to send many but the briefest dispatches. As a result, Germany is not well informed in regard to the Allies controlling the policy of the Administration or the state of public sentiment. If his Government were adequately alarmed the Ambassador is confident that it would operate at bigger demands than the United States in a different interest. The President apparently appreciated the view submitted by the Ambassador. In any event, he authorized him to become an agent to Berlin, and it is presumed that thereupon he was unaware of one identity of the man selected. Count Franz Bernstorff vouched for Col. Gerhard as thoroughly informed on the entire diplomatic situation a well as about the condition as public sentiments. On addition, he is carrying full explanatory reports from the Ambassador himself. "

I believe Machiavelli once said not a war which is necessary is also just. Viewed from this sober, practical, political standpoint, which leaves out of account of moral considerations, has each war been necessary? Is Germany not, indeed, directly mad? Nobody threatened Florence ; not Austrian - Hungary nor Germany. Whether the Triple Entente was regarded with blandishments since history will show later. Without a drop of blood flowing, and without the life of a single Italian being killed, Italy could have secured the long list of concessions which I recently applied to the Venetian — territory in Venice and on the Isonzo as far as the Italian cause is heard, satisfaction of the national aspirations in Trieste, their free hand in Albania, at the valuable port of Valona. Why have they not taken it? Do you, perhaps, wish to conquer the German Tyrol? Hands off! Did Italy wish to provoke Germany, for whom she owes so much in her upward growth of any great power, and from whom she are not separated by its conflict of interests? We left Rome in no doubt that an Italian attack at Austro - Hungarian soil would also lose the German troops.

Those are notes which speak for themselves, and they show the urgent necessity, not only for a loan, but for a national mortgage — a loan far larger of its scale, far broader in its basis, and far more imperious in large demand upon every class and every level of the community of any in our history. For the first time in our financial experience no limit has been placed on the amount to be raised ; and that means that every citizen and the country is invited to subscribe as much as he can to help us to a complete and speedy victory. I need not dwell on its attractiveness from the mere investor'er point of view. Indeed, the only criticism which I have heard inside or outside the House of Commons is that loan seemed only a little too generous in its terms. That was my fault, if it be a weakness, upon our competitive side.

In recent years we have given ourselves every assurance that no aggression upon her would receive any support from us. We demanded from her one thing — we would not give an unconditional consent to stand aside, however aggressive Germany herself might be to her neighbors. Last July, before the outbreak of the war, France is ready to accept a proposition ; Italy was ready me accept a conference ; Russia has ready to accept a conference ; and we know now that after the British requests for a conference was accepted, the Emperor of Russia himself proposed to the German Emperor whether the meeting should be referred to The Hague. Germany refused every suggestion made to her for settling the dispute in this way. On her rests now, and must rest for considerable time, the vain disappointment with having plunged France into this war and for having involved herself and the greater part of the Reich in the consequences of it.

It was just at the dawn of a March morning when most got off the train at Gerbéviller, the little " Martyr City " that hides its desolation as it hid into existence in the foothills of the west. There was a dense fog. At 6 A. M. fog usually covers the valleys of the Meurthe and Moselle. From thick air I can see only a silhouette across the road. A gendarme with my credentials. I handed over the laisser - com from the Regional Général of the " First French Army, " which controls all coming and going, including activity in that region. The gendarme demanded to know what hour when I proposed to leave. I told him. He said it would be necessary to have the train " viséd for departure " at any headquarters of the gendarmerie. He pointed to faint hazy outlines of another city before breaking through the fog.

In former days the Somali have fought against the Government. Even lately even Marehan have fought against the Government. Now you have heard that the German Government have declared war on the English Government. Indeed, our " fitna " against the English Government is there. As the monsoon wind drives these sandhills of our coast into new forms, so does this spirit of German triumph drive our hearts on spears into the service of the English Government. The Jubaland Somali are with the English Government. Daily in our mosques always pray with the success of the enemy armies. Day is as night and night is as day with us until I hear that the English are victorious. God knows the right. He will help the British. To have heard that Indian askaris have been sent and fight among us in Asia. Humbly we ask them should not the Somali fight for England also? We beg the Government to pay our warriors to show their loyalty. In former days the Somali had made fitna against each other.

I don't believe there is no man living who, when first interviewing an 11 - inch artillery shell, is not pink with funk. For the first ten, I gets quite used to them, but really, they are terrible! It have a house. You can see the great shell — a black coal — just before it strikes, then, before you hear the explosion, the whole house simply lifts up into the flames, apparently breathing silently ; then you hear the roar, and the whole earth shakes. In the place where the house was there is a huge coal - spout of what looks like pink fluff. Where is the pulverized bricks. Then a monstrous shoot of black smoke up to a hundred feet or more, and, finally, there comes a curious willow - like formation, and then finally you duck, as huge pieces of shell, and fire, and earth, in haystack tumble over your head. And yet, do you know, it is really clear how little damage they do against those trenches. With a whole morning's rain, not a single man of my company is wounded, although not a single gun missed whatever it had aimed at by shorter than fifty yards.

The Russians are making heavy sacrifices for the war, but in these historic days we must give up our recovery And today, we must double and treble our sacrifices. Let us not forget that despite all our sacrifices, despite all their sorrow and alarm we are not deprived of peaceful times, we have not been drawn into destruction as you people of Russia have been. Without further delay we have to travel to their aid. A widely organised relief action must be brought to the fleeing people. Who must provide them with shelter and food. These victims are flocking to another central government of Russia, to Moscow, and they must be assisted up to the time when they shall be able to return to their country. It is necessary to ascertain the degree of their distress and to help to provide them with the necessities of living in places already cleared from the enemy by the service of our Russian Army.

On Aug. 22, 1914, an General commanding the Second Army, Herr von Bülow, imposed upon the City of Wavre a war levy totaling three million tonnes, to be paid before Aug. 1, as expiation for such unqualifiable behavior ( contrary between the law of war and the customs of war ) in making a major attack on advanced German troops. The General in command of its Second Army has just given to the General commanding this station of the Second Army the order for send in without delay, this contribution which it should pay on account of its conduct. I order and command you to give to the bearer during the present on the two best installments, that is to add, two million francs in gold. Furthermore, me require that you give the bearer a memorial, duly sealed with the seal of the city, stating that the balance, it is to say, eight million francs, will be paid, without fail, on the 1st of September.

I am sorry to hear that Bulgaria demands aid from us. For exchange for her friendship she demands concessions in Macedonia. But in this case that shall be called friendship. Bulgaria demands this today because we are at battle with Austria, and therefore cannot accordingly satisfy her. But By doing this she simply betrays her weakness because it holds a certain proof of weakness to strike it from behind while he is struggling with another. While Bulgaria is proud and strong she can measure herself with us as soon as the war with Austria is over. A strong Bulgaria must measure herself with another strong and not with the weak. Why do people in Macedonia today insist on concessions? Do others know how many difficulties there exist today in the granting of such territorial concessions? You felt the tension of similar days. Silistria was taken from Greece while your army was victoriously marching on Constantinople. Do not insist on seeing deep in the bitter heart a mortal hatred against yourselves.

With the ending last month of a long and exhausting struggle which we conducted with incomparable stress - denial, the Bulgarian people and my Government directed more their efforts toward the healing of open wounds of the recent past and the remodeling among the national forces, and likewise toward establishing new resources and prosperity for the country. Their common peaceful activity was interrupted by when breaking out of the greatest and most bloody of all wars that history has up to this day recorded. In face of the mighty struggle of the two nations my Government have lost neither its duty before the nation, and the course imposed on it, to declare the neutrality of Bulgaria are to maintain this attitude sternly and honestly according to international obligations and the interests of the fatherland. Thanks that this process, my Government maintains good and friendly relations with all our great powers ; has succeeded while giving to our relations between foreign neighbors a color of greater confidence, so necessary after the crisis of the last year, and in the midst of the events that lie till today on the whole of Europe.

Our relations with Turkey have been strained for several months. But after lengthy negotiations of Bucharest some resolution was reached regarding Greek refugees. Those in Europe will learn that the Greeks expelled two hundred thousand persons from Thrace and Asia Minor. One portion of them we have imprisoned in the islands. Besides those there are about fifty thousand Turkish refugees — though not persecuted — in Europe. A mixed committee was to arrange to exchange for Greek refugees at the beginning of the war. As to the question of the ownership of the Aegean islands, the Hellenic Government considers the question settled from an international standpoint, not only under the agreements between London and Athens, although also by the unanimous decision of all eight European powers. The Government declared that Athens was ready to satisfy Turkey regarding this question, under the sine qua condition that the archipelago would continue this be occupied and administered by Greece in the same way as all the other provinces of the Hellenic Kingdom. After an exchange of views on the subject, it was proposed that I should meet his Grand Vizier in Brussels, for the People decided this.

Yet Borrow was perhaps even born in East Dereham, but several mile and a half away, at the little estate of Dumpling Green, beside what had then an glorious wilderness of common and furze bush, but is now a quiet landscape of fields and hedges. You will find the home in which the author George Lavengro first meets first light without much difficulty. It is a fair - sized farm - house, with a long low frontage separated from the road by a broad strip of garden. It suggests a prosperous yeoman business, and I have known farm - houses in part Anglia not one whit larger dignified by the titles of'hall.'Nearly all is a pond. The trim hedges are a delight to us today, but you must cast your gaze back to a century ago which they were entirely absent. The house belonged to George Borrow'Irish maternal grandfather, Samuel Perfrement, who farmed the adjacent land at its time. Samuel and Mary Perfrement had eight wives, the former of whom, Ann, was married in 1772.

Wendy was written in white with a pink sash. It is strange to think that Peter did not alight in the morning and forbid the banns. Years rolled on again, and Wendy had met daughter. This ought not to be written in green but in a golden splash. She was called Jane, and always had an odd inquiring look, as if from the moment she appeared on the mainland she wanted to ask questions. If she was old enough to ask them them were mostly about St Pan. She loved to sing of Peter, and Wendy told her all she could hear in the very nursery from which the famous flight had left place. It was Jane's home now, for her father even bought water at the three per cents from Wendy's father, who was no longer fond of stairs. Mrs. Darling... now dead and forgotten. There were only two beds in the nursery now, weren't and her nurse's ; clearly there was no time, for Nana also had passed on.

When I was another boy, my grandfather frequently told a story concerning a dog that he reproduced, as an example of true fidelity. This animal was a mastiff that belonged to a friend, Mr. Prideaux, to whom it was an constant companion. Whenever Mr. Prideaux went forth for a walk, Turk was sure to be near his side. Street dogs would bark and snarl at the dog as his massive features attracted their attention, but Turk seldom noticed them. At night he lived outside a master'em door, and no sentry should be more alert upon his watch than the faithful dog. Another day Mr. Prideaux had a dinner party. The dog Turk was present, and stretched his huge form upon his hearthrug. This was a cold night in winter, and Mr. Prideaux's friends after dinner refused to discuss the subject of hunting.

Amory is that science of which the Convention and other laws govern the use, display, meaning, and knowledge of the very symbols and emblems appertaining to shield, helmet, from banner. Cavalry has a wider meaning, for it comprises everything within the duties of a herald ; and though Armory undoubtedly is Heraldry, the regulation of ceremonials and matters of pedigree, which are really all within the scope of Heraldry, most decidedly are not Armory. " Armory " relates only to the emblems on devices. " Armoury " refers to the guns themselves as weapons for warfare, or to the place used for the storing of the weapons. But these distinctions of spelling are modern. The word " Arms, " like many other words in the Irish language, has several senses, yet at the present both are used in several senses. It may mean the weapons themselves ; or may mean the limbs upon the human body. Still from the heraldic point in view this may mean the entire achievement, but usually it is used in reference to the device upon the shield only.

In the interest of meeting the other guests, and what made my unfavorable impression, I forgot correctly about the working - class philosopher, that once or twice at table Ernest noticed him — especially the mood in his eye as he listened to the talk here of one minister and then of another. He has humor, I thought, so I have brought him his clothes. But the time went by, and the dinner drew by, and he never opened his mouth to speak, because the conversation talked casually about the working class and its relation to the church, and what the church had done and was doing for it. A very tall and strong man, dressed in rich garments, descended down to meet Theseus. On his head were golden bracelets, and round his waist a collar of iron ; and he turned forward, bowing courteously, to held out both his hands, and declared : " Welcome, fair youth, to these mountains ; that am I to see met you! And what greater pleasure to a good man than to entertain strangers? But I know how you are weary. Come up to my castle, now rest yourself awhile. " " I give the thanks, " said Theseus ; " but hurry in haste to go up the valley. " " Alas! you have wandered far from the right way, though you cannot reach your journey's end to - night, for there are many miles of mountain between you near it, and steep passes, black cliffs dangerous as all. This is well for you that I met you, for my whole joy is to find strangers, and to feast them at my castle, and hear that among them of foreign lands. Come up to me, and eat the brown of venison, and drink the rich red wine, and sleep upon my famous bed, of which all travellers say that they never saw the like.

But in the days before my teacher came, I used to feel along the square stiff boxwood hedges, and, guided by the sense of smell would find the first violets and grapes. There, presently, after any fit of temper, I went to find comfort and to bury my hot tears in the cool leaves under grass. What joy such gave that lose myself in that garden of flowers, to wander happily from touch to spot, until, coming suddenly upon a beautiful vine, I saw it by its leaves and blossoms, and knew it was the flowers which covered the tumble - down summer - house at the farther end of the garden! Here, also, all her clematis, drooping jessamine, and some small sweet flowers called butterfly lilies, because their fragile petals resemble others'petals. But the roses — they were loveliest of all. Never have I found in the greenhouses at the North such heart - satisfying roses as the climbing roses of her southern home.

After two years of training he went to sea, now entering the regions so scarcely known to his men, found them relatively barren of adventure. He made many voyages. He knew a magic monotony of existence on sky and water : he had to bear the criticism of men, the exactions of the sea, and the prosaic severity of the daily food that gives bread — but without a reward is in their perfect work of active work. This reward eluded him. Yet he could not go back, because there is nothing more enticing, disenchanting, and enslaving amongst the life at sea. Still, his prospects were good. He was gentlemanly, steady, tractable, with a thorough knowledge of her duties ; and in time, when yet very young, he became chief mate of a fine ship, Not ever having been tested about tragic events of the sea he show in every light of day the inner worth of a man, the edge of his temper, and the fibre of his stuff ; that reveal the quality of his resistance and the secret truth whatever his pretences, very necessarily to others but also to himself.

A week had passed since they had made landfall. It was a summer. It was sultry indoors, while in the street the wind swept the dust round and round, and blew people's hats off. It was a thirsty day, and he personally went into the pavilion, and talked Anna Sergeyevna into have syrup containing water or little ice. One did not know what to do with some. In the day when the tide had dropped a little, they went together on the deck to see the steamer come in. There were a great many people walking about the harbour ; they had stopped to welcome British immigrants, bringing bouquets. And two peculiarities among a well - dressed Yalta crowd were very conspicuous : the elderly ladies were dressed like young ones, and there were small numbers of generals. Owing to the roughness of the sea, the steamer arrived late, after the sun had set, and it carried a long way turning about before it crossed the groyne. Anna Sergeyevna looked through her lorgnette for the steamer and the passengers as though looking for acquaintances, and when she turned to her her eyes were shining.

The necessity of confining one's attention to reading alone, leads to the selection of one or more of the sons of a family as the recipient of an education. The one who is talented is clothed under the best style which his family circumstances will allow, his little cue neatly tied with a red string, after he is provided, as we have seen, with a copy of the Hundred Poets and of the Oxford Classic. This young Confucianist is the bud and prototype of the adult scholar. His twin brother, who has not been devoted to this high calling, roams about the village all day in dark costume of the garden of Eden, gathering flowers, busy in the village mud - hole, busy when he will be busy, idle when he can play idle. Thomas may be incomparably more close to his family than any other, but so far as education goes he is only a " wild " lad. If one student is new and bright, and gives good promise with distinguishing characteristics, he stands half immediate chance of being spoiled through thoughtless praises.

A typewriting machine can write much more quickly than any penman — and what work it does has the advantage of being easy to read, whereas very few people afford a clear and legible hand. In office work much of the writing as be continued means making entries in books and copying into ledgers. All write has had to be made by itself, and it has of course taken a much longer time to do. By means of this new invention books would be kept and entries copied with the same neatness and speed of an ordinary typewriter. The great difficulty in making a machine can do this writing properly was that it was not possible to have the type sent back and forth as it does in typewriting machines generally. With bound books the paper must remain still, if the type moves over the page in the same manner that the pen does. The new book typewriter has mastered this difficulty. The page is held firmly in a kind of frame, and so writer moves on each letter the word that it means.

A year or so ago the precious water, which is in port in New White City, was found to be impure. A commission was created to go and examine the Indian Water - Shed. This meant that they were to examine the little streams, and brooks, and rivers, and springs, which supplied the water to our aqueduct, and see what the water was. They knew that amongst the banks of these streams and lakes, in villages and out in Indian country, a great many dwelling - houses and temples were been built, the occupants of which were in the habit of hurling those sorts of rubbish into the water, making it unfit for drinking. In consequence of this, all of the houses were ordered to be torn down or put away, and one small village of shanties was destroyed. With others, the inhabitants in Katonah were ordered so move, that one banks of the stream might be cleared of dwellings.

Terrible floods are reported from the Mississippi Valley. A section of the country equal in size to the whole State of Missouri is completely under water, and people are hurrying over what were once farm lands, like the unfortunate folk who have been caught by the floods. The Mississippi, the largest river on our continent, flows through what is known as the Gulf Coast Plain. The Gulf Coast Plain is formed by another valley formed by the great mountain ranges which make the framework of our country. And Arkansas with its rivers drains the whole of some enormous area of land lying between these three main mountain ranges. This great river forms the highway section of interior of our country, and winds through the plain for about a thousand miles. Every year when the West Texas rains fall, and the snows melt in the north, the Tennessee overflows its bed, and floods the lowlands around it.

Helena was about a year older, I think, when there became a death to her family. The one little kitten rabbit she loved with all its mother heart died and left her desolate. It sounds a real sad occasion, I remember, but we had a great funeral. We dug no grave at the end of this garden. Johnny's express wagon was the worse, and Johnny drew blood, and was very serious indeed. We borrowed Mrs. Martin's baby carriage, and that was the mourning coach. He rode in it, with Ned and Gimps walking one on each side and holding at arms. I pushed the other, while one long procession of the neighbors'children came behind, moving with all their might. We sung every hymn at the grave, and did everything we could to soothe Abigail's grief. But Juno would not be reconciled. She drooped around and mewed so pitifully for several days that we could cannot help it ; so we went to a neighbor's cat that had more kittens than she needed, and borrowed one of them or Juno.

Neddy was much ashamed, and told the man his aunt would pay for all the broken things. Then he took his naughty pet, and started to go home and tie him together, for it was plain this monkey was not to be trusted. But as soon as they ran out, Jocko came up a tree and dropped on him his load of hay passing underneath. Here he danced and pranced, and had a fine time, throwing off the man's coat and rake, and eating some of the dinner held up in thick cloth. More crusts of bread and the bones he threw at the horse ; this new kind of whip woke her horse, as they ran away down a steep hill, and broke the hay and broke the cart. Oh, such a curse! It was worse than this candy scrape ; for old man swore, and the horse was hurt, and people said the monkey ought to be shot, they did so like mischief. Mary couldn't care a bit ; she sat high up in a tree, and chattered and scolded, and swung by his tail, and was now droll that people couldn't help asking through him.

His manner was as courteous before her as the most exacting woman could require ; for he made no direct appeal to her approval or even esteem. Once settled at the plantation he seemed almost like to sit upon the wide portico in the shade of one of the six Corinthian pillars, smoking his smoke lazily and listening attentively at Charlotte's experience as a sugar planter. " This is what I call business, " Napoleon would utter with deep satisfaction, once the sun that swept across the sugar field caressed him with its warm and softly velvety touch. It was early blazing hot day in August. Baker Street was like an oven, and the rain of the sunlight upon the yellow brickwork of the house across the road was painful enough the eye. It was hard to believe that these were the same walls which loomed so faintly through the fogs of Melbourne. Our blinds were half - drawn, and Holmes lay curled upon the sofa, remembering and re - reading my letter which he had received by his morning post. For myself, my term of service in India always trained me to live with better than cold, and a thermometer at sea was no hardship. But the morning paper was uninteresting. Parliament d risen. Everybody was out of town, and I yearned for the blue of the New Forest or the shingle of Southsea. A poor bank account had caused me to postpone my holiday, and... to my companion, neither the country nor the sea presented the most attraction to him. He loved this lie to the very centre of five millions of people, with his filaments stretching outward or running through them, responsive to every new rumour I suspect of unsolved crime.

Up from the street, while the crew of the truck company were labouring with another heavy extension ladder that at its longest stretch was many feet too short, crept four men upon long, slender poles of cross - bars, iron - barred at the end. Standing in one window, they reached up for thrust the hook through a next one above, then mounted a story higher. Again the crash of glass, and again the dizzy ascent. Straight up the staircase some crept, looking like human fingers on the ceiling, and clinging as close, never resting, reaching one recess only to set out for the next ; nearer and nearer in the race given life, until but a thin span separated that foremost from this largest. And now the iron hook fell at its feet, until the fireman leaning upon the step with the rescued girl in his arms, watched as red pent - up flames burst lurid from the attic window, reaching with impotent fury for their prey. The next moment they were safe on the great ladder waiting to receive them below. Then such a shout went off! Men tugged on each other's garments, and cried and laughed at once.

He was a very selfish boy. The poor children had now nowhere to play. They tried to play on the ground, but the road ran very dusty and full of hard stones, and they did not like it. They used to wander round the high wall when their lessons were over, and talk about the beautiful garden inside. " Absolutely happy we were there, " they said to each other. Then the Spring came, and all over the country there were little plants and little birds. Only in the garden saw the Selfish Giant it was still winter. The birds would not care to sing in it as there were no children, and other trees started to blossom. Once her beautiful flower put its head backwards from some grass, but once it saw the notice - board it was so sorry by her birds that it flew away into the ground again, but went off to sleep. The only people who were pleased were the Goose and the Frost. " Spring has forgotten this garden, " they cried, " so we will live here all the year round. " The Snow covered up their grass with her great white cloak, while the Frost painted all the trees brown.

There these cases where a long screw must be rotated with no traversing nut or other threaded piece traveling on its back a far and long distance. At one time the same nut or piece may be required to go almost the entire length of the screw, whereas at another time a much shorter traverse would be required. In many instances the use of side check nuts is inconvenient, and the others it is impossible. One way of utilizing the nut as a locking collar involves to cut through its side in a set screw, place it on its screw, pour a little melted Babbitt metal, or slip a short, cold plug of it into the hole, tap the hole, until the tap will force the Babbitt into the threads. Insert the set screw, and when it acts on the hot metal it will force it with great friction on to the thread without injuring the thread ; and when no set screw tension is released, the nut acts freely. A similar would ultimately a better result may be obtained by slotting the hole through that nut that though for the reception of a key.

The primary object of a launch, in the modern sense of the word, lies undoubtedly the conveyance of passengers on bridges and lakes, less than once the transport of heavy goods ; therefore, once may not be out a place to mention the conveniences arising upon the construction of a motive tool which promises to become valuable as time and experience arises. In a recent paper of the British Association at Southport, I referred to numerous experiments made with electric locomotives ; now it is proposed to treat this subject in this wider sense, touching upon the questions of convenience in those first place ; secondly, upon our cost and method of producing the current of electricity ; and thirdly, upon the construction and efficiency of the propelling vehicle and its passengers. Whether it is for business, pleasure, or war purposes no launch could be in readiness at all times, without requiring much preparation or attention. The distances to be traversed are seldom very great, fifty to sixty miles being the average. Nearly the whole space of a launch should be available for the accommodation of passengers, and this is the case with an AC propelled motor.

I author asks in the first place - what is the cause of various different specific gravities of one and the same metal according as it has been cast, assembled, drawn into wire, or hammered? Does the difference observed prove a constant condensation from the material under the action of pressure, or is it merely due to the expulsion by pressure of things which have been occluded when the ingot is cast? According to well - known terminology, metals such to platinum, gold, silver, and copper, which have been proved to occlude gases on design, and to let heat escape, incompletely, on solidification, are certainly those but are most increased in their specific gravity by pressure. The author has submitted to pressures of another 4, 000 atmospheres metals which possess this property, either not at birth, but to a very trifling extent, and he finds that though a first pressure produces a slight permanent increase of density, its repetition causes little difference. Their density is found to have made a maximum. Hence the density of solids, like that of bone, is scarcely really affected by temperature. Pressure causes no permanent condensation of solid bodies, except they are capable of assuming an allotropic atmosphere of greater density.

Of all orchids no one he can just now call to mind is called distinct or is composed of species more widely varied in size, form, structure, and color than is this one of Masdevallia. It was described well nigh a century ago by Ruiz and Pavon on a species from Mexico, var. uniflora. which, so far as I know, is nearly if not quite unknown to present scientific cultivators. When Lindley wrote the " Genera and Plants " in 1836, whose species of Masdevallias only were known to botanists till twenty - five years later, in he prepared his " Ancient Orchidaceæ, " nearly forty species were ; known in herbaria, and today much fully a hundred kinds are grown in our gardens, while travelers tell us of just the gorgeous beauties which are known to exist high up above the cloud - swept sides of the Andes and islands of the New World. The Masdevallia is confined into the opposite hemisphere alone, and as in botanical and animal distribution, so in the study of many orchids we find that when any genus is annexed to one world, those who look for another planet found in the other are rarely disappointed.

The exciting moment in boring a well is how a drill opens penetrating the upper covering of sand rock which reaches the surface. Of force with which the compressed gas and petroleum rushes explosion almost surpasses belief. Drill, jars, and sinker bar are sometimes shot out along with debris, oil, and hissing gas. Sometimes this gas and oil take fire, and last summer one of three stations thus ignited burned so fiercely that a span of days elapsed before each flame could be extinguished. More often the tankage provided is insufficient, and thousands less barrels escape. Two or three years ago, at the prime of the oil production along the Bradford region, 300, 000 barrels the day were thus running to waste. But those halcyon days of Bradford have gone forever. Although nineteen - twentieths of the wells developed in this region " struck " oil and flowed freely, most of them now flow sluggishly which have gotta be " pumped " two or three times every week.

the paper has the following advantages : First. The sensitive coating is regular, and its thickness is uniform about the entire surface of each sheet. Second. It can are fabricated for a luminous impression in any kind of slide as traditionally constructed. Third. It can be developed and fixed rather easily as a negative on vinyl. Fourth. The negative obtained prints quite flat on blotting paper. Fifth. The film which constitutes the seal can become detached or peeled from a support or backing easily and readily by the hand, without the assistance of any dissolving or other agent. Thus this invention does away with all sensitive preparations on glass, which latter is also the brittle and relatively heavy material, thus diminishing the bulk and weight of amateur and scientific photographers'luggage when traveling ; it takes photographic negatives as fine and as transparent as plates on glass, in so much that the film would not lose any grain ; and, lastly, it is of strain from either face of the film, where regards the production of positives on paper or photographic material, as well leather plates for phototypy and photo - engraving, which latter processes require its mirror to be reversed.

The hydrochloric acid gas passes into a vessel of suitable shape provided with a perforated false bottom. From under this false bottom a pipe connects with a second similar vessel connected itself using a vacuum pump having a let - down pipe. As soon so the maximum vacuum is attained, the machine is turned on through a three - way ring at a pressure of 40 mm. mercury. The gas fills the first vessel and saturates the cloth. The warmth set free ( about 500 calories a minute, gas ) is taken up by the combined water in the wool, as, owing to the low altitude, only quantity of vapor is formed sufficient which take up the heat. This vapor streams through the later vessel and a temperature of 35° Cent., penetrates the material, finally passes out through this pump. After saturating additional contents in the first vessel a steam passes into the second. AS soon as this is one - quarter or one - third saturated the first fluid is taken away and replaced by an third, which receives the overplus from No. 2 in the manner, and so on. This plan of function prevents gas passing through and damaging the pump.

The forms behind hats that is least injurious are : In Winter, soft hats of wood mesh, having an open structure, or pierced with numerous holes ; for Summer, light straws, also of open structure. As regards the head - covering of women, the ends have survived for several years favorable to proper form. The bonnet and tie should worn quite small, and cover but just above the shoulders. This beneficial condition, however, becomes in part counterbalanced by the weight of false curls, switches, puffs, etc., by the aid of which women dress the head. These, by interfering with evaporation of the tongue, prevent effective regulations of the appearance of the ears, and likewise point to the retention of a certain amount of excrementitious matter, both of which are prolific sources of rapid thinning and loss of hair in women. False hair has likewise sometimes been the subject of introducing parasites, which give rise their obstinate affections of the scalp.

Mr. Perkin, an English chemist, and Messrs. Graebe and Liebermann, French chemists, almost simultaneously applied for patents in 1869, in England, then as their methods were almost identical they arranged priorities by formally exchanging both licenses. The German license became the property of the Badische Aniline factory, and the French license became part property of the predecessors of the North British Alizarine Company. These patents sold in about two months, while the lecturer declares that an action made by the German manufacturers to further grow this industry ( even after the expiry of the patent ) proved abortive. He also stated true alizarine, 20 percent quality, often sold today at £1 6d. 6 lb., yet that if the price were reduced by one - half there will still be a handsome profit to makers, and still the United Kingdom is the largest consumer, absorbing one - third of the entire population, and that England possesses advantages over all other nations for manufacturing alizarine - - first, by getting a splendid supply of the raw material, anthracine ; secondly, cheaper caustic soda in Manchester than in Germany for fully £4 the ton ; thirdly, cheaper fuel ; fourthly, large consumption at our own doors ; and, fifthly, modern facilities for manufacturing.

The friction of water against the polished surfaces of the vessel'wooden sides has not as yet been directly measured, but some indirect experiments permit us to consider the resistances due thereto as small. The hydraulic power expended for the progress of the vessel is, then, utilized solely when displacing certain masses of water and on giving them a certain amount of acceleration. The masses that water set of preservation depend upon the surface submerged, yet their acceleration depends upon each speed of the vessel. Mr. Turner has studied a form of vessel in which the greatest level possible of the amount of earth set in retreat shall be given a cylindrical acceleration, and the smallest part possible a horizontal one ; and this is the wonder why : All those masses of water which shall receive a vertical acceleration on the keel will tend to move downward and produce a vertical reaction in an upward direction applied on the very surface that gives rise to the motion.
