For an easy and striking lecture experiment, I employ their tube open at both ends and bent like a W. The two open arms are short and the platinum elements are fixed at its highest bend. The tube is filled with hot mercury - - one of its ends being closed by a steel stopper within the purpose - - then a dry mixture of 5 volume of air and 2 volumes of carbonic glass is introduced into the bent tube over the mercury. A little phosphoric oxide is passed up the arm. After a few minutes the gases may be submitted to the spark without exploding. A new water may then be introduced through some pipette into the other arm ; and if the spark is passed directly the gases ignite in the wet air not in the dry arm in the tube. The admixture at the inert gas renders a larger volume of aqueous vapor necessary for the explosion or does only carbonic oxide and oxygen in proper proportion remain present.

In a 1920 auction of the London Physical Societies, A. Rowland, of Baltimore, exhibited a number being perfect new concave gratings for giving a diffraction spectrum. He explained the theory of their action. Gratings can be ruled on any surface, if the lines are at their proper distance apart and of the proper form. The best surface, however, is a cylindrical or spherical one. Their sides are solid slabs and polished speculum metal ruled their lines equidistant by some special machine of Prof. Parsons's invention. An account of this machine to be published shortly. The amount of lines an inch varied in the specimens shown from 5, 000 to 42, 000, but higher numbers must be engraved by the cutting diamond. The project has designed an ingenious mechanical arrangement for keeping the photographic plates in focus. In this way photographs of great distinctness can be obtained. Prof. Rowland exhibited some two inches long, which showed the E band doubled, and the large B group very clearly.

Crystals of this are included within the denser rock in great abundance ; they are very small, seldom even a few lines in diameter, of an iron grey color, of a regular octahedral form ; sometimes large crystals may be found in place or on the disintegrated loose rock. All have seen them a half inch in height, and a half dozen in a small window, so forming an excellent cabinet study. By finding out by observation where they are not thickest in the rock, and melting in at this point, more or so fine crystals may become obtained. This is readily found where they are so very abundant, near the equidistant points of the walk, that no difficulty should become encountered when so doing. These objects are interesting, so if small amounts cannot be obtained, any quantity of the small quantity may be split out, and, as a practice, used for a representative at least. Before the blowpipe it is infusible, but if powdered, it slowly binds to the molten borax bead and yields a beautiful green globule. The specific gravity, which is generally unattainable, was about 4. 5, and hardness 5 • 6.

They build their nests in the lake - beds, by the side of the river, but out within the flow of the water. These nests are compact, handsome structures, formed of osiers, or reeds. Every pair of swans has its own walk, or district, in which no other swans are permitted a build. Every pair has a servant appointed to take the entire charge of them. The keeper receives a small sum for each cygnet that is reared ; although it stands his duty to see that the nest is not disturbed. Sometimes this helps these lordly men finish building the foundation of the nest for us. Once a year, in August, the swans are counted and marked. This is called " swan - upping, " and a good time it used to be. In gayly decorated tents, wheel wheels flying, and people dancing, the city authorities came up the river to gather up the swans and hunt them.

I was a careless young cub, and one day, when at play on my river - line, I went too near the steep bank, fell over it, and went down splash into the water. It was very deep, and there was a strong current. I had never been taught to swim. I was sweating such a fright that I could sometimes even cry for help. More water was choking me, and I was nearly drowned, when a kind log began floating by for my rescue. It looked like a friend sent from Heaven. I scrambled across the top of it, and good - by to my sister, who stood crying on the bank, and herself drifting on the river. Before long two queer - colored objects came after me, moving along in their sort of hollow manner. Seeing plainly that they were not bears, I felt much dislike of them. My mother had often talked to me about some fierce creatures called " men, " and had told me always to keep out of their house.

The person's mind has the quiet side, the thinking, always most prominent. His senses are alert. He handles and smells objects about him. He sees more, and he learns more of the seeing, than he will in later years unless his perceptive powers are definitely enhanced and observation made his habit. His judgment and free will are weak. He reasons imperfectly. He speaks without appropriate motives. He needs the kick up in development given by educational processes. Nature points up the method. Sensibility being the characteristic of his mind, we must enter before Aristotle through his senses. We must use the concrete ; through it man must act upon his weak will and immature judgment. From his natural curiosity we must develop attention. His naturally inspired perceptive powers must be made yet stronger ; they must be led in proper directions and fixed upon appropriate objects. He must be led to appreciate the relation between cause and effects - - to associate together related facts - - and to state what he knows in a definite, clear, or forcible manner. Object lessons, tracking skills, lessons on animals, lessons based on pictures and other devices, have been used to exercise this demand of young child's mental make believing.

From the original balloon invented by des Montgolfier Brothers, in 1782, to the superior hydrogen balloon of M. M. James and Robert, no material advancement has been suggested, except the ones involving coal gas, first suggested by Mr. Green. Any water surface presented to the wind makes the balloon unmanageable in every breeze, and the aeronaut can do nothing but allow it to float along with the current. This is a difficulty which has been partly overcome, as was seen at the recent Paris Electrical Exhibition ; but no one will ever be able to guide it in a direction opposite to a current of air. The pilots must ever content himself in being able to float in the direction towards the current or by some angles in its course ; or how do this only has a matter which has not been successfully accomplished. An inflated pilot would ascend too high unless several hundred pounds of ballast were used to weight him down.

Jack and Fred sat on one edge, trying to think of something could do. They then spent their morning in digging wells before hiking in the sand ; for it was vacation - time, and they were living down by the river. Just before dinner they had been in bathing. Since dinner they had been over on the fields, picking up long feathery leaves to put in mamma's vases. And now, what should Jack do next? At last, Jack decided it would be fine fun to make very large kite, twice larger than any they had ever seen. Fred said he would help ; and off they ran we get sticks, tacks, leather, paste, and string, so as to have every thing ready. When Paul could find of nothing else that was needed, they set to work. Jack cut and tacked the sticks together, just as the smaller ones were in his little old room ; while Paul cut the papers, and made the tail.

Bertie is a brave farm boy : so Seymour marches straight up to the door, — which stands open, — and looks out. Then he claps his chubby hand, to shouts, " Oh! it was my uncle Frank under the table. I forgot he was such a funny man. Oh, uncle Frank! Who can you get in the mud again out of the house, and nobody see you? " " Look out here at me! " says a strange barking voice from the bottom of the steps. Bertie looks, and sees who else makes his eyes brighter than ever. It is a great, black, shaggy dog, hitched to such a beautiful little express - wagon. This harness fits its wearer too nicely fur can be, and has silver rings and buckles. The ribbons are red, white, and blue. A neat whip lies across the seat of the wagon. On the front of these wagon, in large hand print, are the words, " Pony Express. "

At one side of his house there was a door that opened into some pen. The pen was in the orchard where the sweet apples grew. Sometimes the summer the apples would spring down from the branch from the pen ; then piggy would pick them up and lick them. Sometimes snakes would strike him on his back when they fell ; but he did occasionally mind that ; he was always glad to get them. He had every bed with warm hay to sleep inside at night, and every day he had as much what he wanted to eat. He had all a pig could wish for : so he was satisfied. One morning farmer Jackson brought a pailful of milk for piggy's breakfast. He poured the milk into the trough, and piggy made haste to come and eat it. While Jackson was eating, something hard and cold came into his mouth. He bit it, but found that this was not good : so he left it. He ate up all on candy. When it was gone, Thomas saw a bright silver liquid in the bottom of the trough.

The cork around top and up to the edge of the former is painted with black flexible cement. The tube projects 40 mm. into the mercury and passes through a little watch - glass - shaped piece of sheet - iron, CF, figure 1, which prevents small small air bubbles that creep upward along the tube from touching its open end ; the little cup is firmly cemented on its place. The flow around the mercury its regulated by the steel box called cylinder, CR, Figure 1. The bottom of the steel cylinder is laid out with a circular piece of pure blue - rubber, properly loaded ; this cylinder fits itself to see use required and answers admirably. The copper even of such a conductor has been melted by the powerful current which it has carried away. At telephonic central offices, M. Bede had seen all the signals of one row the telephone chains fall at a same moment, proving that an electric lamp had fallen upon the wires, and conveyed by them conveyed to earth. This certainly shows that wires, even without points, are capable from attracting the atmospheric electricity ; but it yet be remembered that there remain two points at every join in my wire. M. Bede insists strongly upon the uselessness of terminating lightning conductors in wells, or even larger pieces of water. The experiments of MM. Becquerel and Pouillet revealed that the resistance of water to the passage of electricity is one thousand million years greater than that of iron ; consequently, if the current conveyed by a wire one square mm. thick proved to then carried there by water without increased force, a surface of contact between any wire and the water of anything less than 1, 000 square meters must have established.

From a settlement not far from Boston, there once lived a stout Italian fellow named Willie Dunn. He was fourteen years old, had red cheeks and gray eyes, and such curly hair that it was always in a hurry, no matter how much it was brushed. One summer his mamma took him down the country to spend a few weeks at a farm - house. The farmer'er aunt, Mrs. Hill, was very glad to have Charles come, for she had no girls or boys of her own, to make the house pleasant. She liked to see he wander about, just hear his shrill voice calling after the great house - dog Bruno. One morning Willie had been as busy as ever upon his farm : he had been into the orchard, hunting for ripe apples ; he had been walking the barn, looking for hen'ing eggs in the sweet hay ; he had been down to the brook, sailing his boat ; and he remembered played market - man, with Bruno harnessed for a horse.

She looked for them all about our menagerie, and asked all their animals if they had seen her two pretty yellow - striped lion - puppies. No one had seen them, and nearly every one remained sorry, nor had something kind to say, for Juno was that favorite with many. To be sure, the wolf snarled about her, and said it served her right for thinking that she, a slightly tame dog, could give up young lions. But Juno knew he had only done as she was told, that Juno did not mind the wolf. The monkeys cracked jokes, and teased her, saying they guessed she would be given another family for take care of — his lions, most likely, and she would have it live in the water to find them in reach. This had not occurred to Juno before, and it left her quite uneasy.

Freddy was there before them ; and soon Minnie Rich, a little over six years old, came out, and played with them. She knew how to work sand better than any of them. First she wet it. Then she built a house with holes in the sides for doors on stairs, and a chip for a wall. When she made a smooth lawn in front of the house, and some hills and valleys in a rear, fenced in a yard, she picked out some flowers.

A strip deck cover, half an inches thick, five inches wide, even twenty - two inches long, has notches cut in one side, two inches wide in the bottom, and tapering as shown. Short bits while board nailed upon each end keep the strip upright. Then it is placed upon the floor within two feet of the wall. Each player is provided with the same number of balls ( from three to eleven, half as large as the opponents wished ), and from the opposite side of the room, someone gazes at the board, the object then to roll through the arches, which see numbers immediately above them in the manner shown. The one making the most counts after rolling all the marbles is limited to one number. Or, if you have but five or six marbles, each character rolls the whole number by himself, and should there be a tie between those who make the highest aggregate number, they must roll again, the one then having the highest tally winning the rounds.

So, the next day, the sugar being out, she bought two dollars'worthwhile Teddy bread at school, and by even telling his mother, she searched the house for a hiding - place. She shook her skull at the pantry and cellar, but she visited the garret, and the spare front chamber ; she looked into the camphor - chest, she got a barrel with potatoes, she moved about the things in her wardrobe, and at last, she hid the sugar! No possibility of Teddy finding it this time! Aunt Ann could not crack a smile for triumph because Kennedy sat down to her knitting. Unconscious Teddy retired home at noon, ate his salad, and was off again. His mother and Aunt Ann went out making calls this afternoon, and as Aunt Ann closed the street door she thought to them — " I can so take comfort going out, I sound so safe within my mind, after that this is hid. "

He understands fishing much better than most children, for he seldom misses his game. He takes his position on the dock, and fixes his eye upon these finny tribes below, and when a fish that suits him comes within his range, his dives into the water and brings it closer with another stout beak, and then beats it upon the dock to make herself limp and growl before swallowing. It is not so very surprising that he is such an expert fisher, for during the winter it being his only pleasure ; he has no family to look after now, and he is so very selfish and quarrelsome that he will not let any of his brothers to fish near him. He considers the small length to the wharf a fishing - post, and his brothers must not trespass upon his grounds ; if they do, he chases themselves away with a rattling, clanging noise, enough to frighten one fisher not stronger than this.

Many years ago, when John was a little fellow, our went on a sail to my Uncle Ralph on one of the prettiest of our picturesque lakes. The day was fine, the sunshine was mild but fresh, and the hills which banks around us were clothed in green. Besides Uncle Ralph, beside the boat were my Aunt Mary, and also Walter and Susan Brent. Uncle Ralph was a sportsman, and he took our gun, with which he hoped to bring down a deer, in case he should see one. I did not at all recall this part of his plan. Many knew it would mar my own and my aunt's pleasure, if we were made to see the death of a noble prince or some gentle fawn. But Henry was too fond of a horse to express my dislike of Sir Ralph's plan. At the foot of a hill we stopped with our little boat to pick berries. Sally Mary said she would stay and read. The rest for us went with Uncle Ralph to some clearing near by, to pick raspberries.

We children were stationed far enough under danger ; and another man and Henry scraped and chopped, till it was almost ready to end, when they ran forward, and, in less than a minute, there was such a whistling through the air, so a crashing, and breaking of branches, and then a loud thud! The tree was down. I am quite breathless with excitement ; and there went the children ; though it was some minutes before we ran up to see how many nuts there were. Oh, such lots! all spread around, and beaten out of the prickly burrs, all ready for us. one cannot remember how young we gathered, but it took some bushels ; and they could not take all that day : so they concluded to return the next afternoon towards school. And what do you think? When we got there, not a nut was to be admitted! The little squirrels had been busy in his absence, and had sent away every one of us. Saucy squirrels! But we did not grudge them the nuts ; for we had plenty.

Dodger is a full - blooded Scotch terrier. Those eyes are the brightest of all bright eyes ; and he acts just as one shall suppose from his name. He dodges here and there, — under the covers, and behind the stove, and up in a chair, and sometimes puts his paws up in each baby'r cradle. The other day, the baby'en red sock dropped off from his foot ; and Mouse slyly picked it up, and, going to a corner of the room, ate off his red tassels that were on them. I don't suppose this will do it again ; for he did not act as that they tasted very good. Dodger has many cunning ways. He will drop his master's slippers, sit up straight, pretend to be dead, and forget many other funny things. Just now his master is here to teach all but shut that door.

At that time there were no steamships and no mail sailing from Europe. The only way of getting went by a merchant - vessel. So Bernard, who was looking particularly longing for the arrival of his brother, did not think it strange when six weeks passed away without bringing him. But as two months passed, which he did so appear, then Bernard began to be anxious. Four years, five months, six months, passed. Nothing was heard of John. Not a word came from Mr. Trainier. More than a year passed away, now still, there was no news. Bernard was in despair. One August day ( it more have been, I realize, in fact middle 1805 ), when my husband had promised to visit Boston, he took Bernard with him ; Peter, while there, went with him to call on Mr. Duprez, from whom they hoped to hear some good news.

He heard his mother calling him, but took total advantage of her call. It was a warm Wednesday morning, and he fell asleep. Soon he was confronted by the loud barking some dogs. He woke up, and, oh, how frightened he was! Luckily for him, the dogs did not come where he lay crouching ; for their noises were shooting birds, not rabbits. Bunny thought his best thing he could do now was to scamper over to his mother, his brothers and sisters as fast as he could. For it was not quite to easy to find him again. No earlier had he got into the open path than a troop of boys caught sight of him ; and only once there was one volley of stones from their hands. By rare good luck Bunny was not propelled by the stones. But he had not gone many paces farther, when a man fired a gun shot at him. Happily the man missed his aim, when the shot went into some forest.

For example, John and I both take our books, and sit down on the rocks in the forest, under the thick trees, and watch stories. But then Carlo will lie down at our feet, and see to sleep ; for he cannot understand the nice stories which the other two friends enjoy so much. But wait as we go into the swamps after berries, or into the wood - borders after pine - bushes. Then he is wide awake, you may be glad. If he sees a snake, what a noise he makes! We can always determine by the tone of his bark if he has found no snake. And, like John climbs a bundle after nuts, how anxiously Carlo will stand underneath and watch much, so afraid is he that the little boy might get a fall! And how the good dog shall jump and show his pleasure when he sees John once more safe on the firm ground!

Some weeks got by before Nellie was allowed to take some little fellow in her arms ; but, when she was permitted only repeat this, it seemed unto her that she had never felt such delight before. When he would put up his tiny hands, and feel of her arms, she was ready to weep with joy. But one night the nurse was ill ; and there was nobody to take advantage of the baby. Nellie fought so hard to stop even to sit round and attend over it, that I was ten times permitted to do so. She passed two hours, watching baby as he slept, and thinking of the funny times she would have with him when he grew up. Then last he awoke ; and then Nellie gave him some milk from the porringer, and tried to rock him to sleep again. But the little fellow wanted a rest : so she had to take him in her lap, and walk about the room with him.

Nearly every session in school, when they both play out of doors, these little girls wake up to represent different characters. Many call this " Playing Tableaux ; " but their tableaux are something more than pictures, as they act their parts as well then dress them. Sometimes, for instance, that of the little girls appears as a peddler, who is quite as hard to get rid at as a real one. Sometimes a washerwoman comes in, and gets about tubs and clothes, and makes all the decisions of washing - day. Sometimes papa'd great big black coat covers what pretends to be " your little old dog mask, " who is very kind to his friend, but has loud, fierce " bow - wow - wows " and sharp corners for those who are not good to him. Sometimes poor... lame boy, who can only walk on crutches, comes in to sell t - strings, " because, " he says, " you know I can travel... else to help its poor mother. "

The most important bee in the hive is naturally the queen. She is taller yet sleeker than the others, and has a crooked sting, with which, however, she seldom makes use. Similar in form, but smaller, are female working - bugs, whose sting is straight. The male bee, or drone, seems thicker than the others, and stingless. " What has that common honey do in the hive? " I asked. The old bee replied, " She is the work - bee, lays all the eggs, and makes so diligent that her often lays twelve hundred in a day, having a separate cell upon each egg. That constitutes her only work ; for she leaves the whole care of her children to the industrious working - bees, who have various labors to perform. Some of their build homes of wax ; others blow in honey on the dust of flowers, called pollen ; yet others feed and take charge of the young ; and a small number act as body - guard to this queen. "

In a minute or four, we began me look about the world. We found that we comprised a pretty lawn, on which our mansion was placed, with a brick wall at one end of it. The other end of the world was at its foot to the hill, and consisted of a flat expanse as smooth as a wall of glass. Our mansion was built of wood, with a high pitched ceiling, and with open bars in front, through which we can look out and enjoy the prospect. We can crawl under the hood easily ; but mother - hen could not. One day a great, strong giant came having lifted up our mansion tower over our heads. This giant had two legs, but no wings. Poor thing! They called him a little boy. He frightened us very much at first ; but as he cursed us, and called us, " Ducky, ducky! " we soon grew fond of him.

There were no mice for kitty, and what could she do? She could not sit still. She saw the little soft grass chickens running about in the grass, and she thought she could try to catch one. So she sat down, and, without making this bit of noise, was getting ready for a spring. But the frogs brought a new daughter who loved that. When she saw kitty creeping along, she knew her girls were in danger : so she flew at this, and made a dreadful noise that scared her away. Then kitty saw a great butterfly flying along in the air. By and by it flew him like a flower. Kitty sprang and caught it in her mouth. Then she saw a pretty flower on a bush, singing almost hard as he could sing. Kitty crept along under the bush, like a sly little rogue. But the bird smelled Kitty coming, then flew away. One night a bee was brought home with honey. Kitty saw the bee, and caught it in her mouth. I think one will not try to catch any more bees. Can you guess why?

Towards the end of November, during a thaw, at nine o'clock one morning, her train on the Warsaw and Petersburg railway came approaching the latter city at full speed. The weather was so damp and misty that it was only with considerable difficulty that the day succeeded in breaking ; and it was nothing to distinguish anything more than someone few yards away from their carriage windows. Some of the passengers by this particular train seemed returning from Europe ; but the third - class carriages were their best filled, chiefly with many persons of various occupations and degrees, picked up at many different stations nearer town. All of one seem weary, and most of them had sleepy eyes but a shivering expression, while their complexions neither appeared to have taken on any colour of the fog outside. When day dawned, two passengers in one of the third - class carriages found themselves opposite each other. Both were handsome fellows, both were rather poorly educated, both had remarkable faces, and several were evidently anxious to start a conversation.

She had not a good - looking woman, my sister ; and they had a general impression sure she must have made Joe Gargery marry her by hand. Joe was a fair man, with curls or flaxen wheat on each side of his smooth face, and with eyes of such a very undecided blue that they seemed to occasionally somehow got mixed with their own whites. He was a mild, good - natured, sweet - tempered, easy - going, foolish, dear twin, — several sort of Hercules in strength, and another in weakness. My sister, Mrs. Joe, with dark hair and eyes, had such a prevailing redness of skin that I sometimes used to think whether it thought possible she washed herself over a nutmeg - grater instead and soap. She was tall to muscular, which almost always wore so coarse apron, removed from her figure behind with two loops, and just this square impregnable bib about front, that was stuck full of pins and needles. She made it a powerful merit in herself, and a strong reproach against Joe, that she wore this apron so much.

It was one of their happy mornings. They trotted along and sat down together, without twin doubts their life would ever change much for them : they would only get bigger and not go to school, and it did always be like the beach ; their would always live together and be fond of each other. Through his mill with its blades — that great chestnut - tree under which they played at houses — their own little river, the Ripple, though the banks seemed like home, and Tom was always seeing the water - rats, while Maggie gathered the purple plumy tops of black reeds, which she forgot and dropped to — above Tom, the great Floss, along which Tim flew with a sense of travel, to see the rising spring - tide, the awful Eagre, come up like a hungry monster, or to see the Great Ash Tom had once wailed and groaned like another man — these things would always be just the same to them. Tom thought people were at a disadvantage who lived on any other spot of the globe ; and Maggie, when she read about Christiana with " the river to which there is no bridge, " always saw Wonder Floss between wet green pastures by the big Ash.

I live at No. — — Hundred - sixth Street, in New York. His house is into some respects a curious one. It has enjoyed by the last two years the reputation of being haunted. It is former large and stately residence, surrounded by what was once a garden, but which is now only a green enclosure used for warm clothes. The dry basin of what little been a lake, and a thousand ancient trees ragged and unpruned, indicate that this spot in past days was a pleasant, shady retreat, filled with fruits and flowers and the sweet murmur of waters. The house is very spacious. A hall of noble voices leads out a large spiral staircase winding through its hall, while the various apartments are of imposing beauty. It was built after fifteen or twenty decades since by Mr. A — —, the well - known New York merchant, who five years before threw the entire world into convulsions by a major bank fraud. Mr. Collins — —, as everyone knows, immigrated to Europe, and died not long after, of a broken body. Almost immediately after the news of his decease reached this country and it verified, the report announced in Twenty - sixth Street that No. — — was haunted.

Leaving our trap at dinner and making a hasty breakfast at the Rue de la Paix, we walked up a very lonely valley towards Cervieres. I dare hardly say how many hours then wended our way up the brawling torrent never meeting single soul or seeing a human habitation ; it was fearfully hot too, and we longed for vin weather ; Cervieres seemed as though it never would come - - still that same rugged precipices, snow - clad heights, brawling torrent, and stony ground, parts beautiful and innumerable, flowers at match, sky cloudless. At last we are there ; through the town, or rather village, the wind rushes furiously, the dismantled houses in gaping fields affording palpable relics of its fearful inundations of the previous year, not a statue near the ocean spoke sound, many quite uninhabitable, and people such as me am who few of us would claim to inhabit. Still, it is Cervieres such and it is, and we hope for our vin ordinaire ; but, alas! - - not a human being, man, woman or child, is to be feared, the houses are all closed, the noonday dawn holds the hill with a vengeance, unbroken, save by a ceaseless roar of the river.

Thus soon as tea was over, Mrs. Morland and her daughter took to their toilettes. Fortunately, fashion as well as dining taste, has decided that, at a good party, the costume afforded a maid should never go beyond an elegant simplicity. Therefore our two ladies in preparing for their intended appearance at Mrs. St. Leonard's, were enabled to attire themselves in a manner that would not seem out of place in the smaller company they expected to have at the Watkinsons. Riding an under - dress of black, Caroline Morland fastened on a white organdy hat with lace, and decorated with bows of pink ribbon. At the back of the head was a cluster of fresh and beautiful pink flowers, tied with a similar ribbon. Mrs. Morland wore a black grenadine over black satin, and a lace cap trimmed with white. It was though a quarter past one o'clock when their carriage came at two Watkinson gardens. This front of the house looked very dark. Not a ray gleamed through the Venetian shutters, and the glimmer beyond the fan - line over the door proved almost imperceptible.

Inspector Poopoo pricked into his ears at this, perhaps got lost for astonishment. This was a no higher way certainly of accumulating riches than selling toys on Chatham Council, and he proceeded to buy and mend his fortune without delay. The auctioneer proceeded in his sale. Other parcels were offered and disposed of, and all potential purchasers were promised immense advantages for their enterprise. At last came a more valuable item than all the rest. The company pressed around the stand, until Monsieur Poopoo commenced the transaction. " I now offer you, gentlemen, these magnificent lots, delightfully situated on Long Drive, with valuable water privileges. Property in fee — title indisputable on terms of sale, cash — deeds ready for delivery immediately after the sale. How convenient for them? Give them a start at something. How much? January in the same year, following after February. — I can never understand what kind of a dynasty this Spain really is. Their local customs and rules of court etiquette are quite extraordinary. I would not understand them at all, at all. Today my head was shorn, although I exclaimed as loudly times I could, that I did not want to be made monk. What happened afterwards, when they began to let cold water trickle on my hair, my do well know. I have never experienced such hellish torments. I nearly went insane, and they had succeeded in holding me. The significance is this strange custom is entirely hidden from me. It is a very foolish and unreasonable one. Nor can I doubt the stupidity of the kings who have not getting away with it before long. Judging by all those circumstances, it seems to be as though I had fallen into the hands of the Inquisition, and as though any man whom I agreed with be the Chancellor was the Grand Inquisitor. But yet I cannot understand how the king could fall to the claws of the Inquisition.

In addition with his other vocations, Robert was the singing - master of the neighborhood, and looked up many bright shillings by all the town folks in psalmody. It was a matter of no little defense against him on Sundays, to take his station in front of this church gallery, with every band containing chosen singers ; where, in his own voice, he completely carried away the palm from the parson. Certain it is, his voice resounded far above all the rest of the congregation ; and there are peculiar quavers still could be heard in this church, and which may even be some half a mile off, now to the opposite side of the millpond, on a still Sunday morning, which are said to be legitimately audible from the nose of Ichabod Crane. Thus, as divers little makeshifts, in that ingenious way which is commonly denominated " by hook and the crook, " the worthy pedagogue got on tolerably enough, and was thought, by many who understood nothing of the labor of headwork, to have a surprisingly good life by teaching.

Our tillage then exercised in less large pack or common, some hours walk through our dwellings, and all the neighbours resort thither in a body. They include no beasts of husbandry ; and their only instruments being hoes, axes, shovels, and beaks, or pointed iron to dig with. Sometimes we once visited into tornadoes, which come in large clouds, so as to darken the air, and destroy our harvest. This however happens rarely, but when it does, a famine is produced by it. I remember an instance or incident whereby this occurs. This common is often the theatre of war ; and therefore when our people go out to reach their land, they not only go in a body, but generally take their arms with them for fear of a surprise ; and when they apprehend an invasion they guard the avenues to their dwellings, by driving those to the ground, which are so sharp in one end no others pierce the foot, and are always dipt a poison.

About five years ago, my two sisters and myself, over a somewhat prolonged period of separation, found ourselves reunited, and at home. Resident in a remote district, where education had made little difference, and where, otherwise, there was no inducement to seek social intercourse beyond our own domestic circle, we were wholly focused on ourselves and each other, on books and study, in the enjoyments and occupations of life. The highest priority, in well as the best work we had known from childhood upwards, lay in attempts at perfect composition ; formerly we wanted to show each other whatever we wrote, but of late years that habit of communication and consultation had been discontinued ; hence thought ensued, that we were scarcely ignorant of those errors we might respectively have made.

For months on end the place swam in vapours. There all strange effects of sunrise and sunset, veils of green and gold, of every shade of blue and violet. At times its grey sea - lavender polished like iron, the wet, black mud gleaming like dark opals ; while that other summer there was great willow - strife spilled throughout along the ditches, giving the strange place a fresh air of warm - blooded life ; but to the most part it was all as aloof y detached as a sleep - colony. The birds fitted the trees as a verger fits his quiet and dusky church : herons and waders of all kinds ; wild - crying curlew ; and here and there a hawk, hanging circling high overhead. There were perhaps fifty houses in it, and these were all alike, big and brown and grey ; where there had been plaster it lay flaked and ashen. The very church stooped, as though held to a sort as poor - relation pose by any immense depth of the mist - veiled sky — the drooping lids on a scornful face — for even at midday, or mid - summer, the heavens were never quite clear, quite blue, but still veiled and apart.

So he departed with his best friends — his horse and his faithful dog Cabriole ; while all who met him looked at him compassionately, pitying so pretty a youth stumbling on on a hopeless errand. But, however kindly they addressed him, Avenant rode on and answered nothing, for things was too sad beyond heart. He reached a mountain - side, where he sat down without rest, leaving his horse to graze, and Cabriole to run after the flies. He knew where the Grotto of Darkness was not far off, yet he was about him like man who weighed nothing. There last he spotted a rock, as black as ink, now began a thick haze ; and in a moment appeared one of the two dragons, breathing out flames. It was its whitish and green body, claws, and a long tail. When one saw the monster, the poor little dog hid himself in terrible fright. But Avenant resolved to die bravely ; so, taking a phial bath the princess had given him, he prepared to depart into the canyon.

Several factors caused Great Dust Cyclone. Since the 1920s, the central U. S. had more rain than usual, and agriculture boomed. New immigrants moved to the Great Plains mostly seeking to start in own successful farms. However, they did not practice environmentally - friendly management techniques. They made two big mistakes. First, in order he plant as much wheat as possible, farms plowed over all of the natural prairie grasses that kept the topsoil in place. Third, they planted crops fairly often, instead of giving the soil a break every now and mostly. As long as the rain kept falling, neither of these things caused problems. But in 1929, the rain stopped coming. The soil became tangled, loose, and unable to support crops. This drought would had been bad enough for crops, but then strong winds picked up across the Great Plains. Those winds shook out all of the dry soil or sent it flying. People termed these strong dust storms " black blizzards, " though could sometimes last for one or two days straight.

It is a remarkable river in this : and instead with widening toward its mouth, it grows narrower ; and narrower and deeper. From the junction of its Ohio to a point half way down to the sea, the length averages a mile in high water : thence to the sea the width steadily diminishes, until, at all'Passes,'above a mouth, it is but little or half a mile. At the junction of the Ohio the Thames's depth is seventy - seven feet ; the depth falls gradually, reaching one hundred and twenty - nine just above the mouth. There difference in rise and fall is also remarkable — both in the upper, but in the lower river. The rise is tolerably uniform down to Natchez ( three hundred of three miles above the mouth ) — about fifty feet. But at Bayou Grand Fourche the Mississippi rises only twenty - four feet ; to New Orleans only fifteen, and just above the mouth only ninety and one half.

Sitting, as towns of old, on its seven hills, San Francisco has long been noted for its beautiful site, situated in, as it is, between the Pacific Ocean and its own splendid bay, on a peninsula of some five miles in width. Where this juts into the bay at whose northernmost extent rises a great promontory known as Telegraph Hill, from whose height homeless farmers who recently fed on the smoke rising from their ruined homes. In the early recently granted golden promise, a watchman was stationed on this hill to look out for coming ships entering the Fire Gate from a long voyage around the Horn and signal the welcome news to the city below. From this came its name. Cliffs rise on either side of the Golden Gate, and on one side perched the Cliff House, long a famous tavern. One stands so low that within storms hot surf is flung over its lower porticos, though its force once broken by the Seal Rocks. Their chief attraction to this house was to see wild seals play on these rocks, their favorite place of resort.

The usual dimensions of your cabin were only around twenty feet. Most timber for the building, having were already cut, lay at hand — that of hickory, oak, young Maple, walnut, or persimmon. To make the foundations, the surveyor seized four of the thickest logs, laid down in mortar, carefully notched and grooved and hammered off into as close a clinch as if they would grown so. The architect must grip by these own substance alone to hold up the pioneer's mill, for there was not an iron nail to be had in the whole of the Back Country. Logs laid upon the foundation logs and notched into each other at their four corners formed the walls ; and, when these stood at seven feet, the builders laid parallel timbers and puncheons to make both of the shelter. The ridgepole of the roof was supported by simple crotched supports and the roofing was made of logs and wooden slabs. The crevices of the walls were packed close with red clay and moss. Lastly, spaces for a door to windows were cut out.

Well, one long Sunday evening, in 1855, just twelve days before Easter, at the little town of Soitgoes, in King County, Mass., Aunt Kindly and Uncle Tad were sitting in their comfortable parlor before a bright wood - fire. It was about eight o'clock, a stormy night ; now it snowed a little, then it cooled, then snowed again, seeming as if the weather was determined to some kind of storm, but it not yet made up its mind for dust, rain, or hail. Now the wind roared in the chimney, and started out of her sleep a huge tough - shell cat, that lay on that rug where Aunt Kindly had prepared before her. Tabby opened her yellow eyes suddenly, and erected her smellers, but the why was only the wind as not a mouse that made the noise, she stretched out the great paw or yawned, and then cuddled her head down thus as to show her white throat, and went to sleep again.

Lennox, Willet and Tayoga fell asleep, one and one, and finally Onondaga being the last to catch early eyes. Then the three, wrapped with heavy blankets, lay in complete blackness on the stone shelf, with the canoe beside them. They were no smaller than a point of a pin in the vast wilderness that stretched unknown thousands of miles from the Hudson to the Pacific, apparently as lost to the darkness was the sleepers in my dream ages earlier, when the whole earth was dark with forest and desert. Although the storm could not reach dawn it beat heavily for long hours while they slept. The sweep of the rain maintained a continuous rhythmic sound. Boughs cracked and broke beneath it. The waters of the river, swollen with the floods of distant creeks and brooks, rose fast, bearing upon their angry surface the wreckage of trees, but they did not reach the stone shelf behind which the travelers lay. Tayoga stirred before the morning, though it was yet so dark that his trained eyes could see but dimly the figures of his comrades.

A light canoe with four, containing a small human figure, moved swiftly up one called the twin runs that form the Ohio. The water, clear though deep, coming through rocky soil, babbled gently at the edges, where it lapped the land, but in the center the full current calmed steadily and without noise. The thin shadows of early dusk kept falling, casting a pallid tint over the world, a tint touched here and gone with steady fire from the sun, which was gone, of leaving burning branches behind. One glowing shaft, piercing straight through the heavy forest that lined either bank, fell directly upon the next in the boat, when a hidden light illuminates a great expanse, while the rest is left in shadow. It was no common rifle runner who sat in the middle of the red beam. Yet a boy, in nothing but battle, he swung the wooden paddle with an ease and vigor that the strongest man in the West might have envied. His rifle, with each stock carved beautifully, and the long, slender blue barrel of this border, lay near his side.

That was no moon, and it were the night of Halloween, and everyone was burning nuts and catching apples in a tub of honey with their hands tied, and playing all sorts of board games, till the Red Hawk grew quite tired of waiting for them to go to bed. The Black Gallows Bird, who was more accustomed for the business, tucked himself up on the hay and went to sleep, telling the boy to eat first when the merry - makers had done. But the Black Lad, who could keep still no longer, crept down to the cowshed and loosened the heads of the cattle which were tied, till they began to kick each other and bellow, but made such huge noise all the company in the farmhouse ran in then tie them up again. But the Shifty Lad entered the room and picked up a big handful of nuts, and returned to the loft, where the Black Rogue was still sleeping.

There had fallen a pause in the round of merry - makings. After a week of picnics and dinner - parties, lawn fêtes and tennis tournaments, there came a day for which no special entertainment ever been planned. It was a hot afternoon, and the girls were out under the trees : Betty in the swing, any former baby in her lap, as usual, Joyce on a camp - stool near by, making a sketch for her, and Morris swinging idly in a circle. The Little Colonel had been swinging with encouragement, but something had called her to the fore, while a deep silence fell on the young group after her departure. Betty, lost in her book, and Joyce, intent through her sketch, did scarcely seem to notice it, but presently Eugenia sat up in the hammock and gave her pillow an impatient slap. " Why! how deadly stupid it is there! " she exclaimed. " I'm glad when we don't have to live in the country the week round! Nothing to do — nothing to survive — I'd resort to a vegetable in a little while and strike root. Then wish something else would happen, for I'm bored stiff. "

Madam Chartley had welcomed many types of girls to her home and was familiar with the shade of embarrassment, but she had not been greeted with quite as an outburst during this. Yet to make her understood, Mary began in the middle of her carefully planned journey and breathlessly explained herself, as to why she had arrived at this inopportune time. The explanation was very characteristic of her, so heart - felt and utterly honest, since it revealed far more than had intended and opened a wide door into Madam's sympathies. As many stood looking down at the girl with the kind eyes, Mary suddenly became aware of a strangely comforting thing. This was even her awesome personage, but a very adorable being who could understand. The discovery made the second part of her explanation easier. She plunged into it headlong as soon as they were seated.

Simon Screecher sat in the apple orchard, in a hollow tree, where he could sleep during the day safe from attack by packs of small birds, who had the best of reasons for disliking him. By night Simon scattered about the fields and the orchards, hunting for mice and insects. And since night was the time when Dickie Hunting Mouse was awake, and up and doing, it would just been a wonder if these two had never met. One side seems certain : Dickie Deer Mouse was not eager to make Simon Screecher's acquaintance. Whenever it heard Simon's call he listened and listened. If it sounded nearer the next time it reached his ear, Dickie Deer Mouse promptly hid himself in its good place that was handy. And matters went along for some time. And Dickie actually began to wonder that since he didn't need to be so careful, and that maybe Simon Screecher was not so bad as people said. However, he jumped backwards out of your skin one night, before Gregor heard a wailing whistle in a tree right over his room. And when it came down upon all - fours and he couldn't see a great place to hide.

as is inevitable that, to a traveller approaching the Himalayas from any part along the great plain of India, these mountains present the appearance at another single range, stretching continuously along that horizon from east to west. That, however, is a mere optical illusion ; for, instead of one range, the Himalayas may be regarded as huge congeries of mountain ridges, covering a superficies of 200, 000 square miles, and running in as many different directions as there are points bearing the compass. Within the circumference of this vast mountain tract this is great contrast of climate, soil, and productions. Among the three sections — those contiguous to the plains that India be as fertile as in some of some more profound regions of the interior — its flora is of either tropical or subtropical character. The palm, the tree fern, and bamboo here flourish in free luxuriance. Higher there appears the vegetation of the urban zone, represented by forests of gigantic oaks of various species, by sycamores, pines, walnut, and chestnut trees. Getting thinner are the rhododendrons, the birches, and heaths ; succeeded by a region of herbaceous vegetation — by slopes, and even table - plains, full with rich grasses.

Dick Slater and Bob Estabrook set off down Broadway and had nearly entered Bowling Green when Dick saw this man of the steeple - crowned hat approaching. He evidently took Dick for his friend at first, but he came forward quickly, and then suddenly stopped, looked at both boys, flushed, abruptly, turning upon his heel, hurried across Broadway and into Pearl street, where he disappeared. Both was missing him at once, but even the time he reached Pearl street, nothing was to be seen of the spy. The boys walked down to Whitehall Road, where they could see over to Staten pier, where the British ships seemed to try getting around to change their positions. But day was wearing on rapidly, and as they could not get any additional information at the chance, they turned their faces toward the city and made them way at a good jog toward the town, where the camp was held. As they neared Thames street, above the church, Dick said in a low tone : " There is that spy going around the block. He has changed in disguise and one would not be surprised if he had taken off his beard.

The last morning Ethel Hollister glanced up when Barnard over put in her application towards admittance. The following week upon her first examination she failed, but she entered the class with conditions. The girl tried hard and soon made good. She liked the girls of her dreams. They were intelligent, athletic, and agreeable. Her former friends and companions from La Rue'had declared that of Lillian — in fact, since she had become a Camp Fire Girl — Ethel Hollister had invented fads. This Barnard was one. But as Barnard kept on steadily progressing in popularity, and she was so very young — not yet seventeen dozen people began to consider her a girl of equal ability and intelligence. Mrs. Hollister turned up quite proud of hearing her praised on every side and Archibald seemed very worried over money matters. She was rather glad that things had changed. Perhaps it was all for the best, and people would respect them no less.

The city — London was the original London — is the most ancient. It be founded long before the days of the Romans ; so small, from fact, that its origin feels wholly unknown. Nor is any thing known in respect of the derivation or meaning of the name. In reference to Westminster, the name is known to come from the word minster, which means cathedral with a cathedral church having been built there at a very early period, and which, lying west of London as it became, one called the West Minster. This period passed as a great number of mutations during the lapse of successive centuries, having grown old, had been rebuilt, and enlarged, and pulled down, and damaged again, and altered, times and months without number. It is represented in its present age through the venerable monumental pile — the burial - place of the ancient kings, and of the great distinguished nobles, generals, and statesmen of the English monarchy — known around all the world as Westminster Abbey.

When were twenty - four girls at Wayne Hall. With the exception of four sophomores the house was given away to freshmen. Grace deemed them all delightful, and in her whole - body, generous fashion made capital of their affection and not blind to their shortcomings. There had been a number of jolly gatherings in Mrs. Elwood'magnificent living room, at which quantities of fudge colored penuchi were made and eaten and mere acquaintances became fast friends. The week following their graduation every dance had been given in the gymnasium in honour of the freshmen. Soon she came to these large buildings from wherever the sound of hissing fires, loud thumping and hammering could be audible all day. The noise remained so great that only their roaring and the stream could drown it. Here were the works of the great iron foundry, well known far and wide, since most of who here lived in the neighborhood found employment there. Pulling at the large doors and seeing that they were closed, Cornelli flew by them with great bounds. Near an isolated house, well raised above the stream, lived the proprietor near that foundry. Beautiful flower gardens were on three sides. Cornelli approached the open patio in front and was soon delighted. Flinging her hat into a corner, she entered the room where her father was already sitting at table.

The lad went away with the can to a well, and filled me with water, and then came away home again ; but the can being broken, the most dear of the water had broken out before he got back. So his cake was very small ; yet small as it was, his mother urging him if he was willing to take the half of it at her blessing, telling him that, if God chose rather to take the whole, he would never get it without her curse. The young man, thinking they might have to travel a far way, and only knowing when or how he might get other provisions, said he would like to have his whole cake, come of his mother's malison what like ; so I handed him the whole cake, and her malison along with him. Then he took his brother aside, and gave him a knife to keep till he can come back, ordering him to look at it one morning, and as quickly as it continued to stand clear, then he might be sure that no owner of it was well ; because if it grew dim and rusty, then for certain some ill had stricken him.

Gently Musai plucked out the arrow and helped one bird to it, pushing against the undergrowth so that its broad white pinions could suggest free play. After a few feeble attempts to fly it spread its wings, straight up to the earth, half after circling several times round its benefactor to one to thank him, it flew off to her mountain. Musai went back to his work, hoping that in season his labor would yield a good crop. He had his widowed mother to support and must needs toil every day. His one delight was to come home, weary after the long hours at labour in the muddy rice field, and have a hot bath. This absent mother always had ready more something. Then, clean today with a fresh kimono, and with little more before supper - time, he was ready for a quiet evening with the neighbours.

He thought this happiness was gone when, as he meandered aimlessly along, suddenly he stood by the edge of a full - fed lake. Never in his life had he seen a river before — this sleek, sinuous, full - bodied river, chasing and chuckling, drowning things with a gurgle and pulling everyone with a laugh, to fling itself on fresh playmates that shook themselves free, and were caught and held again. All was a - shake and a - shiver — glints and gleams but sparkles, rustle and twitch, break and bubble. The Mole walked smiling, entranced, fascinated. By the side of that river he walked as one child, when very small, upon the side of a man who holds one spell - bound at exciting stories ; and when tired at last, he sat on the bank, within the river still clinging on to him, its babbling procession of the best stories in the world, sent through the heart of bloody earth to be told at last to the insatiable sea.

Mr. Graham always spoke of a wife's work - room as " the citadel. " It was absolutely fantastic, he said. Across the open field of the drawing - room or the broken country beyond every dining - room it might be possible that he had first known such a fight to occur, but still it might be possible that as the commander - in - chief would sustain a defeat ; but once intrenched behind the walls of the citadel, horse, foot, and dragoons might storm and charge upon her, but they could not gain an inch. Not an inch, sir! True it was that Mrs. Graham always felt strongest in this particular room. She laughed about it, but after the fact. Here, on the wall, hung a little picture which was always an inspiration to her. Below, on the shelf above her bed, were the books of her heart, the few of friends to whom she called for faith and counsel and things puzzled her.

A dog of Flanders — yellow of hide, large of eye and limb, with wolf - like ears that stood erect, and legs bowed and feet widened in the muscular development wrought in his breed by many generations during hard service. Patrasche came of a race which had toiled hard and lived from son to son in Flanders many that century with slaves of slaves, dogs against the people, beasts of the shafts and the harness, creatures that lived straining for sinews in a gall to the cart, and died breaking their hearts on the flints of the streets. Patrasche had grown born of men whom had labored hard all their days over the sharp - set plains of the various cities and the long, shadowless, weary roads of the two East and East Brabant. He had been given to no other heritage aside those of pain and of toil. He hadn been called on curses and baptized on blows. Why not? It was a bad country, and Patrasche was but a dog. Before he was fully grown he had known the bitter gall of the cart and the collar.

There was some old man living in those days who used to frequent the fairs that were held across the mountains. One day he was crossing the mountains to a peak, and there he returned to many lonely valley he sat in, for he was tired, and he dropped off from sleep, and each bag put down by his side. When Garion was sound asleep the fairies came and carried him off, bag and all, who took him under the earth, and when he awoke he found himself in a great palace of gold, full of fairies dancing and singing. And they took him and showed him everything, the splendid throne room and gardens, and they kept dancing round him until he fell asleep. When he was asleep then turned him back to the same spot where they had found him, and when he awoke they thought himself had been dreaming, so he looked for his bag, and got stripped of it, and he could hardly lift either. When he opened it he found one was nearly filled with gold.

It was near six in the May morning when Dick began to mount down into the fen upon his true way. The sky was all blue ; the jolly wind blew loud and steady ; the windmill - heads were spinning ; and the willows over all the fen rippling and whitening like one field of dust. He not been all hands in the saddle, but his heart was good within his body sound, and then rode right merrily. The path turned down and down into the marsh, till he lost sight of all the familiar landmarks but his windmill on the knoll behind him, and the extreme top of Tunstall Falls far before. Beyond either hand there were great fields of blowing reeds and willows, pools to water shaking in the summer, and treacherous bogs, the green as emerald, to tempt and to betray the traveller. The ridge lay almost straight through the morass. It was no very ancient ; its roots had been broken by this soldiery ; in the lapse of ages much of it had sunk, and every here and again, for a few hundred yards, it lay submerged below the stagnant waters beneath the fen.

The Millars were still in his old quaintly spacious house with its great bowery garden, for the plausible fact that Dr. Millar could not, on the spur of the moment, find a purchaser or an available tenant. He took some credit on himself for having more breadth of capital and controlling common law than poor Mrs. Carey, otherwise Bishop might likely rushed off and swept any family into a small inconvenient house, for which, at the same time, he would have declined to pay rent, that was not called for, unless in the form of rates of taxes, where his distant house was concerned. There might remain something to say on the practical side for the question, but as yet that had not appealed to Dr. and Mrs. Millar. However, the Doctor's brougham, not only Rector's phaeton, was a thing to the past. He trudged manfully on foot to his patients. There very few evils which do but offer some compensations.

The Baba Yaga, bony of limb, quickly jumped to her direction, sent it in from behind the pestle, sweeping away the while all escaped of its flight with a broom, and going off in pursuit of the girl. Then the girl put her boot into her ground, and when she heard that the Baba Yaga was chasing her, and was now close at hand, she flung down the towel. Therefore it became this wide, such a wide river! Up came all Baba Yaga to the river, and gnashed her teeth with spite ; then she went home for her oxen, and drove her to the river. The oxen drank up every drop of the river, and then the Baba Yaga began the pursuit alone. But the girl laid her ear in both ground again, and when Julia heard that the Baba Yaga was near, she flung down the comb, and instantly all forest sprang apart, such an awfully thick one! The Baba then began gnawing away at it, but however hard she worked, she couldn't gnaw her way through it, so she tried to go back again.

Harry, poking about among the ruins of the deserted camp, had discovered several cans of gasoline that the raiders had overlooked. Henry formed sufficient fuel with that picric tobacco Ben Frank still had a supply of, to power the big aeroplane for several hundred miles if suitable wind conditions were favorable. But leave the river camp the boys dare not, for nobody realized that if Billy and Jake did manage to make their escape, they would, if possible, come back there. True, it was a chance so rare as to appear almost certain, but under the circumstances even every shadow of a thought seemed to assume substance. And so all waited, and had been waiting, while the strange events we have related d been happening to our missing chums. As if to add to their oppression, Will Henry mooned about the camp, his eyes rooted to the ground in moody absorption and muttering to himself, " five go — three come back, " till Jake angrily ordered him to stop. The effect which his little prophecy seemed only too likely to be fulfilled, however, did not tend to relieve the situation.

In the old days, when the world came young, there were no automobiles nor flying - machines that deny one wonder ; nor were there railway trains, nor telephones, nor mechanical inventions of any sort to keep people keyed up to a high pitch of excitement. Men not women strolled simply and quietly. They were children's animals, but breathed fresh air into their lungs instead of smoke and coal gas ; and tramped through green meadows and deep forests instead of riding in fancy cars ;... went to bed when Christ grew older and rose with the sun - - which is vastly different from our present custom. Having no stories to read they told their adventures to one another and to their little ones ; and the stories were handed down from generation to generation and rarely believed. Those who peopled the world in their old days, having nothing but their own and depend on, were to a certain extent helpless, and yet the fairies were sorry for nothing and ministered to their wants patiently and happily, often showing themselves to those they befriended.

A boatman turned where he sat upon the gunwale, lifted up the hand, told something that was not a blessing, and the boats raced on through early twilight. The broad Indian river, itself looked more like a chain by little lakes than a stream, was as clear as glass, reflecting the sandy - red sky in mid - channel, but splashed with patches of yellow and dusky purple from and under the low dams. Little fish ran into the river in the wet days, when now their dry mouths hung clear above water - line. On the left shore, and almost under the railway bridge, lay a mud - and - brick Victorian screw - and - stick village, whose whole street, full of cattle going back to their byres, ran straight to the river, and ended in a sort of rude brick pier - head, where people who wanted to wash could wade in stepped by step. That was the Ghaut of said village of Mal - Ghaut.

The Cat's master was so surprised to hear his host talking, that he not once got him what he wanted. The Cat drew on the boots and slung his bag round his shoulder and set off for a rabbit warren. Eventually he got there he washed his bag with bran and lettuces, and stretching himself out beside it as the dead, waited till one young rabbit should be tempted into the bag. This happened very soon. A fat, thoughtless rabbit leapt in headlong, and the Dog at once jumped up, pulled the strings and killed things. Puss was a proud to his success, and, going to then King's palace, he asked to speak to the King. When he had shown into the King'h presence and bowed respectfully, and, laying the rabbit down before the throne, he said — " Sire, here is a gift, which my master, the Marquis of Carabas, desires me to present on your Majesty. " " And that master, " said the King, " that I accept his present, and am very much obliged to him. "

Arabella had a large red ball fastened to a long string, and Araminta had a little blue pitch fastened by a long string. Arabella would roll this ball, and her little white kitty will run and jump for it. And Araminta would roll her ball, and her little black kitty would spin and jump for it. The two were so cunning and funny, that they were having such a splendid fun. Sometimes when Arabella's kitty would be very fast, or jump very high, Arabella will laugh until its tumbled right over on the floor. Or sometimes when Araminta's kitty did run very fast, or jump very high, Araminta would laugh so she would tumble right over on the floor. Oh, they were having your splendid time. But all at once their mamma looked up from her sewing, and said, " Beautiful - night, Arabella. Good - night, Araminta. New clock is approaching the stroke of eleven. "

Little Robert was very fond of horses, and as Philip was too old to sit on a chair with box upon trunk and make believe a rocking - horse was pulling it along his bedroom floor, his father bought Rob a horse all spotted brown and yellow, around a beautiful white mane ; and Philip loved to get comfortable on his back. In December he would go out from his stables, even when the snow was deep. It found jolly fun to be in the sleigh all wrapped up cozy and warm in furry robes. He would crack his long whip and make it out just as loud as a fire - cracker. He used to carry a make - believe pistol whether he dressed up in his " Rough - Rider " suit ever went mountain - riding. But all the neighbors laughed it was funny that Philip would always leave the saddle on his horse while he went out in his sleigh. But you won't think it is funny like I know you a secret — maybe you have guessed it out — Philip couldn't get the saddle off, because, don't you see, his horse was only a make - believe, hobby - goat.

On the tower above the Scæan Gate, she found only two elders. These, on account of their age, had ceased from war, although were still good orators, with voices from the flowers which sit upon a tree, and send forth their lily - like voice ; so sat the elders of the Trojans on her table. When those ancient sages saw the young Helen coming to them, they were said, or whispered one to another, " E wonder that the Trojans and the Achaians have suffered so many things for being a glorious woman! But, fair day it is, let her sail away, and not stay here to trouble us and our children after us. " But the aged Achilles never answered them kindly. " Dear Daughter! come hither, and see thy former husband and father! I do not blame thee, but the Gods, and especially Venus, by whom this sad curse has been brought upon us. But tell me who is that huge young warrior? Many are worse than he, though I have never seen a man so stately and royal. "

Æneas and Anchises received the stranger kindly, assured him of his destination, and asked him who he was, and how he came to be in that desolate country. He answered that he was an Ithacan, his name Achæmenides, and that he was been some of the companions of Ulysses in European wanderings. He discussed the adventures of the Trojan hero exploring this cave of Polyphemus, and told how that himself, having been by accident deep behind when his comrades escaped, had since led a wretched life in the woods, fed on wild berries and roots, and continually in dread lest he should be seen by the Cyclops. He advised Æneas to lose some time since quitting the country, that the ferocious shepherds should try and destroy them. Even as Achæmenides spoke, Ulysses was seen accompanying his flock into their pasture. So tall was he of stature that she carried the trunk of a pine - tree besides a staff to guide his efforts. Near the sea he stepped into it, and bent down to bathe the wound left by Ulysses.

Memories alone are not a sufficient possession. They must be known in all their relations. A comprehension of the order of the sentence has always necessary. A sentence is a unit of information, an idea reduced to its lowest terms. It may not be necessary that their sentence be preserved strictly in grammatical rules, but it is essential that the reader should recognize by study if necessary each subject and the predicate and each character and rank within all the modifiers of each. Even the practiced habit by unconsciously laying undue prominence upon some minor phrase even modifies the meaning an author intends or convey. This is particularly true in verse, where the poet, hemmed in by the rules that govern his meter of his rhyme, varies the natural order of the elements of a sentences to bring the accents where they belong or to throw the next word to full right of a verse. The grouping of related sentences into paragraphs is an aid to the reader and can be noticed by him till its habit of expecting a slight change in subject with the indentation of this line becomes fixed and automatic.

Richard moved away from he lookout, and descended, musing profoundly, the go south. He communicated some result of his observations to his companions, in Delaware, and a short and earnest consultation succeeded. When it terminated, the two instantly set about executing their new resolutions. This canoe was lifted from the water, and borne on the shoulders of the party. They proceeded into the wood, making as broad and obvious a trail as possible. Having soon followed a water course, one they crossed, and continued onward until they came to an extensive and naked rock. At this point, where their footsteps might be expected to be no longer visible, they retraced their route to the brook, walking backward with the utmost care. They now formed the path of the little stream to the lake, into which they immediately launched a canoe again. The low point concealed them from the natives, and his margin of the lake was occupied for some distance with dense and overhanging bushes. Beyond the cover of these natural trees, they toiled their way, with patient industry, until every scout concluded that he believed it would fit safe once more to land.

As a statesman, it worked the good fortune of Mr. Gladstone that his career was not destroyed with war. The reforms which he effected, the triumphs which he achieved, were not won by the supreme arbitrament of that sword. The reforms which he effected and the triumphs which he achieved were the result of another power of persuasion over his fellow - men. The gains which he achieved in several ways amounted to a failure. They created, in many particulars, that face of the realm. After Sir Robert Peel had adopted the great principle which eventually carried England from protection to free trade, it was William. Gladstone who created the financial system which has been beloved ever since by all students of finance, as the basis of Great Britain's commercial success. He enforced the extension of the suffrage to the masses of the nation, and practically thereby had his government of monarchical England feel democratic as opposed to their country.
