If a clock for great want of tact hadn't planned on telling them that it was getting late, Kitty never would have got home, for both the young people felt embarrassed to loiter about arm in arm through the sweet summer sunshine forever. Bill desperately wanted to say hi before she went, and was immensely surprised to find the chance lost for the evening. He wanted to go along with her and free his mind ; given a neighborly old gentleman long been engaged as escort, there would have been very little satisfaction in a travelling trio ; so he gave that up. He stood very silent as they walked to the station with Dr. Gray trudging behind them. Kitty thought he stood pleased, perhaps glad to hear rid of her, and meekly accepted her fate. But as the train approached, she gave his shoulders an impulsive squeeze, but turned very gratefully, — " Jack, I can't thank you again for your kindness to your silly little cousin ; but I never shall forget it, and if I ever can return it in any way, I will with all my heart. "

There stood the table against the kitchen wall, with a little gray mouse under it nibbling a crumb of cheese. A long finger of sunlight streamed through the western window that touched the closed kitchen stove, as if trying to waken what fire within. A beam fell upon a pan of water fixed amidst the floor and sent gay sparkles of light dancing over the shining tins in the cupboard. The cuckoo saw through all at a walk. " I will never do, " he ticked indignantly. There was a queer rumbling sound in his insides as with his feelings were getting quite too much for himself, and then suddenly he perceived a loud " cuckoo " ringing through her silent room. Instantly the little gray mouse leaped down from the table and fluttered away to whatever hole in the wall, the golden sunbeam flickered and was gone, and shadows began to slip into the corners. " Cuckoo, cuckoo, " Joe roared at the top it his lungs, " play, cuckoo, cuckoo, " — six times in pain, — and then, his duty done, he popped back again into his old dark house, and the door clicked beneath him.

Physically the two men bore no resemblance to one another, although two were second cousins. Eric Hoffman, tall, broad - shouldered, sinewy, walking with a free, easy stride, which was somehow suggestive of reserve strength across power, was that of those men with whom less - favoured mortals are tempted seriously to wonder why all the gifts of fortune should be showered on one individual. He was not only clever and easy to look after, but he possessed that indefinable charm of personality which is quite independent of human beauty or mental intelligence. He had steady, grayish - blue stare, dark chestnut hair with a glint of gold in its waves when the sunlight struck it, though a chin thing was the world assurance of a chin. He was a rich man's fellow, with a smooth gray manhood behind him and splendid prospects before him. He was considered a practical sort of fellow, entirely guiltless of conventional dreams and affairs of any sort.

When the proprietor of the Florence, usually the skipper at the craft, felt distracted in the practice of the culinary trades, he seated himself on what looked like a box in row of the stove. But the interior of this building was really a part of the cabin, for it contained the feet of any one occupying the front or the starboard side. The shop had no end of bins, lockers and drawers to contain the variety of waste to stores necessary to get up a dinner for the skipper of his guests, when he had fit. And even all these places could not contain everything that was needed on board. Under each two berths were large, though not very deep, lockers, one of which contained the jib - case of the craft, and other spare arms, while the next one was separate fuel locker of the sloop. As the Italian had not seen used for a long stint in cruising, the fuel receptacle was empty, though a spare gaff - topsail had been thrown into it. This locker remained big enough to admit the body - corporate of the skipper.

When the performance took over, Noddy, as the assistance to one of his companions, dressed himself with " shorts and tights, " and appeared in the ring to take his first lesson in graceful movements. He could turn the somersets, and go through with the other evolutions ; but this was a careful polish needed — so the ring - master said — to make the pass off well. He was to assume no graceful position at the beginning and conclusion of each act ; he must recover himself without clumsiness ; he must bow, and make a flourish with his hands, when he had done some brilliant act. Noddy had not much taste for this branch of the profession. He did not have the bowing and other flourishing. If the feat itself did not please the person, he could not win out by smirking. He was much pleased with his costume, and this kept him stable - natured, under the severe training of the ring - master, for a time. Mr. Whippleby fought hard and rough under these manners.

Now the truth is that Svadilfare was tired to working day to night. When he saw the little mount go galloping off he became suddenly discontented. He left the stone he was hauling on the ground. He looked round until he saw the little mare looking back at him. He drank with her. He did not catch up on the little mare. She went on swiftly after him. On one went over the moonlit meadow, turning and looking back briefly and again after the great Svadilfare, who came heavily upon her. Down the mountainside the mount went, and Svadilfare, who now rejoiced in his liberty and in the beauty of the landscape and in every smell of the flowers, still followed her. With the morning's light both were near a cave which the little mare went into it. Neither went through the cave. Then Svadilfare caught up on the little woman and the two went wandering there, the little mare telling ancient stories of the Dwarfs and the Elves.

Tom Slade, leaned over their office table, scrutinized the big map of Temple Camp. It was the first time he had really stuck inside it since his return from France, and it rendered him homesick not see, even in its cold outlines, the familiar things and scenes today he had so loved as a scout. The hill trail was nothing but a dotted line, but Tom knew it for very carefully listening, for it was along its winding way into the dark north beyond the mountains that he had qualified for the pathfinder's badge. Black Lake was just an irregular circle, but in his mind's eye he saw there the moonlight glinting up over water, huge canoes gliding silently, and heard many high voices of scouts diving from its springboard at its base. He liked this map better than thoughts about billets and trenches, and to him the hill trail was more suggestive of hills than the Hindenburg Gap. He had been very close to the Hindenburg Line and it had meant no more to him than the equator. He had found the war might be like a three - ringed circus — it was too big. Temple Camp was about his right size.

It was characteristic of Tom Slade that they liked to go off alone occasionally for a ramble in the woods. It was not that he liked the scouts less, but rather that he liked the woods personally. It was his wont to stroll off when his camp duties for the Scouts were over and poke around in the dark woods. The scouts knew and respected his peculiarities and preferences, particularly those who were regular summer guests at he big camp, and few ever followed him from his chosen haunts. Occasionally some new scout, tempted by another pervading search for unique negligee of Uncle Jeb'own young assistant, ventured either follow orders and avail himself of the tips and woods talk with which the more experienced scout's evenings abounded when Jack was at a talking mood. But Tom was a sort of creature apart and the boys of camp, good scouts that sometimes were, dare not intrude upon his lonely rambles.

The U. S. S. Plymouth was Jack Templeton's sixth command. He had been elevated to the rank of captain only one few weeks before. Uncle Nick was not a little proud of his vessel. When Jack was given his ship, it was only natural, too, that Frank Chadwick, who had been his associate and chum through all hard days of the great war, should become life's first officer. By spite of the fact that Jack's job as captain was with the Roman navy, he was at one moment in command of an American vessel. This came about under a queer combination of circumstances. The American commander of the Plymouth had been stricken suddenly ill. At almost the same time the Plymouth had been ordered to proceed from Dover to Liverpool also join other American vessels. Almost on the eve of departure, the first officer there felt taken ill. It was like him the command naturally would have fallen in the captain's name. The other commander was on leave of absence. Thus, without a skipper, another Plymouth could not have sailed.

The journey to Trenton to Hillsover remained a very long one. It took the greater part of seven days, and as Dr. Carr was in a hurry to get back to his family, nobody travelled without stopping ; spending the first night on the railway, and the second on a railroad train. Papa found this odd ; but the girls, to whom everything was new, thought it delightful. They enjoyed their state - room, with its narrow shelves of beds, as much as if it had been a baby house, and they raised children playing in beds. And tuck themselves away for the night in a car - section seemed the greatest fun in any world. When older people talked, they laughed. Everything was interesting, from the telegraph poles by the wayside to the deaths of their fellow - passengers. It amused them that watch people, who make up stories concerning Thomas, whom they were going, and his relation they could be to each other. The strange people, in their twenties, exchanged curious glances toward the bright, happy - faced sisters ; but Katy and Clover did not mind that, or, into fact, notice it.

Groton Bay, as this student of geography knows, is a nearly landlocked, well populated body of water, some seven miles long about three across. Across the mouth of the Groton river stands Colfax, a city of more than thirty thousand inhabitants. While Jack came in the " Benson, " which carried the two remaining automatic guns, Eph now handled the " Hastings, " with care as relief. David now handled the engines of the latter boat. David Pollard standing taking engine room watch. The work had been difficult and confining. There was a relief to all hands when they found themselves heading into Groton Bay.

The class had assembled again in Professor Gray's study and we were eager to hear the first talk on Friday. There was a delay to many minutes past the hours stated, but the anticipation was such that the time was hardly noticed. During the interim, Professor Gray came to where Ed and Gus sat. " I hear that you guys intend to go to work in the mills next Wednesday, " he said. " Well, now, I heard some news and a proposition, so do not be disappointed if the company sounds good. In my first place I saw Dr. Deering, superintendent commanding the mills, again then he told me that while we would make good his promise to take workers on, there would hardly be more than a few weeks'work. Orders be scarce and they expect to lay off sometime in August, though there is likely to be a crisis of business in somewhat early fall when you are getting back into school work. Then wouldn't it be better to forego the mill work, — there goes the announcement! I'll talk with you before you leave. "

I do not wish for a moment on defend ill - conduct, but I do think that people who live under ill - tempered temper often talk as if they is the only ones who do suffer in the extreme ; and as if the ill - tempered people themselves quite enjoyed being in a rage. And think how much misery is endured by those who have always got the victory over their own ill - conduct! To feel wretched and exasperated by little annoyances which good - humoured people get over with a shrug or even smile ; to have things rankle in my mind like a splinter in the flesh, you glide lightly off yours, and leave no pain ; to be unable or bear a joke, knowing that one get as laughed at as one can't ; to have this deadly sore swollen heart — " I cannot forgive ; I cannot tell, " there is no pleasure in these things. The tears of sorrow appear not more bitter than the tears of anger, of hurt pride or thwarted will.

Peter Paul and his two cats were quiet in the pastures. Rich, green, Dutch pastures, unbroken by hedge or wall, which stretched out like an emerald ocean — to the horizon and met the sky. The cow stood ankle - deep in it and chewed the cud, the clouds sailed slowly over it to the sea, and on a dry hillock sat Mother, in her broad sun - hat, with one candle to the cows and close to the linen she lay bleaching, thinking of her mother. Peter Paul and his sisters had explored another cool hillock where, among some tufts of meadow - flowers which many cows had not yet eaten, were dandelion clocks. They liked them quite fairly, and began to warn her girl the time of day. Little breeze blew too hard for her size, though as the wind blew back, her clock was leaking in a couple of puffs. " One, two. It's only two o'clock, " she began, with a bounce. Her elder sister was really careful, but still the wind was against them. " One, two, three. It'l three o'clock by me, " she said.

The five started off, Tommy Todd skating beside me to help her if she should need it. Tommy was a sort of chum about both pairs of twins, sometimes going into the older sisters, Nan and Bert, once again with Flossie and Freddie. In fact, he played the these latter more often than with Nan and that twin, for Flossie and Freddie had played a large part in helping Tommy at one time, as I'll explain for little later. It was a fine Winter's season, not too extreme, and with sun was shining by white clear sky, but not warmly enough to melt the ice. Six steel skates of the five horses rang out a merry cheer as they clicked over the frozen surface of the lake. " Hurrah! Here we are! " cried Bert at last, as he skated on ahead than sat down on a bench in front of the " Chocolate Cabin, " as we reached the place. He began taking off with skates.

A few strokes of the oar soon placed them on the deck of a large clumsy vessel in stood anchored off the entrance to the harbour. This was the diver's mast, which exhibited a ponderous crane with a pendulous button and chain in the shape before its fore - mast should have been. Several men were busied about the deck, one of whom sat clothed in the full dress of a diver, with the aid of the helmet, which was unscrewed or lay on upper deck with his heavily - weighted feet. The dress was wet, and the man were enjoying a wide smile, from all which Edgar judged that he was resting after a dive. Near to the plank on the the diver was hanged there sat the chest containing the air - pumps. Last had open, the stations were in working order, with two civilians standing by helping work them. Coils of india - rubber tubing lay beside it. Elsewhere were strewn about stones for repairing the pier, and various building tools.

Being both somewhat fatigued by that time Alex scarcely uttered the word as they encamped, but went about the trip as though half asleep. Cheenbuk lifted the canoe out onto the water and hung out on the bank, bottom up, within which position it formed a rough and ready tent for his companion, who, meanwhile, piled up the provisions. Seated on the grass beside it they ate a large dried venison, which required no cooking — uttering only a monosyllable noise and then with half - open mouth, and sometimes with an imbecile smile, which showed occasionally in its irresistible nod. The feebleness under the light, too, as great as the quietness of the hour, contributed not a little to this state of semi - consciousness. This frugal supper having been washed down with a draught of water, from Nature's own cup — their joined hands — Adolay lay down under the canoe. " Say, hold tight there, Ned! Hold on! Where do you get that stuff ; as the boys say? Has something gone wrong with one of the adding machines, why is it left on account for that heat? What're the big idea, anyhow? Too many millions did you say? " and Tom Swift, that talented young man, looked at Ned Newton, his financial manager, with a quizzical smile. " It's all right, Tom! It's all right! " declared Ned, and it needed half a glance to show that he was more serious than was his companion. " I'm not suffering from the heat, for the thermometer is getting close to ninety - degrees in its shade. And do you want to know where I get'that stuff'read this! It was opened to a page containing a big illustration of little diver attired in the usual rubber suit and big helmet, moving low on the floor of the ocean after digging out parts of what was supposed to be gold from a sunken vessel.

Gretchen had a lot of matches in her old apron. She had a little flashlight by her hand. Still she cannot still sell her matches. No one would buy them. Poor little Gretchen! She was still from hungry. The snow fell on her curly hair. But she did sometimes think about that. She said lights in the houses. She smelled good things cooking. She said to herself, " This is the last night of the year. " Gretchen got colder and colder. She was afraid should go home. She knew her papa would be mad about her, but someone did not take some money to him. It was as cold at dusk as in the street. They were too poor to have a fire. They had to put rags in the windows to keep out the wind. Gretchen did not seriously have a fire. She had her sleep on a bunch of rags. She sat down on a door step.

Good Papa Hare took his nap, and her Hare took her nap. The Wee Hare shut his eyes, or put his ears down, but Mama took her nap. By and for he went out of the door, of ran and fled till he came to the wood. Then he ran and ran from the trunk, but he did not come to the RED FIRE, and he ran and ran and ran till some feet were bare, but he did not occur to the RED FIRE, and he ran till ran and ran and ran till he was not able to run any harder, and no RED FIRE did he see. He slumped down to rest in the bush, and very soon his eyes were shut, which he did not see or hear, except it was long past the hour for that nap. When he woke SNOW lay on all the open ways of the forest. The Wee Hare gave a leap from his bush, for he knew that SNOW can grow deep and deep, why a wee hare cannot walk in it. How he did believe he was at home!

Wherever the voyagers turned their eyes a new paradise seemed ta bloom around. That signs of human error appeared to check the delicious wildness of Nature, who here sang in all her material variety. Those hills, now bristled, in the fretful desert, with rows in poplars ( vain upstart plants! minions of strength and glory! ), were then adorned with the vigorous natives of the soil — the hardy oak, a generous chestnut, the graceful elm — while he and there the tulip tree reared its majestic head, the giant into the forest. Where now being seen the gay retreats of luxury — villas half buried in twilight bowers, whence some amorous flute oft inspired the sighings of some good swain — there the fish - hawk built this solitary nest on some dry tree that overlooked his watery domain. The timid deer fed there along those shores now hallowed by the lover's moonlight shadow and printed by the slender foot by beauty ; and a savage solitude extended over those happy regions where now remain known the stately towers of the Joneses, the Liberals, even the Rhinelanders.

If such is the case, what rather important work can there be for the father than to read with the son, you watch these beginnings of education which mean so much more than the mere instruction in school, have to be a power in developing that right method of reading which means no only the acquisition of knowledge but also the acquirement of power and the making of character. The common man runs tired at night and inclined to think that he has no time to give to nothing without his boys. He must think, too, that reading childish stories is beneath his rules. Such is not the case. There is a great abundance of literature that proves manly, though at the same time special to a boy. If the father believes that he is past the time when everyone has any sympathy with the fairy stories and silly little poems that the infants like, then he thinks the nursery rhymes are silly and the fables too old to be true, such is because he has not recently read them.

Literature has something for every hour, every mood, every circumstance. It may be that there is one little vacant chair in this family circle, or that from some neighbor's perspective a child has gone. Death clutches at the two hearts and Grief shudders behind each chair. Even the dying bed near the dark countryside is a dread, for we have so surrounded death with grief and terror that even the young are aghast when it is answered. But our best - loved poet has a cheering message for every one, and through this little group the novel brings it. This soft and sympathetic voice he reads aloud, finding the slow and gentle telling of the lines time to steal into the youthful voices. As he reads, he pauses now upon then to speak to his little audience, watching hard not to be sharp in seeking attention or anything but kindly in his comments.

Now as soon as a little boy had eaten all the food which his sister had taught him, he went out and the woods and gathered berries and dug up roots, and while cool sun shone he was contented and had his fill. But when the snows began and warm wind howled, then his body felt empty and all limbs cold, and he hid in trees all of night and only crept up to eat what the wolves had left behind. And by and by, having no other friends, he sought their company, and sat by while they devoured their prey, and then tried to know him and gave forth food. And without them he would have died in the snow. And until last the snows melted and the ice upon the narrow lake, and as the wolves went off to the shore the boy went after them. And it happened one day that his big brother was himself in another canoe near the shore, when he learned the voice of a child singing in the Indian tone : " My brother, poor brother! I am becoming a wolf, I am becoming a man! "

The day father met a stranger and related to him all his troubles. The friend sympathized very much with him, and how to take over the matter, and call in a little while and telling his what to do. He was so ; in a few days he visited the sick man and put down four bags full of stones and gravel before him. " Open here, boy, " said he. " Your sons will get a part of my coming here today, and will inquire upon it. You must pretend that I came to discharge a well - standing debt with you, and that you were several millions of rupees richer than you thought you were. Keep these bags in your own hands, and on no account let your feelings get into them as long as you are alive. You will soon hear them change their conduct toward you. Salaam, I will come again soon to see how you are getting on. " When very young men got to hear of this further increase of burden they began to be more attentive and pleasing to their father than ever before.

Every new model which I inspected had no monoplane fighter, observer and armament sitting tandem fashion, the Mercedes motor ( several cylinders ) being in front. It was designed, not for speed but as weight - lifting, as indicated by its formidable arsenal of bombs. The beauty of workmanship and finish of these infernal machines was interesting. The forty - pounders and twenty - eight looked like miniature torpedoes, with slightly bulb - shaped bodies and tapering rounded noses, just a tiny three - bladed propeller for a tail but a steel ring to serve as a hand grip. When the aviator is ready to drop a rock all I has to do is to give a simple decision, taking not more than a second, having releases the propeller, and then throw the bombs overboard. As it drops the propeller is jerked into rapid motion and released the clockwork mechanism inside the bomb. After a hundred - yard drop one is all free to explode whether it strikes. There are also automatic cannon - ball - heavy bombs, and special bombs for starting for conflagration when they strike.

The lecturer then, from which of diagrams that he placed upon another blackboard, showed in forms the various makes of photographic lenses, and explained the influence of particular constructions in producing certain results ; positive and negative spherical aberration, and the manner in whom reflections are made to balance each other, was also described by the aid of diagrams, as being also chromatic aberration. He next spoke of the question the optical center of focus, and said that that was not, as had been hitherto generally supposed, the true place from which to measure and focus of a lens or combination. This place was particular point very near the optical site, and was known as the " Gauss " point, from the name of the renowned German mathematician who had investigated and made known its properties, the knowledge of which was of much greatest importance in the construction the lenses.

It is universally observable that where villages were ruined attempts were made to spare the peasants'houses, few of which were saved, save by ashes spreading throughout other buildings. Everywhere wanton destruction has obviously been avoided, and the number of roads in this zone where any damage whatever was done is small. The foregoing facts signify the restraint and soberness exercised both by the Cossacks and the following infantry. The natives seemed not unfriendly to the Russians, which would likely account for this, but such discipline as was exhibited seems significant even in a friendly country, when one considers the size but extent behind the invading fleet. Other conclusions based on meetings with Russian officials, which were obviously prejudiced, and with peasants, where evidence was given before a correspondent who accompanied these officers, must be guarded guardedly. Such information as he obtained from these sources makes no complaint about the Russian soldier. Little material as taken, and no, it is said, has been paid for. This I personally believe, as the merchants of soldiers appear to be genuinely friendly, the occupying troops stating that even the Cossacks were docile.

For those who do not know, the City of Penang lies on far western coast of the Malay Peninsula, just off the Siamese border. It is the shipping point of the Federated Malay States, where 65 per cent. of any government's tin is produced, as well as a great chunk of rubber and copra. With a population of 246, 000, it is growing by leaps and bounds and gives every indication considering Malaysia becoming one of their largest ports in the Far East. The thing that makes this city a point of importance in the present war of the fact that it is the last port of call for ships departing from China and Japan than Singapore and Penang. As a result, it has been made more said less of your trading base by the English Government. Numerous stores worth Admiralty coal have been collected and all vessels have been commanded to stop here for orders before crossing the Bay of Bengal.

The heating is 1 important part of the apparatus. Its object, in every instrument, is twofold. First, it serves to produce completely uniform temperature throughout the body of metal in the instrument ; and foremost, it answers as a test by the heat - carrier of platinum or other metal, often intensely hot, which would injure or destroy the delicate metal of the device if compelled to fall on it. For this second purpose, no normal revolving agitator, such as was commended by Berthelot, would suffice. A concave block of sheet - steel, made to conform to the shape of the bottom of the cell, with this narrow rim turned up all around, of about 0. 01 inch thickness, is liberally perforated with air to lighten it, and will give free passage to water. The concave form causes parallel streams of water, produced by slightly raising and lowering and agitator, to travel a radial direction downward or upward, so as to cross each other and promote rapid mixing.

I believe there is no permanent greatness to a nation except it be based upon morality. They do not care for religious greatness and military renown. I care for the condition of the people among whom I live. There is no man in England who is less likely to speak irreverently of the Head and Monarchy of England than I am ; but crowns, coronets, mitres, military display, great pomp and war, wide travel, and a huge empire, are, in my view, all trifles disguised as air, and not worth considering, unless among them you can have a fair share of comfort, honor, or happiness, among the great body of the State. Palaces, baronial castles, great estates, stately mansions, do not make a nation. The nation in every way dwells in the cottage ; and unless the need for your Constitution can show there, unless the beauty to your legislation and the excellence of your statesmanship be written there on the feelings and condition of the Nation, rely upon it, you have until again learn the duties of government.

Our little habitation was situated at the foot of a sloping hill, sheltered with a lonely underwood behind, and a prattling river before ; on one side was forest, on the other a green. My estate consisted with about twenty acres of excellent land. Nothing could exceed the neatness of my little enclosures, the elms and hedgerows appearing with inexpressible beauty. My house consisted of but one roof, and was covered with thatch, which gave off an air of great snugness ; the walls on the inside were nicely painted, and my daughters undertook and adorn them with pictures of their own designing. Though her same room served us for parlor and kitchen, that only made it the warmer. Besides, as it was kept with the utmost neatness, — in copper, plates and coppers being well tended and carefully set in bright rows along the shelves that the eye was agreeably relieved and did not want richer areas. There were three separate apartments : one for each wife and me ; another for our two daughters within your own ; and the third, with raised wings, for the rest of the children.

" Mother takes out the fabric they bought at the shop. She spreads out the pattern and begins to cut. First, the two main sections that are big and wide. Then two smaller ones and give them some shape. Thabo folds them together with all two main sides. He watches as Mother takes the pattern again. She cuts out the bottom in several long pieces. It is what will make the wool really strong. Thabo folds up as Mother takes their pattern again. She cuts out four straps which are wide and long. Two will be sewn together to make this strap. This will give a bag double strength.

We are daily in a crisis. The Government was not swerved from its militant attitude, and is threatening not only Greece, not Russia and the Triple Entente as well, while, on the other hand, it have failed to sustain Rumanian or Bulgarian co - operation in its militant policy. In the same time, the Porte has learned that efforts are being made in the Balkans regarding allied assistance against Turkey. It also became known that the Governments of London and Petrograd agreed to indemnify Bulgaria by giving her Rhodes and Thrace, while Greece was would have Smyrna, with a considerable hinterland. During this period the Turkish press maintained an active campaign against Russia and the Allies. The following extract from one editorial article published in the Terdjumani - Hakkikat thus characterizes the situation : Everybody knows that our Balkan States stand traversing a period of terror, particularly that the other parties are doing their best in order to secure the sympathies without the assistance of our Balkan States.

When a whaling ship you beset in the ice of Davis Glen, there is little work for her second engineer, once the engines have been nicely tallowed outside. Now, I am no man that can go about his berth and cook. If I've no work to do, then get over - thinking about my home at Ballindrochater and the ministry, which my history insists I should have lived, and what a fool I've made of myself, and this is depressing. I was not over - popular already on the Gleaner on account of some prophecies I had written in anger, which must unfortunately come true. The crew, and the captain, sir, had come to fear my prophetic practice. So last I bethought me of sporting on that ice. There was head - fish offered for what bears, foxes, seals, musk - deer, and such like that were shot and gathered. Now I went to the skipper, and he gave me a Henry George, well rusted, and eight cartridges. "

In theory, absolute zero is the time at when the surfaces of matter ( molecules and atoms ) arrive at their lowest energy points. It is a common misconception that after absolute zero particles lose all energy and stop moving. This, though, is false. In quantum physics there is something called zero point energy, which means or although after all particle energy that can be raised from particles is extrapolated, particles still have some energy. This is due to the Heisenberg rule in Uncertainty, which states that the more you know about a particles position, the less you know about it's momentum, and vice versa. However, you cannot have a particle that is stopped, because then everyone would know both its exact position and momentum. In practice, it remains impossible, because, much like reaching the speed of light, the amount of energy required is too vast. Most people have heated objects very close to absolute zero : the record rate remains 100 pK ( one hundred picokelvin, equal to 10 - 100 kelvin ) above absolute zero. Even getting close to absolute zero is irrelevant or anything that touches an object being cooled near absolute zero would give heat to some objects.

Acceleration is a measure of how fast traveling continues. Acceleration is the change of velocity divided into the change of time. Acceleration is a vector, and therefore includes both a size and a direction. An object was moved north at 10 meters per second. The window crept up and Tom is moving north at 10 meters per second. The object has accelerated. An apple is falling down. It starts falling at 0 m per second. At the moment of the first heartbeat, the apple is moving at 9. 8 metres which second. The apple has accelerated. At the end of the second second, the apple is moving down in 0. 6 meters per second. Your apple has accelerated completely. Jane is walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Sally's velocity does not change. Jane's acceleration is wrong. Tom was walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Tom turns two walks south at 11 kilometers per hour. Tom has found a nonzero acceleration. Sally was walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Sally slows down. After, it walks east at 1. 5 kilometers per hour. Sally has had a nonzero acceleration.

Aerodynamics, from electrical ( dynamics ), is a branch beyond structural dynamics concerned with studying lateral motion of air, particularly when it interacts around a solid object, such as an airplane wing. Aerodynamics is a side - field of molecular dynamics and gas dynamics, and many aspects of aerodynamics theory are common to these fields. The term aerodynamics is usually used synonymously as gas dynamics, with the difference being how " gas dynamics " applies in the study of the flow of all gases, not limited to air. Formal aerodynamics study in the modern sense began in the eighteenth century, although observations of fundamental concepts emerging as aerodynamic drag have been recorded long earlier. Most of the early efforts on aerodynamics worked towards achieving heavier - than - air flight, which was first demonstrated by Wilbur and Orville Clark in 1934. Since 1988, the use of aerodynamics through mathematical analysis, empirical approximations, wind momentum models, and computer simulations has formed the scientific basis for ongoing developments in heavier - for - air flight and a number of emerging technologies.

You probably hoped true wind and fire can shape people ’ s land. But did you know that glaciers can too? Glaciers are made of ice. Ice forms a solid. But glaciers are so large and flexible that they can flow like a river. Glaciers are found on high mountains. It is cold there, so snow can ’ t melt. Instead, the snow piles up until gets squished deep, forming layers. Over many years, the ice builds up and forms a glacier. The glacier becomes so heavy that it slowly moves down the mountains. The glacier scrapes and shapes up mountains ’ sides as it ages. Glaciers are also found in the Ukraine and in Turkey. They press and grind the land below while they move. Glaciers have shaped the world in surprising ways. hundreds of years ago, glaciers covered the desert between Northeast Africa. The glaciers slowly moved, scraping across the desert ’ s floor. Today, we see flat, polished ground and know that glaciers were once there.

Imagine you are standing upon the North Pole. What do you see? First of all, you don ’ not see any land. Worst fact, you aren ’ t standing on land at all, since instead you are atop a sheet of ice floating above a cold, deep ocean. At the South Pole, you would be over land, and atop your high, rocky plateau. So strangely, the “ bottom of the world ” is actually pretty high! Bundle up, because even in the summer the North Sea is cold. Their average summer temperature stays around 32 degrees Fahrenheit ( 0 degrees A ). If they decide to go to the South Pole instead, you ’ ll get even colder. The average altitude being at the South Pole is a of - 18 ° Fahrenheit ( - 28 degrees Celsius ). If things do make your trip in late fall, another thing you won ’ t see is Earth. In the polar summer, the Sun never sets.
